predicted_text:
Below is practical, up-to-date information you can use right now―where to go for a definite diagnosis, how treatment is usually organised, and where people with abetalipoproteinemia (ABL, Bassen-Kornzweig disease) find medical expertise, financial help and peer support.  Because the disease is rare, almost everything happens through regional or national “centres of excellence” for lipid or inborn-error-of-metabolism disorders, and through rare-disease charities.

─────────────────────────────────
1. Getting a firm diagnosis
─────────────────────────────────
1. Primary tests usually already done  
   • Fasting lipid profile: extremely low total-C, LDL-C < 15 mg/dL (0.4 mmol/L); low triglycerides.  
   • Peripheral blood smear: >5–10 % acanthocytes (spur-shaped red cells).  
   • Stool fat or low serum fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K).  

2. Confirmatory tests  
   • Apolipoprotein B < 5 mg/dL.  
   • Genetic testing for biallelic pathogenic variants in the MTTP gene (found in >95 % of cases).  
   • Occasionally intestinal biopsy showing absence of Apo-B–containing lipoproteins.

3. Who can order/interpret testing  
   • Clinical lipidologist or metabolic physician.  
   • Medical geneticist (hereditary lipid panel or a targeted next-generation sequencing panel that includes MTTP).  
   • Large hospital paediatric or adult gastro-enterology/liver departments often partner with genetics.

4. Where to go (examples—choose the closest)  
   UNITED KINGDOM  
     – National Severe Hyperlipidaemia & Rare Dyslipidaemia Service (Birmingham, London, Manchester, Glasgow). Referral via GP or local consultant.  
     – Metabolic clinics at Great Ormond Street, Evelina London, Addenbrooke’s Cambridge.  

   UNITED STATES  
     – NIH Undiagnosed Diseases Program, Bethesda, MD.  
     – Boston Children’s Hospital Lipid Clinic.  
     – Baylor College of Medicine / Texas Children’s Mito-Autosomal Recessive Metabolic Clinic.  
     – University of Washington Medicine Lipid Clinic.  

   AUSTRALIA / NZ  
     – Royal Melbourne Hospital Metabolic Service.  
     – Starship Children’s Hospital, Auckland.  

   CANADA  
     – McGill University Health Centre Rare Lipid Disorders Clinic, Montréal.  
     – SickKids Toronto Inherited Metabolic Diseases Program.  

Ask your GP or primary-care doctor to make a referral; attach copies of the lipid profile and any vitamin-level results to speed triage.

─────────────────────────────────
2. What day-to-day management looks like
─────────────────────────────────
• Lifelong high-dose fat-soluble vitamins  
      Vitamin A 10–25 k IU/day  
      Vitamin E 100–300 mg/kg/day (children) or 2–8 g/day (adults) – dose to keep plasma α-tocopherol normal  
      Vitamins D3 & K per serum levels; some centres give K 5–10 mg/wk.  

• Diet  
      – <20 % of calories from long-chain fat (�� 20–25 g/day in adults).  
      – Emphasise medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) oil (absorbed directly to portal vein).  
      – Liberal complex carbohydrate and protein to maintain weight.  
      – Loperamide or cholestyramine if steatorrhoea troublesome.  

• Monitoring schedule  
      Every 6–12 months: lipid profile, fat-soluble vitamin levels, INR, liver function.  
      Annual ophthalmology (retinitis pigmentosa), neurology (ataxia, neuropathy), growth in children, DEXA every 2–3 y.  

• Complications that can be prevented or slowed by early treatment  
      – Progressive vision loss (retinal degeneration) if vitamin A/E remain low.  
      – Spinocerebellar ataxia, peripheral neuropathy.  
      – Osteopenia/osteoporosis from vitamin D deficiency.  
      – Coagulopathy (vitamin K).  

• Pregnancy and contraception  
      – Women can carry healthy pregnancies; coordinate with metabolic/obstetric team, continue vitamin supplements.

─────────────────────────────────
3. Finding expert & peer support
─────────────────────────────────
Rarer conditions rarely have disease-specific charities in every country, but several umbrella organisations actively help ABL families and will know clinicians who treat it.

INTERNATIONAL / ONLINE  
• Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD, USA NIH)  
  https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/ – information specialists answer e-mail/phone queries and point to clinics and trials.

• National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD

<gold_response>
Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome: Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome is a rare disease passed down through families. The person is unable to fully absorb dietary fats through the intestines. Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome is caused by a defect in a gene that tells the body to create lipoproteins (molecules of fat combined with protein). The defect makes it hard for the body to properly digest fat and essential vitamins. It is an autosomal recessive condition that more often affects males. Symptoms include: - Balance and coordination difficulties - Curvature of spine - Decreased vision that gets worse over time - Developmental delay - Failure to thrive (grow) in infancy - Muscle weakness - Poor muscle coordination that usually develops after age 10 - Protruding abdomen - Slurred speech - Stool abnormalities, including fatty stools that appear pale in color, frothy stools, and abnormally foul-smelling stools There may be damage to the retina of the eye (retinitis pigmentosa). Tests that may be done to help diagnose this condition include: - Apolipoprotein B blood test - Blood tests to look for vitamin deficiencies (fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K) - "Burr-cell" malformation of the red cells (acanthocytosis) - Complete blood count (CBC) - Cholesterol studies - Electromyography - Eye exam - Nerve conduction velocity - Stool sample analysis Genetic testing may be available for mutations in the MTP gene. Treatment involves large doses of vitamin supplements containing fat-soluble vitamins (vitamin A, vitamin D, vitamin E, and vitamin K). Linoleic acid supplements are also recommended. People with this condition should talk to a nutritionist. Diet changes are needed to prevent stomach problems. This involves: - Limiting fat intake to 5 to 20 grams per day. - Do not eat more than 5 ounces daily (140 grams) of lean meat, fish, or poultry. - Use skim milk instead of whole milk. Supplements of medium-chain triglycerides are taken under the supervision of a health care provider. They should be used with caution, because they may cause liver damage. How well a person does depends on the amount of brain and nervous system problems. Complications may include: - Blindness - Mental deterioration - Loss of function of peripheral nerves, uncoordinated movement (ataxia) Call your provider if your infant or child has symptoms of this disease. Genetic counseling can help families understand the condition and the risks of inheriting it, and learn how to care for the person. High doses of fat-soluble vitamins may slow the progression of some problems, such as retina damage and decreased vision. Updated by: Chad Haldeman-Englert, MD, FACMG, Fullerton Genetics Center, Asheville, NC. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I am very sorry your friend is so ill.  Because her condition sounds life-threatening (she is already transfusion-dependent and is now coughing up blood), she needs to be seen urgently by doctors who manage thalassaemia every day—usually a hematologist at a hospital that runs a dedicated thalassaemia or hemoglobinopathy clinic.  
Below is an overview of what usually has to be done, why she may now be bleeding, and where in different parts of the world highly experienced centres can be found.  Take this information to the doctors who are caring for her now; they can help arrange a transfer or referral if necessary.

1.  Why she is so sick
• Thalassaemia major (and some severe intermedia forms) means the body cannot make enough normal haemoglobin.  The bone marrow keeps trying to produce red cells but they are ineffective, so she becomes profoundly anaemic.  
• To stay alive she needs regular red-blood-cell transfusions every 2–5 weeks.  Transfusions keep her haemoglobin high enough for normal growth and organ function, but each unit of blood adds iron to the body.  Unless that iron is removed with “chelation” medicine, it accumulates and damages the liver, heart, and endocrine glands.  
• Repeated transfusions can also enlarge the spleen, cause bone changes, increase risk of infections, and—if not rigorously cross-matched—produce antibodies that make it harder to find compatible blood.

2.  Why she might be coughing up blood (hemoptysis)
• Severe throat irritation or infection while platelets are low.  
• Lung infection (pneumonia, tuberculosis, fungal infection).  
• High pressure in blood vessels of the lungs or heart failure from iron toxicity.  
• Bleeding varices if the liver is heavily damaged by iron.  
• “Extramedullary haematopoiesis” masses pressing on airways.  
Because some of these are emergencies, she should be evaluated in a hospital NOW—chest X-ray/CT, complete blood count, coagulation profile, ferritin level, echocardiogram and liver assessment.

3.  Standard components of care
a) Scheduled packed-red-cell transfusions with leukocyte-reduced, phenotype-matched blood.  
b) Iron chelation: subcutaneous deferoxamine, oral deferiprone or deferasirox; MRI T2* to measure liver/heart iron every 1–2 years.  
c) Monitoring and treatment of endocrinopathies (diabetes, thyroid, growth delay, infertility), bone disease, and infections.  
d) Folic acid, vaccination against hepatitis A/B, meningococcus, pneumococcus, Haemophilus.  
e) Splenectomy if the spleen is enormous or transfusion requirement doubles.  
f) Management of complications such as heart failure, liver cirrhosis, pulmonary hypertension.

4.  Potential curative / disease-modifying therapies
• Allogeneic stem-cell (bone-marrow) transplantation—best results if done early, matched sibling donor, survival >90 % in experienced centres.  
• Matched unrelated-donor or haplo-identical transplants are possible in specialised units.  
• Gene therapy / gene editing trials (lentiviral β-globin addition or CRISPR-mediated HbF reactivation) are under way in Europe, the USA and Asia; a few products are already licensed in the EU/UK.  Clinic must determine eligibility.

5.  Where specialised thalassaemia care is routinely available
This is not a complete list but names internationally recognised programmes you can contact directly; all have English-speaking staff and experience arranging cross-border care.

United States  
• Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) – Comprehensive Thalassemia Center  
• Boston Children’s Hospital / Dana-Farber – Hematology Program  
• UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospitals (San Francisco & Oakland) – Northern California Comprehensive Thalassemia Center  
• Stanford University Medical Center – Blood & Marrow Transplant Program  
• UCLA Mattel Children’s Hospital – Pediatric Hematology  
(Cooley’s Anemia Foundation website lists additional US centres.)

Canada  
• Hospital for Sick Children (SickKids), Toronto – Thalassemia & Sickle Cell Clinic  
• BC Children’s Hospital, Vancouver – Hemoglobinopathy Clinic

Europe  
• University College London Hospitals (UCLH), UK – National Haemoglobinopathy Centre  
• Great Ormond Street Hospital, London – Paediatric Stem-Cell Transplant  
• San Raffaele Scientific Institute, Milan; “Fondazione IRCCS Ca’ Granda” Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico, Milan – among Europe’s largest adult & paediatric thalassaemia programs  
• Ospedale Pediatrico Bambino Gesù, Rome – Paediatric Hematology/Transplant

<gold_response>
Thalassemia (Treatment): Treatment for thalassemia depends on which type you have and how severe it is. Treatments for mild thalassemia Signs and symptoms are usually mild with thalassemia minor and little, if any, treatment is needed. Occasionally, you may need a blood transfusion, particularly after surgery, after having a baby or to help manage thalassemia complications. People with severe beta-thalassemia will need blood transfusions. And because this treatment can cause iron overload, they will also need treatment to remove excess iron. An oral medication called deferasirox (Exjade, Jadenu) can help remove the excess iron. Treatments for moderate to severe thalassemia Treatments for moderate to severe thalassemia may include: - Frequent blood transfusions. More-severe forms of thalassemia often require frequent blood transfusions, possibly every few weeks. Over time, blood transfusions cause a buildup of iron in your blood, which can damage your heart, liver and other organs. To help your body get rid of the extra iron, you may need to take medications that rid your body of extra iron. - Stem cell transplant. Also called a bone marrow transplant, a stem cell transplant may be an option in select cases, including children born with severe thalassemia. It can eliminate the need for lifelong blood transfusions and drugs to control iron overload. During this procedure, you receive infusions of stem cells from a compatible donor, usually a sibling.
</gold_response>

General information – not a substitute for your own physician’s advice

1. What an absence seizure is  
   • A brief (usually 5-20 seconds) episode of altered consciousness caused by a burst of abnormal electrical activity in the brain.  
   • The person typically “blanks out,” may stare, stop talking, or flutter the eyelids, then resumes what he or she was doing.  
   • Most people do not fall, shake, or notice any after-effects.

2. Permanent brain damage is very unlikely  
   • A single typical absence seizure, or even many short, well-controlled seizures, does not injure the brain the way a stroke or head trauma does.  
   • Studies using MRI, EEG and neuropsychological testing show no evidence that brief, isolated absence seizures kill brain cells or leave scars in brain tissue.

3. Possible indirect or long-term effects if seizures are frequent or untreated  
   • Learning and memory: Children (and adults) can miss bits of conversation or classroom instruction each time a seizure occurs. Dozens of seizures a day can add up to significant “lost time” and may look like inattention or poor scholastic performance.  
   • Behavior and mood: The frustration of having uncontrolled seizures, or the social reaction of peers, can contribute to anxiety, low self-esteem, or depression.  
   • Developmental issues: Some epilepsy syndromes that include absence seizures (e.g., Lennox-Gastaut, Doose, juvenile myoclonic epilepsy) are associated with developmental or cognitive difficulties, but these problems are due to the underlying syndrome, not directly to the fleeting absence events.  
   • Prolonged seizures: “Absence status epilepticus” (continuous or repeated absence seizures lasting 30 minutes or more) is uncommon but can cause confusion and requires urgent medical treatment.

4. Physical injury risk is low but not zero  
   • Because consciousness is briefly impaired, a person could walk into traffic, fall from a bicycle, or have an accident while swimming, cooking, or using machinery.  
   • Injuries from the seizure itself (tongue biting, bruising, etc.) are rare; most people simply stop moving and then continue as if nothing happened.

5. Why treatment matters  
   • Anti-seizure medicines (e.g., ethosuximide, valproic acid, lamotrigine) or, in some cases, dietary therapy can usually control absence seizures.  
   • Good control reduces the cumulative “time lost,” improves attention and school/work performance, and lowers the chance of prolonged seizures.  
   • Regular follow-up with a neurologist/epileptologist, adherence to medication, adequate sleep, and avoidance of known triggers (flashing lights, hyperventilation) are key.

6. When to seek medical help quickly  
   • A seizure lasting longer than about 30 seconds without full recovery.  
   • Apparent continuous confusion or a series of repeated seizures without normal periods in between.  
   • New symptoms such as convulsions, loss of balance, or head injury during a spell.

Bottom line  
Typical brief absence seizures do not cause direct brain damage or physical harm, but frequent or uncontrolled episodes can interfere with learning, mood, and safety. Effective treatment and regular medical follow-up minimize these risks. If you or your child is having absence seizures, work with a healthcare professional to keep them well controlled.

<gold_response>
Absence seizure: An absence seizure is the term for a type of seizure involving staring spells. This type of seizure is a brief (usually less than 15 seconds) disturbance of brain function due to abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Absence seizures occur most often in people under age 20, usually in children ages 6 to 12. In some cases, the seizures are triggered by flashing lights or when the person breathes faster and more deeply than usual (hyperventilates). They may occur with other types of seizures, such as generalized tonic-clonic seizures (grand mal seizures), twitches or jerks (myoclonus), or sudden loss of muscle strength (atonic seizures). Most absence seizures last only a few seconds. They often involve staring episodes. The episodes may: - Occur many times a day - Occur for weeks to months before being noticed - Interfere with school and learning - Be mistaken for lack of attention, daydreaming or other misbehavior Unexplained difficulties in school and learning difficulties may be the first sign of absence seizures. During the seizure, the person may: - Stop walking and start again a few seconds later - Stop talking in mid-sentence and start again a few seconds later The person usually does not fall during the seizure. Right after the seizure, the person is usually: - Wide awake - Thinking clearly - Unaware of the seizure Specific symptoms of typical absence seizures may include: - Changes in muscle activity, such as no movement, hand fumbling, fluttering eyelids, lip smacking, chewing - Changes in alertness (consciousness), such as staring episodes, lack of awareness of surroundings, sudden halt in movement, talking, and other awake activities Some absence seizures begin slower and last longer. These are called atypical absence seizures. Symptoms are similar to regular absence seizures, but muscle activity changes may be more noticeable. The doctor will perform a physical exam. This will include a detailed look at the brain and nervous system. An EEG (electroencephalogram) will be done to check the electrical activity in the brain. People with seizures often have abnormal electrical activity seen on this test. In some cases, the test shows the area in the brain where the seizures start. The brain may appear normal after a seizure or between seizures. Blood tests may also be ordered to check for other health problems that may be causing the seizures. Head CT or MRI scan may be done to find the cause and location of the problem in the brain. Treatment for absence seizures includes medicines, changes in lifestyle for adults and children, such as activity and diet, and sometimes surgery. Your doctor can tell you more about these options. Updated by: Amit M. Shelat, DO, FACP, Attending Neurologist and Assistant Professor of Clinical Neurology, SUNY Stony Brook, School of Medicine, Stony Brook, NY. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

predicted_text:
Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD)

1. What it is  
•  ALD is a rare, inherited disorder that damages the myelin (the insulation) surrounding nerves in the brain and spinal cord and can also affect the adrenal glands.  
•  It belongs to a group of conditions called peroxisomal disorders; the body cannot break down certain “very-long-chain” fatty acids (VLCFAs), so they accumulate and harm nerve cells.  

2. Cause / genetics  
•  ALD is almost always caused by a change (mutation) in the ABCD1 gene on the X-chromosome.  
   – Because the gene is on the X-chromosome, the disease is “X-linked.”  
   – Males (who have only one X-chromosome) are usually the ones who develop symptoms.  
   – Females who carry the mutation usually remain healthy or develop milder, later-onset symptoms, but they can pass the gene to their children.  
•  ALD is not contagious and is not caused by anything the parents did during pregnancy.

3. Main forms of the disease  
The same mutation can lead to different forms in different people—even within the same family.

• Childhood cerebral ALD  
   – Onset: usually between 4 and 10 years of age.  
   – Symptoms: behavior or learning problems that look like ADHD, vision or hearing loss, clumsiness, seizures. Without treatment, progressive brain damage can lead to severe disability within a few years.  

• Adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN)  
   – Onset: late teens to adulthood.  
   – Symptoms: gradually worsening stiffness/weakness of the legs, bladder or bowel problems, sexual dysfunction. Progresses slowly over many years.  

• Addison-only disease (isolated adrenal insufficiency)  
   – The adrenal glands fail to make enough cortisol, causing fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, or crisis under stress. Some of these boys/men later develop cerebral disease or AMN; some do not.

4. How it is diagnosed  
•  Blood test for elevated VLCFAs (very-long-chain fatty acids).  
•  MRI of the brain can show demyelination (white-matter changes).  
•  Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the ABCD1 gene.  
•  In several U.S. states and some other countries, ALD is now part of routine newborn screening.

5. Treatment and management  
There is no cure yet, but several treatments can slow or prevent damage if started early:

• Hematopoietic stem-cell transplant (bone-marrow or umbilical-cord blood transplant)  
  – The only proven way to halt progression of the childhood cerebral form—BUT it must be done early, before major neurologic symptoms appear.  

• FDA-approved gene therapy (elivaldogene autotemcel, brand name Skysona)  
  – Recently approved in the U.S. for boys with early, active cerebral ALD who do not yet need a stem-cell donor. Available only in specialized centers.  

• Adrenal hormone replacement  
  – Lifelong oral corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone) for anyone who develops adrenal insufficiency (“Addison’s disease”).  

• “Lorenzo’s Oil” and dietary fat restriction  
  – A mixture of two special fatty acids (glycerol trioleate and trierucate). It lowers VLCFAs in the blood and may delay—but does not reliably prevent—cerebral disease. Usually combined with a low-fat diet and close biochemical monitoring.  

• Symptomatic and supportive care  
  – Physical and occupational therapy for stiffness/spasticity.  
  – Baclofen or other antispasticity medications.  
  – Anti-seizure medicines if seizures occur.  
  – Assistive devices, speech therapy, special education services, psychological support for the family.

6. Prognosis  
• Childhood cerebral ALD progresses rapidly without treatment; early transplant or gene therapy can be life-saving and preserve function.  
• AMN progresses more slowly; most men will eventually need walking aids, but life expectancy can be near-normal.  
• Ongoing monitoring (neurologic exams, adrenal testing, MRI at regular intervals) is essential because form and severity can change over time.

7. Living with ALD / resources  
Because ALD is complex and rare, families often work with a multidisciplinary team at a major children’s hospital or a specialized leukodystrophy center.

Reliable information and support:  
• Kennedy Krieger Institute’s ALD/AMN Center�� https://www.kennedykrieger.org/  
• ALD Connect (patient and family support, research updates)�� https://aldconnect.org/  
• U.S. Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD)�� https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/  
• National

<gold_response>
Adrenoleukodystrophy: Adrenoleukodystrophy describes several closely related disorders that disrupt the breakdown of certain fats. These disorders are passed down (inherited) in families. Adrenoleukodystrophy is usually passed down from parent to child as an X-linked genetic trait. It affects mostly males, although some women who are carriers can have milder forms of the disease. It affects about 1 in 20,000 people from all races. The condition results in the buildup of very-long-chain fatty acids in the nervous system, adrenal gland, and testes. This disrupts normal activity in these parts of the body. There are 3 major categories of disease: - Childhood cerebral form -- appears in mid-childhood (at ages 4 to 8) - Adrenomyelopathy -- occurs in men in their 20s or later in life - Impaired adrenal gland function (called Addison disease or Addison-like phenotype) -- adrenal gland does not produce enough steroid hormones Childhood cerebral type symptoms include: - Changes in muscle tone, especially muscle spasms and uncontrolled movements - Crossed eyes - Handwriting that gets worse - Difficulty at school - Difficulty understanding what people are saying - Hearing loss - Hyperactivity - Worsening nervous system damage, including coma, decreased fine motor control, and paralysis - Seizures - Swallowing difficulties - Visual impairment or blindness Adrenomyelopathy symptoms include: - Difficulty controlling urination - Possible worsening muscle weakness or leg stiffness - Problems with thinking speed and visual memory Adrenal gland failure (Addison type) symptoms include: - Coma - Decreased appetite - Increased skin color - Loss of weight and muscle mass (wasting) - Muscle weakness - Vomiting Tests for this condition include: - Blood levels of very long chain fatty acids and hormones that are produced by the adrenal gland - Chromosome study to look for changes (mutations) in the ABCD1 gene - MRI of the head Adrenal dysfunction may be treated with steroids (such as cortisol) if the adrenal gland is not producing enough hormones. A specific treatment for X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is not available. A bone marrow transplant can cure a people of the condition. The childhood form of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is a progressive disease. It leads to a long-term coma (vegetative state) about 2 years after nervous system symptoms develop. The child can live in this condition for as long as 10 years until death occurs. The other forms of this disease are milder. These complications can occur: - Adrenal crisis - Vegetative state Call your health care provider if: - Your child develops symptoms of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy - Your child has X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy and is getting worse Genetic counseling is recommended for couples with a family history of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy. Mothers of affected sons have an 85% chance of being a carrier for this condition. Prenatal diagnosis of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is also available. It is done by testing cells from chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis. These tests look for either a known genetic change in the family or for very long chain fatty acid levels. Updated by: Chad Haldeman-Englert, MD, FACMG, Fullerton Genetics Center, Asheville, NC. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m glad you reached out—anal fissures can be very painful, but most heal with the right care. Below is general information and self-help advice, followed by guidance on when and where to seek professional help and reliable resources for further support.

WHAT AN ANAL FISSURE IS  
• A small tear in the thin tissue (anoderm) that lines the anal canal.  
• Usually occurs after passing a hard or large stool, prolonged constipation or diarrhea, childbirth, or vigorous wiping.  

COMMON SYMPTOMS  
• Sharp, cutting pain with or after a bowel movement (can last minutes to hours).  
• Bright-red blood on the toilet paper or surface of the stool.  
• A visible crack or small lump (“sentinel pile”) at the anal opening.  
• Spasm of the anal sphincter, which can worsen pain and slow healing.  

SELF-CARE MEASURES THAT OFTEN WORK  
1. Soften the stool  
   – Aim for 25-35 g of fiber/day: fruits, veggies, whole grains, fiber supplement (e.g., psyllium, methylcellulose).  
   – Drink at least 6-8 glasses of water or non-caffeinated fluid daily.  
   – Consider an OTC stool softener such as docusate if recommended by your pharmacist or clinician.

2. Relieve pain and promote blood flow  
   – Warm “sitz baths”: sit in 3-4 inches of comfortably warm water for 10-15 min, 2-3 times/day and after bowel movements.  
   – OTC topical anesthetic (e.g., 5% lidocaine) or a zinc oxide barrier ointment to protect the area.  
   – Non-prescription pain relievers such as acetaminophen or an NSAID (ibuprofen/naproxen) if you tolerate them.

3. Avoid straining  
   – Go as soon as you feel the urge; prolonged sitting on the toilet increases pressure.  
   – Elevating feet on a small stool can straighten the canal and ease passage.  
   – Do not use harsh soaps or wipes containing alcohol or perfume.

WHEN TO SEEK MEDICAL CARE  
• Severe pain or bleeding, or bleeding mixed in the stool.  
• No improvement after 1–2 weeks of correct self-care, or symptoms >6 weeks (may indicate a chronic fissure).  
• Recurrent fissures or those occurring off the midline (can be a sign of Crohn’s disease, infection, or other conditions).  
• Fever, pus, or a swelling that could indicate an abscess.  

WHAT A CLINICIAN CAN DO  
• Confirm the diagnosis with a gentle exam (usually no invasive scopes needed initially).  
• Prescribe topical vasodilators that relax the sphincter and hasten healing:  
  – 0.2–0.4 % nitroglycerin ointment (may cause headache).  
  – 2 % diltiazem or nifedipine cream/gel (fewer headaches).  
• Botulinum toxin (Botox) injections if ointments fail.  
• Small outpatient surgery (lateral internal sphincterotomy) cures >90 % of chronic fissures but is reserved for persistent cases.

OTHER POSSIBLE CAUSES OF YOUR SYMPTOMS  
Hemorrhoids, proctitis, Crohn’s disease, infection, skin conditions (psoriasis, lichen planus) and, very rarely, anal cancer. This is why persistent or atypical fissures need a professional evaluation.

FINDING SUPPORT & RELIABLE INFORMATION

I’m glad you reached out—anal fissures can be very painful, but most heal with the right care. Below is general information and self-help advice, followed by guidance on when and where to seek professional help and reliable resources for further support.

WHAT AN ANAL FISSURE IS  
• A small tear in the thin tissue (anoderm) that lines the anal canal.  
• Usually occurs after passing a hard or large stool, prolonged constipation or diarrhea, childbirth, or vigorous wiping.  

COMMON SYMPTOMS  
• Sharp, cutting pain with or after a bowel movement (can last minutes to hours).  
• Bright-red blood on the toilet paper or surface of the stool.  
• A visible crack or small lump (“sentinel pile”) at the anal opening.  
• Spasm of the anal sphincter, which can worsen pain and slow healing.  

SELF-CARE MEASURES THAT OFTEN WORK  
1. Soften the stool  
   – Aim for 25-35 g of fiber/day: fruits, veggies, whole grains, fiber supplement (e.g., psyllium, methylcellulose).  
   – Drink at least 6-8 glasses of water or non-caffeinated fluid daily.  
   – Consider an OTC stool softener such as docusate if recommended by your pharmacist or clinician.

2. Relieve pain and promote blood flow  
   – Warm “sitz baths”: sit in 3-4 inches of comfortably warm water for 10-15 min, 2-3 times/day and after bowel movements.  
   – OTC topical anesthetic (e.g., 5% lidocaine) or a zinc oxide barrier ointment to protect the area.  
   – Non-prescription pain relievers such as acetaminophen or an NSAID (ibuprofen/naproxen) if you tolerate them.

3. Avoid straining  
   – Go as soon as you feel the urge; prolonged sitting on the toilet increases pressure.  
   – Elevating feet on a small stool can straighten the canal and ease passage.  
   – Do not use harsh soaps or wipes containing alcohol or perfume.

WHEN TO SEEK MEDICAL CARE  
• Severe pain or bleeding, or bleeding mixed in the stool.  
• No improvement after 1–2 weeks of correct self-care, or symptoms >6 weeks (may indicate a chronic fissure).  
• Recurrent fissures or those occurring off the midline (can be a sign of Crohn’s disease, infection, or other conditions).  
• Fever, pus, or a swelling that could indicate an abscess.  

WHAT A CLINICIAN CAN DO  
• Confirm the diagnosis with a gentle exam (usually no invasive scopes needed initially).  
• Prescribe topical vasodilators that relax the sphincter and hasten healing:  
  – 0.2–0.4 % nitroglycerin ointment (may cause headache).  
  – 2 % diltiazem or nifedipine cream/gel (fewer headaches).  
• Botulinum toxin (Botox) injections if ointments fail.  
• Small outpatient surgery (lateral internal sphincterotomy) cures >90 % of chronic fissures but is reserved for persistent cases.

OTHER POSSIBLE CAUSES OF YOUR SYMPTOMS  
Hemorrhoids, proctitis, Crohn’s disease, infection, skin conditions (psoriasis, lichen planus) and, very rarely, anal cancer. This is why persistent or atypical fissures need a professional evaluation.

Anal fissures are common and usually heal with simple measures like stool-softening, warm baths, and topical pain relief. If symptoms are severe, last more than a couple of weeks, or keep coming back, get examined—effective prescription treatments and minor procedures are available.

This information is for general educational purposes and not a substitute for an in-person medical evaluation. If you develop heavy bleeding, intense pain, fever, or any new concerning symptom, please seek medical care promptly.

Anal fissure (Treatment): Anal fissures often heal within a few weeks if you take steps to keep your stool soft, such as increasing your intake of fiber and fluids. Soaking in warm water for 10 to 20 minutes several times a day, especially after bowel movements, can help relax the sphincter and promote healing. If your symptoms persist, you'll likely need further treatment. Nonsurgical treatments Your doctor may recommend: - Externally applied nitroglycerin (Rectiv), to help increase blood flow to the fissure and promote healing and to help relax the anal sphincter. Nitroglycerin is generally considered the medical treatment of choice when other conservative measures fail. Side effects may include headache, which can be severe. - Topical anesthetic creams such as lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine) may be helpful for pain relief. - Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) injection, to paralyze the anal sphincter muscle and relax spasms. - Blood pressure medications, such as oral nifedipine (Procardia) or diltiazem (Cardizem) can help relax the anal sphincter. These medications may be taken by mouth or applied externally and may be used when nitroglycerin is not effective or causes significant side effects. Surgery If you have a chronic anal fissure that is resistant to other treatments, or if your symptoms are severe, your doctor may recommend surgery. Doctors usually perform a procedure called lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS), which involves cutting a small portion of the anal sphincter muscle to reduce spasm and pain, and promote healing. Studies have found that for chronic fissure, surgery is much more effective than any medical treatment. However, surgery has a small risk of causing incontinence.

predicted_text:
Can someone who has Angelman syndrome have children?

• Angelman syndrome does not usually affect the reproductive organs, so men can make sperm and women can ovulate and carry a pregnancy.  
• Because most people with classic Angelman syndrome have severe intellectual disability, seizures and motor-coordination problems, very few go on to have children in practice.  Pregnancies have, however, been reported—mainly in women who have a milder or “mosaic” form of the condition.

If a parent who has Angelman syndrome does have a child, can the syndrome be passed on?

Yes, it can be, but the chance depends on both (1) which genetic mechanism caused the parent’s Angelman syndrome and (2) whether the parent is the mother or the father.

1. Mother with Angelman syndrome  
   • Deletion of the Angelman region, a disease-causing change (mutation) in the UBE3A gene, or an imprinting-center defect: each pregnancy has about a 50 % chance of Angelman syndrome.  
   • Very rare causes (e.g., paternal uniparental disomy in the mother): recurrence risk is low.

2. Father with Angelman syndrome  
   • The abnormal chromosome or gene he passes on is “paternally imprinted” (normally switched off in the child’s brain), so his children are usually not affected.  
   • His daughters, however, can carry the abnormal copy; if they later become mothers they could pass Angelman syndrome to their own children.

Because the exact risk varies with the underlying genetic change, anyone with Angelman syndrome (or the family of an affected person) who is considering pregnancy should meet with a genetics professional.  Genetic counseling, prenatal testing and/or pre-implantation genetic testing can be offered when the mutation or deletion in the family is known.

<gold_response>
Is Angelman syndrome inherited?: Most cases of Angelman syndrome are not inherited, particularly those caused by a deletion in the maternal chromosome 15 or by paternal uniparental disomy. These genetic changes occur as random events during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs and sperm) or in early embryonic development. Affected people typically have no history of the disorder in their family. Rarely, a genetic change responsible for Angelman syndrome can be inherited. For example, it is possible for a mutation in the UBE3A gene or in the nearby region of DNA that controls gene activation to be passed from one generation to the next.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m sorry your father is going through this; hearing the words “leukemia” is frightening.  
The good news is that hairy-cell leukemia (HCL) is one of the most treatable leukemias and most people diagnosed today go on to live many years – often with a normal life span.

1. What HCL is  
• A rare, slow-growing cancer of the blood in which abnormal B-lymphocytes build up in the bone marrow and spleen.  
• The name comes from small “hair-like” projections seen on the cells under the microscope.  
• It usually appears in adults over 40 (average age ≈ 55–60) and is about four times more common in men.

2. How serious is it?  
• Untreated, it can cause low blood counts that lead to infections, anemia, bleeding, or an enlarged spleen.  
• Fortunately, because it grows slowly and responds extremely well to modern drugs, most patients do very well after treatment.  
• Five-year survival rates exceed 90 % and many patients are alive and well 15–20 years after diagnosis. Some studies even show life expectancy approaching that of people without HCL.

3. Standard treatments  
Treatment is usually started only if the blood counts are low or symptoms appear. The first-line medicines are given by IV for just a few days and often put the disease into remission for many years.  
• Cladribine (2-CDA) – single 5- to 7-day infusion or once-daily injections.  
• Pentostatin – IV every 2 weeks for several months.  
These drugs produce complete remissions in about 80–90 % of patients.  
Other options (used if the first drug fails or the disease comes back) include:  
• Rituximab (MabThera®, Rituxan®) – antibody infusion.  
• Moxetumomab pasudotox (Lumoxiti®).  
• Interferon-alpha – rarely used today but helpful in some situations.  
• Splenectomy (spleen removal) – seldom needed now.

4. Long-term outlook  
• Remissions often last 7–15 years or longer. Relapses can occur, but the same or new drugs usually work again.  
• Regular follow-up blood tests (every 3–6 months at first, then yearly) are important.  
• Risk of transformation to an aggressive leukemia or lymphoma is very low.  
• Most people can keep working and carrying on normal activities between brief treatment courses.

5. What your family should do now  
• Be sure the diagnosis has been confirmed by a hematologist/oncologist, usually with a bone-marrow biopsy and special tests (immunophenotyping).  
• Discuss whether your father needs treatment right away or watchful waiting.  
• Ask the doctor about infection-prevention steps (vaccinations, prompt treatment of fevers) because the drugs can temporarily lower white cells.  
• Maintain healthy lifestyle habits – balanced diet, regular exercise, avoiding smoking, moderating alcohol.  
• Seek emotional support; many patients find reassurance in HCL support groups (e.g., Hairy Cell Leukemia Foundation).

Bottom line  
Hairy-cell leukemia is a serious diagnosis, but it is highly treatable. With current therapies, most 55-year-old patients enter long remissions and can expect to live a long, good-quality life. Staying in close follow-up with a hematologist and treating promptly when needed are the keys to that success. Best wishes to your father and your family.

<gold_response>
Hairy cell leukemia (Treatment): Treatment isn't always necessary for people with hairy cell leukemia. Because this cancer progresses very slowly and sometimes doesn't progress at all, some people prefer to wait to treat their cancer only if it causes signs and symptoms. The majority of people with hairy cell leukemia eventually need treatment. If your hairy cell leukemia causes signs and symptoms, you may decide to undergo treatment. There is no cure for hairy cell leukemia. But treatments are effective at putting hairy cell leukemia in remission for years. Chemotherapy Doctors consider chemotherapy drugs the first line of treatment for hairy cell leukemia. The great majority of people will experience complete or partial remission through the use of chemotherapy. Two chemotherapy drugs are used in hairy cell leukemia: - Cladribine. Treatment for hairy cell leukemia typically begins with cladribine. You receive a continuous infusion of the drug into a vein over several days. Most people who receive cladribine experience a complete remission that can last for several years. If your hairy cell leukemia returns, you can be treated with cladribine again. Side effects of cladribine may include infection and fever. - Pentostatin (Nipent). Pentostatin causes remission rates similar to cladribine, but it's given on a different schedule. People who take pentostatin receive infusions every other week for three to six months. Side effects of pentostatin may include fever, nausea and infection. Biological treatments Biological therapy attempts to make cancer cells more recognizable to your immune system. Once your immune system identifies cancer cells as intruders, it can set about destroying your cancer. Two types of biological treatments are used in hairy cell leukemia: - Interferon. Currently, the role of interferon in hairy cell leukemia treatment is limited. You might receive interferon if chemotherapy hasn't been effective or if you can't take chemotherapy. Most people experience partial remission with interferon, which is taken for a year. Side effects include flu-like symptoms, such as fever and fatigue. - Rituximab (Rituxan). Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody approved to treat non-Hodgkin lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia, though it's sometimes used in hairy cell leukemia. If chemotherapy drugs haven't worked for you or you can't take chemotherapy, your doctor might consider rituximab. Side effects of rituximab include fever and infection. Surgery Surgery to remove your spleen (splenectomy) might be an option if your spleen ruptures or if it's enlarged and causing pain. Though removing your spleen can't cure hairy cell leukemia, it can usually restore normal blood counts. Splenectomy isn't commonly used to treat hairy cell leukemia, but it may be helpful in certain situations. Any surgery carries a risk of bleeding and infection.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Short answer  
• At this time there is no treatment that is accepted by the medical community as a “cure” for asthma.  
• Current therapy can control the disease very well for most people, and many children may appear to “grow out of” their symptoms, but the underlying tendency toward airway inflammation and hyper-reactivity usually remains.  
• Research continues (e.g., biologic drugs, immunomodulation, gene-directed therapy), but nothing yet eliminates asthma permanently.

A consumer-friendly overview

What doctors mean by “no cure”  
Asthma is a chronic (long-term) inflammatory disease of the airways. In most chronic diseases a “cure” would mean the problem never comes back without ongoing treatment. With asthma, if controller medicine and trigger avoidance are stopped, symptoms and airway inflammation almost always return. Therefore the consensus guideline documents from major organizations all state that asthma is “controllable but not curable.”

Guideline statements  
• U.S. National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) 2020 Focused Updates:  
  “There is currently no cure for asthma, but asthma can be effectively managed….”  
• Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) 2023:  
  “Asthma cannot be cured, but for most patients good control can be achieved.”  
• American Academy of Pediatrics/British Thoracic Society, etc., use similar wording.

Why some people seem “cured”  
• About 30–50 % of children with mild asthma have no symptoms by late adolescence. However, lung-function testing often still shows some reactivity, and symptoms may return in adulthood—especially with respiratory infections, smoking, weight gain, or occupational exposures.  
• In adults, long symptom-free periods can occur, but stopping maintenance therapy usually allows inflammation to smolder and future attacks remain possible.

Current treatments aim to  
1. Prevent daily and night-time symptoms.  
2. Minimize need for quick-relief (rescue) inhaler.  
3. Prevent exacerbations that need oral steroids, ED visits, or hospitalization.  
4. Preserve normal lung function and exercise ability.  
Controller options include inhaled corticosteroids, leukotriene modifiers, long-acting bronchodilators, and, for moderate-to-severe disease, biologic agents (e.g., anti-IgE, anti-IL-5, anti-IL-4Rα monoclonal antibodies).

What’s in the research pipeline  
• Additional biologic drugs targeting other inflammatory pathways.  
• Immunotherapy approaches (e.g., sublingual or subcutaneous allergen immunotherapy) — can reduce symptoms but does not constitute a cure.  
• Regenerative and gene-editing strategies are still experimental.

Practical takeaway for patients  
• Work with your clinician to develop and keep an up-to-date Asthma Action Plan.  
• Take controller medicines even when you feel well if they’re prescribed for you.  
• Identify and avoid triggers (allergens, viral infections, smoke, air pollution, exercise without pre-treatment, certain workplace exposures, etc.).  
• Keep vaccinations current (influenza, COVID-19, pneumococcal if eligible).  
• Monitor symptoms and peak-flow, and seek prompt care for worsening attacks.

Where to read more  
1. National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI). 2020 Focused Updates to the Asthma Management Guidelines. https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov  
2. Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA). Global Strategy for Asthma Management and Prevention (2023). https://ginasthma.org  
3. American Lung Association. “Is Asthma Curable?” https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/asthma/learning-more-about-asthma/cure  
4. MedlinePlus. “Asthma.” https://medlineplus.gov/asthma.html  

These articles discuss, in plain language, that asthma is currently considered controllable but not curable.

(Information provided for general educational purposes and is not a substitute for personal medical advice. Always consult your healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.)

Asthma (Overview): Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath. predicted_text:
Bad breath (the medical term is “halitosis”) is extremely common and almost always treatable once the source is found. The key is to tackle the problem from two angles:

1) remove or neutralize odor-producing bacteria/chemicals in the mouth, and  
2) identify and treat any underlying dental, ENT, stomach-esophageal, medication-related, or systemic conditions that may be feeding the odor.

Below is a practical step-by-step guide.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Start with meticulous oral-care basics
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Brush well, twice a day, 2 full minutes each time. Angle the brush gently into the gum line where odor-causing plaque collects. A power/sonic toothbrush can help.  
• Floss (or use interdental picks/water flosser) once a day. Food trapped between teeth is a top source of bad breath.  
• Clean the tongue. 40–60 % of oral bacteria live on the tongue’s back surface. Use a tongue scraper (available in any drug store) or the ridged back of some toothbrushes. Scrape from back to front 2–3 times, rinsing the scraper between passes.  
• Rinse, but choose the right rinse. Alcohol-based “fresh-breath” rinses often mask odor only briefly and can worsen dry mouth. Look instead for:
  – Chlorhexidine 0.12 % (prescription; very effective but can stain teeth if overused)  
  – Cetylpyridinium chloride or essential-oil rinses (Listerine Zero, Crest Pro-Health, etc.)  
  – Zinc-containing rinses/toothpastes, which neutralize sulfur compounds.  
• Replace toothbrush or electric brush head every 3 months or after illness.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Hydrate and stimulate saliva
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Dry mouth allows odor-producing compounds to concentrate.  
• Aim for at least 6–8 glasses (�� 2 L) of plain water daily.  
• Chew sugar-free gum or suck xylitol mints to trigger saliva flow.  
• Limit caffeine, alcohol, and recreational drugs—they dry the mouth.  
• If you take medications that cause dry mouth (antihistamines, many antidepressants, blood-pressure meds), ask your prescriber if alternatives or dose timing adjustments are possible. Over-the-counter saliva substitutes (Biotène, XyliMelts) can help.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Check lifestyle & diet triggers
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Tobacco (smoked or chewed) and vaping: major culprits. Quitting often yields rapid improvement.  
• Odorous foods (garlic, onions, fish, certain spices) release sulfur compounds that can linger up to 24 h. Rinse, chew parsley or mint, or drink green tea afterward; but prevention (limiting intake) works best.  
• High-protein “keto” dieting can create a fruity or acetone-like odor; increase complex carbs or speak with a dietitian if bothersome.  
• Alcohol overuse can cause a stale “boozy” odor for hours.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Schedule a dental examination and cleaning
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Persistent halitosis despite good home care is most often linked to:
• Gum (periodontal) disease  
• Untreated cavities  
• Poorly fitting crowns, dentures, or braces harborage  
A dentist can perform deep cleaning, treat infection, polish rough restorations, and check for wisdom-tooth or root-canal issues that harbor bacteria.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5. If odor persists, look beyond the mouth
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Ask your primary-care clinician or an ENT/gastroenterologist to rule out:

ENT sources  
• Chronic sinusitis or post-nasal drip (bacteria digest nasal mucus → sulfur gas).  
• Tonsil stones (tonsilloliths); can often be seen as white specks in tonsil crypts.  
• Chronic throat infections.

Digestive/respiratory sources  
• Gastro-esophageal reflux disease (GERD) or silent reflux.  
• H. pylori gastritis or stomach ulcers.  
• Lung infections or bronchiectasis (rare but possible).

Systemic or metabolic causes (less common but important)  
• Poorly controlled diabetes (sweet/acetone “fruity” breath, sign of ketoacidosis)  
• Advanced kidney disease (urine/ammonia odor)  
• Severe liver disease (musty/fishy odor, “foetor hepaticus”)  
• Trimethylaminuria (“fish-odor syndrome,” genetic)  
• Some vitamin or amino-acid metabolic disorders.

Bring a list of your medications and major health conditions when you are evaluated.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6. When to seek prompt medical care
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Sudden, very sweet/acetone breath with excessive thirst, frequent urination, or fatigue (possible diabetic ketoacidosis—emergency).  
• Breath that smells like ammonia

What is Bad Breath?: There are many reasons why you might have bad breath. You can get it if you don't brush and floss regularly. Bacteria that build up in your mouth and between your teeth produce the bad odor. Other problems in your mouth, such as gum disease, dry mouth or cavities, may also cause it. Sinusitis or problems with your nose may be to blame. You can also have bad breath if you eat some foods, like raw onions, garlic or cabbage. And of course smoking causes its own bad aroma. Some diseases and medicines are associated with a specific breath odor. Having good dental habits, like brushing and flossing regularly, help fight bad breath. Mouthwashes, mints or chewing gum may make your breath fresher. If you have an underlying disorder, treating it may help eliminate the breath odor.
</gold_response>

Below is a brief “state-of-the-science” overview of the three treatments you asked about.  Nothing here replaces an in-person discussion with your own psychiatrist or primary-care clinician.

1.  Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)

•  What it is – A non-invasive procedure that uses a rapidly alternating magnetic field to produce small electrical currents in a specific area of cortex (usually the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex).  A typical acute course is 5 sessions a week for 4-6 weeks; each session lasts 20-40 min and you remain awake.

•  Regulatory status – The U.S. FDA has cleared TMS for adults who have treatment-resistant Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and, more recently, for obsessive-compulsive disorder and smoking cessation.  It is NOT yet FDA-cleared specifically for bipolar disorder or for generalized anxiety disorder (GAD); use for those conditions is considered “off-label.”

•  What the research shows  
  – Bipolar depression:  About 25–30 small studies and case series exist.  Response rates (�� 50 % symptom drop) run 40–60 %; remission rates (minimal symptoms) 25–35 %.  Manic switching is uncommon but has been reported, so patients are generally kept on a mood stabilizer.  
  – GAD (without bipolar):  Data are more limited; pilot trials show modest anxiety reduction, but larger controlled studies are still underway.  No solid evidence yet for GAD + bipolar specifically.  
  – Durability:  About half of responders keep the benefit at 6-12 months, sometimes needing maintenance (“booster”) sessions.

•  Side-effects – Scalp discomfort or headache in ~30 %, almost always mild; brief lightheadedness; rare (< 0.1 %) induction of a seizure (screening removes most risk).

•  Bottom line – Good option for treatment-resistant bipolar depression when standard medication / psychotherapy combinations have not worked, but still considered investigational for that indication.  Not enough data yet to recommend it specifically for generalized anxiety.

2.  Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)

•  What it is – Under brief general anesthesia an electrical current induces a generalized brain seizure lasting 20-60 seconds.  A typical acute course is 6-12 treatments over 2-4 weeks.

<gold_response>
Generalized anxiety disorder (Treatment): Treatment decisions are based on how significantly generalized anxiety disorder is affecting your ability to function in your daily life. The two main treatments for generalized anxiety disorder are psychotherapy and medications. You may benefit most from a combination of the two. It may take some trial and error to discover which treatments work best for you. Psychotherapy Also known as talk therapy or psychological counseling, psychotherapy involves working with a therapist to reduce your anxiety symptoms. Cognitive behavioral therapy is the most effective form of psychotherapy for generalized anxiety disorder. Generally a short-term treatment, cognitive behavioral therapy focuses on teaching you specific skills to directly manage your worries and help you gradually return to the activities you've avoided because of anxiety. Through this process, your symptoms improve as you build on your initial success. Medications Several types of medications are used to treat generalized anxiety disorder, including those below. Talk with your doctor about benefits, risks and possible side effects. - Antidepressants. Antidepressants, including medications in the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) classes, are the first line medication treatments. Examples of antidepressants used to treat generalized anxiety disorder include escitalopram (Lexapro), duloxetine (Cymbalta), venlafaxine (Effexor XR) and paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva). Your doctor also may recommend other antidepressants. - Buspirone. An anti-anxiety medication called buspirone may be used on an ongoing basis. As with most antidepressants, it typically takes up to several weeks to become fully effective. - Benzodiazepines. In limited circumstances, your doctor may prescribe a benzodiazepine for relief of anxiety symptoms. These sedatives are generally used only for relieving acute anxiety on a short-term basis. Because they can be habit-forming, these medications aren't a good choice if you have or had problems with alcohol or drug abuse.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m sorry your family is facing this.  
Because every breast-cancer plan is built around the tumor’s biology AND the patient’s overall health, the exact recommendations cannot be finalized until the surgical (post-lumpectomy) pathology report is back.  
Below is a framework you can use when you meet with the breast surgeon, radiation oncologist and medical oncologist.  It summarizes the usual options for women in their 80s and the factors that guide decisions.

1. Confirm the exact diagnosis and stage  
   • Is it purely ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or has it already broken through the duct wall (invasive ductal carcinoma)?  
   • Size of each focus, grade, margins (how close the tumor comes to the cut edge).  
   • Hormone-receptor status: estrogen (ER) and progesterone (PR) receptors.  
   • HER2/neu status.  
   • Any lymph-node involvement (a sentinel-node biopsy is often done during lumpectomy; in a frail 84-year-old it can sometimes be omitted if the tumor is truly small and non-invasive).

2. Adjuvant (after-surgery) treatments that MAY be discussed

   A. Radiation therapy  
      • Standard after a lumpectomy because it cuts the risk of the cancer returning in the same breast by ~50–70 %.  
      • For healthy women ≥70 with a small (��2 cm), lymph-node-negative, ER-positive tumor, several major trials (CALGB 9343, PRIME II) showed that you can safely skip radiation if she takes hormonal therapy; it raises the local-recurrence rate a little but does NOT shorten life expectancy.  
      • Ask about a short-course regimen (e.g., 5–10 treatments over 1–2 weeks) if radiation is chosen; this is now standard in many centers for older adults.

   B. Hormonal (endocrine) therapy  
      • If the tumor is ER- or PR-positive (most breast cancers in older women are), pills that lower estrogen levels are the mainstay.  
           – Aromatase inhibitors (letrozole, anastrozole, exemestane) once daily for 5 years; side-effects: joint stiffness, bone thinning, hot flashes.  
           – Tamoxifen 20 mg daily for 5 years; side-effects: hot flashes, small clot/stroke or uterine-cancer risk.  
      • Bone density should be checked before and during aromatase-inhibitor use; calcium/vitamin D, weight-bearing exercise, and sometimes a bone-strengthening drug are added.

   C. Chemotherapy  
      • Far fewer 80-year-olds benefit from chemo. It is considered only if the tumor is clearly aggressive:  
        – Triple-negative (ER-, PR-, HER2-) or high-grade invasive cancer >2 cm or with positive nodes.  
      • The oncologist will weigh heart, kidney, and marrow reserve, other illnesses, functional ability, and what incremental survival benefit chemo would add; often the benefit is small and the risk of harm is significant.  
      • A genomic assay such as Oncotype DX or MammaPrint can estimate whether chemotherapy will help in ER-positive, HER2-negative, node-negative cancers; if the recurrence score is low, chemo can be safely avoided.

   D. HER2-targeted therapy (trastuzumab, etc.)  
      • Used only if the tumor over-expresses HER2 (��15 % of breast cancers).  
      • Requires IV infusions every 3 weeks for a year and serial heart-function checks; seldom offered to frail elders unless the potential benefit is large.

   E. No further treatment / surveillance only  
      • For tiny, low-grade DCIS with wide clear margins, or for patients whose other medical problems outweigh the risk of breast cancer recurrence, surveillance alone is reasonable.  
      • Follow-up involves a physical exam every 6–12 months and annual mammogram.

3. Key geriatric considerations  
   • Overall life expectancy at 84 averages 6–7 years, but may be >10 years in a vigorous woman or <2 years in someone with serious heart, lung or cognitive problems. Treatments that mainly reduce recurrences after 10 years may not be worthwhile.  
   • A “geriatric assessment” (walking speed, medications, memory, nutrition, social support) helps predict tolerance to therapy and should be part of the oncology work-up.  
   • Quality of life matters: preserving independence, avoiding lengthy daily trips to a radiation center, and minimizing drug side-effects often guide choices as much as survival statistics.

4. Questions to take to the oncology team  
   1. Exactly what did the final pathology show—stage, grade, ER/PR, HER2, margins?  
   2. Do you feel a sentinel lymph-node biopsy is necessary in her case?  
   3. Based

<gold_response>
Breast cancer (Treatment): Treatment is based on many factors, including: - Type of breast cancer - Stage of the cancer (staging is a tool your providers use to find out how advanced the cancer is) - Whether the cancer is sensitive to certain hormones - Whether the cancer overproduces (overexpresses) the HER2/neu protein Cancer treatments may include: - Hormone therapy. - Chemotherapy, which uses medicines to kill cancer cells. - Radiation therapy, which is used to destroy cancerous tissue. - Surgery to remove cancerous tissue: A lumpectomy removes the breast lump. Mastectomy removes all or part of the breast and possibly nearby structures. Nearby lymph nodes may also be removed during surgery. - Targeted therapy uses medicine to attack the gene changes in cancer cells. Hormone therapy is an example of targeted therapy. It blocks certain hormones that fuel cancer growth. Cancer treatment can be local or systemic: - Local treatments involve only the area of disease. Radiation and surgery are forms of local treatment. They are most effective when the cancer has not spread outside the breast. - Systemic treatments affect the entire body. Chemotherapy and hormonal therapy are types of systemic treatment. Most women receive a combination of treatments. For women with stage I, II, or III breast cancer, the main goal is to treat the cancer and prevent it from returning (recurring). For women with stage IV cancer, the goal is to improve symptoms and help them live longer. In most cases, stage IV breast cancer cannot be cured. - Stage 0 and ductal carcinoma: Lumpectomy plus radiation or mastectomy is the standard treatment. - Stage I and II: Lumpectomy plus radiation or mastectomy with lymph node removal is the standard treatment. Chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, and other targeted therapy may also be used after surgery. - Stage III: Treatment involves surgery, possibly followed by chemotherapy, hormone therapy, and other targeted therapy. - Stage IV: Treatment may involve surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, hormone therapy, other targeted therapy, or a combination of these treatments. After treatment, some women continue to take medicines for a time. All women continue to have blood tests, mammograms, and other tests after treatment to monitor for the return of cancer or development of another breast cancer. Women who have had a mastectomy may have reconstructive breast surgery. This will be done either at the time of mastectomy or later.
</gold_response>

The National Library of Medicine (NLM) provides several consumer-friendly resources that list and explain the conditions, injuries, and exposures that can damage peripheral nerves.  The clearest summary is on the MedlinePlus “Peripheral Neuropathy” topic page and in the NINDS (National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke) Peripheral Neuropathy Fact Sheet—both are maintained by NLM.

According to those NLM sources, peripheral neuropathy can be caused by:

• Diabetes mellitus – the single most common cause in the United States.  
• Physical injury or trauma – fractures, dislocations, car- or sports-related injuries, surgery, prolonged pressure on a nerve (e.g., from crutches, cast, repetitive motions).  
• Systemic (whole-body) diseases  
  – Kidney failure/uremia  
  – Liver disease  
  – Hypothyroidism  
  – Connective-tissue and autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, Sjögren syndrome, Guillain-Barré syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy).  
• Infections  
  – Shingles (herpes zoster)  
  – Lyme disease  
  – HIV/AIDS  
  – Hepatitis C  
  – Leprosy (Hansen disease)  
  – Diphtheria, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus and others.  
• Exposure to toxins or poisons  
  – Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic)  
  – Industrial chemicals and solvents  
  – Certain herbicides and insecticides.  
• Alcohol abuse – both direct toxicity and associated vitamin deficiencies.  
• Vitamin and nutritional deficiencies, especially of B-vitamins (B1, B6, B12), vitamin E, and niacin.  
• Certain medicines and medical treatments  
  – Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., vincristine, paclitaxel, cisplatin)  
  – Some antibiotics (metronidazole, nitrofurantoin)  
  – Antiretrovirals for HIV

• Bone marrow disorders – multiple myeloma, lymphoma, monoclonal gammopathy, amyloidosis.  
• Metabolic or endocrine disorders – including metabolic syndrome, acromegaly.  
• Vascular problems – reduced blood flow to the nerves (vasculitis, peripheral artery disease).  
• Idiopathic neuropathy – in a significant percentage of people, no specific cause is found.

These pages give additional details on how each cause damages nerves, typical symptoms, diagnosis, and available treatments.

The National Library of Medicine (NLM) provides several consumer-friendly resources that list and explain the conditions, injuries, and exposures that can damage peripheral nerves.  The clearest summary is on the MedlinePlus “Peripheral Neuropathy” topic page and in the NINDS (National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke) Peripheral Neuropathy Fact Sheet—both are maintained by NLM.

According to those NLM sources, peripheral neuropathy can be caused by:

• Diabetes mellitus – the single most common cause in the United States.  
• Physical injury or trauma – fractures, dislocations, car- or sports-related injuries, surgery, prolonged pressure on a nerve (e.g., from crutches, cast, repetitive motions).

  – Industrial chemicals and solvents  
  – Certain herbicides and insecticides.  
• Alcohol abuse – both direct toxicity and associated vitamin deficiencies.

Peripheral Neuropathy (Definition): Peripheral neuropathy describes damage to the peripheral nervous system, which transmits information from the brain and spinal cord to every other part of the body. More than 100 types of peripheral neuropathy have been identified, each with its own characteristic set of symptoms, pattern of development, and prognosis. Impaired function and symptoms depend on the type of nerves -- motor, sensory, or autonomic -- that are damaged.  Some people may experience temporary numbness, tingling, and pricking sensations, sensitivity to touch, or muscle weakness. Others may suffer more extreme symptoms, including burning pain (especially at night), muscle wasting, paralysis, or organ or gland dysfunction. Peripheral neuropathy may be either inherited or acquired. Causes of acquired peripheral neuropathy include physical injury (trauma) to a nerve, tumors, toxins, autoimmune responses, nutritional deficiencies, alcoholism, medical procedures, and vascular and metabolic disorders. Acquired peripheral neuropathies are caused by systemic disease, trauma from external agents, or infections or autoimmune disorders affecting nerve tissue. Inherited forms of peripheral neuropathy are caused by inborn mistakes in the genetic code or by new genetic mutations.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
What pneumonia is  
• “Pneumonia” simply means an infection-related inflammation of the air sacs (alveoli) in one or both lungs.  
• Most cases are caused by a germ you can catch from someone else―usually a bacterium (for example Streptococcus pneumoniae) or a virus (influenza, RSV, COVID-19, etc.). Less often it is due to fungi, or from inhaling food/vomit (“aspiration pneumonia”).  
• It is not a hereditary or lifelong disease; it is an acute illness that almost always clears with the right treatment.

Is it contagious?  
• The organisms that produce pneumonia can be spread in the tiny droplets we all exhale when we cough, sneeze, or even talk. In that sense pneumonia can be “infectious.”  
• With bacterial pneumonia, once the patient has been on an appropriate antibiotic for 24–48 hours, the risk of passing the germ to others falls sharply.  
• After complete recovery there is no carrier state—she will not go on “giving” pneumonia to you or anyone else.

Can it be cured completely?  
• In otherwise healthy people most community-acquired pneumonia is fully cured.  
  – Bacterial pneumonia: usually 5-10 days of the correct oral or IV antibiotic, sometimes longer.  
  – Viral pneumonia: antibiotics do not help, but antivirals (e.g. for influenza) may, and the body clears the virus on its own with rest and good care.  
• Symptoms such as fatigue or an occasional cough can linger for a few weeks, but the infection itself is gone.  
• A small minority of people—those with chronic lung disease, diabetes, weak immune systems, the very young, or the elderly—may need hospitalization, longer therapy, or closer follow-up.

How you can help her right now  
1. Make sure she is being seen by a qualified clinician (doctor, nurse practitioner, or physician assistant). A chest X-ray and sometimes blood/sputum tests help confirm the diagnosis and choose the right drug.  
2. Encourage her to finish the entire course of any prescribed antibiotic even if she feels better in a few days.  
3. See that she rests, drinks plenty of fluids, eats nourishing food, and avoids alcohol and all tobacco smoke.  
4. Remind her to return promptly if she develops any warning signs: increasing shortness of breath, persistent fever, chest pain, confusion, or if her symptoms are not clearly improving after 48–72 hours on treatment.  
5. After she has recovered, talk with her clinician about preventing future episodes: annual flu shot, the pneumococcal vaccine series (recommended for many adults), and COVID-19 vaccination or boosters if due.  
6. If she has repeated bouts of “pneumonia,” she should be evaluated for conditions that make the lungs more vulnerable (asthma, COPD, immune-system problems, gastro-oesophageal reflux with aspiration, tuberculosis, etc.).

What you can do for yourself  
• Wash your hands frequently, avoid sharing eating utensils or drinks while she is still symptomatic, and stay up-to-date on your own flu, COVID-19 and pneumococcal vaccines.  
• Beyond common-sense hygiene there is no special precaution that should deter you from marrying her once she is well.

Bottom line  
Pneumonia is usually an acute, treatable infection. With proper medical care your friend should recover completely and will not remain contagious. Helping her obtain prompt treatment, complete the medicine as directed, and keep follow-up appointments is the best support you can offer—and it poses no long-term barrier to a healthy marriage.

Reliable information sources for further reading  
• CDC: “Pneumonia” – https://www.cdc.gov/pneumonia  
• MedlinePlus (U.S. National Library of Medicine): https://medlineplus.gov/pneumonia.html  
• American Lung Association: https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/pneumonia

(Information provided for general educational purposes; it is not a substitute for personal medical advice.)

<gold_response>
Pneumonia (Treatment): Treatment for pneumonia involves curing the infection and preventing complications. People who have community-acquired pneumonia usually can be treated at home with medication. Although most symptoms ease in a few days or weeks, the feeling of tiredness can persist for a month or more. Specific treatments depend on the type and severity of your pneumonia, your age and your overall health. The options include: - Antibiotics. These medicines are used to treat bacterial pneumonia. It may take time to identify the type of bacteria causing your pneumonia and to choose the best antibiotic to treat it. If your symptoms don't improve, your doctor may recommend a different antibiotic. - Cough medicine. This medicine may be used to calm your cough so that you can rest. Because coughing helps loosen and move fluid from your lungs, it's a good idea not to eliminate your cough completely. In addition, you should know that very few studies have looked at whether over-the-counter cough medicines lessen coughing caused by pneumonia. If you want to try a cough suppressant, use the lowest dose that helps you rest. - Fever reducers/pain relievers. You may take these as needed for fever and discomfort. These include drugs such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). Hospitalization You may need to be hospitalized if: - You are older than age 65 - You are confused about time, people or places - Your kidney function has declined - Your systolic blood pressure is below 90 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) or your diastolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg or below - Your breathing is rapid (30 breaths or more a minute) - You need breathing assistance - Your temperature is below normal - Your heart rate is below 50 or above 100 You may be admitted to the intensive care unit if you need to be placed on a breathing machine (ventilator) or if your symptoms are severe. Children may be hospitalized if: - They are younger than age 2 months - They are lethargic or excessively sleepy - They have trouble breathing - They have low blood oxygen levels - They appear dehydrated
</gold_response>
