This procedure involves using an endoscope—a small, flexible tube with a light—to see the upper GI tract, which includes the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum—the first part of the small intestine. The test is performed at a hospital or outpatient center by a gastroenterologist—a doctor who specializes in digestive diseases. The endoscope is carefully fed down the esophagus and into the stomach and duodenum. A small camera mounted on the endoscope transmits a video image to a monitor, allowing close examination of the intestinal lining. A person may receive a liquid anesthetic that is gargled or sprayed on the back of the throat. An intravenous (IV) needle is placed in a vein in the arm if general anesthesia is given. The test may show blockage or large bezoars—solid collections of food, mucus, vegetable fiber, hair, or other material that cannot be digested in the stomach—that are sometimes softened, dissolved, or broken up during an upper GI endoscopy. Upper GI series. An upper GI series may be done to look at the small intestine. The test is performed at a hospital or outpatient center by an x-ray technician, and the images are interpreted by a radiologist—a doctor who specializes in medical imaging. Anesthesia is not needed. No eating or drinking is allowed for 8 hours before the procedure, if possible. If the person has diabetes, a health care provider may give different instructions about fasting before the test. During the procedure, the person will stand or sit in front of an x-ray machine and drink barium, a chalky liquid. Barium coats the small intestine, making signs of gastroparesis show up more clearly on x rays. Gastroparesis is likely if the x ray shows food in the stomach after fasting. A person may experience bloating and nausea for a short time after the test. For several days afterward, barium liquid in the GI tract causes stools to be white or light colored. A health care provider will give the person specific instructions about eating and drinking after the test. Ultrasound. Ultrasound uses a device, called a transducer, that bounces safe, painless sound waves off organs to create an image of their structure. The procedure is performed in a health care provider’s office, outpatient center, or hospital by a specially trained technician, and the images are interpreted by a radiologist; anesthesia is not needed. The images can show whether gallbladder disease and pancreatitis could be the cause of a person’s digestive symptoms, rather than gastroparesis. Gastric emptying scintigraphy. The test involves eating a bland meal—such as eggs or an egg substitute—that contains a small amount of radioactive material. The test is performed in a radiology center or hospital by a specially trained technician and interpreted by a radiologist; anesthesia is not needed. An external camera scans the abdomen to show where the radioactive material is located. The radiologist is then able to measure the rate of gastric emptying at 1, 2, 3, and 4 hours after the meal. If more than 10 percent of the meal is still in the stomach at 4 hours, the diagnosis of gastroparesis is confirmed. SmartPill. The SmartPill is a small electronic device in capsule form. The SmartPill test is available at specialized outpatient centers. The images are interpreted by a radiologist. The device is swallowed and moves through the entire digestive tract, sending information to a cell-phone-sized receiver worn around the person’s waist or neck. The recorded information provides a detailed record of how quickly food travels through each part of the digestive tract. Gastric emptying breath test. With this test, the person eats a special test meal that includes a natural material with a special type of carbon in it. Then, breath samples are taken over a period of several hours to measure the amount of the material in the exhaled breath. The results allow the health care provider to calculate how fast the stomach is emptying. How is gastroparesis treated? Treatment of gastroparesis depends on the severity of the person’s symptoms. In most cases, treatment does not cure gastroparesis, which is usually a chronic, or long-lasting, condition. Gastroparesis is also a relapsing condition—the symptoms can come and go for periods of time. Treatment helps people manage the condition so they can be as comfortable and active as possible. Eating, Diet, and Nutrition Changing eating habits can sometimes help control the severity of gastroparesis symptoms. A health care provider may suggest eating six small meals a day instead of three large ones. If less food enters the stomach each time a person eats, the stomach may not become overly full, allowing it to empty more easily. Chewing food well, drinking noncarbonated liquids with a meal, and walking or sitting for 2 hours after a meal—instead of lying down—may assist with gastric emptying. A health care provider may also recommend avoiding high-fat and fibrous foods. Fat naturally slows digestion and some raw vegetables and fruits are more difficult to digest than other foods. Some foods, such as oranges and broccoli, contain fibrous parts that do not digest well. People with gastroparesis should minimize their intake of large portions of these foods because the undigested parts may remain in the stomach too long. Sometimes, the undigested parts form bezoars. When a person has severe symptoms, a liquid or puréed diet may be prescribed. As liquids tend to empty more quickly from the stomach, some people may find a puréed diet helps improve symptoms. Puréed fresh or cooked fruits and vegetables can be incorporated into shakes and soups. A health care provider may recommend a dietitian to help a person plan meals that minimize symptoms and ensure all nutritional needs are met. When the most extreme cases of gastroparesis lead to severe nausea, vomiting, and dehydration, urgent care may be required at a medical facility where IV fluids can be given. Medications Several prescription medications are available to treat gastroparesis. A combination of medications may be used to find the most effective treatment. Metoclopramide (Reglan). This medication stimulates stomach muscle contractions to help with gastric emptying. Metoclopramide also helps reduce nausea and vomiting. The medication is taken 20 to 30 minutes before meals and at bedtime. Possible side effects of metoclopramide include fatigue, sleepiness, and depression. Currently, this is the only medication approved by the FDA for treatment of gastroparesis. However, the FDA has placed a black box warning on this medication because of rare reports of it causing an irreversible neurologic side effect called tardive dyskinesia—a disorder that affects movement. Erythromycin. This antibiotic, prescribed at low doses, may improve gastric emptying. Like metaclopramide, erythromycin works by increasing the contractions that move food through the stomach. Possible side effects of erythromycin include nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. Other medications. Other medications may be used to treat symptoms and problems related to gastroparesis. For example, medications known as antiemetics are used to help control nausea and vomiting. Botulinum Toxin Botulinum toxin is a nerve blocking agent also known as Botox. After passing an endoscope into the stomach, a health care provider injects the Botox into the pylorus, the opening from the stomach into the duodenum. Botox is supposed to help keep the pylorus open for longer periods of time and improve symptoms of gastroparesis. Although some initial research trials showed modest improvement in gastroparesis symptoms and the rate of gastric emptying following the injections, other studies have failed to show the same degree of effectiveness of the Botox injections.1 Gastric Electrical Stimulation This treatment alternative may be effective for some people whose nausea and vomiting do not improve with dietary changes or medications. A gastric neurostimulator is a surgically implanted battery-operated device that sends mild electrical pulses to the stomach muscles to help control nausea and vomiting. The procedure may be performed at a hospital or outpatient center by a gastroenterologist. General anesthesia may be required. The gastroenterologist makes several tiny incisions in the abdomen and inserts a laparoscope—a thin tube with a tiny video camera attached. The camera sends a magnified image from inside the stomach to a video monitor, giving the gastroenterologist a close-up view of the tissues. Once implanted, the settings on the battery-operated device can be adjusted to determine the settings that best control symptoms. Jejunostomy If medications and dietary changes don’t work, and the person is losing weight or requires frequent hospitalization for dehydration, a health care provider may recommend surgically placing a feeding tube through the abdominal wall directly into a part of the small intestine called the jejunum. The surgical procedure is known as a jejunostomy. The procedure is performed by a surgeon at a hospital or outpatient center. Anesthesia is needed. The feeding tube bypasses the stomach and delivers a special liquid food with nutrients directly into the jejunum. The jejunostomy is used only when gastroparesis is extremely severe. Parenteral Nutrition When gastroparesis is so severe that dietary measures and other treatments are not helping, a health care provider may recommend parenteral nutrition—an IV liquid food mixture supplied through a special tube in the chest. The procedure is performed by a surgeon at a hospital or outpatient center; anesthesia is needed. The surgeon inserts a thin, flexible tube called a catheter into a chest vein, with the catheter opening outside the skin. A bag containing liquid nutrients is attached to the catheter, and the nutrients are transported through the catheter into the chest vein and into the bloodstream. This approach is a less preferable alternative to a jejunostomy and is usually a temporary treatment to get through a difficult period of gastroparesis. How is gastroparesis treated if a person has diabetes? An elevated blood glucose level directly interferes with normal stomach emptying, so good blood glucose control in people with diabetes is important. However, gastroparesis can make blood glucose control difficult. When food that has been delayed in the stomach finally enters the small intestine and is absorbed, blood glucose levels rise. Gastric emptying is unpredictable with gastroparesis, causing a person’s blood glucose levels to be erratic and difficult to control. The primary treatment goals for gastroparesis related to diabetes are to improve gastric emptying and regain control of blood glucose levels. In addition to the dietary changes and treatments already described, a health care provider will likely adjust the person’s insulin regimen. To better control blood glucose, people with diabetes and gastroparesis may need to take insulin more often or change the type of insulin they take take insulin after meals, instead of before check blood glucose levels frequently after eating and administer insulin when necessary A health care provider will give specific instructions for taking insulin based on the individual’s needs and the severity of gastroparesis. In some cases, the dietitian may suggest eating several liquid or puréed meals a day until gastroparesis symptoms improve and blood glucose levels are more stable. What are the problems of gastroparesis? The problems of gastroparesis can include severe dehydration due to persistent vomiting gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which is GER that occurs more than twice a week for a few weeks; GERD can lead to esophagitis— irritation of the esophagus bezoars, which can cause nausea, vomiting, obstruction, or interfere with absorption of some medications in pill form difficulty managing blood glucose levels in people with diabetes malnutrition due to poor absorption of nutrients or a low calorie intake decreased quality of life, including work absences due to severe symptoms Points to Remember Gastroparesis, also called delayed gastric emptying, is a disorder that slows or stops the movement of food from the stomach to the small intestine. Gastroparesis can occur when the vagus nerve is damaged by illness or injury and the stomach muscles stop working normally. Food then moves slowly from the stomach to the small intestine or stops moving altogether. Most people diagnosed with gastroparesis have idiopathic gastroparesis, which means a health care provider cannot identify the cause, even with medical tests. Diabetes is the most common known cause of gastroparesis. People with diabetes have high levels of blood glucose, also called blood sugar. Over time, high blood glucose levels can damage the vagus nerve. The most common symptoms of gastroparesis are nausea, a feeling of fullness after eating only a small amount of food, and vomiting undigested food— sometimes several hours after a meal. Other common symptoms include gastroesophageal reflux (GER), pain in the stomach area, abdominal bloating, and lack of appetite. Gastroparesis is diagnosed through a physical exam, medical history, blood tests, tests to rule out blockage or structural problems in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and gastric emptying tests. Changing eating habits can sometimes help control the severity of gastroparesis symptoms. A health care provider may suggest eating six small meals a day instead of three large ones. When a person has severe symptoms, a liquid or puréed diet may be prescribed. Treatment of gastroparesis may include medications, botulinum toxin, gastric electrical stimulation, jejunostomy, and parenteral nutrition. For people with gastroparesis and diabetes, a health care provider will likely adjust the person’s insulin regimen. References [1] Bai Y, Xu MJ, Yang X, et al. A systematic review on intrapyloric botulinum toxin injection for gastroparesis. Digestion. 2010;81(1):27–34. Clinical Trials The National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) and other components of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) conduct and support research into many diseases and conditions. What are clinical trials, and are they right for you? Clinical trials are part of clinical research and at the heart of all medical advances. Clinical trials look at new ways to prevent, detect, or treat disease. Researchers also use clinical trials to look at other aspects of care, such as improving the quality of life for people with chronic illnesses. Find out if clinical trials are right for you. What clinical trials are open? Clinical trials that are currently open and are recruiting can be viewed at www.ClinicalTrials.gov. I am not your personal physician, and this information can’t replace an in-person medical assessment.  That said, chest discomfort in anyone—especially at age 72—needs to be treated as a potential emergency, even if you have known esophageal or stomach problems.

Why you should seek immediate care
• Heart‐related causes (heart attack, angina, aortic dissection) can mimic or overlap with pain from gastritis or esophagitis.  
• Trouble talking can signal shortness of breath or poor oxygenation.  
• If a heart or major-vessel problem is present, every minute counts.

What to do right now
1. Call 911 (or your local emergency number) or have someone drive you to the nearest Emergency Department.  
2. Chew one full-strength aspirin (325 mg) if you are not allergic, have no history of serious stomach bleeding, and have not been told to avoid aspirin.  
3. Sit upright, loosen tight clothing, and stay as calm as possible while you wait for help.  
4. Do NOT try to drive yourself, and do NOT wait for another clinic appointment.

What the emergency team will do
• Check heart rhythm, blood pressure, and oxygen.  
• Perform an ECG, blood tests for heart damage, and possibly imaging studies.  
• Give pain or reflux medication if they determine it is gastrointestinal in origin, but only after ruling out life-threatening causes.

When things are stable
Ask your doctor about an ongoing plan for:
• Diverticulosis: adequate fiber and fluids, prompt attention to any abdominal pain or fever.  
• Gastritis/Esophagitis: acid-suppressing medicines, avoiding NSAIDs, caffeine, alcohol, smoking, late meals, and large/fatty meals.  
• Regular follow-up if you have reflux, because chronic inflammation can lead to complications.

Bottom line
Chest pain plus difficulty speaking or breathing at your age is an emergency until proven otherwise. Please call 911 or get to an Emergency Department immediately.

Below you’ll find reliable, plain-language information about glaucoma, plus ways to have free brochures mailed to you and where to find additional help.  Use this as a starting point and be sure to discuss all questions with your eye-care professional.

--------------------------------------------------
1. What glaucoma is
--------------------------------------------------
• Glaucoma is a group of eye diseases that damage the optic nerve, the cable that connects the eye to the brain.  
• Most forms are linked to a build-up of pressure inside the eye (intra­ocular pressure, IOP).  
• When the nerve is damaged, blind spots develop. Vision loss is usually gradual and painless, so many people do not notice symptoms until significant damage has occurred. Vision that is lost cannot be restored, but early treatment can slow or stop further loss.

--------------------------------------------------
2. Main types
--------------------------------------------------
• Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) – most common; drainage channels are open but work poorly.  
• Angle-closure glaucoma – the drainage angle suddenly or gradually closes; can cause a rapid pressure rise (“acute angle-closure”) that is an emergency.  
• Normal-tension glaucoma – optic-nerve damage occurs even though IOP is “normal.”  
• Secondary glaucomas – caused by another condition (eye injury, inflammation, steroid use, etc.).  
• Congenital / juvenile glaucomas – present at birth or in childhood.

--------------------------------------------------
3. Risk factors
--------------------------------------------------
• Age > 40, especially > 60  
• Family history of glaucoma  
• African, Hispanic/Latino, or Asian ancestry (varies with type)  
• Elevated IOP  
• Thin corneas  
• Myopia (nearsightedness) or hyperopia (farsightedness) depending on type  
• Diabetes, high blood pressure, migraine, sleep apnea  
• Long-term steroid use  
Regular comprehensive dilated eye exams are the best way to catch glaucoma early.

--------------------------------------------------
4. Symptoms to watch for
--------------------------------------------------
Most open-angle glaucoma has no obvious symptoms. Angle-closure attacks may cause severe eye pain, headache, halos around lights, nausea, or sudden blurred vision—seek emergency care. Report any changes in peripheral (side) vision to your doctor.

--------------------------------------------------
5. How glaucoma is diagnosed
--------------------------------------------------
• Tonometry – measures IOP  
• Ophthalmoscopy / optic-nerve imaging (OCT, photos)  
• Visual-field (perimetry) testing  
• Gonioscopy – examines the drainage angle  
• Pachymetry – measures corneal thickness

--------------------------------------------------
6. Treatment options
--------------------------------------------------
Treatment goal = lower eye pressure to a safer level.

A. Eye drops (first-line in most cases)  
   – Prostaglandin analogs, beta-blockers, alpha-agonists, carbonic-anhydrase inhibitors, rho-kinase inhibitors.  
   – Must be taken every day; missing doses lets pressure rise again.

B. Oral medicine  
   – Acetazolamide or methazolamide sometimes used short-term or when drops not enough.

C. Laser procedures  
   – SLT (selective laser trabeculoplasty) for open-angle glaucoma.  
   – Laser iridotomy for angle-closure risk or attack.  
   – Cyclophotocoagulation for advanced cases.

D. Surgery  
   – Trabeculectomy, glaucoma drainage devices (“tubes”), minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS), or combined cataract-glaucoma procedures.  
Your doctor chooses therapy based on type, severity, target pressure, overall health, and lifestyle.

--------------------------------------------------
7. Living with glaucoma
--------------------------------------------------
• Take drops exactly as prescribed; set phone alarms or use dosing aids.  
• Keep a list of all medications and bring to appointments.  
• Schedule eye exams as advised (often every 3–6 months).  
• Ask if you can monitor eye pressure at home.  
• Protect eyes from injury; wear sunglasses for glare/UV protection.  
• Manage general health: blood-pressure control, regular exercise, healthy diet rich in leafy greens, fish, and colorful fruits/vegetables.  
• Stop smoking; moderate caffeine; stay well hydrated.  
• Driving: have regular visual-field tests, avoid night driving if glare is a problem.  
• Emotional support: vision loss can cause anxiety; consider counseling, low-vision rehab, or support groups.

--------------------------------------------------
8. What to ask your doctor
--------------------------------------------------
• What type of glaucoma do I have?  
• What is my current eye pressure and my target pressure?  
• Which treatment do you recommend and why?  
• How will we monitor my optic nerve and visual field?  
• What side effects should I look for?  
• If treatment doesn’t reach the target, what is next?  
• Can

--------------------------------------------------
• Glaucoma is a group of eye diseases that damage the optic nerve, the cable that connects the eye to the brain.  
• Most forms are linked to a build-up of pressure inside the eye (intra­ocular pressure, IOP).  
• When the nerve is damaged, blind spots develop. Vision loss is usually gradual and painless, so many people do not notice symptoms until significant damage has occurred. Vision that is lost cannot be restored, but early treatment can slow or stop further loss.

--------------------------------------------------
2. Main types
--------------------------------------------------
• Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) – most common; drainage channels are open but work poorly.  
• Angle-closure glaucoma – the drainage angle suddenly or gradually closes; can cause a rapid pressure rise (“acute angle-closure”) that is an emergency.  
• Normal-tension glaucoma – optic-nerve damage occurs even though IOP is “normal.”  
• Secondary glaucomas – caused by another condition (eye injury, inflammation, steroid use, etc.).  
• Congenital / juvenile glaucomas – present at birth or in childhood.

--------------------------------------------------
3. Risk factors
--------------------------------------------------
• Age > 40, especially > 60  
• Family history of glaucoma  
• African, Hispanic/Latino, or Asian ancestry (varies with type)  
• Elevated IOP  
• Thin corneas  
• Myopia (nearsightedness) or hyperopia (farsightedness) depending on type  
• Diabetes, high blood pressure, migraine, sleep apnea  
• Long-term steroid use  
Regular comprehensive dilated eye exams are the best way to catch glaucoma early.

--------------------------------------------------
4. Symptoms to watch for
--------------------------------------------------
Most open-angle glaucoma has no obvious symptoms. Angle-closure attacks may cause severe eye pain, headache, halos around lights, nausea, or sudden blurred vision—seek emergency care. Report any changes in peripheral (side) vision to your doctor.

--------------------------------------------------
5. How glaucoma is diagnosed
--------------------------------------------------
• Tonometry – measures IOP  
• Ophthalmoscopy / optic-nerve imaging (OCT, photos)  
• Visual-field (perimetry) testing  
• Gonioscopy – examines the drainage angle  
• Pachymetry – measures corneal thickness

--------------------------------------------------
6. Treatment options
--------------------------------------------------
Treatment goal = lower eye pressure to a safer level.

A. Eye drops (first-line in most cases)  
   – Prostaglandin analogs, beta-blockers, alpha-agonists, carbonic-anhydrase inhibitors, rho-kinase inhibitors.  
   – Must be taken every day; missing doses lets pressure rise again.

B. Oral medicine  
   – Acetazolamide or methazolamide sometimes used short-term or when drops not enough.

C. Laser procedures  
   – SLT (selective laser trabeculoplasty) for open-angle glaucoma.  
   – Laser iridotomy for angle-closure risk or attack.  
   – Cyclophotocoagulation for advanced cases.

D. Surgery  
   – Trabeculectomy, glaucoma drainage devices (“tubes”), minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS), or combined cataract-glaucoma procedures.  
Your doctor chooses therapy based on type, severity, target pressure, overall health, and lifestyle.

--------------------------------------------------
7. Living with glaucoma
--------------------------------------------------
• Take drops exactly as prescribed; set phone alarms or use dosing aids.  
• Keep a list of all medications and bring to appointments.  
• Schedule eye exams as advised (often every 3–6 months).  
• Ask if you can monitor eye pressure at home.  
• Protect eyes from injury; wear sunglasses for glare/UV protection.  
• Manage general health: blood-pressure control, regular exercise, healthy diet rich in leafy greens, fish, and colorful fruits/vegetables.  
• Stop smoking; moderate caffeine; stay well hydrated.  
• Driving: have regular visual-field tests, avoid night driving if glare is a problem.  
• Emotional support: vision loss can cause anxiety; consider counseling, low-vision rehab, or support groups.

--------------------------------------------------
8. What to ask your doctor
--------------------------------------------------
• What type of glaucoma do I have?  
• What is my current eye pressure and my target pressure?  
• Which treatment do you recommend and why?  
• How will we monitor my optic nerve and visual field?  
• What side effects should I look for?  
• If treatment doesn’t reach the target, what is next?  
• Can

Glaucoma: Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that can damage the optic nerve. This nerve sends the images you see to your brain. Most often, optic nerve damage is caused by increased pressure in the eye. This is called intraocular pressure. Watch this video about: Glaucoma Glaucoma is the second most common cause of blindness in the United States. There are four major types of glaucoma: - Open-angle glaucoma - Angle-closure glaucoma, also called closed-angle glaucoma - Congenital glaucoma - Secondary glaucoma The front part of the eye is filled with a clear fluid called aqueous humor. This fluid is made in an area behind the colored part of the eye (iris). It leaves the eye through channels where the iris and cornea meet. This area is called the anterior chamber angle, or the angle. The cornea is the clear covering on the front of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and angle. Anything that slows or blocks the flow of this fluid will cause pressure to build up in the eye. - In open-angle glaucoma, the increase in pressure is often small and slow. - In closed-angle glaucoma, the increase is often high and sudden. - Either type can damage the optic nerve. Open-angle glaucoma is the most common type of glaucoma. - The cause is unknown. The increase in eye pressure happens slowly over time. You cannot feel it. - The increased pressure pushes on the optic nerve. Damage to the optic nerve causes blind spots in your vision. - Open-angle glaucoma tends to run in families. Your risk is higher if you have a parent or grandparent with open-angle glaucoma. People of African descent are also at higher risk for this disease. Closed-angle glaucoma occurs when the fluid is suddenly blocked and cannot flow out of the eye. This causes a quick, severe rise in eye pressure. - Dilating eye drops and certain medicines may trigger an acute glaucoma attack. - Closed-angle glaucoma is an emergency. - If you have had acute glaucoma in one eye, you are at risk for it in the second eye. Your health care provider is likely to treat your second eye to prevent a first attack in that eye. Secondary glaucoma occurs due to a known cause. Both open- and closed-angle glaucoma can be secondary when caused by something known. Causes include: - Drugs such as corticosteroids - Eye diseases such as uveitis (an infection of the middle layer of the eye) - Diseases such as diabetes - Eye injury Congenital glaucoma occurs in babies. - It often runs in families. - It is present at birth. - It is caused when the eye does not develop normally. OPEN-ANGLE GLAUCOMA - Most people have no symptoms. - Once vision loss occurs, the damage is already severe. - Slow loss of side (peripheral) vision (also called tunnel vision). - Advanced glaucoma can lead to blindness. ANGLE-CLOSURE GLAUCOMA Symptoms may come and go at first, or steadily become worse. You may notice: - Sudden, severe pain in one eye - Decreased or cloudy vision, often called "steamy" vision - Nausea and vomiting - Rainbow-like halos around lights - Red eye - Eye feels swollen CONGENITAL GLAUCOMA Symptoms are most often noticed when the child is a few months old. - Cloudiness of the front of the eye - Enlargement of one eye or both eyes - Red eye - Sensitivity to light - Tearing SECONDARY GLAUCOMA - Symptoms are most often related to the underlying problem causing the glaucoma. - Depending on the cause, symptoms may either be like open-angle glaucoma or angle-closure glaucoma. The only way to diagnose glaucoma is by having a complete eye exam. - You will be given a test to check your eye pressure. This is called tonometry. - In most cases, you will be given eye drops to widen (dilate) your pupil. - When your pupil is dilated, your eye doctor will look at the inside of your eye and the optic nerve. Eye pressure is different at different times of the day. Eye pressure can even be normal in some people with glaucoma. So you will need other tests to confirm glaucoma. They may include: - Using a special lens to look at the angle of the eye (gonioscopy). - Photographs or laser scanning images of the inside of your eye (optic nerve imaging). - Checking your retina. The retina is the light-sensitive tissue at the back of your eye. - Checking how your pupil responds to light (pupillary reflex response). - 3-D view of your eye (slit lamp examination). - Testing the clearness of your vision (visual acuity). - Testing your field of vision (visual field measurement). The goal of treatment is to reduce your eye pressure. Treatment depends on the type of glaucoma that you have. OPEN-ANGLE GLAUCOMA - If you have open-angle glaucoma, you will probably be given eye drops. - You may need more than one type. Most people can be treated with eye drops. - Most of the eye drops used today have fewer side effects than those used in the past. - You also may be given pills to lower pressure in the eye. If drops alone do not work, you may need other treatment: - Laser treatment uses a painless laser to open the channels where fluid flows out. - If drops and laser treatment do not work, you may need surgery. The doctor will open a new channel so fluid can escape. This will help lower your pressure. - Recently, new implants have been developed that can help treat glaucoma in people having cataract surgery. ACUTE ANGLE GLAUCOMA An acute angle-closure attack is a medical emergency. You can become blind in a few days if you are not treated. - You may be given drops, pills, and medicine given through a vein (by IV) to lower your eye pressure. - Some people also need an emergency operation, called an iridotomy. The doctor uses a laser to open a new channel in the iris. Sometimes this is done with surgery. The new channel relieves the attack and will prevent another attack. - To help prevent an attack in the other eye, the procedure will often be performed on the other eye. This may be done even if it has never had an attack. CONGENITAL GLAUCOMA - Congenital glaucoma is almost always treated with surgery. - This is done using general anesthesia. This means the child is asleep and feels no pain. SECONDARY GLAUCOMA If you have secondary glaucoma, treating the cause may help your symptoms go away. Other treatments also may be needed. Open-angle glaucoma cannot be cured. You can manage it and keep your sight by following your provider's directions. Closed-angle glaucoma is a medical emergency. You need treatment right away to save your vision. Babies with congenital glaucoma usually do well when surgery is done early. How you do with secondary glaucoma depends on what is causing the condition. If you have severe eye pain or a sudden loss of vision, get immediate medical help. These may be signs of closed-angle glaucoma. You cannot prevent open-angle glaucoma. Most people have no symptoms. But you can help prevent vision loss. - A complete eye exam can help find open-angle glaucoma early, when it is easier to treat. - All adults should have a complete eye exam by the age of 40. - If you are at risk for glaucoma, you should have a complete eye exam sooner than age 40. - You should have regular eye exams as recommended by your provider. If you are at risk for closed-angle glaucoma, your provider may recommend treatment before you have an attack to help prevent eye damage and vision loss. Updated by: Franklin W. Below is unbiased, evidence-based information you can use as a starting point.  It is not a substitute for an in-person examination or professional medical advice, so please share any plans with a qualified clinician (usually a dermatologist or your primary care provider).

1. Identify the cause first  
   • The commonest cause of gradual balding in men is androgenetic alopecia (“male-pattern hair loss”).  
   • Other possibilities include thyroid disease, iron or vitamin-D deficiency, recent high fever or surgery (telogen effluvium), autoimmune alopecia areata, fungal scalp infection, medication side-effects, and excessive styling or chemical damage.  
   • A doctor can usually distinguish these by history, scalp exam and, if needed, simple blood tests or a scalp biopsy.

2. FDA-approved medical treatments for male-pattern baldness  
   (Work best when started early, before many follicles are permanently lost; neither is a “cure.”)  
   a) Minoxidil (topical)  
      • 5 % foam or solution, applied to the thinning areas once or twice daily.  
      • Can slow shedding and stimulate thicker regrowth in 30-60 % of users.  
      • First results take 3–6 months; must be continued indefinitely or the new hair is lost.  
      • Side-effects: scalp irritation, itching/flaking, unwanted facial hair if it drips, rarely fast heartbeat or dizziness.  
   b) Finasteride (oral, prescription only)  
      • 1 mg tablet daily blocks conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) in the scalp.  
      • About 80 % of men halt further loss and 60-70 % see some regrowth over 6–12 months.  
      • Side-effects (uncommon but well publicized): reduced libido, erectile difficulty, mood changes; usually reversible after stopping.  
      • Contraindicated in women of child-bearing age and in men trying to conceive (can affect semen DHT levels).

3. Other options that may help (less robust evidence)  
   • Low-level laser or LED light devices (combs, helmets) used 10–20 min, 3–4×/week.  
   • Microneedling rollers combined with minoxidil (small studies only).  
   • Oral dutasteride (stronger DHT blocker; used off-label).  
   • Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) scalp injections every 4–6 weeks for 3–4 sessions, then maintenance.  
   • Nutritional supplements if a specific deficiency is proven (iron, vitamin D, zinc, biotin in true biotinidase deficiency—rare). “Hair vitamins” have little evidence in otherwise well-nourished adults.  
   • Anti-inflammatory or immune-modulating injections (steroids, JAK inhibitors) for alopecia areata—this is a different disease pattern (round bare patches).

4. Surgical / procedural solutions  
   • Follicular-unit hair transplantation: modern techniques move small grafts from the back of the scalp to the front with natural appearance; cost and surgeon skill vary widely.  
   • Scalp micropigmentation (tattoo-like shading) or high-quality hair systems (bonded “pieces”) for cosmetic coverage.

5. Everyday scalp & hair care tips  
   • Use a gentle shampoo 2–3×/week; avoid daily very-hot blow-drying.  
   • Limit harsh dyes, perms, tight braids/pony-tails.  
   • Eat a balanced diet rich in protein, fruit, vegetables, healthy fats; stop smoking; manage stress (both nicotine and cortisol accelerate follicle miniaturization).  
   • Protect scalp from sunburn — hats or SPF sprays.

6. When to see a professional promptly  
   • Sudden patchy loss, bald spots with redness or scaling, pus, pain, eyebrow/eyelash loss, or hair falling out in clumps.  
   • If you try minoxidil or finasteride but notice troubling side-effects.  
   • If you have signs of hormonal or thyroid imbalance (weight change, heat/cold intolerance, acne, breast tenderness).

Key take-aways  
• Start with a medical evaluation so you treat the correct problem.  
• For typical male-pattern loss, minoxidil and/or finasteride remain the best-studied, cost-effective first steps.  
• Consistency and realistic expectations are essential: think in months, not weeks, and maintenance is lifelong.  
• Combine medical therapy with healthy lifestyle and, if desired, cosmetic or surgical methods for optimal coverage.

Good luck—and remember, even Dr. Evil ended up with a Mini-Me!

<gold_response>
Hair loss (Treatment): Effective treatments for some types of hair loss are available. But some hair loss is permanent. With some conditions, such as patchy alopecia, hair may regrow without treatment within a year. Treatments for hair loss include medications, surgery, laser therapy, and wigs or hairpieces. Your doctor may suggest a combination of these approaches in order to get the best results. The goals of treatment are to promote hair growth, slow hair loss or hide hair loss. Medication If your hair loss is caused by an underlying disease, treatment for that disease will be necessary. This may include drugs to reduce inflammation and suppress your immune system, such as prednisone. If a certain medication is causing the hair loss, your doctor may advise you to stop using it for at least three months. Medications are available to treat pattern baldness. Two medications approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat hair loss are: - Minoxidil (Rogaine). Minoxidil is an over-the-counter liquid or foam that you rub into your scalp twice a day to grow hair and to prevent further hair loss. It may be used by men and women. With this treatment, some people experience hair regrowth, a slower rate of hair loss or both. The effect peaks at 16 weeks and you need to keep applying the medication to retain benefits. Possible side effects include scalp irritation, unwanted hair growth on the adjacent skin of the face and hands, and rapid heart rate (tachycardia). - Finasteride (Propecia). This prescription drug is available only to men. It's taken daily in pill form. Many men taking finasteride experience a slowing of hair loss, and some may show some new hair growth. You need to keep taking it to retain benefits. Rare side effects of finasteride include diminished sex drive and sexual function and an increased risk of prostate cancer. Women who are or may be pregnant need to avoid touching crushed or broken tablets. Surgery In the most common type of permanent hair loss, only the top of the head is affected. Hair transplant or restoration surgery can make the most of the hair you have left. During this procedure, your surgeon removes tiny plugs of skin, each containing a few hairs, from the back or sides of your scalp. He or she then implants the plugs into the bald sections of your scalp. You may be asked to take a hair loss medication before and after surgery to improve results. Surgical procedures to treat baldness are expensive and can be painful. Possible risks include infection and scarring. Wigs and hairpieces You may want to try a wig or a hairpiece as an alternative to medical treatment or if you don't respond to treatment. It can be used to cover either permanent or temporary hair loss. Quality, natural-looking wigs and hairpieces are available. If your hair loss is due to a medical condition, the cost of a wig may be covered by insurance. You'll need a prescription for the wig from your doctor.
</gold_response>

  – The size and pattern of the curve  
  – Whether the curve is getting worse (progression)  
  – Any symptoms such as pain, breathing problems, or visible deformity

2. First step: a formal evaluation  
• Make an appointment with an orthopedic spine surgeon or a physiatrist (rehabilitation physician) who has experience in scoliosis.  
• Bring your previous X-rays and any reports. Re-examination may include:  
  – Physical examination (spinal alignment, flexibility, neurologic status)  
  – Full-length standing X-ray to measure the current Cobb angle  
  – Occasionally MRI if there are pain, neurologic findings, or atypical curve patterns

3. Typical treatment pathways  
A. Observation (“watchful waiting”)  
   • Often chosen for mild curves (<20–25°) or if you are almost finished growing.  
   • Follow-up X-rays every 6–12 months to check that the curve is not worsening.

B. Specific exercise–based therapy  
   • Scoliosis-specific physiotherapy (Schroth method, SEAS, or BSPTS programs) targets core strength, postural muscle balance, and breathing mechanics.  
   • Evidence suggests it can slow mild curve progression and improve posture/comfort.  
   • Exercises from the internet/Youtube can be misleading—best learned from a trained therapist.

C. Bracing  
   • Used mainly in growing adolescents with curves roughly 25–40°.  
   • Must be worn the prescribed number of hours/day (often 16–23) to be effective.  
   • Types: TLSO (Boston), Chêneau-style, night-time bending brace, etc.  
   • Goal is to prevent the curve from getting worse so that surgery is not required.

D. Surgery  
   • Considered when the curve is usually ≥45–50°, is progressing, or causes functional/ cosmetic or cardiopulmonary issues.  
   • Standard operation: posterior spinal fusion with metal rods and screws.  
   • Newer growth-friendly options (vertebral body tethering, growing rods) may be used in some younger patients.  
   • Discuss benefits (curve correction, preventing progression) and risks (infection, hardware problems, stiffness) with a spine surgeon who performs these procedures regularly.

4. Self-care and lifestyle tips  
• Maintain a healthy body weight; excess weight increases spinal load.  
• General aerobic activity (walking, swimming, cycling) keeps back muscles healthy.  
• Core-strengthening and postural exercises (under professional guidance) can reduce muscle fatigue and pain.  
• Avoid heavy unilateral carrying (e.g., a heavy bag on one shoulder). Use a backpack or distribute weight evenly.  
• Address pain early: heat/ice, over-the-counter analgesics (paracetamol, NSAIDs if tolerated), and physical therapy often help. Chronic pain that does not improve warrants medical review.

5. About sending your X-ray  
• Online images alone are not enough to make safe treatment decisions. A specialist needs to correlate the films with a physical examination and your medical history.  
• If tele-consultation is available in your region, many spine clinics can review digital X-rays securely and then decide whether you need an in-person visit.

6. When to seek prompt medical care  
• Rapidly increasing back pain, numbness/weakness in the legs, bowel/bladder changes, or shortness of breath all require immediate medical attention.

Key take-away  
The right treatment depends on your curve size, growth stage, and symptoms. Begin with an evaluation by an orthopedic spine specialist who will review your X-rays, examine you, and outline the options (observation, targeted exercises, bracing, or surgery). Early and individualized management offers the best chance of preventing progression and maintaining function.

Good luck, and don’t hesitate to schedule that specialist appointment soon.

Scoliosis (Treatment): Treatment depends on many things: - The cause of scoliosis - Where the curve is in your spine - How big the curve is - If your body is still growing Most people with idiopathic scoliosis do not need treatment. But you should still be checked by a doctor about every 6 months. If you are still growing, your doctor might recommend a back brace. A back brace prevents further curving. There are many different types of braces. What kind you get depends on the size and location of your curve. Your provider will pick the best one for you and show you how to use it. Back braces can be adjusted as you grow. Back braces work best in people over age 10. Braces do not work for those with congenital or neuromuscular scoliosis. You may need surgery if the spine curve is severe or getting worse very quickly. Surgery involves correcting the curve as much as possible: - Surgery is done with a cut through the back, belly area, or beneath the ribs. - The spine bones are held in place with 1 or 2 metal rods. The rods are held down with hooks and screws until the bone heals together. - After surgery, you may need to wear a brace for a while to keep the spine still. Scoliosis treatment may also include: - Emotional support: Some children, especially teens, may be self-conscious when using a back brace. - Physical therapy and other specialists to help explain the treatments and make sure the brace fits correctly.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m glad you reached out—obesity is common, complex, and very treatable. Most people do best with a structured, multi-pronged plan and the guidance of trained professionals. Below is an overview of the options and resources that typically help adults succeed in losing weight and keeping it off.

1. Start with a medical evaluation  
• Ask your primary-care clinician for a complete physical, including blood pressure, cholesterol, blood sugar/A1c, liver function, thyroid, and screening for sleep apnea.  
• Review all medications—some cause weight gain and can often be substituted.  
• Discuss any joint limitations, cardiac issues, or other concerns so your exercise plan is safe.

2. Set realistic goals  
• Small, steady losses (5-10 % of starting weight over 3–6 months) improve blood pressure, blood sugar, and arthritis pain.  
• Focus on behavior goals (e.g., “walk 30 min five days a week”) rather than just the scale.

3. Nutrition strategies that work  
• Calorie deficit: Most adults lose 1 lb/week by trimming 500 kcal/day. Online calculators (CDC Body Weight Planner) can individualize targets.  
• Emphasize vegetables, fruits, lean protein, beans, whole grains, and healthy fats (nuts, olive oil); limit sugary drinks, refined carbs, fried foods, alcohol.  
• Plate method: ½ plate non-starchy vegetables, ¼ lean protein, ¼ whole grain or starchy veg.  
• Meal planning, grocery lists, and pre-portioning snacks reduce impulse eating.  
Professional help: A registered dietitian (RD/RDN) can tailor a plan to your preferences, culture, budget, and any medical conditions. Most insurance (and Medicare for diabetes/kidney disease) now covers visits.

4. Physical activity  
• Goal: ≥150 min/week of moderate aerobic activity (brisk walking, cycling, swimming) plus 2 strength-training sessions to preserve muscle.  
• If you’re sedentary, start with 5–10 min increments and gradually add time or intensity.  
• Everyday movement counts: take stairs, park farther away, stand/walk during phone calls.  
• Consider a referral to physical therapy or a specialized exercise physiologist if you have joint pain or mobility limits.

5. Behavior and mental-health tools  
• Self-monitor: food/activity logs or apps (MyFitnessPal, Lose It!) and weekly weigh-ins.  
• Identify triggers for overeating (stress, boredom, social situations). Use coping skills such as walking, calling a friend, or brief meditation instead of food.  
• Adequate sleep (7–9 hr) and stress management (deep breathing, yoga, CBT techniques) help regulate hunger hormones.  
• Individual or group counseling, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), or programs like Overeaters Anonymous and TOPS offer accountability and emotional support.

6. FDA-approved weight-loss medications (for BMI ≥ 30, or ≥ 27 with a weight-related condition)  
• Orlistat (Alli, Xenical), phentermine/topiramate (Qsymia), bupropion/naltrexone (Contrave), liraglutide (Saxenda), semaglutide (Wegovy).  
• Average additional loss: 5–15 % of body weight when combined with lifestyle changes.  
• Side-effects and contraindications vary—must be prescribed and monitored by a clinician experienced in obesity medicine.

7. Metabolic/Bariatric surgery (for BMI ≥ 40, or ≥ 35 with diabetes, hypertension, sleep apnea, etc.)  
• Options: sleeve gastrectomy, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, adjustable gastric band, biliopancreatic diversion/duodenal switch.  
• Typical loss: 25–35 % of total body weight long term; often puts diabetes and hypertension into remission.  
• Requires lifelong follow-up, vitamin supplementation, and adherence to nutritional guidelines.  
• Most insurers (including Medicare/Medicaid) cover surgery when criteria are met.

8. Evidence-based weight-management programs  
• In-person: Weight Watchers, Jenny Craig, hospital-based programs, YMCA Diabetes Prevention Program.  
• Digital/telehealth: Noom, Omada, Mayo Clinic Diet, Virta (for diabetes).  
Look for components such as regular weigh-ins, calorie/food tracking, behavior counseling, and at least 6 months of active support.

9. Community and online resources  
• NIH: “Aim for a Healthy Weight” (nhlbi.nih.gov)  
• Obesity Action Coalition (obesityaction.org) for education and local support groups.  
• Academy of Nutrition & Dietetics (eatright.org) to find an RDN by ZIP code.  
• Physical Activity Guidelines (health.gov/moveyourway) for age-appropriate exercise ideas.

10. Insurance coverage & practical tips  
•

<gold_response>
Overweight and Obesity (Treatment): Treatment for overweight and obesity depends on the cause and severity of your condition. Possible treatments include healthy lifestyle changes, behavioral weight-loss treatment programs, medicines, and possibly surgery. You may need treatments for any complications that you have. Healthy lifestyle changes To help you aim for and maintain a healthy weight, your doctor may recommend that you adopt lifelong healthy lifestyle changes. Heart-healthy eating. Learn about which foods and nutrients are part of a healthy eating pattern. It’s important to eat the right amount of calories to maintain a healthy weight. If you need to lose weight, try to reduce your total daily calories gradually. Use the Body Weight Planner to find out your daily calorie needs and to set goals. Visit healthy recipes and plan for success. Talk with your doctor before beginning any diet or eating plan. Visit Chose My Plate or 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans for more information. Physical activity. Many health benefits are associated with physical activity and getting the recommended amount of physical activity needed each week. Physical activity is an important factor in determining whether a person can maintain a healthy body weight, lose excess body weight, or maintain successful weight loss. Before starting any exercise program, ask your doctor about what level of physical activity is right for you. Visit Physical Activity Has Many Health Benefits for more information. Healthy Sleep. Studies have shown some relationship between lack of sleep and obesity. Read Sleep Deprivation and Deficiency more information. Making lifelong healthy lifestyle changes, such as heart-healthy eating and physical activity, can help you modify your energy balance to help you aim for and maintain a healthy weight. For example: To aim for a healthy weight, or lose weight, you want your energy OUT to be more than your energy IN. To maintain weight loss you want your energy IN and energy OUT to be the same.  Behavioral weight-loss programs Your doctor may recommend you enroll in individual or group behavioral weight-loss programs to treat your overweight and obesity. In these programs, a trained healthcare professional will customize a weight-loss plan for you. This plan will include a moderately-reduced calorie diet, physical activity goals, and behavioral strategies to help you make and maintain these lifestyle changes. Read Living With for more information about required follow-up for these behavioral treatment programs. Read more Did you know your brain’s pleasure and reward centers can be stimulated by food and the act of eating, making it harder to change eating patterns and lose weight? Researchers know that our brains can become patterned so that we feel pleasure or reward from eating. This can make us unconsciously crave food so our bodies feel that sense of pleasure. It can also make it hard to change our eating patterns, lose weight, or maintain a healthy weight. Researchers are studying whether cognitive behavioral therapies can be an effective treatment for overweight and obesity by retraining the brain to not associate pleasure with food and the act of eating. Medicines When healthy lifestyle changes are not enough, your doctor may treat your overweight and obesity with FDA-approved medicines. These medicines work in the following parts of your body. Brain. Several medicines change the way the brain regulates the urge to eat, which can help to decrease appetite. Some examples of these medicines are diethylpropion, phendimetrazine, lorcaserin, naltrexone/bupropion, and liraglutide. Gastrointestinal tract. Orlistat is the only available medicine. It blocks your intestines from absorbing fat from foods in your diet. Weight loss medicines are not recommended as a single treatment for weight loss. These medicines can help you lose weight but when combined with lifestyle changes may result in greater weight loss. Some of these medicines should not be used if you have certain conditions or are taking certain medicines. Also, these medicines have side effects. Talk to your doctor if you are pregnant, planning to get pregnant, breast feeding, or have a family history of cardiovascular diseases such as high blood pressure, heart attack, or stroke. Surgical procedures Some patients with obesity do not respond to healthy lifestyle changes and medicines. When these patients develop certain obesity-related complications, they may be eligible for the following surgeries. Gastric bypass surgery. A small part of the stomach is connected to the middle part of the intestine, bypassing the first part of intestine. This decreases the amount of food that you can eat and the amount of fat your body can take in and store. Gastrectomy. A big portion of the stomach is removed to decrease the amount of food that you can eat. Gastric banding. A hollow band is placed around the upper part of the stomach creating a smaller stomach. This decreases the amount of food you can eat. Talk to your doctor to learn more about the benefits and risks of each type of surgery. Possible complications include bleeding, infection, internal rupture of sutures, or even death. Read gastric bypass surgery for more information. Read more Interested in learning why these surgeries lead to weight loss in some patients? First, these surgeries reduce the amount of food stored in the stomach and the amount of calories your body can take in. This can help your body restore energy balance. Second, these surgeries change the levels of certain hormones and the way the brain responds to these hormones to control hunger urges. After surgery, some people are less interested in eating or they prefer to eat healthier foods. In some cases, genetic differences may affect how much weight loss patients experience after bariatric surgery. Look for Living With will explain recommendations that your doctor may give, including lifelong healthy lifestyle changes and medical care to prevent your condition from recurring, getting worse, or causing complications. Research for Your Health will explain how we are using current research and advancing research to treat people with overweight and obesity. Participate in NHLBI Clinical Trials will discuss our ongoing clinical studies that are investigating treatments for overweight and obesity.
</gold_response>

----------------------------------------------------------------
1. Goals of HIV treatment (ART = antiretroviral therapy)
----------------------------------------------------------------
• Suppress the virus to “undetectable” levels (�� 200 copies/mL).  
  – Undetectable = Untransmittable (U = U): when viral load is durably undetectable there is effectively no sexual transmission.  
• Restore/maintain immune function (CD4 count).  
• Prevent HIV-related illness and death.  
• Improve overall quality of life.

----------------------------------------------------------------
2. Current first-line ART options (U.S. DHHS Guidelines, 2023)
----------------------------------------------------------------
Most start with one pill taken once daily that contains:
• 1 “backbone” integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI) such as bictegravir, dolutegravir, or cabotegravir* plus  
• 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) such as tenofovir alafenamide or disoproxil + emtricitabine (or lamivudine).

*Long-acting injectable cabotegravir/rilpivirine every 1–2 months may be an option after suppression on oral ART.

• Start ART as soon as possible after diagnosis—ideally the same day.  
• 95 %+ adherence is still the gold standard; missed doses allow viral rebound and resistance.  
• Routine labs: viral load & CD4 (every 3–6 mo), chemistries, lipids, renal function; watch for drug–drug interactions.

----------------------------------------------------------------

----------------------------------------------------------------
A. Gender-affirming hormone therapy (GAHT)  
• Estrogens can modestly lower levels of some NNRTIs and PIs via CYP3A4 induction, but clinically significant problems are uncommon with modern INSTI-based regimens.  
• No evidence that GAHT stops ART from working, or vice-versa.  
• Approach: do NOT cut back on hormones to “protect” the HIV meds; instead pick an ART regimen with minimal interactions, monitor estradiol levels if possible, and adjust hormone dose by clinical goals, not by fear of interactions.

• If using injectable estrogens or silicone, emphasize sterile needles/syringes, single-use vials, and safe injection sites to lower bacterial infection and hepatitis risk.

• Trans women have disproportionate rates of depression, PTSD, substance use and violence exposure—all associated with reduced ART adherence.  
• Trauma-informed, gender-affirming care settings improve retention in HIV care and viral suppression.

• Pap tests (for neovagina or cervix if present), mammography per guidelines once on estrogen >5 years, bone density if on tenofovir DF or if risk factors.

predicted_text:
Endometriosis is different for every woman, so its impact ranges from barely noticeable to life-altering:

1. Little or no trouble  
   • Some women have small spots of endometriosis and feel only mild cramps during their periods—if anything at all.

2. Moderate, recurring problems  
   • Many experience heavy or irregular periods, pelvic pain that flares before or during menstruation, pain with sex, and bowel or bladder discomfort.  
   • Symptoms can take days to settle and may interfere with school, work, exercise, or intimacy.

3. Severe, chronic disease  
   • Pain can become daily, not just monthly, and may spread to the lower back, legs, or nerves.  
   • Large ovarian cysts (“chocolate cysts”), extensive scar tissue, or organs stuck together (adhesions) can develop, sometimes distorting the pelvis.  
   • Fertility may be reduced; about 30-40 % of women who struggle to conceive have endometriosis as an underlying factor.  
   • Deep lesions can involve the bowel, bladder, ureters, diaphragm, or, rarely, the lungs, causing painful bowel movements, blood in the urine, intestinal blockage, or chest pain with breathing.  
   • Repeated surgeries, lost workdays, fatigue, and chronic pain can lead to anxiety, depression, and significant loss of quality of life.

4. Very rare complications  
   • Severe bowel or urinary obstruction requiring emergency surgery.  
   • Scar-related nerve damage or bleeding into the abdomen.  
   • Malignant transformation of endometriosis into cancer occurs, but it is uncommon (<1 % of cases).

The good news: Even in advanced cases, treatments—hormonal medication, pain-relief strategies, laparoscopy to remove disease, fertility therapies, and lifestyle support—can greatly lessen symptoms and improve fertility and quality of life.

If you suspect your endometriosis is worsening (increasing pain, bowel or bladder changes, trouble getting pregnant), see a gynecologist with experience in the disease; early, tailored management can keep it from getting “that bad.”

predicted_text:
Knock-knees (medical term: genu valgum) means the knees angle inward so that, when you stand with your knees touching, the ankles stay apart.  In toddlers this is usually normal and straightens on its own, but by about age 10–11 the final adult alignment is fixed.  At 23 your bones have finished growing, so “remolding” with braces or special shoes is no longer effective.  Management depends on three things:

1.  How large the angle is (mild, moderate, severe)  
2.  Whether it is causing symptoms (knee or ankle pain, difficulty running, frequent falls, early arthritis)  
3.  Whether there is an underlying medical problem (old rickets, previous fracture, obesity, ligament laxity, etc.)  

Step-by-step approach

1.  Orthopaedic assessment  
   • Make an appointment with an orthopaedic surgeon who treats lower-limb deformities.  
   • Expect a physical exam, measurement of the intermalleolar distance (gap between the ankles while knees touch) and standing, full-length, weight-bearing X-rays or a “scanogram” to see where the angulation is coming from (femur, tibia, or both).  
   • The doctor will also check vitamin-D/calcium levels and look for signs of metabolic bone disease if the cause is unclear.

2.  Non-surgical measures (help symptoms but do NOT change bone alignment)  
   • Weight control – extra weight increases the inward angle and joint stress.  
   • Physiotherapy: strengthen hip abductors, quadriceps, and core muscles; stretch tight iliotibial band, hamstrings, and calves.  Exercises often used:
       – Side-lying leg raises  
       – Clamshells with resistance band  
       – Monster/lateral walks with miniband  
       – Wall sits or body-weight squats with knees aligned over second toe  
       – Bridges and lunges  
   • Shock-absorbing shoes or lateral-wedge insoles may reduce knee pain in mild cases.  
   • Pain control: short courses of NSAIDs if needed, ice after activity.

   Remember: these steps can improve strength, posture, and discomfort, but they will NOT straighten the bones.

3.  Surgical correction (the only way to actually realign bones in an adult)  
   Considered when the deformity is:
      – cosmetically unacceptable to the patient  
      – causing pain, gait problems, or early joint damage  
      – >10–12° valgus or intermalleolar gap >10 cm in a mature skeleton  

   Options your surgeon may discuss:  
      a. Distal femoral osteotomy (most common) – the femur above the knee is cut and realigned with a plate and screws; bone heals in the corrected position.  
      b. Tibial osteotomy – used if the tibia is the main source of the angle.  
      c. Gradual correction with an external fixator (Ilizarov or hexapod frame) – useful for very large or complex deformities.  

   Hospital stay is usually 2–4 days; partial weight bearing with crutches for 6–8 weeks; return to most activities in 3–6 months; full bone healing can take 6–12 months.  Success rates are high, but risks (infection, non-union, nerve/artery injury, deep-vein thrombosis) need to be weighed against expected benefit.

4.  Lifestyle & bone health  
   • Ensure adequate calcium (1000 mg/day) and vitamin D (600–1000 IU/day, or as advised).  
   • Avoid smoking and excess alcohol—both delay bone healing if you choose surgery.  
   • Keep up lifelong quadriceps and hip-strengthening exercises to protect the joint cartilage.

Bottom line

Because you are already an adult, only surgery can truly “straighten” knock knees; exercises and weight management can ease symptoms and slow joint wear.  Start by seeing an orthopaedic surgeon for precise measurement and discussion of whether corrective osteotomy is appropriate for you.  A physiotherapist can help you begin a strengthening and stretching program right away while you make this decision.

Knock knees: Knock knees are condition in which the knees touch, but the ankles do not touch. The legs turn inward. Infants start out with bowlegs because of their folded position while in their mother's womb. The legs begin to straighten once the child starts to walk (at about 12 to 18 months). By age 3, the child becomes knock-kneed. When the child stands, the knees touch but the ankles are apart. By puberty, the legs straighten out and most children can stand with the knees and ankles touching (without forcing the position). Knock knees can also develop as a result of a medical problem or disease, such as: - Injury of the shinbone (only one leg will be knock-kneed) - Osteomyelitis (bone infection) - Overweight or obesity - Rickets (a disease caused by a lack of vitamin D) A health care provider will examine your child. Tests will be done if there are signs that knock knees are not a part of normal development. Knock knees are not treated in most cases. If the problem continues after age 7, the child may use a night brace. This brace is attached to a shoe. Surgery may be considered for knock knees that are severe and continue beyond late childhood. Children normally outgrow knock knees without treatment, unless it is caused by a disease. If surgery is needed, the results are most often good. Complications may include: - Difficulty walking (very rare) - Self-esteem changes related to cosmetic appearance of knock knees - If left untreated, knock knees can lead to early arthritis of the knee Call your provider if you think your child has knock knees. There is no known prevention for normal knock knees. Updated by: Neil K. Kaneshiro, MD, MHA, Clinical Assistant Professor of Pediatrics, University of Washington School of Medicine, Seattle, WA. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Medical Director, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

predicted_text:
I am not your medical provider, and the information below is for general education only.  If you decide to proceed, you will need an in-person evaluation by a qualified clinician (ear-nose-throat specialist, facial plastic surgeon, or plastic surgeon).

1. Why the nose often needs surgery after an old fracture
   • After 3 years the broken bones and cartilage have already healed in their displaced position.  
   • To straighten or narrow the nose or improve breathing, the surgeon usually has to “re-fracture” (osteotomize) and reset the nasal bones and/or perform septal surgery.  
   • No splint, injection, or exercise can reposition fully healed bone.

2. First steps
   • Make an appointment with an ENT physician (otolaryngologist) who does nasal surgery, or a board-certified facial plastic surgeon.  
   • Bring a list of concerns: appearance, breathing problems, sinus infections, snoring, sleep apnea, headaches, etc.  
   • The doctor will perform a detailed nasal exam (external inspection, endoscopy of the inside) and may order a low-dose CT scan to see the exact deformity.

3. Procedure names you may hear
   • Septoplasty – straightens the internal cartilage partition (septum) to improve airflow.  
   • Septorhinoplasty or “functional rhinoplasty” – combines septoplasty with work on the outside of the nose (bones, tip cartilage) to correct deformity and/or improve breathing.  
   • Cosmetic rhinoplasty – focuses mainly on appearance; insurance usually will not cover if it’s purely cosmetic.

4. Insurance and cost
   • If you have documented breathing obstruction, frequent sinus infections, or related problems, insurers often cover the functional portions of surgery (septoplasty, turbinate reduction, fracture osteotomies).  
   • Purely cosmetic changes (e.g., reducing a bump, making the tip smaller) are usually paid out of pocket.  
   • Obtain a pre-authorization letter and a cost estimate that separates functional vs. cosmetic fees.

5. What surgery and recovery are like
   • Usually outpatient (go home the same day).  
   • Anesthesia: general or deep IV sedation.  
   • Length: 1–3 hours depending on complexity.  
   • A splint and sometimes internal silicone stents are placed for 5–7 days.  
   • Swelling and bruising peak at 2–4 days, most bruising resolves by 2 weeks, but subtle swelling can persist up to a year.  
   • Restrictions: no strenuous exercise for 2 weeks, no contact sports for 6–8 weeks, avoid glasses resting on the bridge for 4–6 weeks.  
   • Follow-up visits at 1 week, 1–3 months, and 6–12 months. Most people return to desk work or school in 7–10 days.

6. Possible risks and complications (all uncommon but real)
   • Bleeding, infection, poor wound healing.  
   • Septal perforation (hole in the septum) or persistent deviation.  
   • Change in smell, numbness, asymmetry, under-/over-correction.  
   • Need for revision surgery (5–15 % depending on complexity).

7. Questions to ask your surgeon
   • How many septorhinoplasties do you perform per year?  
   • Can I see before-and-after photos of similar cases?  
   • What realistic results should I expect?  
   • What is the revision rate in your practice?  
   • What will be itemized costs and what can insurance cover?  
   • What happens if I have a problem on nights/weekends?

8. Non-surgical options
   • If cosmetic appearance is not your main concern and you only have mild nasal obstruction, medical measures (nasal steroid sprays, antihistamines, saline irrigations) can help but will not straighten bone.  
   • Injectable “liquid rhinoplasty” with fillers can camouflage small contour irregularities but cannot narrow or straighten crooked bones and may worsen airway problems.

Bottom line
A three-year-old nasal fracture can still be corrected, but only with surgery.  Book an in-person consultation with an ENT or facial plastic surgeon, discuss both functional and cosmetic goals, request imaging and a detailed treatment plan, and review costs and recovery expectations before proceeding.

<gold_response>
Nose fracture: A nose fracture is a break in the bone or cartilage over the bridge, or in the sidewall or septum (structure that divides the nostrils) of the nose. A fractured nose is the most common fracture of the face. It most often occurs after an injury and often occurs with other fractures of the face. Nose injuries and neck injuries are often seen together. A blow that is forceful enough to injure the nose may be hard enough to injure the neck. Serious nose injuries cause problems that need a health care provider's attention right away. For example, damage to the cartilage can cause a collection of blood to form inside the nose. If this blood is not drained right away, it can cause an abscess or a permanent deformity that blocks the nose. It may lead to tissue death and cause the nose to collapse. For minor nose injuries, the provider may want to see the person within the first week after the injury to see if the nose has moved out of its normal shape. Sometimes, surgery may be needed to correct a nose or septum that has been bent out of shape by an injury. Symptoms may include: - Blood coming from the nose - Bruising around the eyes - Difficulty breathing through the nose - Misshapen appearance (may not be obvious until the swelling goes down) - Pain - Swelling The bruised appearance most often disappears after 2 weeks. If a nose injury happens: - Try to stay calm. - Breathe through your mouth and lean forward in a sitting position to keep blood from going down the back of your throat. - Squeeze the nostrils closed and hold pressure to stop the bleeding. - Apply cold compresses to your nose to reduce swelling. If possible, hold the compress so that there isn't too much pressure on the nose. - To help relieve pain, try acetaminophen (Tylenol). - DO NOT try to straighten a broken nose - DO NOT move the person if there is reason to suspect a head or neck injury Get medical help right away if: - Bleeding will not stop - Clear fluid keeps draining from the nose - You suspect a blood clot in the septum - You suspect a neck or head injury - The nose looks deformed or out of its usual shape - The person is having difficulty breathing Wear protective headgear while playing contact sports, or riding bicycles, skateboards, roller skates, or rollerblades. Use seat belts and appropriate car seats when driving. Updated by: Josef Shargorodsky, MD, MPH, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

predicted_text:
I’m sorry this has gone on so long for you—chronic anal pain can make everyday life miserable.  
Because your fissure has persisted for two years, you are already in the “chronic” category (anything that lasts more than 6-8 weeks). At this point most fissures will NOT close with home care alone; they usually need prescription medicines or a simple office/surgical procedure. Below is an overview of what typically works, steps you can take on your own, and when to seek specialist care.

----------------------------------------------------------------
1. Rule-out other causes and complications  
----------------------------------------------------------------
• A tear that will not heal can be misdiagnosed. Crohn’s disease, infection (TB, HIV, syphilis), skin disorders, or even early cancer can mimic a fissure.  
• Long-standing fissures may form a “sentinel pile” (skin tag) or develop a small tunnel (fistula).  
>>> See a colorectal surgeon or gastroenterologist for an exam (anoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy) to confirm the diagnosis and look for underlying disease.

----------------------------------------------------------------
2. First-line medical therapy (requires a prescription)  
----------------------------------------------------------------
These medicines relax the internal anal sphincter so blood flow improves and the crack can knit together.

A. Topical nitroglycerin 0.2–0.4 %  
   • Apply a pea-sized amount just inside the anal canal twice daily for 6–8 weeks.  
   • 50–70 % heal. Main side effect: headache (take acetaminophen, use smaller amount, or lie down after application).

B. Topical calcium-channel blocker cream or ointment  
   • Diltiazem 2 % or nifedipine 0.2–0.5 % 2–3×/day for 6–8 weeks.  
   • Similar healing rates to nitroglycerin but far fewer headaches. Often compounded by a pharmacy.

C. Botulinum toxin injection  
   • A 5-minute office procedure. 20–30 units injected into the internal sphincter; success rate 70-90 %.  
   • Works within days, lasts ~3 months—long enough for most fissures to close. Minimal downtime.

D. Short-term pain relief  
   • Lidocaine 5 % ointment before and after bowel movements.  
   • NSAIDs or acetaminophen if tolerated.

If you have already tried prescription creams without success or can’t tolerate side effects, move to step 3.

----------------------------------------------------------------
3. Gold-standard cure: Lateral Internal Sphincterotomy  
----------------------------------------------------------------
• A minor outpatient surgery (15–20 min) that cuts a small portion of the internal sphincter.  
• Healing in >95 % of chronic fissures; recurrence under 5 %.  
• Temporary gas leakage occurs in <10 %; long-term incontinence is rare (<1–2 % when done by an experienced colorectal surgeon).  
• Recovery: sitz baths, stool softener, back to desk work in 3–5 days, heavy lifting in 2–3 weeks.

----------------------------------------------------------------
4. Supportive measures you can start today  
----------------------------------------------------------------
Bowel habit  
• Aim for soft, formed “banana” stools—neither pellets nor diarrhea.  
• Fiber: 25–35 g/day from food + optional psyllium, methyl-cellulose, or wheat dextrin. Introduce gradually to avoid gas.  
• Fluids: 1.5–2 L (6–8 cups) water/day unless restricted by another condition.  
• Osmotic stool softener (e.g., polyethylene glycol 17 g powder daily) is often better than stimulant laxatives.

Toilet technique  
• Do not strain or linger; sit no more than 2–3 minutes.  
• Elevate feet on a small stool to straighten the anorectal angle.  
• Wipe gently; consider rinsing with a bidet or peri-bottle and patting dry.

Sitz baths  
• Warm (not hot) water up to the hips for 10–15 minutes, 2–3 times/day and after BMs.  
• Increases blood flow and relaxes sphincter.

Diet/lifestyle  
• Limit sharp, spicy, or constipating foods if they worsen symptoms.  
• Regular exercise, even walks, stimulates bowel motility and improves circulation.  
• Manage stress; anxiety tenses pelvic muscles and can aggravate pain.

----------------------------------------------------------------
5. When to seek immediate attention  
----------------------------------------------------------------
• Severe or increasing pain, fever, redness, swelling → possible abscess.  
• Persistent bleeding or stools that look black/tarry.  
• New bowel control problems.  
• Unexplained weight loss, night sweats, or other systemic symptoms.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Brief action plan  
----------------------------------------------------------------
1. Make an appointment with a colorectal surgeon; request evaluation and discuss topical dilt
