<gold_response>
Anal fissure: An anal fissure is a small tear in the thin, moist tissue (mucosa) that lines the anus. An anal fissure may occur when you pass hard or large stools during a bowel movement. Anal fissures typically cause pain and bleeding with bowel movements. You also may experience spasms in the ring of muscle at the end of your anus (anal sphincter). Anal fissures are very common in young infants but can affect people of any age. Most anal fissures get better with simple treatments, such as increased fiber intake or sitz baths. Some people with anal fissures may need medication or, occasionally, surgery. Signs and symptoms of an anal fissure include: - Pain, sometimes severe, during bowel movements - Pain after bowel movements that can last up to several hours - Bright red blood on the stool or toilet paper after a bowel movement - Itching or irritation around the anus - A visible crack in the skin around the anus - A small lump or skin tag on the skin near the anal fissure When to see a doctor See your doctor if you have pain during bowel movements or notice blood on stools or toilet paper after a bowel movement. Common causes of anal fissure include: - Passing large or hard stools - Constipation and straining during bowel movements - Chronic diarrhea - Inflammation of the anorectal area, caused by Crohn's disease or another inflammatory bowel disease - Childbirth Less common causes of anal fissures include: - Anal cancer - HIV - Tuberculosis - Syphilis - Herpes Factors that may increase your risk of developing an anal fissure include: - Infancy. Many infants experience an anal fissure during their first year of life; experts aren't sure why. - Aging. Older adults may develop an anal fissure partly due to slowed circulation, resulting in decreased blood flow to the rectal area. - Constipation. Straining during bowel movements and passing hard stools increase the risk of tearing. - Childbirth. Anal fissures are more common in women after they give birth. - Crohn's disease. This inflammatory bowel disease causes chronic inflammation of the intestinal tract, which may make the lining of the anal canal more vulnerable to tearing. - Anal intercourse. Complications of anal fissure can include: - Failure to heal. An anal fissure that fails to heal within six weeks is considered chronic and may need further treatment. - Recurrence. Once you've experienced an anal fissure, you are prone to having another one. - A tear that extends to surrounding muscles. An anal fissure may extend into the ring of muscle that holds your anus closed (internal anal sphincter), making it more difficult for your anal fissure to heal. An unhealed fissure can trigger a cycle of discomfort that may require medications or surgery to reduce the pain and to repair or remove the fissure. If possible, your doctor will perform a digital rectal exam, which involves inserting a gloved finger into your anal canal, or use a short, lighted tube (anoscope) to inspect your anal canal. However, if this is too painful for you, your doctor may be able to diagnose an anal fissure only by observation. An acute anal fissure looks like a fresh tear, somewhat like a paper cut. A chronic anal fissure likely has the tear, as well as two separate lumps or tags of skin, one internal (sentinel pile) and one external (hypertrophied papilla). The fissure's location offers clues about its cause. A fissure that occurs on the side of the anal opening, rather than the back or front, is more likely to be a sign of another disorder, such as Crohn's disease. Your doctor may recommend further testing if he or she thinks you have an underlying condition: - Flexible sigmoidoscopy. Your doctor will insert a thin, flexible tube with a tiny video into the bottom portion of your colon. This test may be done if you're younger than 50 and have no risk factors for intestinal diseases or colon cancer. - Colonoscopy. Your doctor will insert a flexible tube into your rectum to inspect the entire colon. This test may be done if you are older than age 50 or you have risk factors for colon cancer, signs of other conditions, or other symptoms such as abdominal pain or diarrhea. Anal fissures often heal within a few weeks if you take steps to keep your stool soft, such as increasing your intake of fiber and fluids. Soaking in warm water for 10 to 20 minutes several times a day, especially after bowel movements, can help relax the sphincter and promote healing. If your symptoms persist, you'll likely need further treatment. Nonsurgical treatments Your doctor may recommend: - Externally applied nitroglycerin (Rectiv), to help increase blood flow to the fissure and promote healing and to help relax the anal sphincter. Nitroglycerin is generally considered the medical treatment of choice when other conservative measures fail. Side effects may include headache, which can be severe. - Topical anesthetic creams such as lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine) may be helpful for pain relief. - Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) injection, to paralyze the anal sphincter muscle and relax spasms. - Blood pressure medications, such as oral nifedipine (Procardia) or diltiazem (Cardizem) can help relax the anal sphincter. These medications may be taken by mouth or applied externally and may be used when nitroglycerin is not effective or causes significant side effects. Surgery If you have a chronic anal fissure that is resistant to other treatments, or if your symptoms are severe, your doctor may recommend surgery. Doctors usually perform a procedure called lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS), which involves cutting a small portion of the anal sphincter muscle to reduce spasm and pain, and promote healing. Studies have found that for chronic fissure, surgery is much more effective than any medical treatment. However, surgery has a small risk of causing incontinence. Several lifestyle changes may help relieve discomfort and promote healing of an anal fissure, as well as prevent recurrences: - Add fiber to your diet. Eating about 25 to 30 grams of fiber a day can help keep stools soft and improve fissure healing. Fiber-rich foods include fruits, vegetables, nuts and whole grains. You also can take a fiber supplement. Adding fiber may cause gas and bloating, so increase your intake gradually. - Drink adequate fluids. Fluids help prevent constipation. - Exercise regularly. Engage in 30 minutes or more of moderate physical activity, such as walking, most days of the week. Exercise promotes regular bowel movements and increases blood flow to all parts of your body, which may promote healing of an anal fissure. - Avoid straining during bowel movements. Straining creates pressure, which can open a healing tear or cause a new tear. If your infant has an anal fissure, be sure to change diapers frequently, wash the area gently and discuss the problem with your child's doctor.

predicted_text:
I’m sorry you’ve been struggling with this for so long. An ingrown toenail that lasts four years is no longer just a nuisance—it is a chronic medical condition that needs proper treatment. Below are some key points, self-care measures you can try right away, and, most importantly, when and how to seek professional help.

1. Why it keeps coming back  
• Shape of the nail or nail bed (some people inherit nails that naturally curve downward).  
• Improper trimming (rounding or cutting the corners too short).  
• Tight shoes or trauma (stubbing the toe, repeated pressure from sports).  
• Thickened nails from fungus or psoriasis.  
• Underlying medical problems (poor circulation, diabetes) that slow healing.

2. Dangers of leaving it untreated  
• Repeated infections (swelling, pus, foul odor).  
• Permanent changes in the nail and surrounding tissue (proud flesh or “granulation tissue”).  
• Bone infection (rare, but possible).  
• Slow‐healing wounds if you have diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, or immune problems.

3. Things you can do today (if the toe is NOT severely infected)  
• Warm salt-water or Epsom-salt soaks: 15–20 min, 2–3 times a day to reduce swelling and soften skin.  
• Keep the toe clean and dry the rest of the time.  
• Wear wide, open-toed or loose shoes; avoid pressure on the nail edge.  
• OTC pain relievers (acetaminophen or ibuprofen if you can take them).  
• Apply an antibiotic ointment and a light, breathable dressing after each soak.  
• If the corner of the nail is just starting to dig in, you may gently lift the edge with a small piece of cotton or dental floss changed daily, but stop if it hurts or bleeds.

4. Stop and seek care immediately if you notice  
• Increasing pain, redness, swelling, warmth, pus, or a foul smell.  
• Fever or feeling unwell.  
• You have diabetes, poor circulation, or a compromised immune system—do not try to treat it at home; see a professional right away.

5. Why professional treatment is your best option now  
After four years, home remedies are unlikely to give lasting relief. A podiatrist (foot specialist), general surgeon, or some family physicians can perform procedures that cure chronic ingrown nails:

• Partial nail avulsion: The doctor numbs the toe and removes only the ingrown edge of the nail.  
• Matrixectomy: After removing the edge, a chemical (phenol) or laser destroys the small part of the nail root so that section never grows back—high success rate (~95 %).  
• Total nail removal: Reserved for severe, distorted, or fungal nails.  
• If infection is present, you may also need oral antibiotics.

These are quick outpatient procedures; you usually walk out wearing an open-toe sandal and return to normal footwear in about a week.

6. Preventing recurrence after it’s fixed  
• Trim nails straight across; leave the corners visible beyond the skin.  
• File sharp edges rather than rounding deeply.  
• Wear shoes with enough toe room; avoid high-pressure athletics without proper footwear.  
• Keep feet clean and dry; treat fungal infections promptly.  
• If you can’t reach your feet easily or have vision/circulation issues, arrange routine podiatry visits.

7. How to arrange care  
• Search online for “podiatrist near me” or ask your primary-care doctor for a referral.  
• If cost is a concern, ask about payment plans, community clinics, or hospital outpatient programs; many offer reduced fees.  
• Bring a list of current medications and medical conditions to the appointment.

Bottom line  
A four-year ingrown toenail won’t resolve on its own; in fact, it can worsen. Basic soaks, roomy footwear, and proper nail care may ease pain temporarily, but definitive treatment by a podiatrist or surgeon is usually fast, relatively painless, and highly effective. Make an appointment as soon as you can, and you should finally get lasting relief.

Ingrown toenail (Treatment): If you have diabetes, nerve problem in the leg or foot, poor blood circulation to your foot, or an infection around the nail, see a provider right away. Don't try to treat an ingrown nail at home. Otherwise, to treat an ingrown nail at home: - Soak the foot in warm water 3 to 4 times a day if possible. After soaking, keep the toe dry. - Gently massage over the inflamed skin. - Place a small piece of cotton or dental floss under the nail. Wet the cotton or floss with water or antiseptic. When trimming your toenails: - Briefly soak your foot in warm water to soften the nails. - Use a clean, sharp trimmer. - Trim toenails straight across the top. Do not taper or round the corners or trim too short.  - Do not try to cut out the ingrown portion of the nail yourself. This will only make the problem worse. Consider wearing sandals until the problem goes away. Over-the-counter medicine that is applied to the ingrown toenail may help with the pain, but it does not treat the problem. If this doesn't work and the ingrown nail gets worse, see your family doctor, a foot specialist (podiatrist), or a skin specialist (dermatologist). If the ingrown nail doesn't heal or keeps coming back, your provider may remove part of the nail: - Numbing medicine is first injected into the toe. - The ingrown part of the nail is removed. This procedure is called a partial nail avulsion. - It takes 2 to 4 months for the nail to regrow. If the toe is infected, your doctor may prescribe antibiotics. After the procedure, follow any instructions for helping your nail heal.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Below is general, educational information.  It is not a substitute for personal medical care.  Please discuss all questions about diagnosis, treatment and family-planning with the physicians who know you and your test results.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
OVERVIEW – WHAT IS KARTAGENER’S SYNDROME?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Kartagener’s syndrome is the “classic triad” of  
  1) chronic sinusitis,  
  2) bronchiectasis (permanent widening of the airways) and  
  3) situs inversus totalis (the heart and other organs are reversed left-to-right).  

• It is one expression of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD), a rare, inherited (autosomal recessive) disorder in which the microscopic “motors” (cilia) that move mucus, bacteria and sperm are either absent, too short or beat abnormally.

• Incidence: 1 in 10 000–30 000 live births (more common where there is consanguinity).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
TYPICAL SIGNS & SYMPTOMS
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Respiratory / Ear-Nose-Throat
• Persistent wet cough from early infancy  
• Recurrent or chronic sinus infections, nasal congestion, nasal polyps  
• Otitis media with possible conductive hearing loss  
• Bronchiectasis visible on CT chest; shortness of breath with exercise  
• Low nasal nitric-oxide levels (helpful screening test)

Organ orientation
• 50 % have complete situs inversus; a smaller fraction have heterotaxy (mixed orientation) which can be associated with congenital heart disease.

Fertility / Genitourinary
• Males: immotile or dysmotile sperm → subfertility or infertility in the vast majority.  
• Females: fallopian-tube cilia beat poorly → reduced fertility, longer time to conceive and slightly higher risk of ectopic pregnancy, but many women do conceive spontaneously.

Other
• Neonatal respiratory distress (even at term) in ~80 %  
• Occasional hydrocephalus in childhood (due to ependymal ciliary dysfunction).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
FERTILITY IN DETAIL
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Men
• Semen analysis typically shows normal sperm count but <10 % motility.  
• Assisted reproductive technology (ART):  
  – IntraCytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI) can give fertilisation rates similar to other causes of male factor infertility.  
  – Some centres use testicular sperm extraction (TESE) + ICSI if ejaculated sperm are non-motile.  
  – Success varies with female partner’s age and embryo quality, but live-birth rates of 20-35 % per cycle are reported.

Women
• Natural conception is possible; reported fertility impairment ranges from mild to moderate.  
• If trying >12 months without success (or >6 months if age ≥35), referral to a fertility specialist is reasonable.  
• Standard fertility treatments (ovulation induction, IUI, IVF) can be offered.  IVF success rates are similar to other women of the same age, though the number of embryos reaching blastocyst stage may be slightly reduced.  
• Ectopic pregnancy risk is 2–3 × general population; early ultrasound to confirm intra-uterine pregnancy is advised.

Pregnancy considerations
• Baseline pulmonary function test and sputum cultures before conception.  
• Aggressive treatment of respiratory exacerbations; daily airway-clearance physiotherapy.  
• If lung function is severely reduced (FEV₁ <40 % predicted), multidisciplinary high-risk obstetric care is recommended.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
DIAGNOSIS (IF NOT ALREADY CONFIRMED)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• History + physical exam (organ position)  
• Very low nasal nitric oxide (screening)  
• High-speed video microscopy of ciliary beat pattern and frequency  
• Transmission electron microscopy of ciliary ultrastructure  
• Immunofluorescence for axonemal proteins  
• Genetic testing: >50 genes known (DNAH5, DNAI1, CCDC40, etc.).  About 70 % of cases can currently be confirmed genetically.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
TREATMENT & LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT
--------------------------------------------------------------------
There is no cure yet; therapy focuses on keeping the lungs and sinuses as healthy as possible.

1. Airway clearance  
   – Daily chest physiotherapy or oscillatory devices (e.g., Acapella®, vest therapy).  
   – Regular exercise (swimming, cycling, walking).

2. Infection control  
   – Prompt culture-guided antibiotics for exacerbations.  
   – Inhaled bronchodilators or hypertonic saline may help clear mucus.  
   – Childhood and adult vaccines (influenza, pneumococcal, COVID-19).

3. ENT care  
   – Periodic hearing tests, ventilation tubes when needed.  
   – Nasal

Below you will find:

1. A plain-language overview of distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) in children  
2. Expected tests, treatment and follow-up  
3. Tips for day-to-day care at home  
4. How to find expert doctors and hospitals in México  
5. Mexican and international patient/parent support organizations (many offer information in Spanish)  
6. Reliable internet and printed resources in Spanish and English

────────────────────────────────────────
1. What is distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA)?
────────────────────────────────────────
• Your kidneys filter the blood and then fine-tune the “acid–base” balance.  
• In dRTA the last part of the kidney tubule (the “distal” tubule) cannot get rid of the normal acid that the body makes every day.  
• Acid builds up in the blood (metabolic acidosis) and the urine stays abnormally alkaline (pH > 5.5).  
• Because the urine is alkaline, calcium and other salts can form stones or deposit in the kidney (nephrocalcinosis).  
• The body loses potassium and bicarbonate, which can cause muscle weakness and poor growth in children.

Why does it happen?  
1. Hereditary (the most common cause in children)  
   – Autosomal dominant form (gene SLC4A1)  
   – Autosomal recessive forms (genes ATP6V1B1 and ATP6V0A4); many of these children will also develop sensorineural hearing loss, sometimes in the first years of life, sometimes later.  
2. Acquired – much rarer in young children (autoimmune diseases such as Sjögren, some medications, obstruction, etc.)

Usual signs and symptoms  
• Poor weight gain or height growth, rickets/osteomalacia (soft bones)  
• Vomiting, dehydration, finding it hard to thrive (“failure to thrive”)  
• Polyuria (passing large volumes of urine), polydipsia (always thirsty)  
• Muscle weakness or episodic paralysis (because potassium may fall)  
• Kidney stones or nephrocalcinosis picked up on ultrasound  
• If hereditary, a family history of kidney stones or hearing problems

────────────────────────────────────────
2. How is it diagnosed?
────────────────────────────────────────
• Blood tests – low bicarbonate (HCO����), normal/ high chloride, often low potassium, normal anion gap.  
• Urinalysis – urine pH usually stays > 5.5 even when blood is acidemic; there is often high calcium and low citrate in urine.  
• Imaging – kidney ultrasound to look for stones/ nephrocalcinosis.  
• Special studies – genetic testing (if available) or ammonium chloride loading test (rarely needed in children today).  
• Hearing test (audiometry) if a recessive gene form is suspected.

────────────────────────────────────────
3. Treatment and follow-up
────────────────────────────────────────
Goal: keep the blood bicarbonate level in normal range so your daughter can grow normally, prevent bone disease and protect the kidneys.

a. Alkali (base) replacement  
   • Sodium bicarbonate, potassium citrate or potassium bicarbonate are given 3–4 times per day.  
   • Dose is adjusted according to weight and lab results. Missing doses for even 24–48 h often brings acid back. Adherence is key!

b. Potassium supplementation  
   • Many children respond well to potassium citrate, which gives both citrate and potassium in one medicine.

c. Thiazide diuretic (sometimes)  
   • Used when calcium levels in urine stay high despite good alkali therapy.

d. Fluids  
   • Encourage plenty of water to dilute the urine (helps prevent stones).

e. Nutrition  
   • Balanced diet; no extra restriction of calcium (unless doctor advises). Limit excessive salt and animal protein; plenty of fruits/vegetables provide natural citrate.

f. Monitoring schedule (can vary)  
   • Every 1–3 months in infants, every 3–6 months in older children: weight/height, blood electrolytes, bicarbonate, kidney function.  
   • Kidney ultrasound every 6–12 months to watch for stones.  
   • Annual hearing test if gene form linked to deafness.

Prognosis  
With early and consistent treatment, most children achieve normal growth, good bone health and normal kidney function. Untreated or poorly treated dRTA can lead to growth failure, bone deformities and chronic kidney disease.

────────────────────────────────────────
4. Where to find experienced doctors and hospitals in México
────────────────────────────────────────
Look for a pediatric nephrologist (nefrólogo pediatra). The following centres all have pediatric nephrology services and experience with rare kidney disorders:

<gold_response>
SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis (Description): SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis is a kidney (renal) disorder that sometimes includes blood cell abnormalities. The kidneys normally filter fluid and waste products from the body and remove them in urine; however, in people with distal renal tubular acidosis, the kidneys are unable to remove enough acid from the body, and the blood becomes too acidic. This chemical imbalance is called metabolic acidosis. The inability to remove acids from the body often results in slowed growth and may also lead to softening and weakening of the bones, called rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. This bone disorder is characterized by bone pain, bowed legs, and difficulty walking. In addition, most children and adults with SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis have excess calcium in the urine (hypercalciuria), calcium deposits in the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis), and kidney stones (nephrolithiasis). In rare cases, these kidney abnormalities lead to life-threatening kidney failure. Affected individuals may also have low levels of potassium in the blood (hypokalemia). Individuals with the features described above have complete distal renal tubular acidosis, which usually becomes apparent in childhood. Some people do not develop metabolic acidosis even though their kidneys have trouble removing acids; these individuals are said to have incomplete distal renal tubular acidosis. Additionally, these individuals may have other features of distal renal tubular acidosis, such as bone problems and kidney stones. Often, people who initially have incomplete distal renal tubular acidosis develop metabolic acidosis later in life. Some people with SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis also have blood cell abnormalities. These can vary in severity from no symptoms to a condition called hemolytic anemia, in which red blood cells prematurely break down (undergo hemolysis), causing a shortage of red blood cells (anemia). Hemolytic anemia can lead to unusually pale skin (pallor), extreme tiredness (fatigue), shortness of breath (dyspnea), and an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly). There are two forms of SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis; they are distinguished by their inheritance pattern. The autosomal dominant form is more common and is usually less severe than the autosomal recessive form. The autosomal dominant form can be associated with incomplete or complete distal renal tubular acidosis and is rarely associated with blood cell abnormalities. The autosomal recessive form is always associated with complete distal renal tubular acidosis and is more commonly associated with blood cell abnormalities, although not everyone with this form has abnormal blood cells.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Lewy body disease (LBD), sometimes called Lewy body dementia, is an umbrella term for two very similar conditions:

• Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) – dementia symptoms appear first or within a year of movement (Parkinson-like) problems.  
• Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD) – Parkinson’s disease is diagnosed first and significant dementia develops later (usually after several years).

Both disorders are caused by the build-up of an abnormal protein (alpha-synuclein) inside brain cells.  
Below are answers to your specific questions, followed by reliable places to learn more.

1) Is Lewy body disease hereditary?  
• For most people, no.  The vast majority of LBD cases are “sporadic,” meaning they occur in people with no strong family history.  
• A small minority of families carry rare gene changes (for example in the SNCA, GBA, LRRK2, or APOE genes) that can increase the chance of developing Lewy body disease or Parkinson’s disease, but even in those families inheritance is not 100 %.  
• Having a parent, brother, or sister with Parkinson’s disease, Lewy body dementia, or Alzheimer’s disease may raise someone’s risk slightly, but it still does not mean the disease is inevitable.  
• At present there is no routine genetic test used to predict LBD because known gene mutations explain only a tiny fraction of cases.

2) Does alcoholism play a role in starting the disease?  
• Current research has not shown chronic alcohol use or alcoholism to be a direct cause or trigger of Lewy body disease.  
• Heavy alcohol use can certainly damage the brain and cause its own forms of cognitive impairment (alcohol-related dementia, Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome), but these are different conditions with different brain changes.  
• That said, excessive alcohol can worsen confusion, balance problems, mood swings, and sleep disturbances, so if someone already has—or is at risk for—LBD it is still wise to limit or avoid alcohol.

3) What are the initial (early) symptoms?  
Early features vary from person to person, but the most common “first signs” include one or more of the following:

Cognitive/psychiatric  
• Fluctuating attention or alertness – periods of staring, confusion, or “spacing out” that can improve and then recur.  
• Subtle memory loss or trouble finding words (often less severe than in early Alzheimer’s).  
• Difficulty planning, multitasking, or judging distances.  
• Visual hallucinations – seeing people, animals, or shapes that are not there; these tend to be detailed and well-formed.  
• Depression, anxiety, apathy, or new-onset paranoia.

Sleep-related  
• REM sleep behavior disorder (acting out vivid dreams, calling out, thrashing) years before other symptoms.  
• Excessive daytime sleepiness.

Movement (Parkinsonian)  
• Slowness of movement (bradykinesia), stiffness/rigidity, shuffling walk, reduced arm swing.  
• Tremor (less prominent than in typical Parkinson’s disease but can occur).  
• Stooped posture, balance problems, falls.

Autonomic / Other  
• Dizziness when standing (orthostatic hypotension), constipation, urinary urgency, reduced sense of smell, sensitivity to heat or cold.  
• Extreme sensitivity to certain antipsychotic (neuroleptic) medications—this sometimes brings the disease to attention.

Because several of these symptoms can mimic Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, normal aging, or mental-health conditions, diagnosis usually requires a neurologist who is familiar with Lewy body disorders. Brain imaging (MRI or CT), sleep studies, neuropsychological testing, and careful medication review all help.

Where to learn more or get help  
• Lewy Body Dementia Association (LBDA) – www.lbda.org – education, support groups, physician finder.  
• National Institute on Aging – https://www.nia.nih.gov/health/lewy-body-dementia – detailed overview.  
• Alzheimer’s Association – https://www.alz.org/alzheimers-dementia/what-is-dementia/types-of-dementia/dementia-with-lewy-bodies  
• MedlinePlus – https://medlineplus.gov/lewybodydementia.html  
• Parkinson’s Foundation – www.parkinson.org

If you are concerned about yourself or a loved one, consider keeping a diary of symptoms (especially fluctuations and hallucinations) and sharing it with a healthcare professional. Early, accurate diagnosis helps families plan, avoid medications that make symptoms worse, and gain access to treatments and support services.

Lewy body dementia: Lewy body dementia is one of the most common forms of progressive dementia. People affected by this condition may experience a variety of symptoms such as changes in alertness and attention; hallucinations; problems with movement and posture; muscle stiffness; confusion; and/or memory loss. Although the exact cause of Lewy body dementia is poorly understood, symptoms are thought to result when clumps of a protein called alpha-synuclein ("Lewy bodies") accumulate in the brain. Lewy body dementia usually occurs sporadically in people with no family history of the condition. Rarely, more than one family member may be affected. There is currently no cure for Lewy body dementia; however, medications may be available to help manage the associated symptoms. [1] [2] [3] The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) provides the following list of features that have been reported in people with this condition. Much of the information in the HPO comes from Orphanet, a European rare disease database. If available, the list includes a rough estimate of how common a feature is (its frequency). Frequencies are based on a specific study and may not be representative of all studies. You can use the MedlinePlus Medical Dictionary for definitions of the terms below. Signs and Symptoms Approximate number of patients (when available) Autosomal dominant inheritance - Delusions - Dementia - Fluctuations in consciousness - Parkinsonism - Visual hallucinations - The exact underlying cause of Lewy body dementia is poorly understood. The symptoms of the condition are thought to occur when clumps of a protein called alpha-synuclein accumulate in the regions of the brain involved in thinking, memory and movement. The build-up of these clumps (which are called "Lewy bodies") appears to be associated with a loss of certain neurons (nerve cells ) in the brain that produce two important neurotransmitters (chemicals that act as messengers between brain cells). The neurotransmitter, acetylcholine, is important for memory and learning. The other, dopamine, plays an important role in behavior, cognition, movement, motivation, sleep, and mood. [4] Although Lewy body dementia usually occurs sporadically, more than one family member can rarely be affected. Studies of these families suggest that there may be a genetic component to the condition in some cases. For example, copy number variants or changes ( mutations ) in the SNCA gene have been reported in a few affected families. [5] [6] The APOE ε4 allele and mutations in the GBA gene have been associated with an increased risk of Lewy body dementia and the APOE ε2 allele with a decreased risk. [5] [7] [2] Most cases of Lewy body dementia are not thought to be inherited . The condition generally occurs sporadically in people with no family history of the condition. [4] Rarely, the condition can affect more than one family member. Some of these cases appear to be due to single gene changes ( mutations ) that follow an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Other familial cases do not follow a specific pattern of inheritance and likely have a multifactorial cause (associated with the effects of multiple genes in combination with lifestyle and environmental factors ). Healthcare professionals typically look at a person’s medical history, symptoms, physical exam, and laboratory test results in order to make a diagnosis. Patients and consumers with specific questions about a genetic test should contact a health care provider or a genetics professional. The Lewy Body Dementia Association offers detailed and up-to-date information regarding the treatment and management of Lewy body dementia . Please click on the link to access this resource.

Below is up-to-date, plain-language information you can share with expectant parents or other caregivers.  Nothing here replaces personal medical care; anyone who is pregnant or planning a pregnancy should review these issues with a qualified health-care professional.

1. What are Tay–Sachs disease (TSD) and clubfoot, and how do they affect a baby?

Tay–Sachs disease  
•  A rare inherited disorder of fat (lipid) metabolism caused by absence of an enzyme called hexosaminidase-A (Hex-A).  
•  Without Hex-A, fatty substances build up in nerve cells, especially in the brain and spinal cord.  
•  Babies are usually normal at birth, but between 3–6 months they begin to lose developmental milestones (sitting, smiling, crawling).   
•  Progressive muscle weakness, loss of vision and hearing, seizures, swallowing problems, and respiratory infections occur.  
•  The infantile form (the most common) is unfortunately fatal, usually by age 4–5 years.  

Clubfoot (talipes equinovarus)  
•  A structural birth defect in which one or both feet are twisted downward and inward at the ankle. The bones, tendons, muscles, and blood vessels are all shortened or angled.  
•  The condition itself is usually painless in infancy, but if untreated it can make standing and walking difficult or impossible and may cause arthritis or chronic pain later in life.  
•  When treated early (usually within the first week or two of life) most children go on to walk, run, and play normally.

2. What causes them, and can they be prevented, treated, or cured?

Tay–Sachs disease  
Cause: An autosomal-recessive mutation in the HEXA gene on chromosome 15. A child must inherit one non-working gene from each parent to have the disease.  
Prevention: Carrier screening before conception or early in pregnancy; if both partners are carriers they may consider in-vitro fertilization with pre-implantation genetic testing, use of donor gametes, or adoption. Prenatal diagnostic tests (chorionic-villous sampling at 10–12 weeks or amniocentesis at ��15 weeks) can determine whether a fetus is affected.  
Treatment/Cure: At present there is no cure. Care is supportive—seizure control, nutrition/hydration, respiratory care, physical therapy, and comfort measures. Clinical trials in gene therapy and enzyme replacement are under way but still experimental.

Clubfoot  
Cause: Usually “idiopathic,” meaning no single known cause. It appears to be multifactorial—genes + in-utero factors. Risks include family history, male sex, low amniotic fluid, maternal smoking, and certain neuromuscular disorders (e.g., spina bifida).  
Prevention: Because the precise cause is unknown, clubfoot can rarely be prevented. Avoiding known risk factors (smoking, alcohol, some drugs) and good prenatal care can reduce risk slightly.  
Treatment: Yes—excellent treatments exist.  
  •  Ponseti method (most common): gentle manipulation and weekly casting for 5–8 weeks, a minor outpatient tendon release in many cases, then use of a special brace at night for 3–4 years.  
  •  French/physiotherapy method: daily stretching, taping, and splinting done by a trained therapist, then bracing.  
  •  Surgery is reserved for the few cases not corrected by casting.  
Cure: With early, consistent treatment more than 95 % of children achieve long-term, pain-free, functional feet.

3. How common are these conditions?

Tay–Sachs disease  
•  General population: ��1 in 320,000 live births.  
•  Certain high-risk ethnic groups:  
   – Ashkenazi Jewish: ��1 in 3,600 births (carrier rate 1 in 27).  
   – French-Canadian (Quebec) and Cajun (Louisiana) groups have similar elevated risks.

Clubfoot  
•  Worldwide average: ��1 in 1,000 live births (about 0.1 %).  
•  United States: roughly 4,000 babies each year.  
•  Twice as common in males; both feet affected about 50 % of the time.

4. How can our agency help couples worried about either condition, and what does it cost?

Genetic Counseling & Screening  
•  We arrange carrier testing for Tay–Sachs (blood test) and interpret the results.  
•  If both partners are carriers we provide non-directive counseling on reproductive options and referrals for reproductive endocrinology, prenatal diagnosis, or adoption services.  
•  Many insurance plans now cover carrier testing for people with Eastern- or Central-European Jewish, French-Canadian, or Cajun ancestry; self-pay cost is typically $100–$250 per

<gold_response>
Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a inherited metabolic disease caused by the harmful buildup of lipids (fatty materials such as oils and acids) in various cells and tissues in the body.  It is part of a group of genetic disorders called the GM2 gangliosidoses.  Tay-Sachs and its variant form are caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A.  Affected children appear to develop normally until about age 6 months.  Then, symptoms begin and include progressive loss of mental ability, dementia, blindness, increased startle reflex to noise, progressive loss of hearing leading to deafness, and difficulty with swallowing.  Seizures may begin in the child's second year. Persons with Tay-Sachs also have "cherry-red" spots in their eyes.  A much rarer form of the disorder, called late-onset Tay-Sachs disease, occurs in individuals in their twenties and early thirties and is characterized by an unsteady gait and progressive neurological deterioration. The incidence of Tay-Sachs has been particularly high among people of Eastern European and Askhenazi Jewish descent., as well as in certain French Canadians and Louisiana Cajuns. Affected individuals and carriers of Tay-Sachs disease can be identified by a blood test that measures hexosaminidase A activity. Both parents must carry the mutated gene in order to have an affected child. In these instances, there is a 25 percent chance with each pregnancy that the child will be affected with Tay-Sachs disease. Prenatal diagnosis is available if desired.  A very severe form of Tay-Sachs disease is know as Sandhoff disease, which is not limited to any ethnic group. Presently there is no specific treatment for Tay-Sachs disease. Anticonvulsant medicine may initially control seizures. Other supportive treatment includes proper nutrition and hydration and techniques to keep the airway open. Children may eventually need a feeding tube. Even with the best of care, children with Tay-Sachs disease usually die by age 4, from recurring infection.
</gold_response>

I’m very sorry your family is facing Menkes disease. The following information is intended to give you an organized overview of what’s known about the disorder, current treatment options, day-to-day care, and ways to obtain specialist help and reliable support. It is not a substitute for medical care from your daughter’s physicians.

1. Understand the condition
   • Cause. Menkes disease (also called Menkes syndrome or X-linked copper transport disease) is caused by pathogenic variants in the ATP7A gene on the X chromosome. The gene defect prevents copper from being transported properly to tissues that need it for normal development.  
   • Who is affected. Because the disorder is X-linked, almost all children who manifest the disease are boys, but girls can be affected in rare circumstances (e.g., unfavorable X-inactivation, X-autosome translocations, or two pathogenic ATP7A variants).  
   • Key features. Poor feeding, floppy muscle tone, seizures, failure to thrive after 2–3 months of age, kinky or steely hair, developmental delay, temperature instability, and characteristic vascular changes.  
   • Natural course. Without therapy, the disease is usually progressive and life-limiting. With very early copper treatment and optimal supportive care, a subset of children achieve longer survival and improved neurologic outcomes.

2. Get the right specialists on board
   • A metabolic or genetic disease center with experience in copper metabolism disorders is central.  
   • Pediatric neurologist (for seizures, tone abnormalities).  
   • Pediatrician/primary care provider to coordinate day-to-day issues (infections, nutrition, vaccinations).  
   • Gastroenterologist / nutrition team (feeding difficulties, G-tube management if needed).  
   • Physical, occupational, and speech therapists (maximize motor and communication skills).  
   • Orthopedist (for bone fragility or scoliosis).  
   • Pulmonologist & ENT as needed (recurrent pneumonias, airway issues).  
   • Social worker/case manager (arrange home nursing, therapies, equipment, respite care).  
   • Genetic counselor (recurrence risk, options for future pregnancies, carrier testing of female relatives).

3. Disease-specific treatment: copper replacement
   • Rationale. Some ATP7A activity is still present in many patients; providing bioavailable copper early can partially bypass the trafficking defect and supply the brain.  
   • What is used. Subcutaneous copper histidinate (also called copper-histidine or CuHis) is the formulation most often studied; doses are typically 50–250 µg/kg/day. Copper chloride is sometimes used if histidinate is unavailable.  
   • Timing matters. Best results are reported when injections start within days to the first few weeks of life, before neurologic injury occurs. In children diagnosed later, copper can still be tried because benefit is unpredictable and side-effects are usually mild (local soreness, transient elevations in liver enzymes).  
   • Monitoring. Serum copper and ceruloplasmin are followed, but clinical parameters—seizure control, tone, developmental milestones—are more important. Copper should be withheld if liver enzymes or ferritin climb markedly; your specialist team will have a protocol.

4. Symptom-directed & supportive care
   • Seizures: standard antiepileptic drugs (levetiracetam, topiramate, phenobarbital, etc.) guided by EEG.  
   • Muscle tone/spasticity: physical therapy, bracing, baclofen or diazepam if needed.  
   • Feeding: high-calorie formulas, thickened feeds, gastrostomy tube if aspiration or failure to thrive.  
   • Temperature instability: dress in layers, avoid overheating, monitor for hypothermia.  
   • Fragile bones/vascular fragility: handle gently, early orthopedics if fractures, screen for cerebrovascular tortuosity if headaches or neurologic events occur.  
   • Immunizations: keep routine schedule; influenza and RSV prophylaxis (palivizumab) can be considered.  
   • Development: early-intervention services, augmentative communication devices, vision/hearing testing.  
   • Palliative care: not “giving up,” but adding a team experienced in comfort measures, symptom control, and family support from an early stage.

5. Day-to-day tips for parents
   • Keep an emergency information sheet (diagnosis, medication list, treating physicians’ contacts) with you.  
   • Learn seizure first-aid and have rescue medicine (e.g., intranasal midazolam) at home and school.  
   • Record weight, feeding volumes, seizure frequency, and any episodes of choking or apnea.  
   • Ask for physical, occupational, and speech therapy evaluations through your state’s early-intervention program—services are usually free until age 3 in the U.S.  
   • If respiratory infections are frequent, request suction equipment and consider

What is Menkes syndrome?: Menkes syndrome is a disorder that affects copper levels in the body. It is characterized by sparse, kinky hair; failure to gain weight and grow at the expected rate (failure to thrive); and deterioration of the nervous system. Additional signs and symptoms include weak muscle tone (hypotonia), sagging facial features, seizures, developmental delay, and intellectual disability. Children with Menkes syndrome typically begin to develop symptoms during infancy and often do not live past age 3. Early treatment with copper may improve the prognosis in some affected individuals. In rare cases, symptoms begin later in childhood. Occipital horn syndrome (sometimes called X-linked cutis laxa) is a less severe form of Menkes syndrome that begins in early to middle childhood. It is characterized by wedge-shaped calcium deposits in a bone at the base of the skull (the occipital bone), coarse hair, and loose skin and joints.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m very sorry to hear how stressful this has been for you.  Below is a practical overview of Milroy disease / primary congenital lymphedema in children, what tests and specialists are usually involved, and the therapies that can help control the swelling.  Use this information to guide discussions with your daughter’s doctors—it is not a substitute for their direct medical care.

1.  What Milroy disease is
•  A rare, inherited form of primary (built-in) lymphedema.  
•  Caused most often by a change in the FLT4/VEGFR-3 gene; it can appear even when no one else in the family is known to have it (a new mutation).  
•  The lymph-drainage channels from birth are either too few, too narrow, or do not pump well, so fluid backs up in the tissues—usually the feet and legs first, sometimes hands, genitals or other areas.  
•  The condition is chronic; there is no cure yet, but modern lymphedema care can keep swelling and complications under good control in most children.

2.  Doctors / clinics who normally look after children with primary lymphedema
•  A paediatrician for overall coordination.  
•  A paediatric vascular/lymphatic anomalies clinic or dermatologist with lymphedema expertise (many major children’s hospitals have one).  
•  Certified lymphoedema therapist (CLT) or physiotherapist trained in manual lymph drainage for children.  
•  Paediatric geneticist (to confirm the exact mutation; this can be useful for future family planning and sometimes for research trials).  
•  Infectious-diseases or dermatology specialist if she ever develops cellulitis (skin infection).  

3.  Tests commonly done
These are painless / low-risk but help plan treatment and rule out other rare problems:  
•  Doppler/duplex ultrasound – checks for blood-clot or venous malformation.  
•  Lymphoscintigraphy or MR-lymphangiography – maps how her lymph vessels are working.  
•  Genetic panel – FLT4 and other primary-lymphedema genes.  
•  Basic blood counts / kidney & liver tests – usually normal, but done to exclude other causes of swelling.  

4.  Day-to-day management (the mainstay of treatment)  
A. Compression therapy
   •  Custom flat-knit stockings, leggings, or sleeve made for infants (companies such as Jobst, Juzo, Sigvaris, Medi have paediatric lines).  
   •  Worn most of the day; removed for naps if advised.  
   •  If legs differ in size, each garment is made to that leg.  
   •  For rapid changes in size (growth spurts) short-stretch bandaging (“multi-layer bandaging”) by a therapist can reduce swelling before a new garment is ordered.  

B. Manual lymph drainage (MLD)
   •  Very gentle skin-stretching strokes that redirect fluid toward healthy lymph channels.  
   •  A trained paediatric CLT can teach you a brief home routine so you can do it daily.  

C. Exercise & positioning
   •  Toddler play that uses the leg and arm muscles acts as a “natural pump” (crawling, climbing, kicking, wading, swimming).  
   •  During quiet times, keeping the swollen limbs comfortably supported on a small pillow reduces pooling.  

D. Skin care
   •  Mild soap, pat dry, apply plain moisturiser (no fragrance) to prevent cracks.  
   •  Prompt treatment of cuts, insect bites, fungal infections to avoid cellulitis.  
   •  Consider Hib, pneumococcal and varicella vaccines on schedule—any fever in a child with lymphedema should be checked early.  

E. Pneumatic compression pump—sometimes offered after age 2–3 if garments alone are not enough.  

F. Surgery—reserved for selected children where intensive conservative therapy fails.  Options include lymphaticovenous bypass or vascularised lymph-node transfer, but these are done only in specialised centres and usually after age 5–7 when the lymph system is larger.  

5.  Signs that need urgent medical review
•  Sudden redness, warmth, pain or fever (possible cellulitis).  
•  Rapid, unexplained increase in swelling on one side only.  
•  Any change in behaviour that suggests discomfort or reduced movement of a limb.  

6.  Outlook
Most children with Milroy disease who enter a structured lymphedema programme early lead active, normal lives.  The key is PREVENTION of long-term tissue changes by: continuous compression, good skin care, and quick treatment of infections.  Regular follow-ups (e.g., every 4–6 months) allow garments to be resized as she grows.

7.  Practical tips for parents
•  Bring two sets

<gold_response>
Milroy disease (Treatment): There is currently no cure for Milroy disease. Management is typically conservative and usually successful in most people. [3] Management of lymphedema should be guided by a lymphedema therapist. Some improvement is usually possible with the use of properly fitted compression hosiery or bandaging and well fitting, supportive shoes. Good skin care is essential. These measures may improve the cosmetic appearance of the affected areas, decrease their size, and reduce the risk of complications. [2] Decongestive physiotherapy , which combines compression bandaging, manual lymphatic drainage (a specialized massage technique), exercise, breathing exercises, dietary measures and skin care, has become the standard of care for primary lymphedema. [3] People with recurrent cellulitis may benefit from prophylactic antibiotics . [2] [3] Surgical intervention is considered a last option when other medical management fails. [3] When possible, people with Milroy disease should avoid: wounds to swollen areas (because of their reduced resistance to infection) long periods of immobility prolonged standing elevation of the affected limb certain medications (particularly calcium channel-blocking drugs that can cause increased leg swelling in some people)[2] Management Guidelines GeneReviews provides current, expert-authored, peer-reviewed, full-text articles describing the application of genetic testing to the diagnosis, management, and genetic counseling of patients with specific inherited conditions.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Ellis-van Creveld (EVC) syndrome is a rare genetic condition that primarily involves the skeleton, teeth/nails and, in about 60 % of patients, the heart.  Because only a few hundred individuals world-wide have been described in the medical literature, reliable “long-term outcome” information is scattered in case reports and small series.  Nevertheless, enough adults with EVC have now been followed to give reasonably good answers to the questions you raise.

1.  What causes EVC and how is it inherited?
•  EVC is usually produced by a change (pathogenic variant) in either the EVC or the EVC2 gene on chromosome 4.  
•  The condition is autosomal-recessive: you need two non-working copies (one from each parent) to be affected.  
•  Each child of an affected adult will automatically receive one non-working copy.  Whether the child actually has EVC depends on the genetic status of the partner:
  – If the partner is not a carrier, the child will be a healthy carrier (0 % chance of being affected).  
  – If the partner is a carrier, each pregnancy has a 25 % risk for EVC, 50 % risk the child will be a carrier, 25 % chance the child will inherit no non-working copies.  
  – Carrier frequency in the general population is estimated at roughly 1:200–1:600, but can be much higher in certain communities (e.g., Old-Order Amish, some Arab populations).  
•  DNA testing can almost always identify the family’s two variants, which allows carrier testing, prenatal diagnosis or pre-implantation genetic testing if you wish.

2.  Life expectancy and adult health
•  Survival to normal adult life is the rule if serious congenital heart disease is absent or surgically repaired.  The oldest reported individuals are in their 60s.  
•  Main adult issues:  
  – Orthopaedic: joint pain, limited elbow motion, early-onset arthritis, genu valgum (“knock knees”) and spine curvature.  
  – Dental: small/missing teeth and gum outpouchings can make oral hygiene difficult; regular dental follow-up is advisable.  
  – Cardiac: endocarditis prophylaxis and cardiology follow-up if a structural defect was present.  
  – Respiratory: occasional restrictive lung disease because of a relatively narrow chest.  
  – Psychosocial: short stature (average adult height 120–150 cm) and hand differences may require workplace and home adaptations, but intellectual development is normal.

3.  Fertility and the ability to have children
•  Fertility appears essentially normal in both men and women with EVC.  No problems with sperm production, ovarian reserve, puberty or hormone levels have been documented in the literature.  
•  The pelvis is small, and women are short-statured, so pregnancy and delivery need specialist obstetric input.  Reported pregnancies usually end with an elective or emergency caesarean section because the maternal pelvis is too small for safe vaginal delivery (cephalopelvic disproportion).  
•  Potential additional risks during pregnancy:
  – Heart: If you have a repaired or unrepaired cardiac defect you should be under joint care of an obstetrician and cardiologist; most women have tolerated pregnancy well when the heart lesion is mild or repaired.  
  – Respiratory: a narrow chest wall plus the upward displacement of the diaphragm in late pregnancy can cause shortness of breath; pulmonary function tests before pregnancy can be helpful.  
  – Musculoskeletal: back pain and early fatigue are common.  
•  Published pregnancy reports
  – ≥ 15 well-documented pregnancies in the medical literature (various countries: USA, UK, India, Korea, Italy, Brazil, Middle East) plus numerous unpublished community reports from the Amish.  
  – Example papers:  
    •  Misra S et al. “Ellis-van Creveld syndrome in pregnancy.” J Obstet Gynaecol 1990.  
    •  Choi JI et al. “Obstetric management in a patient with Ellis-van Creveld syndrome.” Korean J Obstet Gynecol 2008.  
    •  Spagnuolo MI et al. “Pregnancy in a woman with Ellis-van Creveld syndrome and operated congenital heart disease.” Congenit Heart Dis 2011.  
  – All mothers delivered healthy infants; some babies had EVC, some did not, depending on partner carrier status.  Caesarean section was used in nearly all cases.  
•  Men with EVC have fathered children naturally; no reports of reduced fertility.

4.  What research is going on?
•  Gene function: EVC and EVC2 proteins localise to the base of the primary cilium, a cellular “antenna” important in Hedgehog signalling.

<gold_response>
Ellis-van Creveld syndrome (Description): Ellis-van Creveld syndrome is an inherited disorder of bone growth that results in very short stature (dwarfism). People with this condition have particularly short forearms and lower legs and a narrow chest with short ribs. Ellis-van Creveld syndrome is also characterized by the presence of extra fingers and toes (polydactyly), malformed fingernails and toenails, and dental abnormalities. More than half of affected individuals are born with a heart defect, which can cause serious or life-threatening health problems. The features of Ellis-van Creveld syndrome overlap with those of another, milder condition called Weyers acrofacial dysostosis. Like Ellis-van Creveld syndrome, Weyers acrofacial dysostosis involves tooth and nail abnormalities, although affected individuals have less pronounced short stature and typically do not have heart defects. The two conditions are caused by mutations in the same genes.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Nephrotic Syndrome (NS) is not a single disease but a group of symptoms that appear when the kidney’s filtering units — the glomeruli — become abnormally “leaky.”  When this happens, large amounts of protein that should stay in the blood spill into the urine.  The classic findings are:  

• Very high urine protein (“proteinuria,” usually >3–3.5 g per day)  
• Low blood albumin (hypo-albuminemia)  
• Swelling (edema) of the legs, eyes, abdomen, or whole body  
• Often high cholesterol and triglycerides  

Why it matters:  Long-standing protein loss can lead to malnutrition, blood-clot risk, infections, and eventually chronic kidney failure if the underlying problem is not controlled.

--------------------------------------------------
COMMON CAUSES
--------------------------------------------------
A. “Primary” (disease starts in the kidney itself)  
1. Minimal-change disease – most frequent in young children; glomeruli look normal under a light microscope but leak protein.  
2. Focal segmental glomerulo-sclerosis (FSGS) – scarring in parts of some glomeruli; may be genetic or triggered by viruses, obesity, or unknown reasons.  
3. Membranous nephropathy – thickening of the glomerular membrane, usually autoimmune.  
4. Other less common primary glomerulopathies.

B. “Secondary” (kidney damage caused by another condition)  
• Diabetes mellitus (diabetic nephropathy) – leading cause in adults  
• Systemic lupus erythematosus  
• Infections (hepatitis B or C, HIV, malaria, syphilis)  
• Certain drugs (NSAIDs, gold, lithium, interferon, some antibiotics)  
• Cancer (solid tumors, Hodgkin’s disease)  
• Amyloidosis, vasculitis, genetic disorders (Alport, congenital NS)  
• Preeclampsia in pregnancy  

--------------------------------------------------
IS IT CURABLE?
--------------------------------------------------
“Cure” depends on the underlying cause:

• Minimal-change disease: >90 % of children and 60–80 % of adults go into complete remission with steroid therapy; many can be considered cured, though relapses occur.  
• Membranous nephropathy, FSGS, lupus nephritis, diabetic nephropathy: may enter partial or complete remission with modern therapies, but some patients progress to chronic kidney disease/kidney failure.  
• Genetic or advanced scarring disorders: usually not “curable,” but progression can often be slowed and symptoms controlled.  
• If irreversible kidney failure occurs, dialysis or kidney transplantation is the definitive treatment.

--------------------------------------------------
TREATMENT / MANAGEMENT
--------------------------------------------------
1. Treat the specific cause  
  – Corticosteroids (prednisone) are first-line for minimal-change disease and often used for FSGS, membranous nephropathy, and lupus.  
  – Other immunosuppressants: cyclophosphamide, calcineurin inhibitors (cyclosporine, tacrolimus), mycophenolate, rituximab, etc., depending on diagnosis.  
  – Control blood sugar in diabetes; antivirals for hepatitis; stop offending drugs; treat cancers, etc.

2. Reduce protein leakage & protect kidneys  
  – ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) or ARBs (e.g., losartan) lower glomerular pressure and proteinuria.  
  – SGLT-2 inhibitors (empagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are increasingly used in diabetic and non-diabetic kidney disease.

3. Manage edema (swelling)  
  – Salt-restricted diet (2 g sodium or less per day)  
  – Diuretics: furosemide, torsemide; sometimes combined with spironolactone or thiazides.  
  – Careful fluid balance; severe cases may need IV albumin followed by diuretics.

4. Control cholesterol & clot risk  
  – Statins or other lipid-lowering drugs;  
  – Low-dose aspirin or anticoagulation if clot risk is high (e.g., very low albumin).  

5. Prevent infection & bone loss  
  – Vaccinations (pneumococcal, influenza, hepatitis B) especially if on steroids or immunosuppressants.  
  – Vitamin D and calcium if long-term steroids used.

6. Lifestyle & monitoring  
  – Healthy weight, exercise within limits of edema/fatigue.  
  – Regular follow-up with a nephrologist: blood pressure, urine protein, kidney function (eGFR/creatinine).

--------------------------------------------------
WHEN TO SEEK CARE
--------------------------------------------------
Call a doctor promptly if you notice:  
• Sudden or worsening swelling, weight gain >4–5 lbs in a

<gold_response>
What causes Nephrotic syndrome?: Nephrotic syndrome is caused by different disorders that damage the kidneys. This damage leads to the release of too much protein in the urine. The most common cause in children is minimal change disease. Membranous glomerulonephritis is the most common cause in adults.In both diseases, the glomeruli in the kidneys are damaged. Glomeruli are the structures that help filter wastes and fluids. This condition can also occur from: - Cancer - Diseases such as diabetes, systemic lupus erythematosus, multiple myeloma, and amyloidosis - Genetic disorders - Immune disorders - Infections (such as strep throat, hepatitis, or mononucleosis) - Use of certain drugs It can occur with kidney disorders such as: - Focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis - Glomerulonephritis - Mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis Nephrotic syndrome can affect all age groups. In children, it is most common between ages 2 and 6. This disorder occurs slightly more often in males than females.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Congenital night-blindness (more precisely “congenital stationary night-blindness” or CSNB) is present from birth; it is not something that develops later in life. You usually find out in one of two ways:

1. Everyday clues (often noticed in infancy or early childhood)
   • The child seems perfectly sighted in daylight but bumps into objects, hesitates, or becomes fearful when the lights are low, at dusk, or in dimly lit rooms.  
   • Parents may notice that the baby does not track toys in a darkened nursery or cries when the lights are turned off.  
   • Older children avoid night games, complain they “can’t see in the dark,” need a flashlight to move around the house, or have difficulty seeing the board in a darkened classroom.

2. Eye-doctor evaluation
   • Routine pediatric or school-vision screening may detect high myopia, nystagmus, or strabismus that often accompany CSNB and prompt referral.  
   • An ophthalmologist performs a full eye exam, then confirms the diagnosis with an electroretinogram (ERG). In CSNB, the rod response on ERG is markedly reduced or absent even though the retina otherwise looks normal.  
   • If several family members are affected, a pattern of inheritance (X-linked, autosomal dominant, or autosomal recessive) may also tip off the diagnosis. Genetic testing can identify the exact gene mutation.

In short, you “know” you have congenital night blindness as soon as someone recognizes the lifelong difficulty seeing in dim light and an eye-care professional confirms it—usually in early childhood, occasionally later if the symptoms were mild or overlooked.

When and how do you know when you have congenital night blindness?
</question>

The response will be provided in these tags:
<response>
Congenital night-blindness (more precisely “congenital stationary night-blindness” or CSNB) is present from birth; it is not something that develops later in life. You usually find out in one of two ways:

1. Everyday clues (often noticed in infancy or early childhood)
   • The child seems perfectly sighted in daylight but bumps into objects, hesitates, or becomes fearful when the lights are low, at dusk, or in dimly lit rooms.  
   • Parents may notice that the baby does not track toys in a darkened nursery or cries when the lights are turned off.  
   • Older children avoid night games, complain they “can’t see in the dark,” need a flashlight to move around the house, or have difficulty seeing the board in a darkened classroom.

2. Eye-doctor evaluation
   • Routine pediatric or school-vision screening may detect high myopia, nystagmus, or strabismus that often accompany CSNB and prompt referral.  
   • An ophthalmologist performs a full eye exam, then confirms the diagnosis with an electroretinogram (ERG). In CSNB, the rod response on ERG is markedly reduced or absent even though the retina otherwise looks normal.  
   • If several family members are affected, a pattern of inheritance (X-linked, autosomal dominant, or autosomal recessive) may also tip off the diagnosis. Genetic testing can identify the exact gene mutation.

In short, you “know” you have congenital night blindness as soon as someone recognizes the lifelong difficulty seeing in dim light and an eye-care professional confirms it—usually in early childhood, occasionally later if the symptoms were mild or overlooked.
</response>

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness: Autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness is a disorder of the retina, which is the specialized tissue at the back of the eye that detects light and color. People with this condition typically have difficulty seeing and distinguishing objects in low light (night blindness). For example, they may not be able to identify road signs at night or see stars in the night sky. They also often have other vision problems, including loss of sharpness (reduced acuity), nearsightedness (myopia), involuntary movements of the eyes (nystagmus), and eyes that do not look in the same direction (strabismus). The vision problems associated with this condition are congenital, which means they are present from birth. They tend to remain stable (stationary) over time. Autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness is likely a rare disease; however, its prevalence is unknown. Mutations in several genes can cause autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness. Each of these genes provide instructions for making proteins that are found in the retina. These proteins are involved in sending (transmitting) visual signals from cells called rods, which are specialized for vision in low light, to cells called bipolar cells, which relay the signals to other retinal cells. This signaling is an essential step in the transmission of visual information from the eyes to the brain. Mutations in two genes, GRM6 and TRPM1, cause most cases of this condition. These genes provide instructions for making proteins that are necessary for bipolar cells to receive and relay signals. Mutations in other genes involved in the same bipolar cell signaling pathway are likely responsible for a small percentage of cases of autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness. Gene mutations that cause autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness disrupt the transmission of visual signals between rod cells and bipolar cells or interfere with the bipolar cells' ability to pass on these signals. As a result, visual information received by rod cells cannot be effectively transmitted to the brain, leading to difficulty seeing in low light. The cause of the other vision problems associated with this condition is unclear. It has been suggested that the mechanisms that underlie night blindness can interfere with other visual systems, causing myopia, reduced visual acuity, and other impairments. Some people with autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness have no identified mutation in any of the known genes. The cause of the disorder in these individuals is unknown. This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations. The parents of an individual with an autosomal recessive condition each carry one copy of the mutated gene, but they typically do not show signs and symptoms of the condition. predicted_text:
Nerium oleander (often just called “oleander”) contains several potent cardiac-glycosides (mainly oleandrin and neriine).  Even small doses can cause poisoning, but the amount that actually has to reach the mouth and be swallowed is much larger than what most people get from briefly handling the plant and then eating finger food.

1. How quickly do symptoms start?
• Most published case reports describe the first symptoms appearing 30 minutes to 4 hours after the toxin is swallowed.
• Occasionally the onset is delayed up to 24 hours, especially if only a very small amount was ingested.
• If no symptoms have appeared by 24 hours, clinically significant poisoning is very unlikely.

2. What symptoms and how severe?
It depends almost entirely on the dose.  From the small residue that would remain on your fingertips after briefly touching the inner stem, the possibilities are:

Likely (if anything occurs at all):
• Mild stomach upset: nausea, a single episode of vomiting, stomach cramps, or loose stool.
• Mild mouth or throat irritation or a “soapy/bitter” taste.

Possible but uncommon with trace exposure:
• More persistent vomiting or diarrhea
• Dizziness, headache
• Slow pulse (bradycardia) or an irregular heartbeat that you might feel as palpitations

Serious toxicity (life-threatening arrhythmias, severe vomiting, confusion, collapse) is extremely unlikely unless you actually chew and swallow leaf, stem, or flower material, or drink a tea made from the plant.

3. What to do now?
• Wash hands and rinse the mouth if not done already.
• Monitor for any nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dizziness, vision changes, or awareness of a very slow/irregular heartbeat during the next 24 hours.
• If ANY concerning symptom appears, or if you are pregnant, have heart disease, or have kidney problems, call Poison Control immediately (U.S. 1-800-222-1222) or seek medical care.
• If the person becomes very drowsy, collapses, has trouble breathing, or develops a very slow or irregular pulse, call emergency services (911 in the U.S.).

Bottom line:
From the scenario you describe—brief contact with the sap and then eating without washing—most people either have no symptoms or, at worst, mild, short-lived stomach upset beginning within a few hours.  Severe oleander poisoning would be exceedingly unlikely, but it is always safest to consult Poison Control or a healthcare professional if any symptoms arise or if you remain concerned.

<gold_response>
Oleander poisoning: Oleander poisoning occurs when someone eats the flowers or chews the leaves or stems of the oleander plant (Nerium oleander), or its relative, the yellow oleander (Cascabela thevetia). This article is for information only. DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual poison exposure. If you or someone you are with has an exposure, call your local emergency number (such as 911), or your local poison center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. Poisonous ingredients include: - Digitoxigenin - Neriin - Oleandrin - Oleondroside Note: This list may not include all poisonous ingredients. The poisonous substances are found in all parts of the oleander plant: - Flowers - Leaves - Stems - Twigs Oleander poisoning can affect many parts of the body. HEART AND BLOOD - Irregular or slow heartbeat - Low blood pressure - Weakness EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT - Blurred vision - Vision disturbances, including halos STOMACH AND INTESTINES - Diarrhea - Loss of appetite - Nausea and vomiting - Stomach pain NERVOUS SYSTEM - Confusion - Death - Depression - Disorientation - Dizziness - Drowsiness - Fainting - Headache - Lethargy SKIN - Hives - Rash Note: Depression, loss of appetite, and halos are most often seen in chronic overdose cases. Seek immediate medical help. DO NOT make a person throw up unless told to do so by poison control or a health care provider. Get the following information: - Person's age, weight, and condition - Name and part of the plant swallowed, if known - Time it was swallowed - Amount swallowed Your local poison center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. This hotline number will let you talk to experts in poisoning. They will give you further instructions. This is a free and confidential service. All local poison control centers in the United States use this national number. You should call if you have any questions about poisoning or poison prevention. It does not need to be an emergency. You can call for any reason, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The provider will measure and monitor the person's vital signs, including temperature, pulse, breathing rate, and blood pressure. Symptoms will be treated as appropriate. The person may receive: - Activated charcoal - Blood and urine tests - Breathing support - Chest x-ray - EKG (electrocardiogram, or heart tracing) - Fluids through a vein (IV) - Medicines to treat symptoms including an antidote to reverse the effects of the poison - Tube through the mouth into the stomach to wash out the stomach (gastric lavage) How well you do depends on the amount of poison swallowed and how quickly treatment is received. The faster you get medical help, the better the chance for recovery. Symptoms last for 1 to 3 days and may require a hospital stay. Death is unlikely. DO NOT touch or eat any plant with which you are not familiar. Wash your hands after working in the garden or walking in the woods. Updated by: Jesse Borke, MD, FACEP, FAAEM, Attending Physician at FDR Medical Services/Millard Fillmore Suburban Hospital, Buffalo, NY. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team. Editorial update 10/26/2016.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Optic atrophy (sometimes called optic nerve atrophy) means that the optic nerve—the “cable” that carries visual information from the eye to the brain—has been damaged and the nerve fibres have wasted away (“atrophy”).  It is a sign of injury to the nerve, not a single disease, and it has many possible causes.

1. Can it be genetic?  
• Yes.  There are inherited forms in which gene changes run in families.  
  – Dominant optic atrophy (often linked to the OPA1 gene) usually starts in childhood.  
  – Leber’s Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (LHON) is caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA and often affects young adult males.  
  – Optic atrophy can also occur as part of broader genetic or mitochondrial disorders (e.g., Wolfram syndrome, some peroxisomal or metabolic diseases).  
• BUT many people with optic atrophy do not have a genetic form; their optic nerve damage is acquired later in life from other conditions.

2. Other common causes (non-genetic)  
• Glaucoma (chronically raised eye pressure)  
• Previous inflammation of the optic nerve (optic neuritis) or swelling from high brain pressure (papilledema)  
• Poor blood flow to the optic nerve (ischemic optic neuropathy, stroke, severe anemia or shock)  
• Trauma to the head or orbit  
• Tumors or other masses pressing on the optic nerve or its blood supply  
• Infections (e.g., syphilis, tuberculosis) or autoimmune diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis, sarcoidosis)  
• Toxic or nutritional damage (e.g., heavy alcohol consumption, tobacco amblyopia, methanol, some medications such as ethambutol or chloroquine, vitamin B-12 deficiency)  
• Hydrocephalus or other conditions that raise intracranial pressure  
• Premature birth with severe retinopathy of prematurity

3. What you should know  
• Once optic nerve fibres are lost, the vision already lost usually cannot be restored.  The goal is to find the cause quickly, stop further damage if possible, and provide vision-rehabilitation aids.  
• An eye-care specialist (optometrist or ophthalmologist) and often a neurologist will do a full examination, blood tests, imaging (MRI/CT), and sometimes genetic testing to look for an underlying reason.  
• If a hereditary form is suspected, genetic counselling can help explain your personal risk, options for family planning, and whether other family members should be tested.

Bottom line  
Yes—some forms of optic atrophy are genetic, but many others are not.  The condition can arise from many different problems such as glaucoma, inflammation, poor blood flow, pressure on the nerve, toxins, or systemic diseases.  Finding the exact cause requires a medical evaluation, because treatment and outlook depend on the underlying problem.

<gold_response>
Optic nerve atrophy: Optic nerve atrophy is damage to the optic nerve. The optic nerve carries images of what the eye sees to the brain. There are many causes of optic atrophy. The most common is poor blood flow. This is called ischemic optic neuropathy. The problem most often affects older adults. The optic nerve can also be damaged by shock, toxins, radiation, and trauma. Eye diseases, such as glaucoma, can also cause a form of optic nerve atrophy. The condition can also be caused by diseases of the brain and central nervous system. These may include: - Brain tumor - Cranial arteritis (sometimes called temporal arteritis) - Multiple sclerosis - Stroke There are also rare forms of hereditary optic nerve atrophy that affect children and young adults. Optic nerve atrophy causes vision to dim and reduces the field of vision. The ability to see fine detail will also be lost. Colors will seem faded. Over time, the pupil will be less able to react to light, and eventually, its ability to react to light may be lost. The health care provider will do a complete eye exam to look for the condition. The exam will include tests of: - Color vision - Pupil light reflex - Tonometry - Visual acuity You may also need a complete physical exam and other tests. Damage from optic nerve atrophy cannot be reversed. The underlying disease must be found and treated. Otherwise, vision loss will continue. Rarely, conditions that lead to optic atrophy may be treatable. Vision lost to optic nerve atrophy cannot be recovered. It is very important to protect the other eye. People with this condition need to be checked regularly by an eye doctor with experience in nerve-related conditions. Tell your doctor right away about any change in vision. Many causes of optic nerve atrophy cannot be prevented. Prevention steps include: - Older adults should have their provider carefully manage their blood pressure. - Use standard safety precautions to prevent injuries to the face. Most facial injuries are the result of car accidents. Wearing seat belts may help prevent these injuries. - Schedule a routine annual eye exam to check for glaucoma. - Never drink home-brewed alcohol and forms of alcohol that are not intended for drinking. Methanol, which is found in home-brewed alcohol, can cause optic nerve atrophy in both eyes. Updated by: Franklin W. Lusby, MD, ophthalmologist, Lusby Vision Institute, La Jolla, CA. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>
