predicted_text:
Yes.  During the last 10-15 years a number of large population and clinic-based studies have looked at “pre-clinical” rheumatoid arthritis (RA).  These studies all point to the same general picture:

1.  The immune system begins to change several years before the first clearly swollen joint appears.  
   •  In blood samples that had been stored in military or public-health biobanks, researchers have found rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-citrullinated-protein antibodies (ACPA) on average 3–5 years before diagnosis and, in some people, up to 9–10 years beforehand.  
     –  Rantapää-Dahlqvist et al., 2003 (Swedish biobank): ACPA detected a mean of 4.5 years (range 1 month-9 years) before symptoms.  
     –  Nielen et al., 2004 (Dutch blood-donor study): RF and ACPA appeared a median of 3 years (range 0-14 years) before onset.  
     –  U.S. Department of Defense Serum Repository, 2010: Auto-antibodies rose as early as 5 years before clinical RA.

2.  Vague, non-specific symptoms often start months to a few years before definite arthritis.  
   •  People frequently report intermittent hand or foot stiffness on waking, general achiness, fatigue or “flu-like” feelings long before a joint actually looks swollen to a doctor.  
   •  A prospective Dutch study (van de Stadt et al., 2010) found that about half of ACPA-positive individuals without arthritis had episodic joint pain or stiffness a median of 2 years before any swelling.

3.  Once a joint first becomes visibly swollen, most clinicians call that “symptom onset,” and early-RA research typically defines “early disease” as symptoms present for ≤6 months.

4.  Age of onset.  RA most often begins between ages 30 and 60, but it can start at any adult age; a childhood counterpart (juvenile idiopathic arthritis) can start before age 16.  Therefore an individual could, in theory, experience the first subtle immune changes or mild symptoms in the teens or twenties, though this is uncommon.

What this means for the consumer
•  The very first biologic changes can occur years before you would notice anything.  
•  The first “feelable” signs (prolonged morning stiffness, symmetrical pain in the fingers, wrists, or balls of the feet, unexplained fatigue) may precede a firm diagnosis by months or even a couple of years.  
•  Because early treatment greatly improves long-term outcome, doctors now encourage anyone with persistent (>6 weeks) joint stiffness or swelling—especially in multiple small joints—to seek medical evaluation promptly.  Blood tests for RF and ACPA and an ultrasound or MRI can sometimes identify RA in this earliest, most treatable phase.

In short, research shows that detectable immune changes can be present up to a decade before obvious arthritis, and mild, non-specific joint symptoms may start months to a few years before RA is formally diagnosed.

<gold_response>
Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder that can affect more than just your joints. In some people, the condition also can damage a wide variety of body systems, including the skin, eyes, lungs, heart and blood vessels. An autoimmune disorder, rheumatoid arthritis occurs when your immune system mistakenly attacks your own body's tissues. Unlike the wear-and-tear damage of osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis affects the lining of your joints, causing a painful swelling that can eventually result in bone erosion and joint deformity. The inflammation associated with rheumatoid arthritis is what can damage other parts of the body as well. While new types of medications have improved treatment options dramatically, severe rheumatoid arthritis can still cause physical disabilities. Signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis may include: - Tender, warm, swollen joints - Joint stiffness that is usually worse in the mornings and after inactivity - Fatigue, fever and weight loss Early rheumatoid arthritis tends to affect your smaller joints first - particularly the joints that attach your fingers to your hands and your toes to your feet. As the disease progresses, symptoms often spread to the wrists, knees, ankles, elbows, hips and shoulders. In most cases, symptoms occur in the same joints on both sides of your body. About 40 percent of the people who have rheumatoid arthritis also experience signs and symptoms that don't involve the joints. Rheumatoid arthritis can affect many nonjoint structures, including: - Skin - Eyes - Lungs - Heart - Kidneys - Salivary glands - Nerve tissue - Bone marrow - Blood vessels Rheumatoid arthritis signs and symptoms may vary in severity and may even come and go. Periods of increased disease activity, called flares, alternate with periods of relative remission - when the swelling and pain fade or disappear. Over time, rheumatoid arthritis can cause joints to deform and shift out of place. Make an appointment with your doctor if you have persistent discomfort and swelling in your joints. Rheumatoid arthritis occurs when your immune system attacks the synovium - the lining of the membranes that surround your joints. The resulting inflammation thickens the synovium, which can eventually destroy the cartilage and bone within the joint. The tendons and ligaments that hold the joint together weaken and stretch. Gradually, the joint loses its shape and alignment. Doctors don't know what starts this process, although a genetic component appears likely. While your genes don't actually cause rheumatoid arthritis, they can make you more susceptible to environmental factors - such as infection with certain viruses and bacteria - that may trigger the disease. Factors that may increase your risk of rheumatoid arthritis include: - Your sex. Women are more likely than men to develop rheumatoid arthritis. - Age. Rheumatoid arthritis can occur at any age, but it most commonly begins between the ages of 40 and 60. - Family history. If a member of your family has rheumatoid arthritis, you may have an increased risk of the disease. - Smoking. Cigarette smoking increases your risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis, particularly if you have a genetic predisposition for developing the disease. Smoking also appears to be associated with greater disease severity. - Environmental exposures. Although uncertain and poorly understood, some exposures such as asbestos or silica may increase the risk for developing rheumatoid arthritis. Emergency workers exposed to dust from the collapse of the World Trade Center are at higher risk of autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. - Obesity. People who are overweight or obese appear to be at somewhat higher risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis, especially in women diagnosed with the disease when they were 55 or younger. Rheumatoid arthritis can be difficult to diagnose in its early stages because the early signs and symptoms mimic those of many other diseases. There is no one blood test or physical finding to confirm the diagnosis. During the physical exam, your doctor will check your joints for swelling, redness and warmth. He or she may also check your reflexes and muscle strength. Blood tests People with rheumatoid arthritis often have an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR, or sed rate) or C-reactive protein (CRP), which may indicate the presence of an inflammatory process in the body. Other common blood tests look for rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. Imaging tests Your doctor may recommend X-rays to help track the progression of rheumatoid arthritis in your joints over time. MRI and ultrasound tests can help your doctor judge the severity of the disease in your body. There is no cure for rheumatoid arthritis. But recent discoveries indicate that remission of symptoms is more likely when treatment begins early with strong medications known as disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). Medications The types of medications recommended by your doctor will depend on the severity of your symptoms and how long you've had rheumatoid arthritis. - NSAIDs. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can relieve pain and reduce inflammation. Over-the-counter NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB) and naproxen sodium (Aleve). Stronger NSAIDs are available by prescription. Side effects may include ringing in your ears, stomach irritation, heart problems, and liver and kidney damage. - Steroids. Corticosteroid medications, such as prednisone, reduce inflammation and pain and slow joint damage. Side effects may include thinning of bones, weight gain and diabetes. Doctors often prescribe a corticosteroid to relieve acute symptoms, with the goal of gradually tapering off the medication. - Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). These drugs can slow the progression of rheumatoid arthritis and save the joints and other tissues from permanent damage. Common DMARDs include methotrexate (Trexall, Otrexup, Rasuvo), leflunomide (Arava), hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil) and sulfasalazine (Azulfidine). Side effects vary but may include liver damage, bone marrow suppression and severe lung infections. - Biologic agents. Also known as biologic response modifiers, this newer class of DMARDs includes abatacept (Orencia), adalimumab (Humira), anakinra (Kineret), certolizumab (Cimzia), etanercept (Enbrel), golimumab (Simponi), infliximab (Remicade), rituximab (Rituxan), tocilizumab (Actemra) and tofacitinib (Xeljanz). These drugs can target parts of the immune system that trigger inflammation that causes joint and tissue damage. These types of drugs also increase the risk of infections. Biologic DMARDs are usually most effective when paired with a nonbiologic DMARD, such as methotrexate. Therapy Your doctor may send you to a physical or occupational therapist who can teach you exercises to help keep your joints flexible. The therapist may also suggest new ways to do daily tasks, which will be easier on your joints. For example, if your fingers are sore, you may want to pick up an object using your forearms. Assistive devices can make it easier to avoid stressing your painful joints. For instance, a kitchen knife equipped with a saw handle helps protect your finger and wrist joints. Certain tools, such as buttonhooks, can make it easier to get dressed. Catalogs and medical supply stores are good places to look for ideas. Surgery If medications fail to prevent or slow joint damage, you and your doctor may consider surgery to repair damaged joints. Surgery may help restore your ability to use your joint. It can also reduce pain and correct deformities. Rheumatoid arthritis surgery may involve one or more of the following procedures: - Synovectomy. Surgery to remove the inflamed synovium (lining of the joint). Synovectomy can be performed on knees, elbows, wrists, fingers and hips. - Tendon repair. Inflammation and joint damage may cause tendons around your joint to loosen or rupture. Your surgeon may be able to repair the tendons around your joint. - Joint fusion. Surgically fusing a joint may be recommended to stabilize or realign a joint and for pain relief when a joint replacement isn't an option. - Total joint replacement. During joint replacement surgery, your surgeon removes the damaged parts of your joint and inserts a prosthesis made of metal and plastic. Surgery carries a risk of bleeding, infection and pain. Discuss the benefits and risks with your doctor. You can take steps to care for your body if you have rheumatoid arthritis. These self-care measures, when used along with your rheumatoid arthritis medications, can help you manage your signs and symptoms: - Exercise regularly. Gentle exercise can help strengthen the muscles around your joints, and it can help fight fatigue you might feel. Check with your doctor before you start exercising. If you're just getting started, begin by taking a walk. Try swimming or gentle water aerobics. Avoid exercising tender, injured or severely inflamed joints. - Apply heat or cold. Heat can help ease your pain and relax tense, painful muscles. Cold may dull the sensation of pain. Cold also has a numbing effect and decreases muscle spasms. - Relax. Find ways to cope with pain by reducing stress in your life. Techniques such as guided imagery, distraction and muscle relaxation can all be used to control pain. Some common complementary and alternative treatments that have shown promise for rheumatoid arthritis include: - Fish oil. Some preliminary studies have found that fish oil supplements may reduce rheumatoid arthritis pain and stiffness. Side effects can include nausea, belching and a fishy taste in the mouth. Fish oil can interfere with medications, so check with your doctor first. - Plant oils. The seeds of evening primrose, borage and black currant contain a type of fatty acid that may help with rheumatoid arthritis pain and morning stiffness. Side effects may include nausea, diarrhea and gas. Some plant oils can cause liver damage or interfere with medications, so check with your doctor first. - Tai chi. This movement therapy involves gentle exercises and stretches combined with deep breathing. Many people use tai chi to relieve stress in their lives. Small studies have found that tai chi may reduce rheumatoid arthritis pain. When led by a knowledgeable instructor, tai chi is safe. But don't do any moves that cause pain.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is not a single-gene, “you-either-get-it-or-you-don’t” disorder that is passed from parent to child the way conditions such as cystic fibrosis or sickle-cell disease are.  What research shows so far is:

1.  PCOS tends to run in families  
   •  If a mother, sister, or close female relative has PCOS, the chance of another woman in the family developing it is higher than in the general population.  
   •  This pattern suggests an inherited (genetic) susceptibility, but there is no single gene responsible.  Instead, several genes that influence how the body handles insulin and makes male-type hormones (androgens) appear to work together.

2.  Genes alone are not the whole story  
   •  Many women with a family history never develop PCOS, and some women with no known family history do.  
   •  Factors that can “tip the balance” include insulin resistance, weight gain, inactivity, diet, and possibly exposures inside the womb (such as high maternal blood sugar or androgen levels during pregnancy).

3.  PCOS cannot be “caught” like an infection, and it is not caused by contraception, an injury, or anything a woman “did wrong.”  
   •  It is a complex hormonal and metabolic condition that develops when genetic tendency meets environmental/lifestyle factors.

Bottom line  
•  A genetic predisposition can be passed from parents, but having the genes does not guarantee PCOS.  
•  Lifestyle factors (weight, physical activity, diet), insulin resistance, and other hormonal influences can determine whether and how severely PCOS shows up.

predicted_text:
I’m glad you asked, because the information you find on-line about polymicrogyria (PMG) ranges from very mild cases to extremely severe ones and that can be frightening.  A few key points may help put your son’s situation in perspective and guide you toward what you can do now.

1. What polymicrogyria is  
• PMG is a malformation of the cerebral cortex that occurs while the baby is still developing in the womb.  
• The surface of the brain ends up with many unusually small folds (“poly-micro-gyria”) and the normal six-layer structure of the cortex is partly disrupted.  
• Once that area of brain is formed this way, it does not “grow back” into a typical cortex. In other words, PMG itself does not disappear with time.

2. Why outcomes are so different from child to child  
• The brain is large and highly specialized; PMG might involve a tiny area on one side or large areas on both sides.  
• Location matters. If the lesion is in the area that controls movement of the legs, gross-motor delay is common; if it is near the speech centers, language may be affected; if it is widespread, global delays and epilepsy are more likely.  
• Some children have additional genetic or medical issues that compound the problem; others do not.

3. What “cannot change” vs. what “can improve”  
• The physical malformation itself will remain visible on MRI.  
• However, the developing brain is remarkably adaptable (neuroplasticity). Other, unaffected areas can learn to take over some functions, and existing pathways can be strengthened with use and therapy.  
• Because your son is still very young, his brain is in its most plastic period. The gains you are already seeing in reaching and grasping show that change is possible even though the MRI will not change.

4. Typical concerns in PMG and what to watch for  
• Motor delays: sitting, crawling, walking.  
• Speech and language delays.  
• Seizures (they can begin months or even years after diagnosis).  
• Feeding/swallowing difficulties in some children.  

5. What helps  
Early, intensive, goal-directed therapies:
• Physical therapy – to build core strength, balance and transitions (sitting, crawling, walking).  
• Occupational therapy – fine-motor skills, self-care (feeding, dressing), sensory integration.  
• Speech-language therapy – communication and, if needed, oral-motor skills for feeding.  
• Developmental follow-up clinics – they coordinate services and monitor progress.  
For many families, Early Intervention (Part C) services in the United States or similar publicly funded programs elsewhere can provide these therapies at no or low cost.

6. Prognosis in everyday terms  
• Many children with limited-area PMG eventually walk, talk, and attend mainstream schools, sometimes with accommodations.  
• Others have moderate to severe disabilities.  
• There is no reliable way to predict precisely at 16 months how far a particular child will go, but steady progress with therapy, absence of seizures, and a small or unilateral lesion are favorable signs.

7. Practical next steps for you

1. What polymicrogyria is  
• PMG is a malformation of the cerebral cortex that occurs while the baby is still developing in the womb.  
• The surface of the brain ends up with many unusually small folds (“poly-micro-gyria”) and the normal six-layer structure of the cortex is partly disrupted.  
• Once that area of brain is formed this way, it does not “grow back” into a typical cortex. In other words, PMG itself does not disappear with time.

2. Why outcomes are so different from child to child  
• The brain is large and highly specialized; PMG might involve a tiny area on one side or large areas on both sides.  
• Location matters. If the lesion is in the area that controls movement of the legs, gross-motor delay is common; if it is near the speech centers, language may be affected; if it is widespread, global delays and epilepsy are more likely.  
• Some children have additional genetic or medical issues that compound the problem; others do not.

3. What “cannot change” vs. what “can improve”  
• The physical malformation itself will remain visible on MRI.  
• However, the developing brain is remarkably adaptable (neuroplasticity). Other, unaffected areas can learn to take over some functions, and existing pathways can be strengthened with use and therapy.  
• Because your son is still very young, his brain is in its most plastic period. The gains you are already seeing in reaching and grasping show that change is possible even though the MRI will not change.

4. Typical concerns in PMG and what to watch for  
• Motor delays: sitting, crawling, walking.  
• Speech and language delays.  
• Seizures (they can begin months or even years after diagnosis).  
• Feeding/swallowing difficulties in some children.  

5. What helps  
Early, intensive, goal-directed therapies:
• Physical therapy – to build core strength, balance and transitions (sitting, crawling, walking).  
• Occupational therapy – fine-motor skills, self-care (feeding, dressing), sensory integration.  
• Speech-language therapy – communication and, if needed, oral-motor skills for feeding.  
• Developmental follow-up clinics – they coordinate services and monitor progress.  
For many families, Early Intervention (Part C) services in the United States or similar publicly funded programs elsewhere can provide these therapies at no or low cost.

6. Prognosis in everyday terms  
• Many children with limited-area PMG eventually walk, talk, and attend mainstream schools, sometimes with accommodations.  
• Others have moderate to severe disabilities.  
• There is no reliable way to predict precisely at 16 months how far a particular child will go, but steady progress with therapy, absence of seizures, and a small or unilateral lesion are favorable signs.

Polymicrogyria: Polymicrogyria is a condition characterized by abnormal development of the brain before birth. Specifically, the surface of the brain develops too many folds which are unusually small. The signs and symptoms associated with the condition vary based on how much of the brain and which areas of the brain are affected; however, affected people may experience recurrent seizures ( epilepsy ); delayed development; crossed eyes ; problems with speech and swallowing; and muscle weakness or paralysis. Bilateral forms (affecting both sides of the brain) tend to cause more severe neurological problems. Polymicrogyria can result from both genetic and environmental causes. It may occur as an isolated finding or as part of a syndrome . Treatment is based on the signs and symptoms present in each person. [1] [2] A wide variety of symptoms may be observed in people with polymicrogyria, depending on the areas of the brain implicated and whether or not it is part of a larger syndrome . Signs and symptoms may include: [3] [4] Developmental delay Crossed eyes Epilepsy Paralysis of the face, throat, and tongue Difficulty with speech and swallowing Drooling The diagnosis of polymicrogyria is made by imaging brain structures using  MRI . Typical findings include areas of the  cerebral cortex with a complex set of small gyri that appear fused to each other and separated by shallow sulci. These findings may be isolated to one side of the brain (unilateral) or may involve both sides of the brain (bilateral). [3] [4] The resources below provide information about treatment options for this condition. If you have questions about which treatment is right for you, talk to your healthcare professional. Management Guidelines GeneReviews provides current, expert-authored, peer-reviewed, full-text articles describing the application of genetic testing to the diagnosis, management, and genetic counseling of patients with specific inherited conditions. The following diseases are related to Polymicrogyria. If you have a question about any of these diseases, you can contact GARD. Bilateral frontal polymicrogyria Bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria Bilateral generalized polymicrogyria Bilateral parasagittal parieto-occipital polymicrogyria Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria
</gold_response>

Unfortunately, there is still no guaranteed way to keep pre-eclampsia from developing, because the exact “trigger” is not yet known.  What most experts agree on, however, is that certain measures can lower a woman’s risk and, just as important, allow the condition to be found and treated early enough to protect both mother and baby.

Below is a summary of strategies that have the best evidence or strongest professional-society support.  They are grouped into three categories:

1. General lifestyle and pregnancy-planning steps  
2. Medical measures for women at higher-than-average risk  
3. Ongoing prenatal surveillance

────────────────────────
1. General lifestyle and pregnancy-planning steps
────────────────────────
• Enter pregnancy as healthy as possible  
  – Attain a healthy body-mass index before conception; even a 5-10 % weight reduction in an overweight woman lowers risk.  
  – Get chronic conditions (high blood pressure, diabetes, kidney disease, lupus, etc.) well-controlled before conceiving and keep them controlled during pregnancy.

• Don’t smoke and avoid second-hand smoke.

• Exercise regularly (moderate, pregnancy-approved activity such as walking, swimming or prenatal yoga 20–30 min on most days).  Regular activity improves vascular function and reduces excessive weight gain—both tied to pre-eclampsia risk.

• Eat a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein, and dairy or other calcium sources.  Good dietary calcium seems particularly helpful in women whose baseline calcium intake is low.

• Space pregnancies at least 12 months apart and, ideally, less than 10 years apart.  Very short or very long inter-pregnancy intervals are associated with higher rates of pre-eclampsia.

────────────────────────
2. Medical measures for women at higher-than-average risk
────────────────────────
Certain interventions are recommended only for women with specific risk factors.  Discuss these options with your obstetric provider before 12–16 weeks’ gestation (the timeframe when the benefits are clearest).

• Low-dose aspirin (81 mg in the United States; 75–150 mg elsewhere)  
  – Who benefits: women with any “high-risk” factor (prior pre-eclampsia, multiple gestation, chronic hypertension, diabetes, kidney disease, autoimmune disease) or ≥2 “moderate-risk” factors (first pregnancy, age ≥35, BMI ≥30, family history of pre-eclampsia, Black race, low socioeconomic status, pregnancy from assisted reproduction).  
  – How to use: begin daily at 12–16 weeks, continue until delivery (or at least 36 weeks).  Meta-analysis shows a 10-25 % relative risk reduction.

• Calcium supplementation (1,000–1,500 mg elemental calcium per day)  
  – Recommended for women who habitually ingest <600 mg/day of dietary calcium (common where dairy intake is low).  
  – Shown to decrease pre-eclampsia by up to 50 % in this subgroup.

• Treat chronic hypertension, ideally with pregnancy-safe medications such as labetalol, nifedipine, or methyldopa if blood pressure exceeds target.

• Optimize glucose control in pre-existing or gestational diabetes.

• In certain autoimmune disorders (e.g., antiphospholipid syndrome), low-dose aspirin PLUS prophylactic heparin is sometimes prescribed.

Interventions that are NOT presently recommended for routine prevention  
• Routine high-dose vitamins C or E, fish-oil supplements, or bed rest have not proven helpful.  
• Limiting salt intake more than is typical for a healthy pregnancy has not shown benefit and may be harmful.  
• Neither progesterone supplements nor diuretics prevent pre-eclampsia.

────────────────────────
3. Ongoing prenatal surveillance (early detection saves lives)
────────────────────────
Because pre-eclampsia can still occur in women who follow every preventive step, regular prenatal care remains the cornerstone of protection.

• Keep every prenatal appointment; accurate blood-pressure checks and urine protein tests are essential.

• Learn the warning signs and call promptly if they appear:  
  – Persistent headache, visual changes (spots, flashes, blurring)  
  – Sudden swelling of face or hands  
  – Rapid weight gain (>2 lbs in a day or >5 lbs in a week)  
  – Pain under the right ribs, nausea/vomiting after mid-pregnancy  
  – Shortness of breath, chest pain, decreased fetal movement

• If you are at increased risk, your provider may add:  
  – More frequent blood-pressure checks (home or office)  
  – Baseline and follow-up lab work (kidney and liver function, platelets)  
  – Uterine artery Doppler ultrasound around 20–24 weeks to look for abnormal blood flow  
  – Fetal growth ultrasounds in the third trimester

Key takeaway
No single step can completely prevent pre-e

Below are brief, plain-language answers to each of the questions you listed.  Where numbers are given (survival rates, etc.) they are U.S. figures from the American Cancer Society or Leukemia & Lymphoma Society unless noted otherwise, and refer to people who receive modern treatment.

1.  What causes leukemia?  
   • Leukemia starts when a single blood-forming cell (in the bone marrow) acquires changes (mutations) in its DNA that let it grow out of control.  
   • Most of the time we never know exactly why that mutation occurred, but known risk factors include:  
        – High-dose ionizing radiation (for example, survivors of atomic-bomb blasts or some radiation therapy).  
        – Long-term exposure to certain chemicals such as benzene.  
        – Previous chemotherapy for another cancer.  
        – Cigarette smoke (mainly for AML).  
        – Certain viruses (HTLV-1 for a rare form of leukemia).  
        – Some inherited conditions that make DNA repair harder (e.g., Down syndrome, Fanconi anemia, Li-Fraumeni).  
   • For the vast majority of patients leukemia is not something they “did wrong,” and in most cases no clear cause is ever found.

2.  Can you survive leukemia?  
   Yes.  Survival depends on the exact type of leukemia, the patient’s age, and how well the disease responds to treatment.  Examples:  
   • Childhood ALL (acute lymphoblastic leukemia): >90 % of children are cured.  
   • CML (chronic myeloid leukemia): With daily targeted pills (TKIs), life expectancy is now close to normal.  
   • Adult AML (acute myeloid leukemia): Roughly 25-30 % of adults under 60 are long-term survivors; cure rates are lower in older adults, but new drugs are improving these numbers.

3.  How does leukemia affect your body?  
   • Bone marrow fills up with abnormal (leukemic) white cells.  
   • Normal blood-cell production is crowded out, leading to:  
        – Anemia (low red cells) → fatigue, shortness of breath, pale skin.  
        – Neutropenia (low infection-fighting white cells) → frequent or severe infections.  
        – Thrombocytopenia (low platelets) → easy bruising, nosebleeds, bleeding gums.  
   • Leukemic cells can also collect in lymph nodes, spleen, liver, skin, gums or the brain/spinal fluid, causing swelling, pain, or neurologic symptoms.

4.  Is leukemia inherited?  
   • Most leukemias are NOT directly inherited.  
   • However, some people inherit genetic syndromes that raise the risk of getting leukemia (see list in Q 1). Families may share environmental exposures as well.

5.  What is “advanced” leukemia?  
   The term is informal and usually means:  
   • A leukemia that has come back after treatment (relapsed) or is no longer responding to therapy (refractory).  
   • A very high leukemia-cell burden that is starting to damage organs.  
   • In chronic leukemias (CML/CLL) it may mean the disease has converted to an “accelerated” or “blast crisis” phase that behaves like an acute leukemia.

6.  How long can someone with leukemia expect to live?  
   There is no single number.  Without treatment, aggressive (acute) leukemias can be fatal within weeks to months. With modern therapy:  
   • Many children with ALL are cured for life.  
   • Adults with CML taking tyrosine kinase inhibitors have a 10-year survival >85 % and can live decades.  
   • Adults with AML who go into a good remission after chemo or transplant may be long-term survivors; others may live months to a few years.  
   • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) often behaves like a long-term condition; some people never need treatment.

7.  Can you tell if you have leukemia?  
   Not reliably by how you feel alone.  Symptoms such as fatigue, frequent infections or bruising are common to many illnesses.  Diagnosis requires:  
   • A complete blood count (CBC) looking for too many or too few blood cells.  
   • A bone-marrow biopsy to see abnormal cells.  
   • Chromosome or molecular tests to classify the exact type.

8.  What treatments do you need to take?  
   Depends on the type:  
   • Acute leukemias (ALL, AML): Combination chemotherapy given in cycles; sometimes high-dose chemo followed by a stem-cell (bone-marrow) transplant; newer drugs include antibody-based and CAR-T therapies.  
   • CML: Daily oral targeted drugs called tyrosine kinase inhibitors (imatinib,

How does leukemia affect your body?4. Is leukemia inherited?5. What is advanced leukemia?6. How long can someone with leukemia expect to live?7. Can you tell if you have leukemia?8. What treatments do you need to take?9. What are the signs of leukemia?10. What is the difference between AML and CML ?
</question>

<response>
Below are brief, plain-language answers to each of the questions you listed.  Where numbers are given (survival rates, etc.) they are U.S. figures from the American Cancer Society or Leukemia & Lymphoma Society unless noted otherwise, and refer to people who receive modern treatment.

1.  What causes leukemia?  
   • Leukemia starts when a single blood-forming cell (in the bone marrow) acquires changes (mutations) in its DNA that let it grow out of control.  
   • Most of the time we never know exactly why that mutation occurred, but known risk factors include:  
        – High-dose ionizing radiation (for example, survivors of atomic-bomb blasts or some radiation therapy).  
        – Long-term exposure to certain chemicals such as benzene.  
        – Previous chemotherapy for another cancer.  
        – Cigarette smoke (mainly for AML).  
        – Certain viruses (HTLV-1 for a rare form of leukemia).  
        – Some inherited conditions that make DNA repair harder (e.g., Down syndrome, Fanconi anemia, Li-Fraumeni).  
   • For the vast majority of patients leukemia is not something they “did wrong,” and in most cases no clear cause is ever found.

2.  Can you survive leukemia?  
   Yes.  Survival depends on the exact type of leukemia, the patient’s age, and how well the disease responds to treatment.  Examples:  
   • Childhood ALL (acute lymphoblastic leukemia): >90 % of children are cured.  
   • CML (chronic myeloid leukemia): With daily targeted pills (TKIs), life expectancy is now close to normal.  
   • Adult AML (acute myeloid leukemia): Roughly 25-30 % of adults under 60 are long-term survivors; cure rates are lower in older adults, but new drugs are improving these numbers.

3.  How does leukemia affect your body?  
   • Bone marrow fills up with abnormal (leukemic) white cells.  
   • Normal blood-cell production is crowded out, leading to:  
        – Anemia (low red cells) → fatigue, shortness of breath, pale skin.  
        – Neutropenia (low infection-fighting white cells) → frequent or severe infections.  
        – Thrombocytopenia (low platelets) → easy bruising, nosebleeds, bleeding gums.  
   • Leukemic cells can also collect in lymph nodes, spleen, liver, skin, gums or the brain/spinal fluid, causing swelling, pain, or neurologic symptoms.

4.  Is leukemia inherited?  
   • Most leukemias are NOT directly inherited.  
   • However, some people inherit genetic syndromes that raise the risk of getting leukemia (see list in Q 1). Families may share environmental exposures as well.

5.  What is “advanced” leukemia?  
   The term is informal and usually means:  
   • A leukemia that has come back after treatment (relapsed) or is no longer responding to therapy (refractory).  
   • A very high leukemia-cell burden that is starting to damage organs.  
   • In chronic leukemias (CML/CLL) it may mean the disease has converted to an “accelerated” or “blast crisis” phase that behaves like an acute leukemia.

6.  How long can someone with leukemia expect to live?  
   There is no single number.  Without treatment, aggressive (acute) leukemias can be fatal within weeks to months. With modern therapy:  
   • Many children with ALL are cured for life.  
   • Adults with CML taking tyrosine kinase inhibitors have a 10-year survival >85 % and can live decades.  
   • Adults with AML who go into a good remission after chemo or transplant may be long-term survivors; others may live months to a few years.  
   • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) often behaves like a long-term condition; some people never need treatment.

7.  Can you tell if you have leukemia?  
   Not reliably by how you feel alone.  Symptoms such as fatigue, frequent infections or bruising are common to many illnesses.  Diagnosis requires:  
   • A complete blood count (CBC) looking for too many or too few blood cells.  
   • A bone-marrow biopsy to see abnormal cells.  
   • Chromosome or molecular tests to classify the exact type.

8.  What treatments do you need to take?  
   Depends on the type:  
   • Acute leukemias (ALL, AML): Combination chemotherapy given in cycles; sometimes high-dose chemo followed by a stem-cell (bone-marrow) transplant; newer drugs include antibody-based and CAR-T therapies.  
   • CML: Daily oral targeted drugs called tyrosine kinase inhibitors (imatinib,
</response>

<gold_response>
Leukemia (Treatment): Treatment for your leukemia depends on many factors. Your doctor determines your leukemia treatment options based on your age and overall health, the type of leukemia you have, and whether it has spread to other parts of your body, including the central nervous system. Common treatments used to fight leukemia include: - Chemotherapy. Chemotherapy is the major form of treatment for leukemia. This drug treatment uses chemicals to kill leukemia cells. Depending on the type of leukemia you have, you may receive a single drug or a combination of drugs. These drugs may come in a pill form, or they may be injected directly into a vein. - Biological therapy. Biological therapy works by using treatments that help your immune system recognize and attack leukemia cells. - Targeted therapy. Targeted therapy uses drugs that attack specific vulnerabilities within your cancer cells. For example, the drug imatinib (Gleevec) stops the action of a protein within the leukemia cells of people with chronic myelogenous leukemia. This can help control the disease. - Radiation therapy. Radiation therapy uses X-rays or other high-energy beams to damage leukemia cells and stop their growth. During radiation therapy, you lie on a table while a large machine moves around you, directing the radiation to precise points on your body. You may receive radiation in one specific area of your body where there is a collection of leukemia cells, or you may receive radiation over your whole body. Radiation therapy may be used to prepare for a stem cell transplant. - Stem cell transplant. A stem cell transplant is a procedure to replace your diseased bone marrow with healthy bone marrow. Before a stem cell transplant, you receive high doses of chemotherapy or radiation therapy to destroy your diseased bone marrow. Then you receive an infusion of blood-forming stem cells that help to rebuild your bone marrow. You may receive stem cells from a donor, or in some cases you may be able to use your own stem cells. A stem cell transplant is very similar to a bone marrow transplant.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Scalp psoriasis can usually be improved, and in many cases kept almost clear, but it often takes TIME, CONSISTENCY and the right combination of products prescribed (or at least supervised) by a dermatologist. Because you have had symptoms for close to a decade, the safest advice is to make an appointment with a skin-specialist if you have not done so recently. The information below will help you understand the options, what usually works best, and how you can care for your scalp at home.

1. What psoriasis is – and why it matters on the scalp  
• Psoriasis is an immune-driven, lifelong tendency for skin cells to multiply too fast, forming thick, red, scaling patches.  
• On the scalp it can be hard to treat because hair blocks direct contact with medication and makes scale removal more difficult.  
• Scalp psoriasis is NOT contagious and does not cause hair loss permanently, but scratching can break hairs and worsen shedding.

2. Step-by-step treatment ladder
A dermatologist will often start with the least aggressive option that is likely to work and move up only if needed.

A. Over-the-counter (OTC) and self-care basics  
• Medicated shampoos used 2–3 times/week, alternating with a gentle everyday shampoo:  
  – Coal tar (1–5 %)  
  – Salicylic acid (2–6 %)  
  – Ketoconazole 2 % or ciclopirox 1 % (antifungal/anti-inflammatory)  
• Scale softening before shampooing: Massage in warm olive/coconut/mineral oil or over-the-counter urea 10–20 % lotion for 30 min to loosen plaques, then comb scales out gently and shampoo.  
• Moisturizers: Light leave-in scalp oils, aloe-based gels or fragrance-free lotions after washing to reduce itching.  
• Lifestyle triggers: Stop smoking, limit alcohol, manage stress (yoga, meditation, regular exercise), keep scalp cool, treat any throat infections quickly. Sunlight (in moderation, 10–15 min) often helps.

B. Prescription topicals (usually first-line for scalp psoriasis)  
• High-potency topical corticosteroids (e.g., clobetasol propionate 0.05 % solution, foam, spray, or steroid-impregnated shampoo) – used daily for 2–4 weeks, then tapered or pulsed.  
• Vitamin D analogues (calcipotriene/calcipotriol 0.005 % solution) – often combined with a steroid in a once-daily foam (betamethasone dipropionate + calcipotriene).  
• Tazarotene 0.1 % gel or foam (a topical retinoid) – usually applied at night; can irritate, so often combined with a steroid.  
• Calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus) – off-label for scalp, helpful near the hairline/ears where skin is thinner.  
Tip: Apply at night; in the morning wash with a medicated shampoo to reduce residue and odor.

C. Office-based treatments  
• Intralesional steroid injections for very thick, stubborn plaques.  
• Targeted narrow-band UV-B or excimer laser/light to small areas (if hair is thin or parted).

D. Systemic therapy – for moderate/severe psoriasis or if topical treatment fails  
• Oral: Methotrexate, cyclosporine, acitretin, apremilast.  
• Biologics (injections or infusions): Adalimumab, etanercept, ustekinumab, secukinumab, ixekizumab, guselkumab, risankizumab, tildrakizumab, bimekizumab, etc. These are highly effective but require screening for infections and regular monitoring.  
• Janus-kinase inhibitors (e.g., deucravacitinib) – an emerging oral option.  
All systemic drugs need prescription and follow-up blood tests.

3. Practical application hints  
• Part hair in rows with a comb, apply solution/foam directly to the skin, not the hair.  
• Use fingertip massage for 30 seconds per spot; let medicine dry before styling.  
• Stick to a schedule for at least 4 – 6 weeks before judging success—psoriasis plaques usually thin gradually.

4. When to see a doctor promptly  
• Severe itching interfering with sleep or work.  
• Painful cracks, bleeding, signs of infection (yellow crust, pus).  
• Psoriasis spreading beyond the scalp (elbows, knees, nails, body folds).  
• Joint pain, morning stiffness, swelling (possible psoriatic arthritis).

5. Complementary options (evidence variable but generally safe)  
• Omega-

<gold_response>
Psoriasis (Treatment): The goal of treatment is to control your symptoms and prevent infection. Three treatment options are available: - Skin lotions, ointments, creams, and shampoos. These are called topical treatments. - Pills or injections that affect the body's immune response, not just the skin. These are called systemic, or body-wide, treatments. - Phototherapy, which uses ultraviolet light to treat psoriasis. TREATMENTS USED ON THE SKIN (TOPICAL) Most of the time, psoriasis is treated with medicines that are placed directly on the skin or scalp. These may include: - Cortisone creams and ointments - Creams or ointments that contain coal tar or anthralin - Creams to remove the scaling (usually salicylic acid or lactic acid) - Dandruff shampoos (over-the-counter or prescription) - Moisturizers - Prescription medicines containing vitamin D or vitamin A (retinoids) SYSTEMIC (BODY-WIDE) TREATMENTS If you have very severe psoriasis, your provider will likely recommend medicines that suppress the immune system's faulty response. These medicines include methotrexate or cyclosporine. Retinoids can also be used. Newer drugs called biologics are used when other treatments do not work. Biologics approved for the treatment of psoriasis include: - Adalimumab (Humira) - Etanercept (Enbrel) - Infliximab (Remicade) - Ustekinumab (Stelara) - Secukinumab (Cosentyx) - Apremilast (Otezla) - Ixekizumab (Taltz) PHOTOTHERAPY Some people may choose to have phototherapy: - This is treatment in which your skin is carefully exposed to ultraviolet light. - It may be given alone or after you take a drug that makes the skin sensitive to light. - Phototherapy for psoriasis can be given as ultraviolet A (UVA) or ultraviolet B (UVB) light. OTHER TREATMENTS If you have an infection, your provider will prescribe antibiotics. HOME CARE Following these tips at home may help: - Taking a daily bath or shower. Try not to scrub too hard because this can irritate the skin and trigger an attack. - Oatmeal baths may be soothing and may help to loosen scales. You can use over-the-counter oatmeal bath products. Or, you can mix 1 cup (240 mL) of oatmeal into a tub (bath) of warm water. - Keeping your skin clean and moist, and avoiding your specific psoriasis triggers may help reduce the number of flare-ups. - Sunlight may help your symptoms go away. Be careful not to get sunburned. - Relaxation and anti-stress techniques. The link between stress and flares of psoriasis is not well understood. - Limiting the alcoholic beverages you drink may help keep psoriasis from getting worse.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Thanks for writing.  Because MS touches on complicated questions— why the immune system mis-behaves, how to repair cells that are already damaged, and how to keep the disease from returning—most specialists avoid putting a firm date on a “cure.”  What they can do, however, is point to the scientific mile-posts that would have to be reached and describe where we are now on each of those roads.

1.  What would a true “cure” look like?  
   • Stop the immune attack permanently (immune re-set).  
   • Protect the brain/spinal cord from further injury (neuro-protection).  
   • Repair or replace the myelin and nerve cells that are already lost (remyelination / regeneration).  
   A therapy that accomplished all three would not just slow MS but eliminate it and undo the harm already done.

2.  How close are we?  
   • Stopping the attack:  In the 1990s there were no disease-modifying drugs; today more than 20 are approved.  Newer B-cell–directed drugs (ocrelizumab, ofatumumab) and S1P-receptor modulators (fingolimod, ozanimod, etc.) can push relapse rates near zero for many people.  Autologous hematopoietic stem-cell transplant (AHSCT) can “re-boot” the immune system and keep 60-80 % of carefully chosen patients relapse-free for 5–10 years.  That’s not yet a cure, but it shows the immune attack can, in principle, be shut down for long stretches.  
   • Neuro-protection:  Several trials are under way with drugs that block specific injury pathways (for example, BTK-inhibitors such as evobrutinib and tolebrutinib).  Early data are encouraging, but none has yet earned FDA approval.  
   • Remyelination / regeneration:  Lab animals can now be remyelinated with cell-based or small-molecule approaches (e.g., clemastine, high-dose biotin, anti-LINGO antibody).  Human trials have shown only modest or mixed benefit so far, but the proof of concept is there.  Multiple teams are refining induced pluripotent stem cells and oligodendrocyte precursor cells that could be injected to replace lost myelin.

3.  Putting it together—how long might it take?  
   • Most researchers I speak with think it is realistic to expect a treatment that reliably “shuts off” new MS activity (step 1) within the next 5–10 years for the majority of patients.  
   • Add another decade (10–20 years from now) for an approved therapy that can also protect at-risk neurons (step 2).  
   • True, routine, clinically meaningful remyelination (step 3) may lag behind, so a full three-part “cure” could be on the order of 20 + years—so potentially within your professional lifetime if you enter medicine or neuroscience.

Those numbers are, of course, educated guesses.  Unexpected breakthroughs—or, conversely, hurdles in long-term safety—can move the finish line.

4.  Why be cautiously optimistic?  
   • MS research is unusually well-funded; it is often cited as a model for translational medicine.  
   • MRI and molecular biomarkers (e.g., serum neurofilament light chain) allow rapid, precise readouts of drug effect—speeding up trials.  
   • The basic biology of autoimmunity and remyelination is now being explored with CRISPR, single-cell RNA sequencing, and AI-guided drug screens that did not exist a decade ago.

5.  What to watch during your university years:  
   • Ongoing phase III trials of BTK inhibitors for progressive MS (evobrutinib, tolebrutinib, remibrutinib).  
   • Larger international trials of AHSCT versus best available drugs.  
   • Gene-editing or CAR-T approaches aimed at deleting autoreactive B cells.  
   • Second-generation remyelination agents (Obexelimab, anti-Semaphorin 4D, and next-gen anti-LINGO antibodies).  
   • Human oligodendrocyte‐precursor cell implants (several early-phase trials expected 2024–2026).

Bottom line  
Yes—there is a credible scientific path to an MS “cure,” and the distance to each milestone is shrinking.  Halting new disease activity may become routine within a decade; reversing existing disability may follow in the 2030s or 2040s.  Whether that will be a single therapy or a multi-step treatment remains to be seen, but the trajectory of research supports cautious optimism.

1.  What would a true “cure” look like?  
   • Stop the immune attack permanently (immune re-set).  
   • Protect the brain/spinal cord from further injury (neuro-protection).  
   • Repair or replace the myelin and nerve cells that are already lost (remyelination / regeneration).  
   A therapy that accomplished all three would not just slow MS but eliminate it and undo the harm already done.

2.  How close are we?  
   • Stopping the attack:  In the 1990s there were no disease-modifying drugs; today more than 20 are approved.  Newer B-cell–directed drugs (ocrelizumab, ofatumumab) and S1P-receptor modulators (fingolimod, ozanimod, etc.) can push relapse rates near zero for many people.  Autologous hematopoietic stem-cell transplant (AHSCT) can “re-boot” the immune system and keep 60-80 % of carefully chosen patients relapse-free for 5–10 years.  That’s not yet a cure, but it shows the immune attack can, in principle, be shut down for long stretches.  
   • Neuro-protection:  Several trials are under way with drugs that block specific injury pathways (for example, BTK-inhibitors such as evobrutinib and tolebrutinib).  Early data are encouraging, but none has yet earned FDA approval.  
   • Remyelination / regeneration:  Lab animals can now be remyelinated with cell-based or small-molecule approaches (e.g., clemastine, high-dose biotin, anti-LINGO antibody).  Human trials have shown only modest or mixed benefit so far, but the proof of concept is there.  Multiple teams are refining induced pluripotent stem cells and oligodendrocyte precursor cells that could be injected to replace lost myelin.

3.  Putting it together—how long might it take?  
   • Most researchers I speak with think it is realistic to expect a treatment that reliably “shuts off” new MS activity (step 1) within the next 5–10 years for the majority of patients.  
   • Add another decade (10–20 years from now) for an approved therapy that can also protect at-risk neurons (step 2).  
   • True, routine, clinically meaningful remyelination (step 3) may lag behind, so a full three-part “cure” could be on the order of 20 + years—so potentially within your professional lifetime if you enter medicine or neuroscience.

Those numbers are, of course, educated guesses.  Unexpected breakthroughs—or, conversely, hurdles in long-term safety—can move the finish line.

4.  Why be cautiously optimistic?  
   • MS research is unusually well-funded; it is often cited as a model for translational medicine.  
   • MRI and molecular biomarkers (e.g., serum neurofilament light chain) allow rapid, precise readouts of drug effect—speeding up trials.  
   • The basic biology of autoimmunity and remyelination is now being explored with CRISPR, single-cell RNA sequencing, and AI-guided drug screens that did not exist a decade ago.

5.  What to watch during your university years:  
   • Ongoing phase III trials of BTK inhibitors for progressive MS (evobrutinib, tolebrutinib, remibrutinib).  
   • Larger international trials of AHSCT versus best available drugs.  
   • Gene-editing or CAR-T approaches aimed at deleting autoreactive B cells.  
   • Second-generation remyelination agents (Obexelimab, anti-Semaphorin 4D, and next-gen anti-LINGO antibodies).  
   • Human oligodendrocyte‐precursor cell implants (several early-phase trials expected 2024–2026).

Bottom line  
Yes—there is a credible scientific path to an MS “cure,” and the distance to each milestone is shrinking.  Halting new disease activity may become routine within a decade; reversing existing disability may follow in the 2030s or 2040s.  Whether that will be a single therapy or a multi-step treatment remains to be seen, but the trajectory of research supports cautious optimism.

what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Multiple Sclerosis?: The National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) and other institutes of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) conduct research in laboratories at the NIH and also support additional research through grants to major medical institutions across the country. Scientists continue their extensive efforts to create new and better therapies for MS. One of the most promising MS research areas involves naturally occurring antiviral proteins known as interferons. Beta interferon has been shown to reduce the number of exacerbations and may slow the progression of physical disability. When attacks do occur, they tend to be shorter and less severe. In addition, there are a number of treatments under investigation that may curtail attacks or improve function. Over a dozen clinical trials testing potential therapies are underway, and additional new treatments are being devised and tested in animal models. In 2001, the National Academies/Institute of Medicine, a Federal technical and scientific advisory agency, prepared a strategic review of MS research. To read or download the National Academies/Institute of Medicine report, go to: "Multiple Sclerosis: Current Status and Strategies for the Future."

predicted_text:
Information for patients / carers – not a substitute for personal medical advice

What treatment are you talking about?
• “Seeds” refers to permanent low-dose-rate (LDR) brachy­therapy. 40-120 rice-sized radioactive seeds (most often iodine-125, palladium-103 or cesium-131) are placed through thin needles into the prostate while you are under anaesthesia.  
• They stay in the gland permanently and give off radiation for weeks-to-months that kills cancer cells.  

How well does it work?
• For properly selected men (small-to-moderate-size prostate, no or few urinary problems) with low- or intermediate-risk disease, 10-15-year cancer-specific survival is 94-98 %.  
• When combined with external-beam radiation ± hormone therapy it is also used for some higher-risk cancers with good results.  
• Major guidelines (NCCN, American Society of Clinical Oncology, American Urological Association, European Association of Urology) list it as a standard option alongside radical prostatectomy and external-beam radiation.

Is it safe?
Nothing in medicine is “risk-free,” but LDR brachytherapy has a long safety record (more than 30 years, >150,000 men treated worldwide) and is considered safe when:

1. You are an appropriate candidate  
   – PSA, Gleason score and MRI/biopsy fit the risk category  
   – Prostate volume usually < 60 cc or can be reduced with short-term hormone tablets  
   – No severe pre-existing urinary obstruction, inflammatory bowel disease or major hip-replacement hardware that blocks the needles

2. It is done by an experienced team in a centre that does quality-assurance CT or MRI after the procedure.

Potential benefits
• Out-patient or 23-hour stay, minimal blood loss, no surgical incision  
• Less risk of long-term urinary incontinence than radical prostatectomy (< 2 %)  
• Very low risk of needing a temporary colostomy or ureteral injury (virtually 0 %)  
• Many men keep erectile function longer than after surgery (but still about 25-50 % may need help with erections over 5-10 years)  
• Recovery is generally rapid; many men return to normal activities in a few days.

Potential short- and long-term side-effects (percentages are approximate)
Short-term (first 3-6 months)  
• Urinary frequency/urgency, burning with urination – 50-70 % (usually mild/moderate)  
• Temporary difficulty emptying bladder – up to 10 %; 1–3 % require a catheter for a week or two  
• Perineal bruising or mild rectal irritation – 5-10 %

Long-term  
• Persistent urinary urgency or weak stream – 10-15 %  
• Urinary incontinence requiring pads – < 2 %  
• Erectile dysfunction – 25-50 % over 5–10 years (risk rises with age, diabetes, heart disease)  
• Rectal bleeding/ulcer – 2–5 % (serious grade 3 < 1 %)  
• Very small lifetime risk of a second pelvic cancer from radiation (estimated < 1 %)  

Radiation precautions
• Most radiation is absorbed inside the prostate. For the first 2 months you may be asked to:  
  – Avoid letting small children sit on your lap for long periods.  
  – Use condoms during sex the first few times in case a seed is expelled (rare).  
  – Carry a doctor’s note when travelling; very sensitive detectors in airports sometimes pick up residual radiation.

How does it compare to other options?
Radical prostatectomy: similar long-term cancer cure for low/intermediate risk; higher rates of immediate incontinence and erectile dysfunction but no radiation exposure.  
External-beam radiation alone: no anaesthesia needed, but 25-45 daily treatments; slightly higher rectal dose than seeds; similar urinary side-effects.  
Active surveillance: avoids treatment side-effects now, but requires frequent PSA/biopsy and carries small risk of progression.

Questions to ask your doctors
• Am I a good candidate for seed implant alone or do I need combined therapy?  
• How many of these procedures has your team performed?  
• What are your rates of urinary retention, ED and rectal complications?  
• Could neoadjuvant hormones shrink my prostate and reduce side-effects?  
• What follow-up schedule (PSA testing, imaging) do you use?  

Bottom line
Permanent seed (LDR brachy­therapy) for prostate cancer is an established, generally safe, and effective option for many men when done by an experienced team. “Safe” does not mean “without risk,” so balance its side-effect profile against surgery, external-beam radiation, or active surveillance and make a decision in discussion with both a urologist and a radiation

Prostate cancer - treatment: Treatment for your prostate cancer is chosen after a thorough evaluation. Your doctor will discuss the benefits and risks of each treatment. Sometimes your doctor may recommend 1 treatment for you because of your type of cancer and risk factors. Other times, there may be 2 or more treatments that could be good for you. Factors you and your doctor must think about include: - Your age and other medical problems you may have - Side effects that occur with each type of treatment - How much the prostate cancer has spread - Your Gleason score, which tells how likely it is that cancer has already spread - Your prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test result Ask your doctor to explain these things following about your treatment choices: - Which choices offer the best chance of curing your cancer or controlling its spread? - How likely is it that you will have different side effects, and how they will affect your life? Radical prostatectomy is a surgery to remove the prostate and some of the surrounding tissue. It is an option when the cancer has not spread beyond the prostate gland. Healthy men who will likely live 10 or more years after being diagnosed with prostate cancer often have this procedure. Be aware that it is not always possible to know for certain, before surgery, if the cancer has spread beyond the prostate gland. Possible problems after surgery include difficulty controlling urine and erection problems. Also, some men need further treatments after this surgery. Radiation therapy works best for treating prostate cancer that has not spread outside of the prostate. It may also be used after surgery if there is a risk that cancer cells are still present. Radiation is sometimes used for pain relief when cancer has spread to the bone. External beam radiation therapy uses high-powered x-rays pointed at the prostate gland: - Before treatment, the radiation therapist uses a special pen to mark the part of the body that is to be treated. - Radiation is delivered to the prostate gland using a machine similar to a regular x-ray machine. The treatment itself is usually painless. - Treatment is done in a radiation oncology center that is usually connected to a hospital. - Treatment is usually done 5 days a week for 6 to 8 weeks. Side effects may include: - Appetite loss - Diarrhea - Erection problems - Fatigue - Rectal burning or injury - Skin reactions - Urinary incontinence, the feeling of needing to urinate urgently, or blood in the urine There are reports of secondary cancers arising from the radiation as well. Proton therapy is another kind of radiation therapy used to treat prostate cancer. Proton beams target the tumor precisely, so there is less damage to the surrounding tissue. This therapy is not widely accepted or used. Brachytherapy is often used for small prostate cancers that are found early and are slow-growing. Brachytherapy may be combined with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced cancers. Brachytherapy involves placing radioactive seeds inside the prostate gland. - A surgeon inserts small needles through the skin beneath your scrotum to inject the seeds. The seeds are so small that you do not feel them. - The seeds are left in place permanently. Side effects may include: - Pain, swelling, or bruising in the penis or scrotum - Red-brown urine or semen - Impotence - Incontinence - Urinary retention - Diarrhea Testosterone is the main male hormone. Prostate tumors need testosterone to grow. Hormonal therapy is treatment that decreases the effect of testosterone on prostate cancer. Hormone therapy is mainly used for cancer that has spread beyond the prostate. The treatment can help relieve symptoms and prevent further growth and spread of cancer. But it does not cure the cancer. The main type of hormone therapy is called a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormones (LH-RH) agonist: - The medicine blocks the testicles from making testosterone. The drugs must be given by injection, usually every 3 to 6 months. - Possible side effects include nausea and vomiting, hot flashes, anemia, fatigue, thinning bones (osteoporosis), reduced sexual desire, decreased muscle mass, weight gain, and impotence. The other type of hormone medicine is called an androgen-blocking drug: - It is often given along with LH-RH drugs to block the effect of testosterone produced by the adrenal glands, which make a small amount of testosterone. - Possible side effects include erection problems, reduced sexual desire, liver problems, diarrhea, and enlarged breasts. Much of the body's testosterone is made by the testes. As a result, surgery to remove the testes (called orchiectomy) can also be used as a hormonal treatment. Chemotherapy and immunotherapy (medicine that helps the body's immune system fight the cancer) may be used to treat prostate cancer that no longer responds to hormone treatment. Usually a single drug or a combination of drugs is recommended. Updated by: Jennifer Sobol, DO, Urologist with the Michigan Institute of Urology, West Bloomfield, MI. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

predicted_text:
I am not a substitute for your grandson’s doctor, but I can give you some general information about rubella and what usually needs to be done.

1. Typical course in children  
• In otherwise healthy children, rubella (“German measles”) is usually a mild illness: low-grade fever, runny nose, swollen glands behind the ears or at the back of the neck, and a fine pink rash that starts on the face and spreads downward.  
• Symptoms often last 3-5 days, and most children recover completely with only rest, fluids, and acetaminophen or ibuprofen for fever/discomfort. Serious complications (encephalitis, bleeding problems) are uncommon.

2. Why he got rubella even after being vaccinated  
• One dose of MMR (measles-mumps-rubella) prevents rubella in about 95 % of people, which still leaves a small chance of “breakthrough” infection. The routine schedule calls for TWO doses (usually at 12-15 months and again at 4-6 years). If he received only one dose, he is less protected. Even with two doses, a very small number of people can still get rubella.

3. Contagiousness and isolation  
• Rubella spreads through respiratory droplets and is contagious from about 7 days before the rash appears until 7 days after the rash starts.  
• Keep him away from school/day-care and from anyone who is pregnant or may become pregnant until at least 7 days after the rash began. (Rubella during pregnancy can cause miscarriage or severe birth defects, called congenital rubella syndrome.)  
• Everyone in close contact (siblings, adults who care for him) should review their own MMR status. Anyone who is not immune should be vaccinated promptly or, if pregnant and unvaccinated, should speak to a physician right away.

4. When to seek medical help immediately  
• Persistent or high fever (>102 °F / 39 °C), severe headache, neck stiffness, seizures, unusual drowsiness or irritability, persistent vomiting, bruising or bleeding, or if he simply seems to be getting worse instead of better.  
• If a pregnant family member or close contact may have been exposed.

5. Follow-up vaccinations  
• After he recovers, confirm with his doctor that he receives the second MMR dose (if he hasn’t already). Two doses give lifelong protection in almost everyone.  
• Make sure all other recommended childhood vaccines are up to date.

6. Supportive home care  
• Plenty of fluids, light meals, and rest.  
• Acetaminophen or ibuprofen for fever/discomfort (avoid aspirin in children).  
• Lukewarm sponge baths or cool compresses can soothe itching.  
• Keep fingernails trimmed and encourage gentle rubbing rather than scratching to lower the risk of infection from broken skin.

7. Bottom line  
In most healthy children, rubella is mild and self-limiting, so there is usually little long-term cause for worry about the child himself. The main concern is preventing spread—especially to pregnant women—and making sure he completes the full two-dose MMR series so he is protected in the future.

If anything about his condition concerns you, or if there is any chance a pregnant woman has been exposed, contact a healthcare professional promptly.

• Keep him away from school/day-care and from anyone who is pregnant or may become pregnant until at least 7 days after the rash began. (Rubella during pregnancy can cause miscarriage or severe birth defects, called congenital rubella syndrome.)  
• Everyone in close contact (siblings, adults who care for him) should review their own MMR status. Anyone who is not immune should be vaccinated promptly or, if pregnant and unvaccinated, should speak to a physician right away.

4. When to seek medical help immediately  
• Persistent or high fever (>102 °F / 39 °C), severe headache, neck stiffness, seizures, unusual drowsiness or irritability, persistent vomiting, bruising or bleeding, or if he simply seems to be getting worse instead of better.  
• If a pregnant family member or close contact may have been exposed.

5. Follow-up vaccinations  
• After he recovers, confirm with his doctor that he receives the second MMR dose (if he hasn’t already). Two doses give lifelong protection in almost everyone.  
• Make sure all other recommended childhood vaccines are up to date.

6. Supportive home care  
• Plenty of fluids, light meals, and rest.  
• Acetaminophen or ibuprofen for fever/discomfort (avoid aspirin in children).  
• Lukewarm sponge baths or cool compresses can soothe itching.  
• Keep fingernails trimmed and encourage gentle rubbing rather than scratching to lower the risk of infection from broken skin.

7. Bottom line  
In most healthy children, rubella is mild and self-limiting, so there is usually little long-term cause for worry about the child himself. The main concern is preventing spread—especially to pregnant women—and making sure he completes the full two-dose MMR series so he is protected in the future.

If anything about his condition concerns you, or if there is any chance a pregnant woman has been exposed, contact a healthcare professional promptly.

predicted_text:
I’m happy to outline the usual medical options and questions to ask your doctors, but only the team that has examined you and reviewed your MRI/CT scans can recommend what is safest and most effective in your own case.  Bring this information to a qualified neurosurgeon (ideally one who routinely treats spina-bifida–related problems) and an orthopaedic spine specialist for individualized advice.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Spina Bifida
-------------------------------------------------------------------
What it is  
• A congenital opening in the spine that can range from mild (occulta) to severe (myelomeningocele).  
• Lifelong issues may include weakness/paralysis, loss of sensation, hydrocephalus, bowel/bladder dysfunction, and risk of tethered cord and syrinx later on.

Typical management after infancy  
• Regular MRI surveillance of the cord and brain.  
• Bladder/bowel programs, physical therapy, bracing or orthotics, skin-care education.  
• Shunting or endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) for hydrocephalus if present.  
• Orthopaedic care for scoliosis, hip/knee/foot deformities.  
• Chiari II malformation decompression if symptomatic.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Vertebral Fusion (Spinal Fusion)
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Why it is done  
• Corrects or stabilises scoliosis/kyphosis or segments that are unstable.  
• In spina bifida patients fusion may have been performed earlier for progressive scoliosis.

Follow-up / problems to look for  
• Pseudarthrosis (non-union), implant failure, infection.  
• Progression of curve above or below the fused section (“adding-on”).  
• Post-fusion discomfort or stiffness.

If you are already fused  
• Physical therapy for core strength and flexibility of the unfused levels.  
• Imaging (X-ray or CT) if new pain or deformity appears.  
• Revision surgery only if hardware breaks, infection happens, or imbalance becomes disabling.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Syrinx (Syringomyelia)
-------------------------------------------------------------------
What it is  
• A fluid-filled cavity inside the spinal cord that can expand and damage nerve tissue.  
Common causes in spina bifida patients: tethered cord, Chiari malformation, scarring around the cord, prior trauma or surgery.

When to treat  
• Progressive pain, weakness, numbness, loss of temperature sensation, or new bowel/bladder changes.  
• Increase in syrinx size on MRI.

Treatment options  
a. Correct the underlying cause (most effective):  
   – Detethering surgery if the cord is tethered.  
   – Chiari decompression if low hindbrain crowding is driving the syrinx.  
b. Syrinx-specific procedures (used less often):  
   – Syringosubarachnoid or syringopleural shunt (creates a channel for fluid to drain).  
   – Expansion duraplasty (widening the dural sac to improve CSF flow) in Chiari-related cases.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Tethered Cord
-------------------------------------------------------------------
What it is  
• The spinal cord is abnormally fixed to tissue (scar, fatty filum, bony spur) and can’t move freely with growth or bending.  
• Stretching damages the cord, causing pain, leg weakness, gait change, sensory loss, foot deformity, incontinence, or scoliosis progression.

Diagnosis  
• MRI showing a low-lying conus, thickened filum, or scar tissue near a prior myelomeningocele repair; sometimes dynamic ultrasound in young children.

When surgery is recommended  
• Any progressive neurological, orthopedic, or urologic decline usually triggers recommendation for detethering.  
• Some surgeons will also offer prophylactic detethering before growth spurts or major scoliosis surgery.

Surgical goals  
• Cut the tethering bands or fatty filum, free the cord, close watertight.  
• Intra-operative neuro-monitoring lowers risk.  
• Hospital stay 2-5 days; low-activity period 2-4 weeks.  
• Risk of retethering later (5-30%); periodic MRI and clinical follow-up are essential.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
Putting it all together: Questions for your specialists
-------------------------------------------------------------------
1. How large is my syrinx, is it changing, and do you believe the tethered cord is the primary driver?  
2. Do you recommend detethering surgery now or watchful waiting with serial MRIs and urodynamics?  
3. If a detethering is done, what is my personal risk of neurological worsening, CSF leak, or recurrence?  
4. Do you see any problems with my prior vertebral fusion (loose hardware, adjacent-segment disease)?  
5. Would you decompress my syrinx at the same time as detethering, or only if it fails
