<gold_response>
Spina bifida (Treatment): Spina bifida treatment depends on the severity of the condition. Spina bifida occulta often doesn't require treatment at all, but other types of spina bifida do. Surgery before birth Nerve function in babies with spina bifida can worsen after birth if it's not treated. Prenatal surgery for spina bifida (fetal surgery) takes place before the 26th week of pregnancy. Surgeons expose a pregnant mother's uterus surgically, open the uterus and repair the baby's spinal cord. Research suggests that children with spina bifida who had fetal surgery may have reduced disability and be less likely to need crutches or other walking devices. In addition, fetal surgery may reduce the risk of hydrocephalus. Ask your doctor whether this procedure may be appropriate for you. Discuss the risks, such as possible premature delivery and other complications, and potential benefits for you and your baby. It's important to have a comprehensive evaluation to determine whether fetal surgery is feasible. This specialized surgery should only be done at a health care facility that has experienced fetal surgery experts, a multispecialty team approach and neonatal intensive care. Typically the team includes a fetal surgeon, pediatric neurosurgeon, maternal-fetal medicine specialist, fetal cardiologist and neonatologist. Cesarean birth Many babies with myelomeningocele tend to be in a feet-first (breech) position. If your baby is in this position or if your doctor has detected a large cyst or sac, cesarean birth may be a safer way to deliver your baby. Surgery after birth Meningocele involves surgery to put the meninges back in place and close the opening in the vertebrae. Because the spinal cord develops normally in babies with meningocele, these membranes often can be removed by surgery with little or no damage to nerve pathways. Myelomeningocele also requires surgery. Performing the surgery early can help minimize risk of infection that's associated with the exposed nerves and may also help protect the spinal cord from more trauma. During the procedure, a neurosurgeon places the spinal cord and exposed tissue inside the baby's body and covers them with muscle and skin. Sometimes a shunt to control hydrocephalus in the baby's brain is placed during the operation on the spinal cord. Treatment for complications In babies with myelomeningocele, irreparable nerve damage has likely already occurred and ongoing care from a multispecialty team of surgeons, physicians and therapists is usually needed. Babies with myelomeningocele may need more surgery for a variety of complications. Treatment for complications - such as weak legs, bladder and bowel problems or hydrocephalus - typically begins soon after birth. Depending on the severity of spina bifida and the complications, treatment may include, for example: - Walking and mobility aids. Some babies may start exercises to prepare their legs for walking with braces or crutches when they're older. Some children may need walkers or a wheelchair. Mobility aids, along with regular physical therapy, can help a child become independent. - Bowel and bladder management. Routine bowel and bladder evaluations and management plans help reduce the risk of organ damage and illness. Evaluations include X-rays, kidney scans, ultrasounds, blood tests and bladder function studies. These evaluations will be more frequent in the first few years of life, but less often as children grow. - Bowel management may include oral medications, suppositories, enemas, surgery, or a combination of these approaches. - Bladder management may include medications, using catheters to empty the bladder, surgery, or a combination. - For children, a specialist in pediatric urology with experience in evaluating and performing surgery on children with spina bifida is the best choice. - Surgery for hydrocephalus. Most babies with myelomeningocele will need a ventricular shunt - a surgically placed tube that allows fluid in the brain to drain into the abdomen. This tube might be placed just after birth, during the surgery to close the sac on the lower back or later as fluid accumulates. A less invasive procedure, called endoscopic third ventriculostomy, may be used, but candidates must be carefully chosen and meet certain criteria. The surgeon uses a small video camera to see inside the brain and makes a hole in the bottom of or between the ventricles so cerebrospinal fluid can flow out of the brain. - Treatment and management of other complications. To help with functioning, special equipment such as bath chairs, commode chairs and standing frames may be needed. Whatever the issue - orthopedic complications, tethered spinal cord, GI issues, skin problems, or others - most spina bifida complications can be treated or at least managed to improve quality of life. Ongoing care Children with spina bifida need close follow-up care and observation. Their primary care doctors follow growth, the need for immunizations and general medical issues. They coordinate your child's medical care. Children with spina bifida also often need treatment and ongoing care from: - Physical medicine and rehabilitation - Neurology - Neurosurgery - Urology - Orthopedics - Physical therapy - Occupational therapy - Special education teachers - Social workers - Dietitians Parents and other caregivers are a key part of the team, learning how to help manage their child's condition and how to encourage and support their child emotionally and socially. Keep in mind that children with spina bifida can go on to college, hold jobs and have families. Special accommodations may be necessary along the way, but encourage your child to be as independent as possible.

Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (Treatment): Unfortunately, no definitive treatments for LGMD exist. Management depends on each individual and the specific type of LGMD that the individual has. However, the American Academy of Neurology has developed guidelines for treatment of LGMD including: [5] [6] Weight control to avoid obesity Physical therapy and stretching exercises to promote mobility and prevent contractures (fixed tightening of the muscles) Use of mechanical aids such as canes, walkers, orthotics, and wheelchairs as needed to help ambulation and mobility Monitoring and surgical intervention as needed for orthopedic complications, such as foot deformity and scoliosis cardiomyopathy A team approach to treatment is recommended including a neurologist , pulmonologist , cardiologist , orthopedic surgeon, physiatrist , physical/occupational/ speech therapist , nutritionist , orthopedist , mental health counselors, and geneticist / genetic counselor . [5] [6] While not a currently available treatment option, some studies have shown  promising results with the use of gene therapy . More research is needed to prove the safety and efficacy of this treatment approach. [6] Management Guidelines The American Academy of Neurology (AAN), the medical specialty society of neurologists, offers a summary of recommended guidelines for Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy  GeneReviews provides current, expert-authored, peer-reviewed, full-text articles describing the application of genetic testing to the diagnosis, management, and genetic counseling of patients with specific inherited conditions. Project OrphanAnesthesia is a project whose aim is to create peer-reviewed, readily accessible guidelines for patients with rare diseases and for the anesthesiologists caring for them. The project is a collaborative effort of the German Society of Anesthesiology and Intensive Care, Orphanet, the European Society of Pediatric Anesthesia, anesthetists and rare disease experts with the aim to contribute to patient safety.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m sorry you’re having trouble with this—it can be a painful and frustrating condition. Below is general information and the usual treatment roadmap for Haglund’s deformity with associated retro-calcaneal and/or sub-cutaneous bursitis. Use it to guide a discussion with your own doctor, podiatrist or physiotherapist; it’s not a substitute for an in-person evaluation.

1. What’s going on?  
• Haglund’s deformity (“pump bump”) is a bony enlargement on the upper back of the heel bone (calcaneus).  
• Shoes (especially stiff-backed ones) or a tight Achilles tendon rub against that bump, irritating one or both bursae in the area—the retro-calcaneal bursa (deep, between bone and tendon) and the sub-cutaneous bursa (superficial, between skin and tendon).  
• The irritated bursa swells and hurts (bursitis). Achilles tendinopathy often co-exists.

2. Why did I get it?  
• Genetic or acquired high-arched foot (pes cavus) or a naturally prominent heel bone.  
• Tight calf/Achilles, lots of uphill running, jumping sports or frequent high-heel use.  
• Poor footwear: stiff heel counters, rigid backs, very high heels abruptly falling to a flat forefoot.

3. Goals of treatment  
a. Reduce inflammation/pain in the bursae.  
b. Reduce pressure and friction over the bony bump.  
c. Lengthen and strengthen the Achilles–calf unit so it glides smoothly.  
d. Address footwear and activity factors.  
e. If all else fails, surgically remove the bony prominence and inflamed bursa.

4. First-line, non-surgical measures (used in combination for at least 3-6 months)  
A. Footwear modification  
   • Choose shoes with a soft, flexible or open back (running shoes with a cut-out, clogs, well-padded sandals).  
   • Avoid “pump” style dress shoes, rigid hiking boots or skates while you’re inflamed.  
   • Heel lift (¼-½ inch) or silicone gel heel cup inside the shoe reduces Achilles pull and contact pressure.  
B. Activity and load management  
   • Temporarily reduce mileage, hills, speed work, plyometrics; switch to cycling, swimming or elliptical.  
   • If work requires standing, use anti-fatigue mats and cushioned shoes.  
C. Ice and anti-inflammatory care  
   • Ice massage 10–15 min after activity or 2–3×/day in flares.  
   • Oral NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) for 1-2 weeks if no contraindications; topical NSAID gels may help.  
D. Stretching and physiotherapy (key component)  
   • Gastrocnemius stretch: stand facing wall, back knee straight, heel down, 30 s × 3–4, 3×/day.  
   • Soleus stretch: same but back knee bent.  
   • Eccentric Achilles loading (heel drop exercises) once acute pain subsides; builds tendon tolerance.  
   • Soft-tissue mobilisation, ultrasound, or shockwave therapy by a physio may speed healing.  
E. Padding/taping  
   • Commercial “pump bump” pads, felt or moleskin doughnut around bump, or kinesio-taping to off-load area.  
F. Weight and systemic factors  
   • Even modest weight loss decreases heel load.  
   • Control systemic inflammatory diseases or metabolic issues (e.g., gout, rheumatoid arthritis).

5. Office-based options if the above isn’t enough  
• Corticosteroid injection into the bursa under ultrasound guidance. Provides 4–12 weeks relief in many people but carries a small risk of Achilles tendon weakening/rupture—best done sparingly and by an experienced clinician.  
• Extracorporeal shock-wave therapy (ESWT) for associated Achilles tendinopathy.  
• Custom orthotics to realign a high-arched or over-pronated foot.

6. When is surgery considered?  
About 10–15 % of patients don’t get durable relief from conservative care and consider surgery, especially if:  
   • Pain persists > 6 months and limits daily activity or sport.  
   • Large bony prominence visible on X-ray or MRI confirms mechanical impingement.  
Common procedures  
   • Resection of the postero-superior calcaneal prominence (often with endoscopic or open approach).  
   • Bursectomy (removing inflamed bursa).  
   • Sometimes partial detachment and re-anchoring of Achilles if bone must be fully exposed.  
Typical recovery timeline  
   • Splint or boot non-weight-bearing 2 weeks

Bursitis of the heel (Treatment): Your provider may recommend that you do the following: - Avoid activities that cause pain. - Put ice on the heel several times a day. - Take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen. - Try using over-the-counter or custom heel wedges in your shoe to help decrease stress on the heel. - Try ultrasound treatment during physical therapy to reduce inflammation. Have physical therapy to improve flexibility and strength around the ankle. The focus will be on stretching your Achilles tendon. This can help the bursitis improve and prevent it from coming back. If these treatments DO NOT work, your provider may inject a small amount of steroid medicine into the bursa. After the injection, you should avoid overstretching the tendon because it can break open (rupture). If the condition is connected to Achilles tendinitis, you may need to wear a cast on the ankle for several weeks. Very rarely, surgery may be needed to remove the inflamed bursa.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
No – loss of central vision from age-related macular degeneration (AMD), even when it is present in only one eye, is not considered a cause of “true” vertigo or inner-ear–type dizziness.  

Why not?  
• AMD affects the macula, the part of the retina that gives sharp central vision.  
• Vertigo and most other dizzy sensations come from the balance (vestibular) system in the inner ear or, less commonly, from the brainstem or circulation—-not from the retina or optic nerve.  
• Even though a sudden change in vision can make some people feel off-balance or “light-headed,” AMD does not disturb the sensory organs that detect motion, so it does not produce the spinning or rocking sensation doctors call vertigo.

If you are experiencing ongoing dizziness or vertigo, it is important to be evaluated for more common causes such as inner-ear disorders (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, vestibular neuritis, Ménière’s disease), medication side effects, low blood pressure, heart rhythm problems, anemia, anxiety, etc.

Dizziness: Dizziness is a term used to describe a range of sensations, such as feeling faint, woozy, weak or unsteady. Dizziness that creates the false sense that you or your surroundings are spinning or moving is called vertigo. Dizziness is one of the more common reasons adults visit their doctors. Frequent dizzy spells or constant dizziness can significantly affect your life. But dizziness rarely signals a life-threatening condition. Treatment of dizziness depends on the cause and your symptoms. It's usually effective, but the problem may recur. People experiencing dizziness may describe it as any of a number of sensations, such as: - A false sense of motion or spinning (vertigo) - Lightheadedness or feeling faint - Unsteadiness or a loss of balance - A feeling of floating, wooziness or heavy-headedness These feelings may be triggered or worsened by walking, standing up or moving your head. Your dizziness may accompanied by nausea or be so sudden or severe that you need to sit or lie down. The episode may last seconds or days and may recur. When to see a doctor Call 911 or seek emergency medical help if you experience dizziness with: - A sudden or severe headache - Ongoing vomiting - A sudden change in speech, vision or hearing - Stumbling or difficulty walking - Fainting - Chest pain or an irregular heart rate - Numbness or weakness - Shortness of breath - A high fever - A very stiff neck - A head injury - Seizures Consult with your doctor if you experience recurrent, sudden, severe dizziness or prolonged episodes of dizziness, faintness, lightheadedness or vertigo. Dizziness has many possible causes, including inner ear disturbance, motion sickness and medication effects. Sometimes it's caused by an underlying health condition, such as poor circulation, infection or injury. The way dizziness makes you feel and your triggers provide clues for possible causes. How long the dizziness lasts and any other symptoms you have also help pinpoint the cause. Inner ear problems that cause dizziness (vertigo) Your sense of balance depends on the combined input from the various parts of your sensory system. These include your: - Eyes, which help you determine where your body is in space and how it's moving - Sensory nerves, which send messages to your brain about body movements and positions - Inner ear, which houses sensors that help detect gravity and back-and-forth motion Vertigo is the false sense that your surroundings are spinning or moving. With inner ear disorders, your brain receives signals from the inner ear that aren't consistent with what your eyes and sensory nerves are receiving. Vertigo is what results as your brain works to sort out the confusion. - Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). This condition causes an intense and brief but false sense that you're spinning or moving. These episodes are triggered by a rapid change in head movement, such as when you turn over in bed, sit up or experience a blow to the head. BPPV is the most common cause of vertigo. - Infection. A viral infection of the vestibular nerve, called vestibular neuritis, can cause intense, constant vertigo. If you also have sudden hearing loss, you may have labyrinthitis. - Meniere's disease. This disease involves the excessive buildup of fluid in your inner ear. It's characterized by sudden episodes of vertigo lasting as long as several hours. You may also experience fluctuating hearing loss, ringing in the ear and the feeling of a plugged ear. - Migraine. People who experience migraines may have episodes of vertigo or other types of dizziness even when they're not having a severe headache. Such vertigo episodes can last minutes to hours and may be associated with headache as well as light and noise sensitivity. Circulation problems that cause dizziness You may feel dizzy, faint or off balance if your heart isn't pumping enough blood to your brain. Causes include: - Drop in blood pressure. A dramatic drop in your systolic blood pressure - the higher number in your blood pressure reading - may result in brief lightheadedness or a feeling of faintness. It can occur after sitting up or standing too quickly. This condition is also called orthostatic hypotension. - Poor blood circulation. Conditions such as cardiomyopathy, heart attack, heart arrhythmia and transient ischemic attack could cause dizziness. And a decrease in blood volume may cause inadequate blood flow to your brain or inner ear. Other causes of dizziness - Neurological conditions. Some neurological disorders - such as Parkinson's disease and multiple sclerosis - can lead to progressive loss of balance. - Medications. Dizziness can be a side effect of certain medications - such as anti-seizure drugs, antidepressants, sedatives and tranquilizers. In particular, blood pressure lowering medications may cause faintness if they lower your blood pressure too much. - Anxiety disorders. Certain anxiety disorders may cause lightheadedness or a woozy feeling often referred to as dizziness. These include panic attacks and a fear of leaving home or being in large, open spaces (agoraphobia). - Low iron levels (anemia). Other signs and symptoms that may occur along with dizziness if you have anemia include fatigue, weakness and pale skin. - Low blood sugar (hypoglycemia). This condition generally occurs in people with diabetes who use insulin. Dizziness (lightheadedness) may be accompanied by sweating and anxiety. - Overheating and dehydration. If you're active in hot weather, or if you don't drink enough fluids, you may feel dizzy from overheating (hyperthermia) or from dehydration. This is especially true if you take certain heart medications. Factors that may increase your risk of getting dizzy include: - Age. Older adults are more likely to have medical conditions that cause dizziness, especially a sense of imbalance. They're also more likely to take medications that can cause dizziness. - A past episode of dizziness. If you've experienced dizziness before, you're more likely to get dizzy in the future. If your doctor suspects you're having or may have had a stroke, are older or suffered a blow to the head, he or she may immediately order an MRI or CT scan. Most people visiting their doctor because of dizziness will first be asked about their symptoms and medications and then be given a physical examination. During this exam, your doctor will check how you walk and maintain your balance and how the major nerves of your central nervous system are working. You may also need a hearing test and balance tests, including: - Eye movement testing. Your doctor may watch the path of your eyes when you track a moving object. And you may be given an eye motion test in which cold and warm water or air are placed in your ear canal. - Head movement testing. If your doctor suspects your vertigo is caused by benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, he or she may do a simple head movement test called the Dix-Hallpike maneuver to verify the diagnosis. - Posturography. This test tells your doctor which parts of the balance system you rely on the most and which parts may be giving you problems. You stand in your bare feet on a platform and try to keep your balance under various conditions. - Rotary-chair testing. During this test you sit in a computer-controlled chair that moves very slowly in a full circle. At faster speeds, it moves back and forth in a very small arc. In addition, you may be given blood tests to check for infection and other tests to check heart and blood vessel health. Dizziness often gets better without treatment. Within a couple of weeks, the body usually adapts to whatever is causing it. If you seek treatment, your doctor will base it on the cause of your condition and your symptoms. It may include medications and balance exercises. Even if no cause is found or if your dizziness persists, prescription drugs and other treatments may make your symptoms more manageable. Medications - Water pills. If you have Meniere's disease, your doctor may prescribe a water pill (diuretic). This along with a low-salt diet may help reduce how often you have dizziness episodes. - Medications that reduce the dizziness. Antihistamines such as meclizine (Antivert) may offer short-term relief from vertigo. Anticholinergics help reduce dizziness. They include scopolamine skin patches (Transderm Scop). - Anti-nausea medications. Your doctor may prescribe a drug to provide immediate relief of nausea. Some of these can cause drowsiness. - Anti-anxiety medications. Diazepam (Valium) and alprazolam (Xanax) are in a class of drugs called benzodiazepines, which may cause addiction. They may also cause drowsiness. - Preventive medicine for migraine. Certain medicines may help prevent attacks of migraine. Therapy - Head position maneuvers. A technique called canalith repositioning (or Epley maneuver) usually helps resolve benign paroxysmal positional vertigo more quickly than simply waiting for your dizziness to go away. It can be done by your doctor, an audiologist or a physical therapist and involves maneuvering the position of your head. It's usually effective after one or two treatments. Before undergoing this procedure, tell your care provider if you have a neck or back condition, a detached retina or blood vessel problems. - Balance therapy. You may learn specific exercises to help make your balance system less sensitive to motion. This physical therapy technique is called vestibular rehabilitation. It is used for people with dizziness from inner ear conditions such as vestibular neuritis. - Psychotherapy. This type of therapy may help people whose dizziness is caused by anxiety disorders. Surgical or other procedures - Injections. Your doctor may inject your inner ear with the antibiotic gentamicin to disable the balance function. The unaffected ear takes over that function. - Removal of the inner ear sense organ. A procedure that's rarely used is called labyrinthectomy. It disables the vestibular labyrinth in the affected ear. The other ear takes over the balance function. This technique may be used if you have serious hearing loss and your dizziness hasn't responded to other treatments. Dizziness usually goes away on its own. If you tend to experience repeated episodes of dizziness, consider these tips: - Be aware of the possibility of losing your balance, which can lead to falling and serious injury. - Avoid moving suddenly and walk with a cane for stability, if needed. - Fall-proof your home by removing tripping hazards such as area rugs and exposed electrical cords. Use nonslip mats on your bath and shower floors. Use good lighting. - Sit or lie down immediately when you feel dizzy. Lie still with your eyes closed in a darkened room if you're experiencing a severe episode of vertigo. - Avoid driving a car or operating heavy machinery if you experience frequent dizziness without warning. - Avoid using caffeine, alcohol, salt and tobacco. Excessive use of these substances can worsen your signs and symptoms. - Drink enough fluids, eat a healthy diet, get enough sleep and avoid stress. - If your dizziness is caused by a medication, talk with your doctor about discontinuing it or lowering the dose. - If your dizziness comes with nausea, try an over-the-counter (nonprescription) antihistamine, such as meclizine (Antivert) or one containing dimenhydrinate (Dramamine). These may cause drowsiness. Nondrowsy antihistamines aren't as effective. - If your dizziness is caused by overheating or dehydration, rest in a cool place and drink water or a sports drink (Gatorade, Powerade, others).

predicted_text:
Dehydration can certainly make a person feel faint or actually pass out, but a sharp or tight chest pain is NOT one of the classic warning signs of dehydration and should never be dismissed as “just dehydration” unless a clinician has ruled out other causes.

Typical moderate-to-severe dehydration symptoms
• Intense thirst, dry mouth or dry tongue  
• Little or no urine, or very dark urine  
• Dizziness, light-headedness, feeling faint on standing (orthostatic hypotension)  
• Rapid heartbeat or palpitations  
• Low blood pressure  
• Fatigue, weakness; sometimes muscle cramps (usually in legs or abdomen)  
• Cool, clammy skin or poor skin turgor  
• Confusion or irritability in severe cases

Why chest pain is different
• Chest pain or a feeling of tightness just beneath the breasts can come from the heart (angina, heart attack), the lungs (pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, asthma), the esophagus (severe reflux or spasm), or even gallbladder or stomach problems that “refer” pain upward.  
• Dehydration can indirectly trigger chest discomfort—for example, by causing a rapid heart rate, lowering blood pressure, or provoking muscle cramps in the chest wall—but this is less common and should be considered a diagnosis of exclusion.

Bottom line
• Feeling dizzy, about to faint, and having chest pain should be treated as a medical emergency until a health-care professional proves otherwise—especially if the pain is new, severe, or accompanied by sweating, nausea, shortness of breath, or radiation to the arm, jaw, or back.  
• Re-hydrating (oral rehydration solution, water plus electrolytes) can help if dehydration is the main problem, but do not delay medical evaluation while waiting to see if the pain disappears.

Seek immediate medical attention (call emergency services) if:
• Chest pain or tightness lasts more than a few minutes or keeps returning  
• There is any fainting or near-fainting spell  
• The person is over 40 or has heart-disease risk factors  
• The pain is associated with shortness of breath, sweating, nausea, or a sense of impending doom

Self-care for mild dehydration (only if no red-flag symptoms):
1. Drink fluids that contain electrolytes (oral rehydration salts, sports drink diluted 1:1 with water, or clear broths).  
2. Sip steadily rather than gulp large volumes at once.  
3. Rest in a cool, shaded environment.  
4. Monitor urine color—pale-yellow is the goal.  
5. Add salty foods or an electrolyte powder if muscle cramping is present.

If symptoms do not improve quickly (within an hour or two for mild dehydration) or if chest discomfort continues, seek professional care.

In short: Severe dehydration often causes dizziness and fainting, but a tight chest pain beforehand is not typical and warrants prompt medical evaluation to rule out heart- or lung-related causes.

The matching is not yet perfect, but we now have reasonably good data that certain drugs or devices work better (or are contraindicated) in particular groups.  Below is a consumer-level overview of what that research shows and how headache specialists usually “match” a treatment to a migraine phenotype.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. How the modern headache field classifies migraine
--------------------------------------------------------------------
International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd ed. (ICHD-3, 2018)  
• Episodic migraine: <15 headache days/month  
• Chronic migraine (CM): ≥15 headache days/month for ≥3 mo, of which ≥8 are migrainous  
• Migraine with aura (visual, sensory, speech)  
• Migraine without aura  
• Menstrual-related migraine (MRM)  
• Vestibular migraine (prominent dizziness/vertigo)  
• Hemiplegic migraine (motor weakness)  
• Basilar-type (now “migraine with brainstem aura”)  
• Status migrainosus (>72 h) and medication-overuse headache (MOH)  

Because the underlying biology differs a little among these groups (CGRP release, cortical spreading depression, hormonal triggers, comorbidities), treatment responses also differ.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Evidence-based “matching” of therapies to migraine type
--------------------------------------------------------------------
ACUTE (attack-abortive) therapies  
• NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen, diclofenac): work in most types; first choice in children and mild attacks.  
• Triptans (sumatriptan, rizatriptan, frovatriptan, etc.): very effective for moderate–severe attacks in migraine with or without aura, chronic or episodic.  Contra-indicated in hemiplegic or brain-stem migraine and in significant vascular disease.  
   – Frovatriptan and naratriptan have the best data for short-term prevention of menstrual-related migraine.  
• Ditans (lasmiditan) and Gepants (ubrogepant, rimegepant): effective in the same populations as triptans but without vasoconstriction; early trials included both aura and non-aura patients.  
• Neuromodulation for acute use  
   – Single-pulse TMS (sTMS; “eNeura”)—best evidence in migraine WITH aura (AAN 2017 Level B) but some benefit in migraine without aura as well.  
   – Non-invasive vagus-nerve stimulation (nVNS; gammaCore)—helps both episodic and chronic migraine; open-label data suggest more benefit in patients with prominent autonomic symptoms.  
   – Remote electrical neuromodulation (REN; Nerivio)––benefit across usual migraine sub-types in RCTs.

<gold_response>
Migraine (Treatment): There is no specific cure for migraine headaches. The goal is to treat your migraine symptoms right away, and to prevent symptoms by avoiding or changing your triggers. A key step is learning how to manage your migraines at home. A headache diary can help you identify your headache triggers. Then you and your doctor can plan how to avoid these triggers. If you have frequent migraines, your doctor may prescribe medicine to reduce the number of attacks. You need to take the medicine every day for it to be effective. Medicines may include: - Antidepressants - Blood pressure medicines - Seizure medicines Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) injections may also help reduce migraine attacks if they occur more than 15 days a month. Some people find relief with minerals and vitamins. Check with your doctor to see if riboflavin or magnesium is right for you. TREATING AN ATTACK Other medicines are taken at the first sign of a migraine attack. Over-the-counter (OTC) pain medicines, such as acetaminophen, ibuprofen, or aspirin are often helpful when your migraine is mild. Be aware that: - Taking medicines more than 3 days a week may lead to rebound headaches. These are headaches that keep coming back due to overuse of pain medicine. - Taking too much acetaminophen can damage your liver. - Too much ibuprofen or aspirin can irritate your stomach or kidneys. If these treatments do not help, ask your doctor about prescription medicines. These include nasal sprays, suppositories, or injections. The group of medicines most often used is called triptans. Some migraine medicines narrow the blood vessels. If you are at risk for having a heart attack or have heart disease, talk with your doctor before using these medicines. Some migraine medicines should not be used by pregnant women. Talk with your doctor about which medicine is right for you if you are pregnant or planning to become pregnant. Other medicines treat symptoms of migraine, such as nausea and vomiting. They may be used alone or along with the other drugs that treat the migraine itself. Feverfew is an herb for migraines. It can be effective for some people. Before using feverfew, make sure your provider approves. Herbal remedies sold in drugstores and health food stores are not regulated. Work with a trained herbalist when selecting herbs.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m sorry you are still feeling unwell.  Typhoid fever can usually be cured, so when symptoms continue for months it means something else is going on that needs careful medical attention.  The following information will help you understand what may be happening and what to discuss with your doctor.  It is not a substitute for an in-person examination.

1.  How typhoid is normally treated  
   • Typhoid fever is caused by the bacteria Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi (or, less often, S. Paratyphi).  
   • With the right antibiotics (for example ceftriaxone, azithromycin, or a fluoroquinolone when the germ is still sensitive) most people improve within 3–5 days and are fully recovered in 7–14 days.  
   • The entire antibiotic course must be completed even if you feel better, otherwise the germ can survive and cause a relapse.  

2.  Why you might still be ill after “one year of treatment”  
   • The antibiotic(s) given did not work because the bacteria were resistant.  Multidrug-resistant (MDR) and extensively drug-resistant (XDR) typhoid are now common in parts of Asia and Africa.  
   • You may have had repeated short courses rather than one full, adequate course guided by a culture test, allowing the bacteria to persist.  
   • You became re-infected from contaminated food or water after the first illness cleared.  
   • You could be a “chronic carrier.”  About 3-5 % of patients continue to harbor the bacteria in their gallbladder or bile ducts; they may feel tired or have low-grade fever, or have no symptoms at all but keep testing positive.  
   • Another condition (for example malaria, viral hepatitis, tuberculosis, autoimmune disease, inflammatory bowel disease, etc.) is being mistaken for persistent typhoid.  

3.  Tests that usually clear up the picture  
   • Blood culture (done before antibiotics are started)  
   • Stool or urine culture (may detect chronic carriage)  
   • Antibiotic sensitivity testing on any positive culture to pick the most effective drug  
   • Complete blood count, liver tests, and ultrasound of the abdomen/gallbladder to look for stones or abscesses  
   • Widal test alone is unreliable; do not base treatment decisions on it without cultures.  

4.  Treatment options if cultures are still positive  
   • A FULL course (10–14 days) of an antibiotic proven effective by sensitivity testing.  In many regions ceftriaxone (IV) or azithromycin (oral) is the first choice.  
   • If you are a chronic carrier, a longer 4–6-week course of an effective oral antibiotic (for example, high-dose ciprofloxacin if the strain is sensitive) may be prescribed.  
   • If chronic carriage is linked to gallstones, removing the gallbladder (cholecystectomy) together with antibiotics cures most carriers.  
   • Never start or stop antibiotics on your own; incomplete or inappropriate treatment drives resistance.  

5.  General measures while you recover  
   • Drink plenty of safe water or ORS to avoid dehydration.  
   • Eat light, soft, and balanced meals; avoid alcohol and very fatty or spicy foods until your digestion is normal.  
   • Rest as needed—prolonged fever can leave you weak.  
   • Keep follow-up appointments; repeat cultures 48–72 hours after finishing antibiotics to be sure the infection is gone.  

6.  Preventing re-infection  
   • ALWAYS wash hands with soap after the toilet and before preparing or eating food.  
   • Drink only boiled, bottled, or properly filtered water.  Avoid ice unless made with safe water.  
   • Eat freshly cooked food while it is still hot; avoid raw salads, unpeeled fruit, and street food of uncertain hygiene.  
   • If someone else in your household has typhoid, they should also complete treatment and practice strict hand-washing.  
   • Consider typhoid vaccination (injectable Vi-polysaccharide or oral Ty21a) for longer-term protection, especially if you live in or travel to high-risk areas.  

7.  When to seek urgent care  
   • Persistent high fever over 102 °F (39 °C)  
   • Repeated vomiting or inability to keep fluids down  
   • Severe abdominal pain, bloating, or blood in stool (may signal intestinal perforation)  
   • Jaundice (yellow eyes/skin), confusion, or severe weakness  

What to do now  
Make an appointment as soon as possible with a qualified physician—ideally an infectious disease specialist or an internist familiar with drug-resistant typhoid.  Bring any records of previous tests or prescriptions.  Ask specifically for:  
   • Blood and stool cultures

   • If someone else in your household has typhoid, they should also complete treatment and practice strict hand-washing.  
   • Consider typhoid vaccination (injectable Vi-polysaccharide or oral Ty21a) for longer-term protection, especially if you live in or travel to high-risk areas.  

7.  When to seek urgent care  
   • Persistent high fever over 102 °F (39 °C)  
   • Repeated vomiting or inability to keep fluids down  
   • Severe abdominal pain, bloating, or blood in stool (may signal intestinal perforation)  
   • Jaundice (yellow eyes/skin), confusion, or severe weakness  

What to do now  
Make an appointment as soon as possible with a qualified physician—ideally an infectious disease specialist or an internist familiar with drug-resistant typhoid.  Bring any records of previous tests or prescriptions.  Ask specifically for:  
   • Blood and stool cultures
</response>

predicted_text:
How to find out if you have ever had chickenpox  

1.  Ask for a blood test that looks for varicella-zoster virus (VZV) IgG antibodies.  
   •  Names you may see on the lab slip: “Varicella-Zoster Virus IgG,” “VZV Ab, IgG,” or simply “Varicella titer.”  
   •  Method used: an ELISA test (some reference laboratories use more sensitive glycoprotein-based ELISA or FAMA, but you do not have to specify this; any standard commercial VZV-IgG test will be accepted).  
   •  A single tube of blood is drawn; results are usually back in 1–3 days.

2.  How to read the report  
   (Each laboratory lists its own numeric cut-offs, but the wording is the same everywhere.)  

   •  Positive / Immune / Reactive (for example, “>165 mIU/mL” or “Index > 1.10”)  
     – VZV IgG antibodies are present.  
     – Means you either had natural chickenpox in the past or you were vaccinated against it.  
     – You are considered immune and you harbor latent virus, so you are eligible for the shingles vaccine (Zostavax or the newer Shingrix) if you meet the age and health criteria.  

   •  Negative / Non-immune / Non-reactive (for example, “<135 mIU/mL” or “Index < 0.90”)  
     – No measurable VZV IgG antibodies.  
     – You are assumed never to have had chickenpox and should receive the 2-dose chickenpox (Varivax) series instead of Zostavax.  
     – After completing Varivax, you could receive a shingles vaccine later if/when you become eligible.  

   •  Equivocal / Borderline  
     – The level is in the gray zone.  
     – The usual approach is to repeat the test, or just proceed as if negative and give Varivax.

Current vaccine guidance & practical points  

•  People born in the United States before 1980 are presumed to have had chickenpox; more than 99 % will test positive, even if they do not remember the illness. Routine testing is therefore not required before giving a shingles vaccine.  
•  ACIP/CDC recommends shingles vaccine (preferably Shingrix; Zostavax is still used in some settings) for adults 50 years and older, regardless of history of chickenpox, unless they have a medical contraindication.  
•  However, if a blood test shows you are seronegative, you should receive the chickenpox vaccine first because shingles vaccine is licensed only for people with prior VZV infection.  
•  Contraindications to Zostavax (live vaccine): immune suppression, pregnancy, anaphylaxis to gelatin or neomycin. Shingrix (non-live) is safer in immunocompetent adults and is preferred by CDC.

Bottom line  

Ask your clinician for a “Varicella-Zoster virus IgG antibody” blood test if you truly want proof.  
– Positive result → you’ve had chickenpox (or were vaccinated) and can proceed with shingles vaccination if you are in the recommended age group.  
– Negative result → get the chickenpox (Varivax) series first; shingles vaccine can wait.  

As always, discuss the results and timing of any vaccines with your health-care provider, especially if you have immune problems, are pregnant, or take immune-modifying drugs.

predicted_text:
Vitelliform macular dystrophy (VMD) – sometimes called Best disease or adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy (AOVMD) – is a rare, inherited eye disorder that affects the macula, the small area in the center of the retina that is responsible for sharp, straight-ahead (central) vision and color perception.  Because the macula is involved, the main symptom is progressive loss of central vision; peripheral (side) vision is usually preserved.

Key points in plain language
•��Cause – Most people with the “juvenile” form (Best disease) have a change (mutation) in the BEST1 gene.  The adult-onset form can be caused by changes in BEST1 or a few other genes (PRPH2, IMPG1, IMPG2).  
•��Inheritance – Usually autosomal dominant (one altered copy of the gene is enough to cause the disease).  Each child of an affected parent has a 50 % chance of inheriting the condition.  
•��Course – The disease often progresses slowly over many years.  Some people maintain useful vision well into adulthood; others develop significant central vision loss.  A small percentage develop complications such as choroidal neovascularization (abnormal new blood vessels under the retina) that can lead to more rapid vision loss if not treated.  
•��Cure – At present there is no cure.  Management focuses on monitoring, treating complications early, and maximizing remaining vision.  Several promising treatments are being studied.

Current care and treatment options
1. Monitoring and early detection  
   •��Regular dilated eye exams with an ophthalmologist (ideally a retina specialist) every 6–12 months.  
   •��Imaging tests such as optical coherence tomography (OCT), autofluorescence, and/or fluorescein angiography are used to follow retinal changes and watch for choroidal neovascularization (CNV).  
   •��Home Amsler grid testing (a simple grid of lines) can help detect new waviness or blanks spots that may signal CNV or sudden changes.

2. Treatment of choroidal neovascularization (if it occurs)  
   •��Anti-VEGF intravitreal injections (bevacizumab/Avastin, ranibizumab/Lucentis, aflibercept/Eylea, etc.) are the current first-line therapy and can often stabilize or improve vision.  
   •��Photodynamic therapy (PDT) with verteporfin (Visudyne) is sometimes used, either alone or as an adjunct.  
   •��Focal laser is rarely used today because of the risk of creating permanent blind spots.

3. Low-vision rehabilitation  
   •��Even without a cure, most people can continue work, school, and hobbies with the help of low-vision aids—high-contrast and magnifying devices, electronic readers, specialized computer software, closed-circuit TV, and orientation & mobility training.  
   •��Ask for a referral to a certified low-vision specialist early; waiting until vision is severely impaired makes adaptation more difficult.

4. Lifestyle steps  
   •��Wear 100 % ultraviolet-blocking sunglasses and a broad-brimmed hat to limit UV exposure, which may reduce retinal stress.  
   •��Do not smoke; smoking increases oxidative stress on the retina.  
   •��Maintain a heart-healthy diet rich in leafy green and colorful vegetables, omega-3 fatty acids (fish), and antioxidant vitamins.  (No supplement has been proved to alter VMD progression, but general retinal-health guidelines apply.)  
   •��Control blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes if present.

5. Genetic counseling and testing  
   •��Molecular testing of BEST1 and related genes can confirm the diagnosis, guide prognosis, and allow at-risk relatives to be tested.  
   •��A board-certified genetic counselor or ophthalmic geneticist can explain inheritance, family planning options, and eligibility for gene-specific clinical trials.

Emerging / research treatments
•��Gene therapy – Because Best disease is usually caused by defective BEST1, several laboratories and companies (e.g., 4D Molecular Therapeutics, MeiraGTx) are testing BEST1 gene-replacement or gene-editing approaches in animal models and early-phase human trials.  No therapy has regulatory approval yet, but progress is encouraging.  
•��Stem-cell-derived retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) implants – Experimental procedures are exploring whether healthy RPE cells can be transplanted to replace damaged tissue.  
•��Pharmacologic chaperones & small molecules – Drugs that help misfolded BEST1 protein reach its proper location in the RPE cell membrane are in pre-clinical development.  
•��Artificial vision / retinal prostheses

<gold_response>
Adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy (Treatment): There is no cure or known treatment to stop the progression of adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy. [2] Management usually includes a comprehensive eye examination once or twice a year to monitor progression of the disease and for complications such as choroidal neovascularization ( CNV ). [4]  CNV is sometimes associated with adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy because macular degeneration can damage the retinal layers. When this happens, the vascular layer of the eye between the sclera and the retina known as the choroid may produce new blood vessels (neovascularization) which grow up through the damaged layers and leak or bleed into the retina. This can cause vision loss on its own. If CNV does develop, anti-VEGF therapy such as Ranibizumab or Bevacizumab can control and even reverse the CNV. However anti-VEGF therapy does not stop or reverse the vision loss caused by adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy, only the extra vision loss that is due to also developing CNV. [2]  Although vision loss is usually slow, when vision is impaired significantly, people with adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy may be referred for low vision testing and rehabilitation. Low vision rehabilitation can help maintain and optimize reading ability and improve overall quality of life. [4] [5]
</gold_response>

Information on Williams Syndrome (WS)

1. What it is  
• Williams Syndrome is a rare genetic condition that is present at birth and affects males and females equally in all ethnic groups.  
• It is caused by the spontaneous deletion of about 26–28 genes on chromosome 7q11.23, including the elastin gene.  
• Incidence: roughly 1 in every 7,500–10,000 live births.

2. Common physical and medical characteristics  
• Characteristic facial appearance: broad forehead, short-upturned nose, full cheeks and lips, wide mouth, small chin (“elfin” or “angel-like” face).  
• Cardiovascular problems: supravalvar aortic stenosis (SVAS) and other vessel narrowing; elevated blood pressure is common in adolescence/adulthood.  
• Connective-tissue laxity and elastin-related issues: joint problems in infancy, stiff joints with age, possible hernias, bowel/bladder motility problems.  
• Growth: usually low birth-weight, slow weight gain, and short stature in adulthood (average adult height ~5 ft / 152 cm).  
• Feeding difficulties in infancy; gastro-esophageal reflux is frequent.  
• Hearing: mild to moderate hearing loss in many adults; hyperacusis (sensitive hearing) common in childhood.  
• Endocrine: high blood calcium in infancy in 15–50 % (causing irritability/vomiting); thyroid abnormalities and early puberty occasionally.  
• Dental anomalies: small, widely spaced teeth, bite problems.  
• Ophthalmologic: strabismus, farsightedness.  
• Increased risk of anxiety disorders and, in adults, depression.

3. Cognitive and behavioral profile  
• Mild to moderate intellectual disability (average IQ 50–70), but great variability; some individuals test in the low-average range, others have more severe impairments.  
• Relative strengths:  
  – Strong long-term auditory memory (remembering names, songs, stories).  
  – Rich spoken vocabulary, good verbal fluency, love of conversation (“cocktail-party speech”).  
  – High social motivation, empathy and friendliness, good face recognition.  
• Relative challenges:  
  – Visual–spatial construction (puzzles, drawing, math, geometry).  
  – Fine-motor coordination, graphomotor skills (handwriting).  
  – Attention deficit, distractibility, anxiety about new situations.  
• High incidence of specific phobias (e.g., loud noises) and generalized anxiety.

4. Medical follow-up (lifelong)  
• Cardiologist: baseline echocardiogram, then every 1–3 yrs (or sooner if abnormal).  
• Blood pressure check at every visit; treat hypertension aggressively.  
• Calcium levels in infancy; treat hypercalcemia with low-calcium formula if needed.  
• Hearing and vision screening annually.  
• Thyroid function tests every 2–3 yrs from age 2 on.  
• Monitor growth, feeding, GI motility, spine (for scoliosis), and dental issues.  
• Adults: renal function, lipid profile, glucose tolerance, mental-health screening.

General principles  
• Use their social drive: teaching through 1-to-1 interaction, peer tutoring, cooperative learning, and role-play works well.  
• Capitalize on language strengths: have student “teach back,” discuss, narrate stories.  
• Present material in small chunks; provide visual models and hands-on examples because visual-spatial construction is weak.  
• Multisensory instruction: combine spoken instructions with pictures, objects, music, and movement.  
• Allow extra time for processing, especially for non-verbal tasks (math, writing, copying).  
• Build routines; anxiety decreases when schedule is predictable.

• Phonics-based reading programs often succeed, supported by their auditory memory.  
• Build comprehension by explicitly teaching inference, main idea, and summarizing, as conversational fluency can mask comprehension gaps.  

Mathematics  
• Concrete manipulatives (base-ten blocks, fraction circles, number lines) are essential.  
• Teach step-by-step problem solving; use visual cues (color-coding, graphic organizers).  
• Incorporate real-life math (shopping, cooking, measuring music beats) to enhance meaning.

Information on Williams Syndrome (WS)

1. What it is  
• Williams Syndrome is a rare genetic condition that is present at birth and affects males and females equally in all ethnic groups.  
• It is caused by the spontaneous deletion of about 26–28 genes on chromosome 7q11.23, including the elastin gene.  
• Incidence: roughly 1 in every 7,500–10,000 live births.

2. Common physical and medical characteristics  
• Characteristic facial appearance: broad forehead, short-upturned nose, full cheeks and lips, wide mouth, small chin (“elfin” or “angel-like” face).  
• Cardiovascular problems: supravalvar aortic stenosis (SVAS) and other vessel narrowing; elevated blood pressure is common in adolescence/adulthood.  
• Connective-tissue laxity and elastin-related issues: joint problems in infancy, stiff joints with age, possible hernias, bowel/bladder motility problems.

<gold_response>
Williams syndrome: Williams syndrome is a rare disorder that can lead to problems with development. It is passed down in families (inherited). Williams syndrome is caused by not having a copy of several genes. Parents may not have any family history of the condition. However, people with Williams syndrome have a 50% chance of passing the disorder on to each of their children. It often occurs randomly. Williams syndrome occurs in about 1 in 8,000 births. One of the 25 missing genes is the gene that produces elastin, a protein that allows blood vessels and other tissues in the body to stretch. It is likely that missing a copy of this gene results in the narrowing of blood vessels, stretchy skin, and flexible joints seen in this condition. Symptoms of Williams syndrome are: - Delayed speech that may later turn into strong speaking ability and strong learning by hearing - Developmental delay - Easily distracted, attention deficit disorder (ADD) - Feeding problems including colic, reflux, and vomiting - Inward bend of the small finger - Learning disorders - Mild to moderate intellectual disability - Personality traits including being very friendly, trusting strangers, fearing loud sounds or physical contact, and being interested in music - Short, compared to the rest of the person's family - Sunken chest The face and mouth of someone with Williams syndrome may show: - A flattened nasal bridge with small upturned nose - Long ridges in the skin that run from the nose to the upper lip - Prominent lips with an open mouth - Skin that covers the inner corner of the eye - Partially missing teeth, defective tooth enamel, or small, widely spaced teeth Signs include: - Narrowing of some blood vessels - Farsightedness - High blood calcium level that may cause seizures and rigid muscles - High blood pressure - Slack joints that may change to stiffness as the person gets older - Unusual star-like pattern in iris of the eye Tests for Williams syndrome include: - Blood pressure check - Blood test for a missing piece of chromosome 7 (FISH test) - Echocardiography combined with Doppler ultrasound - Kidney ultrasound There is no cure for Williams syndrome. Avoid taking extra calcium and vitamin D. Treat high blood calcium, if it occurs. Blood vessel narrowing can be a major health problem. It is treated based on how severe it is. Physical therapy is helpful to people with joint stiffness. Developmental and speech therapy can also help. For example, having strong verbal skills can help make up for other weaknesses. Other treatments are based on the person's symptoms. It can help to have treatment coordinated by a geneticist who is experienced with Williams syndrome. A support group can be helpful for emotional support and for giving and receiving practical advice. The following organization provides additional information about Williams Syndrome: Williams Syndrome Association -- www.williams-syndrome.org About 75% of people with Williams syndrome have some intellectual disability. Most people will not live as long as normal due to the various medical issues and other possible complications. Most people require full-time caregivers and often live in supervised group homes. Complications may include: - Calcium deposits in the kidney and other kidney problems - Death (in rare cases from anesthesia) - Heart failure due to narrowed blood vessels - Pain in the abdomen Many of the symptoms and signs of Williams syndrome may not be obvious at birth. Call your health care provider if your child has features similar to those of Williams syndrome. Seek genetic counseling if you have a family history of Williams syndrome. There is no known way to prevent the genetic problem that causes Williams syndrome. Prenatal testing is available for couples with a family history of Williams syndrome who wish to conceive. Updated by: Chad Haldeman-Englert, MD, FACMG, Fullerton Genetics Center, Asheville, NC. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Lewy body dementia (LBD) is actually an umbrella term for two closely-related conditions:  

• Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) – dementia symptoms appear before, or within a year of, motor (Parkinson-like) symptoms.  
• Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD) – Parkinson’s disease is diagnosed first and significant dementia follows later (usually after a year or more).

Although Alzheimer’s disease is the most commonly discussed dementia, LBD is the second-most common degenerative dementia in people over 65, accounting for 5–10 % (some studies say up to 20 %) of all cases. Because its early symptoms can look like Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, a psychiatric disorder, or a medication side-effect, it is frequently under-diagnosed – yet it demands different management in several respects (for example, many antipsychotic drugs used safely in Alzheimer’s can be dangerous in LBD).

Key features that help distinguish LBD

1. Fluctuating cognition – marked “good days and bad days,” or even good hours and bad hours.  
2. Visual hallucinations – often detailed and well-formed (children, animals, people).  
3. REM sleep behavior disorder – acting out dreams; can precede dementia by years.  
4. Parkinsonism – slow movement, stiffness, shuffling gait, masked facial expression, tremor.  
5. Severe sensitivity to antipsychotics – even a single dose of haloperidol or risperidone can cause extreme rigidity, confusion, or a life-threatening reaction called neuroleptic malignant syndrome.  
6. Autonomic dysfunction – blood-pressure drops, fainting, constipation, urinary urgency/incontinence.  
7. Memory loss is usually less prominent early on than in Alzheimer’s, but attention, executive function, and visual–spatial abilities decline early.

Diagnosis

No single test proves LBD. A specialist (neurologist, geriatric psychiatrist, or cognitive disorders clinic) usually combines:

• Detailed history and exam (ask about hallucinations, sleep behaviors).  
• Neuropsychological testing (often shows “fluctuating” results).  
• Brain imaging – MRI or CT to rule out other causes; DaTscan (dopamine transporter SPECT) can support an LBD diagnosis by showing reduced dopamine activity in the basal ganglia.  
• Lab tests to exclude vitamin deficiencies, thyroid problems, infection, etc.  
• Sleep study if REM sleep behavior disorder is suspected.

Treatment: symptom-based

There is no cure yet, but a combination of medications, non-drug strategies, and caregiver education can greatly improve quality of life.

Cognitive / behavioral  
• Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) – often the first treatment; benefit cognition, hallucinations, and fluctuations.  
• Memantine – modest additional benefit in some patients.  
• Avoid or use extreme caution with “typical” or many “atypical” antipsychotics. If absolutely necessary, quetiapine or clozapine (under close monitoring) are preferred. Pimavanserin has FDA approval for Parkinson-related psychosis and is being used more in LBD.

Motor (parkinsonism)  
• Levodopa/carbidopa may help stiffness or slowness, but can worsen hallucinations. Start with very low doses.  
• Physical and occupational therapy to maintain mobility and prevent falls.

Sleep  
• REM sleep behavior disorder often responds to melatonin (3-12 mg at bedtime) or low-dose clonazepam. Ensure a safe sleep environment (e.g., padded bed rails, removing sharp objects).

Autonomic symptoms  
• Midodrine or fludrocortisone for low blood pressure; dietary salt/fluid adjustments; compression stockings.  
• Scheduled toileting, pelvic-floor therapy, or medications for urinary urgency; stool softeners/fiber for constipation.

Mood & anxiety  
• Low-dose SSRIs (e.g., sertraline) are usually tolerated; avoid paroxetine because of anticholinergic effects.

Non-drug approaches  
• Regular daily routine, good lighting, contrast cues (big wall calendar, whiteboard).  
• Exercise, music, pet or art therapy.  
• Avoid sensory overload; keep tasks simple and instructions one step at a time.  
• Reminders that hallucinations are a symptom of the disease can be reassuring.

Prognosis

Average survival from symptom onset is 5–8 years, but it ranges widely (2–20 + years). Course is typically faster than Parkinson’s disease dementia and similar to, or a bit shorter than, Alzheimer’s. Sudden worsening can follow infections, surgery, dehydration, new medications, or environmental changes.

Caregiver issues

• Education about fluctuations, hallucinations, and drug sensitivities prevents crises.  
• Build a multidisciplinary team (neurologist, PCP, physical/occupational therapist, sleep specialist).  
• Plan

Lewy body dementia (Overview): Lewy body dementia, also known as dementia with Lewy bodies, is the second most common type of progressive dementia after Alzheimer's disease dementia. Protein deposits, called Lewy bodies, develop in nerve cells in the brain regions involved in thinking, memory and movement (motor control). Lewy body dementia causes a progressive decline in mental abilities. People with Lewy body dementia may experience visual hallucinations, and changes in alertness and attention. Other effects include Parkinson's disease-like symptoms such as rigid muscles, slow movement and tremors. Lewy body dementia care at Mayo Clinic
</gold_response>

1. What is Cri du chat syndrome?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Cri du chat (“cry of the cat”) syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p-).  The main clinical features are a high-pitched cat-like cry in infancy, developmental delay, distinctive facial appearance, and variable medical problems.

Key search terms you can use:

Below is a quick “road-map” to finding reliable information on Cri du chat syndrome (also called 5p- or 5p- deletion syndrome).  It includes:

• A short description of the condition (so you can choose the right search terms)  
• Simple step-by-step instructions for searching PubMed or Google Scholar  
• Direct links to several FREE full-text review articles and key papers  
• Names of journals that frequently publish on this topic  
• A few trusted patient-friendly websites

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. What is Cri du chat syndrome?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Cri du chat (“cry of the cat”) syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p-).  The main clinical features are a high-pitched cat-like cry in infancy, developmental delay, distinctive facial appearance, and variable medical problems.

Key search terms you can use:
   “Cri du chat”, “5p deletion”, “5p minus syndrome”, “chromosome 5p-”, “5p- syndrome”.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. How to run a quick search in PubMed
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Go to https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov  
2. In the search box type:  cri du chat syndrome review[Title] OR “5p- syndrome” review  
3. On the results page, click “Free full text” (left column) if you need free articles.  
4. Sort by “Best Match” or “Most Recent”.  
5. Click any title to open the abstract; the full-text link (often “PubMed Central”) is on the right.

Tip: Adding the word review retrieves broad overviews that are easiest to read first.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Selected FREE full-text review articles
--------------------------------------------------------------------
(The links work as of April 2024; all are open access.)

1) Cornish K, Bramble D.  “Cri-du-chat syndrome.”  Orphanet Journal of Rare Diseases 2023;18:221.  
   https://ojrd.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13023-023-02755-0  
   A current, patient-oriented review covering genetics, clinical picture, management, and family issues.

   https://www.mdpi.com/2073-4425/11/3/403  
   Explains genotype-phenotype correlations and modern diagnostic methods.

   https://ojrd.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1750-1172-1-33  
   Classic comprehensive clinical review (still cited widely).

4) Espirito Santo LR et al.  “Motor development in children with cri-du-chat: review and therapeutic perspectives.”  Journal of Physical Therapy Science 2018;30(5):697-703.  
   https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5989068/

5) Elliott RD, Case AP.  “Speech and language characteristics in 5p- deletion (cri-du-chat) syndrome.”  Journal of Communication Disorders 2019;82:105915.

predicted_text:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is considered an uncommon (rare) disease overall, but it is one of the most common life-shortening genetic disorders seen in people of Northern European ancestry.

How often it occurs  
• Worldwide: roughly 70,000–100,000 people are living with CF.  
• United States: about 30,000 people have CF, and 1,000 or so new cases are diagnosed each year.  
• At birth: approximately 1 in 2,500–3,500 white (non-Hispanic) newborns has CF. The condition is less frequent in other groups—about 1 in 15,000 African-American births and 1 in 30,000 Asian-American births.  
• Carrier frequency: about 1 in 25–30 people of Northern European descent carries a single faulty CF gene (carriers are healthy but can pass the gene to their children).

Bottom line  
CF is rare in the general population, yet among Caucasians it is the most common fatal inherited disorder, with about one in every 3,000 babies affected and roughly one in every 25–30 adults carrying the gene.
