<question>
how do you diagnose anxiety
</question>

The response will be provided in these tags:
<response>
Diagnosing anxiety is not something you can reliably do on your own; it involves a structured evaluation by a qualified health-care professional (usually a primary-care doctor, nurse practitioner, psychiatrist, psychologist, or licensed counselor). Below is an overview of what typically happens during the diagnostic process.

1. Initial conversation and medical history  
   • Your clinician asks about your main concerns—what you feel, how long you’ve felt it, and how it affects your daily life (work, school, relationships, sleep, appetite, energy, etc.).  
   • They take a full medical, psychiatric, and family history, because anxiety can run in families and can also be triggered or worsened by certain medical conditions (for example, thyroid disorders, heart arrhythmias, asthma, chronic pain) or medications (such as stimulants, some asthma medicines, or high doses of caffeine).  
   • Substance use (alcohol, nicotine, cannabis, recreational drugs) is reviewed, because it can mimic or aggravate anxiety.

2. Physical exam and possible lab tests  
   • A brief physical exam helps rule out medical problems that can look like anxiety (e.g., overactive thyroid, anemia, vitamin deficiencies).  
   • Routine labs might include a complete blood count (CBC), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), basic metabolic panel, or others tailored to your symptoms.

3. Standardized screening tools  
   • Clinicians often use quick questionnaires such as the GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7), the Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI), or the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAM-A). These are not diagnostic on their own, but they quantify symptom severity and track progress over time.

4. Diagnostic interview (DSM-5 criteria)  
   • For an official mental-health diagnosis, professionals refer to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th edition (DSM-5).  
   • Example: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) requires:  
     – Excessive anxiety and worry occurring more days than not for at least 6 months and about a number of events or activities.  
     – Difficulty controlling the worry.  
     – At least three of six physical or cognitive symptoms (restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, or sleep disturbance).  
     – Clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.  
   • Other anxiety-related diagnoses (panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, specific phobia, separation anxiety, etc.) each have their own criteria.

5. Ruling out other mental-health conditions  
   • Depression, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), bipolar disorder, or substance-induced mood/anxiety disorders can overlap with or masquerade as anxiety.  
   • Your clinician will ask symptom-specific questions to tease these apart because treatment approaches can differ.

6. Collaborative discussion and treatment planning  
   • Once criteria are met (or not) and other causes are excluded, the clinician will explain the diagnosis in plain language, discuss treatment options (therapy, lifestyle changes, medications if needed), and co-develop a plan with you.  
   • If the presentation is complex, a referral to a psychiatrist, psychologist, or other specialist may be recommended for further evaluation.

Self-screening vs. professional evaluation  
• Online quizzes or self-checklists can highlight potential problems, but they cannot confirm a diagnosis.  
• If worries, panic attacks, or physical symptoms (racing heart, shortness of breath, trembling, stomach upset) are frequent, intense, hard to control, or causing you to avoid normal activities, it’s time to seek professional help.

When to seek urgent care  
• Severe anxiety accompanied by chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, or a feeling you might pass out should be evaluated urgently to rule out medical emergencies.  
• Thoughts of self-harm or suicide require immediate attention—call 988 in the U.S. (or your local crisis line) or go to the nearest emergency department.

Key takeaway  
A true diagnosis of an anxiety disorder is based on a comprehensive interview, possible physical exam and labs, standardized screening tools, and DSM-5 criteria—all interpreted by a trained professional. If anxiety is interfering with your life, reach out to your primary-care provider or a mental-health specialist for a formal assessment and personalized care.
</response>

<gold_response>
Anxiety (Diagnosis): You may start by seeing your primary care doctor to find out if your anxiety could be related to your physical health. Your doctor can check for signs of an underlying medical condition that may need treatment. However, you may need to see a mental health specialist if you have severe anxiety. A psychiatrist is a medical doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treating mental health conditions. A psychologist and certain other mental health professionals can diagnose anxiety and provide counseling (psychotherapy). To help diagnose an anxiety disorder and rule out other conditions, your provider may: - Give you a psychological evaluation. This involves describing your thoughts, feelings and behavior to help pinpoint a diagnosis and check for related complications. Anxiety disorders often occur along with other mental health problems - such as depression or substance abuse - which can make diagnosis more challenging. - Compare your symptoms to the criteria in the DSM-5. Many doctors use the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association, to diagnose an anxiety disorder.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
How a prolapsed bladder (also called a cystocele) develops

1. What a prolapsed bladder is
   • A cystocele happens when the wall of tissue that normally supports the bladder and separates it from the vagina becomes stretched or weakened.  
   • When that support gives way, the bladder “drops” or bulges into the front wall of the vagina.  
   • In more advanced cases the bladder can protrude to or beyond the vaginal opening.

2. Common ways the support tissues become weakened
   • Pregnancy and vaginal childbirth  
     – Particularly multiple births, large babies, long or difficult labors, forceps/vacuum deliveries, or an episiotomy/tearing.  
   • Loss of estrogen after menopause  
     – Estrogen keeps pelvic tissues firm; declining levels thin and weaken them.  
   • Repeated heavy lifting, high-impact exercise, or jobs/hobbies that strain the core muscles.  
   • Chronic increases in abdominal pressure  
     – Long-term coughing (smoking, lung disease), frequent or prolonged constipation/straining with bowel movements, or chronic sneezing allergies.  
   • Obesity or significant weight gain, which constantly pushes downward on the pelvic floor.  
   • Prior pelvic or gynecologic surgery, especially hysterectomy, which can disrupt supportive ligaments.  
   • Genetic or connective-tissue conditions that make ligaments inherently weaker (less common).  
   • Aging in general: muscles and connective tissues lose tone over time.

3. Less common situations
   • In men a similar problem can occur after prostate surgery, but this is unusual; “prolapsed bladder” usually describes the female condition.

4. What increases the chance you will notice symptoms
   • The greater the number or severity of the risk factors above, the more likely the bladder support will fail.  
   • Symptoms often start or worsen when you stand for long periods, lift heavy objects, or strain with bowel movements, and may improve when you lie down.

5. Can it be prevented?
   • Perform regular Kegel (pelvic-floor) exercises before and after pregnancy and throughout life.  
   • Maintain a healthy weight.  
   • Treat chronic cough or allergies; stop smoking.  
   • Avoid chronic constipation—eat fiber, use stool softeners if needed, don’t strain.  
   • Use correct technique and exhale when lifting; limit unnecessary heavy lifting.  
   • Discuss estrogen therapy after menopause if appropriate (ask your clinician).  
   • Seek early help for any mild bulging or urinary incontinence—conservative measures (pelvic-floor physical therapy, pessaries) work best when started early.

If you think you may have a cystocele—pressure in the vagina, a bulge you can feel, urinary leakage or incomplete emptying—make an appointment with your primary-care provider, gynecologist, or a urogynecologist for evaluation and tailored treatment options.

<gold_response>
Anterior prolapse (cystocele) (Causes): Your pelvic floor consists of muscles, ligaments and connective tissues that support your bladder and other pelvic organs. The connections between your pelvic floor muscles and ligaments can weaken over time, as a result of trauma from childbirth or chronic straining of pelvic floor muscles. When this happens, your bladder can slip down lower than normal and bulge into your vagina (anterior prolapse). Possible causes of anterior prolapse include: - Pregnancy and vaginal childbirth - Being overweight or obese - Repeated heavy lifting - Straining with bowel movements - A chronic cough or bronchitis
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
How people “get” (develop) a neuromuscular disorder depends on which specific disorder you are talking about.  Neuromuscular disorders are an umbrella group of hundreds of conditions that affect the nerves that send signals from the brain and spinal cord to the muscles or the muscles themselves.  They can be broadly divided into two categories:

1. Inherited (genetic) disorders  
2. Acquired (develop after birth) disorders  

Below is a plain-language overview of the main ways these conditions arise.

——————————————————
1. Inherited (genetic) neuromuscular disorders
——————————————————
• How they occur  
  – A change (mutation) in a gene that is important for nerve or muscle function is passed from parent to child, or arises spontaneously in the egg or sperm.  
  – Examples:  
    • Muscular dystrophies (e.g., Duchenne, Becker)  
    • Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA)  
    • Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT)  
• Can they be prevented?  
  – Not once conception has occurred.  Genetic counseling, carrier testing, and in some cases in-vitro fertilization with genetic screening (PGT) can reduce the chance of passing some of these disorders to a child.

——————————————————
2. Acquired neuromuscular disorders
——————————————————
These develop after birth from a variety of causes:

A. Autoimmune conditions  
   • The body’s immune system mistakenly attacks nerves or muscles.  
   • Examples: Myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP), polymyositis, dermatomyositis.  
   • Triggers can be infections, other autoimmune diseases, or (rarely) certain medications or vaccines.

B. Metabolic / endocrine disorders  
   • Long-standing diabetes (diabetic neuropathy)  
   • Thyroid disease (hypo- or hyperthyroidism)  
   • Vitamin deficiencies (B₁₂, B₁, E, niacin)  
   • Chronic kidney or liver failure

C. Toxic / drug-induced damage  
   • Alcohol misuse  
   • Chemotherapy agents, some antibiotics, statins, amiodarone, colchicine, antiretrovirals, etc.  
   • Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic)  
   • Solvents or industrial chemicals

D. Infectious causes  
   • Viruses: HIV, COVID-19 (post-viral neuropathies), Zika, West Nile  
   • Bacteria: Lyme disease, diphtheria, leprosy  
   • Post-polio syndrome in people who had polio earlier in life  
   • Most of these are not “caught” as a neuromuscular disorder per se; rather, the infection damages nerves/muscles and the consequence is a neuromuscular complication.

E. Vascular / ischemic causes  
   • Stroke or lack of blood flow to a nerve (mononeuritis multiplex, vasculitic neuropathy)

F. Mechanical / compression injuries  
   • Carpal tunnel syndrome, ulnar neuropathy, radiculopathy from disc herniation, traumatic nerve injury, repetitive strain

G. Degenerative / multifactorial disorders  
   • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS or Lou Gehrig’s disease)  
     – Exact cause unknown; likely a mix of genetic susceptibility and environmental triggers (toxins, head trauma, etc.).  
   • Some cases of peripheral neuropathy are labeled “idiopathic” (no clear cause found).

——————————————————
Risk factors you can and cannot change
——————————————————
Cannot change  
• Family history/genetics  
• Increasing age (many acquired neuropathies are more common with age)  
• Certain congenital conditions

May be modifiable  
• Diabetes control, alcohol use  
• Vitamin intake / nutrition  
• Exposure to toxins or certain medications (sometimes alternatives exist)  
• Workplace ergonomics (repetitive strain, vibration)  
• Weight management (reduces nerve entrapment risk)  
• Prompt treatment of infections, thyroid disease, autoimmune disorders

——————————————————
Are neuromuscular disorders contagious?
——————————————————
• The vast majority are NOT contagious.  
• Only the underlying infection in infectious neuropathies is contagious (e.g., polio, Lyme). The nerve damage itself is not passed person-to-person.

——————————————————
When to see a doctor
——————————————————
• Persistent muscle weakness, cramping, twitching, or atrophy  
• Numbness, tingling, burning pain in feet or hands that worsens or spreads  
• Drooping eyelids, double vision, trouble swallowing, or fatigable weakness  
• Sudden or rapidly progressing weakness (medical emergency)  
• Family history of neuromuscular disease and planning a pregnancy

——————————————————
Key take-aways
——————————————————
1.

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
Neuromuscular Disorders (Summary): Summary Neuromuscular disorders affect the nerves that control your voluntary muscles. Voluntary muscles are the ones you can control, like in your arms and legs. Your nerve cells, also called neurons, send the messages that control these muscles. When the neurons become unhealthy or die, communication between your nervous system and muscles breaks down. As a result, your muscles weaken and waste away. The weakness can lead to twitching, cramps, aches and pains, and joint and movement problems. Sometimes it also affects heart function and your ability to breathe. Examples of neuromuscular disorders include - Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis - Multiple sclerosis - Myasthenia gravis - Spinal muscular atrophy Many neuromuscular diseases are genetic, which means they run in families or there is a mutation in your genes. Sometimes, an immune system disorder can cause them. Most of them have no cure. The goal of treatment is to improve symptoms, increase mobility and lengthen life.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is not one single disease; it is a rise in blood pressure inside the arteries of the lungs that can be triggered by many different medical conditions, lifestyle factors, or, less commonly, by an inherited gene change. Below is an overview of how people “get” pulmonary hypertension, organized by the major medical categories doctors use.

1. Problems that start in the lung-blood vessels themselves  (Group 1: Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension – PAH)  
• Idiopathic (no clear cause found).  
• Heritable (a gene mutation, most often in BMPR2 or a related gene, runs in the family).  
• Drug or toxin exposure (e.g., certain appetite suppressants such as the old “fen-phen,” some chemotherapy drugs, methamphetamine, cocaine).  
• Associated diseases: connective-tissue disorders such as scleroderma or lupus, HIV infection, congenital heart defects that let blood flow abnormally between the heart’s chambers, portal hypertension from severe liver disease, schistosomiasis (a parasitic infection in some tropical regions).

2. Left-sided heart disease (Group 2)  
Anything that makes the left side of the heart weak or stiff can cause blood to back up into the lungs and raise pressure:  
• Untreated or poorly treated high blood pressure.  
• Coronary artery disease or prior heart attacks.  
• Heart-valve problems (mitral or aortic valve disease).  
• Heart-muscle disorders such as cardiomyopathies.

3. Lung diseases or long-term low oxygen (Group 3)  
• Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD, emphysema, chronic bronchitis).  
• Interstitial lung diseases, pulmonary fibrosis.  
• Untreated obstructive sleep apnea or obesity-hypoventilation syndrome.  
• Long-term high-altitude exposure in susceptible individuals.  
• Certain congenital lung problems such as cystic fibrosis.

4. Chronic blood clots in the lung’s arteries (Group 4: chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension, CTEPH)  
• After one or more pulmonary emboli (blood clots) that never fully dissolve, scar tissue narrows or blocks the lung arteries.

5. Miscellaneous or multifactorial causes (Group 5)  
• Blood disorders with chronic clotting (e.g., sickle-cell disease, polycythemia).  
• Some metabolic or kidney diseases, sarcoidosis, certain tumors pressing on the pulmonary vessels.

Other risk factors and contributors  
• Female sex (PAH is more common in women).  
• Age > 45 for most types, but heritable or congenital-heart-related PAH can appear in children and young adults.  
• Family history of PAH.  
• Use of appetite suppressants, stimulants, or IV street drugs.  
• Untreated congenital heart disease (“holes” in the heart) letting blood shunt from left to right.  
• Autoimmune diseases such as scleroderma, mixed connective-tissue disease.

How it develops  
Regardless of the underlying trigger, pulmonary hypertension arises when the small arteries inside the lungs become narrowed, scarred, inflamed, chronically blocked by clots, or subject to abnormally high back-pressure from the heart. Blood has a harder time passing through, resistance rises, and the right side of the heart has to pump much harder. Over time the right ventricle can enlarge and weaken, leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, chest pressure, swelling of the legs or abdomen, and fainting spells.

Can it be prevented?  
• Treat and control conditions that commonly lead to PH (high blood pressure, heart valve disease, COPD, sleep apnea, recurrent blood clots).  
• Avoid appetite-suppressant or stimulant drugs not prescribed by a physician.  
• Seek early care for unexplained shortness of breath or exercise intolerance.  
• If you have a strong family history of PAH or a connective-tissue disease, ask your doctor about screening.

Bottom line  
You don’t “catch” pulmonary hypertension the way you catch a cold; it develops secondary to other heart, lung, or systemic problems, to certain drugs/toxins, or—less commonly—from a genetic change. Identifying and treating the root cause early, plus regular follow-up with a cardiologist or pulmonologist, provides the best chance of slowing or controlling the disease.

Pulmonary Hypertension (Causes): Pulmonary hypertension (PH) begins with inflammation and changes in the cells that line your pulmonary arteries. Other factors also can affect the pulmonary arteries and cause PH. For example, the condition may develop if: The walls of the arteries tighten. The walls of the arteries are stiff at birth or become stiff from an overgrowth of cells. Blood clots form in the arteries. These changes make it hard for your heart to push blood through your pulmonary arteries and into your lungs. Thus, the pressure in the arteries rises, causing PH. Many factors can contribute to the process that leads to the different types of PH. Group 1 pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) may have no known cause, or the condition may be inherited. ("Inherited" means the condition is passed from parents to children through genes.) Some diseases and conditions also can cause group 1 PAH. Examples include HIV infection, congenital heart disease, and sickle cell disease. Also, the use of street drugs (such as cocaine) and certain diet medicines can lead to PAH. Many diseases and conditions can cause groups 2 through 5 PH (often called secondary PH), including: Mitral valve disease Lung diseases, such as COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) Sleep apnea Sarcoidosis For more information about the types of PH and the diseases, conditions, and factors that can cause them, go to "Types of Pulmonary Hypertension."
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Checking the amount of cholesterol in your body is simple and painless—it is done with a blood test often called a “lipid panel” or “lipid profile.”

1. What the test measures  
   • Total cholesterol  
   • LDL (“bad”) cholesterol  
   • HDL (“good”) cholesterol  
   • Triglycerides  
   • Sometimes: non-HDL cholesterol and a calculated LDL/HDL ratio  

2. How the blood is obtained  
   • Standard laboratory draw: A clinician takes a small sample of blood from a vein in your arm; the sample is sent to a lab.  
   • Finger-stick (point-of-care) test: A drop of blood from a fingertip is analyzed in the clinic or with certain home test kits. Venous samples are still considered the most accurate.  

3. Fasting vs. non-fasting  
   • Traditionally you were asked to fast 9–12 hours before the test (no food or drink except water).  
   • Many guidelines now accept non-fasting samples, especially for routine screening. Your doctor will tell you whether fasting is necessary for your specific situation.  

4. Where to get tested  
   • Doctor’s office, clinic, or hospital laboratory (often part of an annual physical).  
   • Community health fairs or pharmacies that offer point-of-care cholesterol screenings.  
   • FDA-cleared home test kits—usually a finger-stick with results read on a small device or mailed to a lab (follow instructions carefully; confirm abnormal results with your healthcare provider).  

5. When to get tested (general guidelines for people with no known heart disease)  
   • Adults 20–39: at least once every 4–6 years, or more often if you have risk factors (e.g., diabetes, smoking, family history).  
   • Adults 40 and older: every 1–2 years or as advised by your provider.  
   • Children and teens: once between ages 9–11 and again between 17–21, earlier or more often if there are risk factors.  

6. Understanding results (typical U.S. adult goals)  
   • Total cholesterol: below 200 mg/dL  
   • LDL cholesterol: below 100 mg/dL (below 70 mg/dL for high-risk individuals)  
   • HDL cholesterol: 40 mg/dL or higher for men, 50 mg/dL or higher for women  
   • Triglycerides: below 150 mg/dL  

7. Follow-up  
   • Discuss results with your healthcare provider; targets may differ if you have heart disease, diabetes, or other conditions.  
   • If levels are high, lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, weight management, quitting smoking) and sometimes medication (statins or others) can lower cholesterol and reduce cardiovascular risk.  

Bottom line: To test your cholesterol, you simply have a blood sample analyzed—usually during a routine visit to your healthcare provider. The process is quick, and the information is key to preventing heart disease and stroke.

High cholesterol (Diagnosis): A blood test to check cholesterol levels - called a lipid panel or lipid profile - typically reports: - Total cholesterol - LDL cholesterol - HDL cholesterol - Triglycerides - a type of fat in the blood For the most accurate measurements, don't eat or drink anything (other than water) for nine to 12 hours before the blood sample is taken. Interpreting the numbers In the United States, cholesterol levels are measured in milligrams (mg) of cholesterol per deciliter (dL) of blood. In Canada and many European countries, cholesterol levels are measured in millimoles per liter (mmol/L). To interpret your test results, use these general guidelines. Children and cholesterol testing For most children, the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute recommends one cholesterol screening test between the ages of 9 and 11, and another cholesterol screening test between the ages of 17 and 21. Cholesterol testing is usually avoided between the ages of 12 and 16 because false-negative results are more likely within this age group. If your child has a family history of early-onset heart disease or a personal history of obesity or diabetes, your doctor may recommend earlier or more frequent cholesterol testing.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Treating a suspected heart attack is a true medical emergency—always call 911 (or your local emergency number) first. Treatment happens in two phases: (1) immediate, lifesaving care and (2) longer-term care to heal the heart and prevent another attack.  

1. What happens before you reach the hospital  
• Call for help right away. Do NOT drive yourself.  
• While waiting for the ambulance:  
  – Chew and swallow an adult aspirin (unless you’re allergic or your doctor has told you not to).  
  – If you have a prescribed nitroglycerin tablet or spray, use it as directed.  
  – Stay calm, loosen tight clothing, and sit or lie comfortably while help is on the way.  

2. Emergency department (ED) and coronary-care unit treatment  
• Rapid tests (ECG, blood tests) confirm whether it is an ST-elevation MI (STEMI) or a non-ST-elevation MI (NSTEMI/UA).  
• Oxygen, pain relief (usually morphine), and continuous heart monitoring are started.  
• Antiplatelet drugs: A high-dose aspirin plus another antiplatelet (e.g., clopidogrel, ticagrelor) to stop the clot from growing.  
• Blood thinners (heparin or similar medicines) to keep new clots from forming.  

Re-opening the blocked artery (reperfusion)  
A. Primary PCI (angioplasty with or without a stent)  
   – A thin tube (catheter) is guided, usually through the wrist or groin, to the blocked coronary artery.  
   – A balloon is inflated to push the clot/plaque aside and a stent is left in place to keep the artery open.  
   – Goal: within 90 minutes of first medical contact for STEMI.  

B. Clot-busting drugs (thrombolytics such as alteplase, tenecteplase)  
   – Given if PCI cannot be done quickly (usually within 120 minutes) or if no cath lab is available.  
   – Most useful within the first 2–3 hours of symptom onset; benefit declines after 12 hours.  
   – Often followed by transfer to a PCI-capable center for possible “rescue” angioplasty.  

C. Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery  
   – Needed if multiple severe blockages, failed PCI, mechanical complications, or certain anatomic patterns.  

3. Stabilization and early hospital care (first 24–72 hours)  
• Beta-blockers to reduce heart workload and prevent dangerous rhythms.  
• ACE inhibitors or ARBs to protect heart muscle and lower blood pressure.  
• High-dose statins to reduce cholesterol and stabilize plaque.  
• Possible aldosterone antagonists (eplerenone, spironolactone) if heart function is poor.  
• Management of complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiogenic shock if they arise.  

4. Recovery and long-term treatment  
Medication “package” most patients leave the hospital with (unless contraindicated):  
• Aspirin for life.  
• A second antiplatelet drug for at least 3–12 months (depending on the stent type and bleeding risk).  
• Beta-blocker.  
• ACE inhibitor or ARB.  
• High-intensity statin.  
• Possible additional drugs for blood sugar, blood pressure, or heart failure.  

Lifestyle changes and cardiac rehabilitation  
• Supervised cardiac rehab program begins days to weeks after discharge; improves fitness and reduces future risk.  
• Quit smoking—this is the single biggest controllable risk factor.  
• Heart-healthy eating pattern (e.g., Mediterranean or DASH diet) low in saturated fat, salt, and processed foods.  
• Gradual, medically guided exercise plan; aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate activity per week once cleared.  
• Maintain a healthy body weight, control blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar.  
• Manage stress, sleep, and emotional health; depression is common after a heart attack—tell your doctor.  

Follow-up care  
• First clinic visit usually 1–2 weeks after discharge, then regular check-ups.  
• Repeat blood tests and imaging (echocardiogram, stress test, or angiogram) as recommended to assess recovery.  
• Strict adherence to medicine and lifestyle plans greatly reduces the risk of another heart attack.  

Key takeaway  
A heart attack is treated first by rapidly restoring blood flow to the blocked heart artery—ideally with emergency angioplasty (PCI). Medications, intensive hospital monitoring, and follow-up care then help the heart heal and prevent future events. Quick action (calling 911 at the very first warning signs) is the single most important step for survival.

Treating a suspected heart attack is a true medical emergency—always call 911 (or your local emergency number) first. Treatment happens in two phases: (1) immediate, lifesaving care and (2) longer-term care to heal the heart and prevent another attack.  

1. What happens before you reach the hospital  
• Call for help right away. Do NOT drive yourself.  
• While waiting for the ambulance:  
  – Chew and swallow an adult aspirin (unless you’re allergic or your doctor has told you not to).  
  – If you have a prescribed nitroglycerin tablet or spray, use it as directed.  
  – Stay calm, loosen tight clothing, and sit or lie comfortably while help is on the way.  

2. Emergency department (ED) and coronary-care unit treatment  
• Rapid tests (ECG, blood tests) confirm whether it is an ST-elevation MI (STEMI) or a non-ST-elevation MI (NSTEMI/UA).  
• Oxygen, pain relief (usually morphine), and continuous heart monitoring are started.  
• Antiplatelet drugs: A high-dose aspirin plus another antiplatelet (e.g., clopidogrel, ticagrelor) to stop the clot from growing.  
• Blood thinners (heparin or similar medicines) to keep new clots from forming.  

Re-opening the blocked artery (reperfusion)  
A. Primary PCI (angioplasty with or without a stent)  
   – A thin tube (catheter) is guided, usually through the wrist or groin, to the blocked coronary artery.  
   – A balloon is inflated to push the clot/plaque aside and a stent is left in place to keep the artery open.  
   – Goal: within 90 minutes of first medical contact for STEMI.  

B. Clot-busting drugs (thrombolytics such as alteplase, tenecteplase)  
   – Given if PCI cannot be done quickly (usually within 120 minutes) or if no cath lab is available.  
   – Most useful within the first 2–3 hours of symptom onset; benefit declines after 12 hours.  
   – Often followed by transfer to a PCI-capable center for possible “rescue” angioplasty.  

C. Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery  
   – Needed if multiple severe blockages, failed PCI, mechanical complications, or certain anatomic patterns.  

3. Stabilization and early hospital care (first 24–72 hours)  
• Beta-blockers to reduce heart workload and prevent dangerous rhythms.  
• ACE inhibitors or ARBs to protect heart muscle and lower blood pressure.  
• High-dose statins to reduce cholesterol and stabilize plaque.  
• Possible aldosterone antagonists (eplerenone, spironolactone) if heart function is poor.  
• Management of complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiogenic shock if they arise.  

4. Recovery and long-term treatment  
Medication “package” most patients leave the hospital with (unless contraindicated):  
• Aspirin for life.  
• A second antiplatelet drug for at least 3–12 months (depending on the stent type and bleeding risk).  
• Beta-blocker.  
• ACE inhibitor or ARB.  
• High-intensity statin.  
• Possible additional drugs for blood sugar, blood pressure, or heart failure.  

Lifestyle changes and cardiac rehabilitation  
• Supervised cardiac rehab program begins days to weeks after discharge; improves fitness and reduces future risk.  
• Quit smoking—this is the single biggest controllable risk factor.  
• Heart-healthy eating pattern (e.g., Mediterranean or DASH diet) low in saturated fat, salt, and processed foods.  
• Gradual, medically guided exercise plan; aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate activity per week once cleared.  
• Maintain a healthy body weight, control blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar.  
• Manage stress, sleep, and emotional health; depression is common after a heart attack—tell your doctor.  

Follow-up care  
• First clinic visit usually 1–2 weeks after discharge, then regular check-ups.  
• Repeat blood tests and imaging (echocardiogram, stress test, or angiogram) as recommended to assess recovery.  
• Strict adherence to medicine and lifestyle plans greatly reduces the risk of another heart attack.  

Key takeaway  
A heart attack is treated first by rapidly restoring blood flow to the blocked heart artery—ideally with emergency angioplasty (PCI). Medications, intensive hospital monitoring, and follow-up care then help the heart heal and prevent future events. Quick action (calling 911 at the very first warning signs) is the single most important step for survival.
</response>

<gold_response>
Heart attack (Treatment): IMMEDIATE TREATMENT - You will be hooked up to a heart monitor, so the health care team can see how regularly your heart is beating. - You will receive oxygen so that your heart doesn't have to work as hard. - An intravenous line (IV) will be placed into one of your veins. Medicines and fluids pass through this IV. - You may get nitroglycerin and morphine to help reduce chest pain. - You may receive aspirin, unless it would not be safe for you. In that case, you will be given another medicine that prevents blood clots. - Dangerous abnormal heartbeats (arrhythmias) may be treated with medicine or electric shocks. EMERGENCY PROCEDURES Angioplasty is a procedure to open narrowed or blocked blood vessels that supply blood to the heart. - Angioplasty is often the first choice of treatment. It should be done within 90 minutes after you get to the hospital, and usually no later than 12 hours after a heart attack. - A stent is a small, metal mesh tube that opens up (expands) inside a coronary artery. A stent is usually placed after or during angioplasty. It helps prevent the artery from closing up again. You may be given drugs to break up the clot. This is called thrombolytic therapy. It is best if these drugs are given soon after the onset of symptoms, usually no later than 12 hours after it and ideally within 30 minutes of arriving to the hospital. Some people may also have heart bypass surgery to open narrowed or blocked blood vessels that supply blood to the heart. This procedure is also called coronary artery bypass grafting and/or open heart surgery. TREATMENT AFTER A HEART ATTACK After several days, you will be discharged from the hospital. You will likely need to take medicines, some for the rest of your life. Always talk to your provider before stopping or changing how you take any medicines. Stopping certain medicines can be deadly. While under the care of your health care team, you will learn: - How to take medicines to treat your heart problem and prevent more heart attacks - How to eat a heart-healthy diet - How to be active and exercise safely - What to do when you have chest pain - How to stop smoking Strong emotions are common after a heart attack. - You may feel sad - You may feel anxious and worry about being careful about everything you do All of these feelings are normal. They go away for most people after 2 or 3 weeks. You may also feel tired when you leave the hospital to go home. Most people who have had a heart attack take part in a cardiac rehabilitation program.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
How doctors usually find out whether someone has asthma  

1. Talk with you about your symptoms and health history  
   • When and how often do you cough, wheeze, feel short of breath or tight-chested?  
   • Do certain things—exercise, cold air, pollen, smoke, pets, viral colds—set the symptoms off?  
   • Have you or close relatives had asthma, eczema, hay fever or allergies?  
   • What medicines are you taking, and have any helped or worsened breathing?  

2. Do a physical examination  
   • The doctor listens for wheezing, looks for signs of allergic rhinitis or eczema, and checks your nose, throat, skin and chest.  
   • Because asthma symptoms can be absent between attacks, the exam can be completely normal. That is why lung-function tests are important.  

3. Measure how well your lungs work (lung-function or “pulmonary function” tests)  
   a. Spirometry – the main test  
      • You take a deep breath and blow hard into a machine.  
      • It records how much air you can blow out in one second (FEV1) and the total amount you blow out (FVC).  
      • You repeat the test after inhaling a quick-acting bronchodilator.  
      • A significant improvement (usually ≥12% and 200 mL rise in FEV1) strongly suggests asthma.  

   b. Peak expiratory flow (PEF) – simple office or home test  
      • Using a small hand-held meter, you blow out as fast as you can.  
      • Readings taken twice a day over several weeks show whether your airflow varies (larger swings are typical of asthma) and whether medicine makes it better.  

   c. Airway-challenge or provocation tests (if routine spirometry is normal but asthma is still suspected)  
      • Methacholine challenge: you inhale a mist that can narrow sensitive airways. Lung function is measured after each dose. Excessive narrowing confirms airway hyper-responsiveness typical of asthma.  
      • Exercise or cold-air challenge: lung function is measured before and after running on a treadmill or breathing cold air.  

   d. Exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO)  
      • A painless breath test that detects airway inflammation often seen in allergic asthma.  

4. Look for related conditions or triggers  
   • Allergy skin or blood tests (dust mites, pollens, animal dander, molds, foods)  
   • Chest X-ray or CT if another lung problem (e.g., infection, COPD) must be ruled out.  
   • Sinus or reflux evaluation when those conditions worsen asthma-like symptoms.  

5. Trial of asthma medicine  
   • Sometimes, especially in young children who cannot perform reliable spirometry, the doctor may give a few weeks of inhaled corticosteroid or bronchodilator therapy. Marked improvement in symptoms and lung function supports the diagnosis.  

Key points to remember  
• There is no single “yes/no” blood test for asthma. Diagnosis combines symptom history, a physical exam and objective lung-function measurements.  
• Asthma symptoms can come and go, so repeated testing or monitoring over time may be needed.  
• Getting an accurate diagnosis is important; wheezing and cough can also be caused by infections, COPD, vocal-cord dysfunction, heart disease, or medication side effects.  
• If you think you may have asthma, see a health professional. Early diagnosis and proper treatment can greatly reduce flare-ups and improve quality of life.

<gold_response>
Asthma (Diagnosis): Your primary care doctor will diagnose asthma based on your medical and family histories, a physical exam, and test results. Your doctor also will figure out the severity of your asthma—that is, whether it's intermittent, mild, moderate, or severe. The level of severity will determine what treatment you'll start on. You may need to see an asthma specialist if: You need special tests to help diagnose asthma You've had a life-threatening asthma attack You need more than one kind of medicine or higher doses of medicine to control your asthma, or if you have overall problems getting your asthma well controlled You're thinking about getting allergy treatments Medical and Family Histories Your doctor may ask about your family history of asthma and allergies. He or she also may ask whether you have asthma symptoms and when and how often they occur. Let your doctor know whether your symptoms seem to happen only during certain times of the year or in certain places, or if they get worse at night. Your doctor also may want to know what factors seem to trigger your symptoms or worsen them. For more information about possible asthma triggers, go to "What Are the Signs and Symptoms of Asthma?" Your doctor may ask you about related health conditions that can interfere with asthma management. These conditions include a runny nose, sinus infections, reflux disease, psychological stress, and sleep apnea. Physical Exam Your doctor will listen to your breathing and look for signs of asthma or allergies. These signs include wheezing, a runny nose or swollen nasal passages, and allergic skin conditions (such as eczema). Keep in mind that you can still have asthma even if you don't have these signs on the day that your doctor examines you. Diagnostic Tests Lung Function Test Your doctor will use a test called spirometry (spi-ROM-eh-tre) to check how your lungs are working. This test measures how much air you can breathe in and out. It also measures how fast you can blow air out. Your doctor also may give you medicine and then test you again to see whether the results have improved. If the starting results are lower than normal and improve with the medicine, and if your medical history shows a pattern of asthma symptoms, your diagnosis will likely be asthma. Other Tests Your doctor may recommend other tests if he or she needs more information to make a diagnosis. Other tests may include: Allergy testing to find out which allergens affect you, if any. A test to measure how sensitive your airways are. This is called a bronchoprovocation (brong-KO-prav-eh-KA-shun) test. Using spirometry, this test repeatedly measures your lung function during physical activity or after you receive increasing doses of cold air or a special chemical to breathe in. A test to show whether you have another condition with the same symptoms as asthma, such as reflux disease, vocal cord dysfunction, or sleep apnea. A chest x ray or an EKG (electrocardiogram). These tests will help find out whether a foreign object or other disease may be causing your symptoms. Diagnosing Asthma in Young Children Most children who have asthma develop their first symptoms before 5 years of age. However, asthma in young children (aged 0 to 5 years) can be hard to diagnose. Sometimes it's hard to tell whether a child has asthma or another childhood condition. This is because the symptoms of asthma also occur with other conditions. Also, many young children who wheeze when they get colds or respiratory infections don't go on to have asthma after they're 6 years old. A child may wheeze because he or she has small airways that become even narrower during colds or respiratory infections. The airways grow as the child grows older, so wheezing no longer occurs when the child gets colds. A young child who has frequent wheezing with colds or respiratory infections is more likely to have asthma if: One or both parents have asthma The child has signs of allergies, including the allergic skin condition eczema The child has allergic reactions to pollens or other airborne allergens The child wheezes even when he or she doesn't have a cold or other infection The most certain way to diagnose asthma is with a lung function test, a medical history, and a physical exam. However, it's hard to do lung function tests in children younger than 5 years. Thus, doctors must rely on children's medical histories, signs and symptoms, and physical exams to make a diagnosis. Doctors also may use a 4–6 week trial of asthma medicines to see how well a child responds.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Edward’s syndrome (trisomy 18) can be recognised by the baby’s physical appearance, but the only way to be certain is to look at the baby’s chromosomes. This can be done before birth (prenatally) or after birth.

1. Before birth  
   • Screening tests (tell you if the pregnancy is at increased risk)  
     – First-trimester combined screening: ultrasound measurement of nuchal translucency plus a blood test for pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) and β-hCG.  
     – Second-trimester maternal serum “quad” screen (AFP, hCG, unconjugated oestriol, inhibin-A).  
     – Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) / cell-free DNA test from the mother’s blood—this is the most sensitive screening test.  
     – Targeted ultrasound: certain findings (e.g., clenched fists, heart defects, growth restriction, strawberry-shaped head) point to trisomy 18.

   • Diagnostic tests (confirm the chromosome change)  
     – Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) – a sample of placental tissue taken at about 11–14 weeks.  
     – Amniocentesis – a sample of amniotic fluid taken from around the baby after 15 weeks.  
     – In either sample the laboratory performs karyotyping, FISH, or chromosomal microarray to look for an extra copy of chromosome 18.

2. After birth  
   • A newborn with typical facial features, clenched fists, rocker-bottom feet, heart defects, etc., raises suspicion.  
   • A blood sample is taken, and the baby’s chromosomes are analysed (standard karyotype or chromosomal microarray) to confirm trisomy 18.

In short, Edwards’ syndrome is definitively diagnosed by chromosome testing—prenatally via CVS or amniocentesis, or postnatally from a blood sample. Screening tests and ultrasound can indicate risk but are not conclusive.

<gold_response>
Trisomy 18 (Exams and Tests): An exam during pregnancy may show an unusually large uterus and extra amniotic fluid. There may be an unusually small placenta when the baby is born. A physical exam of the infant may show unusual fingerprint patterns. X-rays may show a short breast bone. Chromosome studies will show trisomy 18. The chromosome abnormality may be present in every cell or present in only a certain percentage of the cells (called mosaicism). Studies may also show part of the chromosome in some cells. Rarely, part of the chromosome 18 becomes attached to another chromosome. This is called translocation. Other signs include: - Hole, split, or cleft in the iris of the eye (coloboma) - Separation between the left and right side of the abdominal muscle (diastasis recti) - Umbilical hernia or inguinal hernia There are often signs of congenital heart disease, such as: - Atrial septal defect (ASD) - Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) - Ventricular septal defect (VSD) Tests may also show kidney problems, including: - Horseshoe kidney - Hydronephrosis - Polycystic kidney
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
How doctors diagnose Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)

1. Comprehensive medical and mental-health interview  
   • Your primary-care clinician or a mental-health professional (psychologist, psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse practitioner, etc.) begins by asking in-depth questions about what you worry about, how often, how long it has been going on, and how it affects your daily life (work, school, relationships, sleep).  
   • They also ask about your general health, use of medicines, caffeine, alcohol or other drugs, family history of anxiety or other mental-health problems, and any recent stresses or traumas.

2. Screening questionnaires  
   • Brief, validated tools such as the GAD-7, Generalized Anxiety Disorder Scale, or the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale may be used. These questionnaires do not make the diagnosis by themselves, but they quantify symptoms and help track progress over time.

3. Physical exam and basic laboratory tests  
   • Because several medical problems (thyroid disease, heart rhythm disturbances, anemia, vitamin B12 deficiency, hormone changes, medication side effects, etc.) can mimic or worsen anxiety, the clinician usually performs a physical exam and may order routine blood work or other tests to rule these out.

4. DSM-5 diagnostic criteria  
   To make an official diagnosis, most clinicians use the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5). The DSM-5 says a person has GAD when ALL of the following are true:  
   • Excessive anxiety and worry, occurring more days than not for at least 6 months, about several events or activities (not limited to one specific situation).  
   • The person finds it difficult to control the worry.  
   • The anxiety is accompanied by three (or more) of the following six symptoms (only one required in children):  
     – Restlessness or feeling keyed-up/on edge  
     – Being easily fatigued  
     – Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank  
     – Irritability  
     – Muscle tension  
     – Sleep disturbance (trouble falling or staying asleep, or unsatisfying sleep)  
   • The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational or other important areas of functioning.  
   • The disturbance is not due to the physiologic effects of a substance (drugs, medications) or another medical condition, and it is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., panic disorder, PTSD, obsessive-compulsive disorder).

5. Ruling out other mental-health conditions  
   • Depression, panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, and some personality disorders can overlap with GAD. The clinician carefully sorts out which condition—or combination—is present.

6. Optional referrals or additional testing  
   • If the presentation is unclear, you may be referred to a psychiatrist or psychologist for specialized assessment or therapy.  
   • In children or adolescents, developmental or learning evaluations might also be suggested.

What to expect afterward  
• Once GAD is confirmed, your clinician will discuss treatment options (usually some combination of cognitive-behavioral therapy, stress-management techniques, and/or medication) and help you set up regular follow-up to monitor progress.

Key points for patients  
• There is no single blood test or brain scan that “shows” GAD—the diagnosis is based on a careful history, symptom checklist, and ruling out other causes.  
• Sharing accurate information (including substance use, sleep habits, and any physical symptoms) is essential for a correct diagnosis.  
• Early diagnosis and treatment significantly improve quality of life and can prevent symptoms from becoming chronic.

predicted_text:
Gonorrhea can only be confirmed with a laboratory test done on a sample taken from the body site that may be infected. A clinician will:

1. Take a brief history and do a physical exam to decide which areas to test (genitals, throat, rectum, eyes in newborns).

2. Collect a specimen:
   • Urine sample (often the first-catch urine) – commonly used for people with penile/urethral infections.  
   • Swab from the cervix, vagina, urethra, rectum, throat, or (rarely) eyes – whichever sites may have been exposed during sex.

3. Send the specimen to the lab for one of these tests:
   • NAAT ( Nucleic Acid Amplification Test ) – detects the DNA/RNA of the bacteria; it is the most sensitive, rapid, and widely used test.  
   • Culture – grows the bacteria on a special medium; useful if antibiotic-resistance testing is needed.  
   • Gram stain – a quick microscope test sometimes done on urethral discharge from symptomatic men; less accurate in women.

Results:
   • NAAT results are usually available within 1–3 days.
   • If a culture is done, results may take several days and can guide choice of antibiotics if resistance is suspected.

Important points:
• Testing is recommended for anyone with symptoms (painful urination, discharge, pelvic pain) and for sexually active people at higher risk, including all sexually active women under 25 and men who have sex with men.  
• Because chlamydia often occurs with gonorrhea, the same sample is usually tested for both.  
• Do not rely on symptoms alone—many people have no symptoms.  
• See a healthcare professional promptly; untreated gonorrhea can cause serious health problems and can be cured with the right antibiotics.

Gonorrhea (Exams and Tests): Gonorrhea can be quickly detected by looking at a sample of discharge or tissue under the microscope. This is called a gram stain. This method is fast, but it is not the most certain. Gonorrhea is most accurately detected with DNA tests. DNA tests are useful for screening. The ligase chain reaction (LCR) test is one of the tests. DNA tests are quicker than cultures. These tests can be performed on urine samples, which are easier to collect than samples from the genital area. Prior to DNA tests, cultures (cells that grow in a lab dish) were used to provide proof of gonorrhea, but are less commonly used now. Samples for a culture are most often taken from the cervix, vagina, urethra, anus, or throat. - Rarely they are taken from joint fluid or blood - Cultures can often provide an early diagnosis within 24 hours. A confirmed diagnosis is available within 72 hours. If you have gonorrhea, you should ask to be tested for other sexually transmitted infections, including chlamydia, syphilis, and HIV herpes and hepatitis.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
How hemophilia is treated

1. Replacement (factor) therapy  
   • The mainstay of treatment is giving the missing clotting factor through an intravenous (IV) infusion.  
     – Hemophilia A: factor VIII concentrate  
     – Hemophilia B: factor IX concentrate  
   • Two ways the factor can be used  
     – On-demand: given as soon as bleeding starts or before a surgery/ dental work.  
     – Prophylaxis: regular infusions (often 1-3 times a week) to keep factor levels high enough to prevent bleeds altogether.

   • Types of factor products  
     – Plasma-derived (cleaned, virus-inactivated human plasma)  
     – Recombinant (laboratory-made, no human blood exposure)  
     – Extended-half-life versions that last longer in the bloodstream, so doses are needed less often.

2. Desmopressin (DDAVP)  
   • A nasal spray or IV medicine that makes the body release stored factor VIII and von Willebrand factor.  
   • Works only for mild or moderate hemophilia A; not useful for hemophilia B.

3. Antifibrinolytic medicines  
   • Examples: tranexamic acid (Lysteda), aminocaproic acid (Amicar).  
   • Taken by mouth or IV to keep clots from breaking down, helpful for mouth, nose, or dental bleeds and after surgery.

4. Topical agents and adjuncts  
   • Fibrin glue, gelatin sponges, or topical thrombin can be applied to wounds.  
   • Ice, pressure, and immobilization still matter.

5. Gene therapy (emerging)  
   • One-time IV treatment that delivers a working copy of the factor gene to liver cells.  
   • Early trials have shown multi-year increases in factor levels, but long-term safety and durability are still being studied.

6. Managing complications  
   • Inhibitors: Some patients develop antibodies (“inhibitors”) that neutralize infused factor. Options include:  
     – Bypassing agents (activated recombinant factor VII, FEIBA)  
     – Immune tolerance induction (repeated high-dose factor to train the body to accept it).  
   • Joint damage: Physical therapy, orthopedic care, and sometimes surgery.  
   • Pain: NSAIDs that do not affect clotting (e.g., celecoxib) or acetaminophen; avoid aspirin and most traditional NSAIDs.

7. Preventive measures & lifestyle  
   • Vaccinations for hepatitis A and B (because of historic risk from blood products).  
   • Good dental hygiene to avoid extractions.  
   • Exercise to strengthen muscles around joints (swimming, cycling) while avoiding high-impact contact sports.  
   • Wear medical-alert identification; keep factor concentrate available for emergencies.

8. Care team and follow-up  
   • Most people are followed in specialized Hemophilia Treatment Centers (HTCs) that provide coordinated hematology, nursing, physical therapy, and social work support.  
   • Regular lab monitoring of factor levels, inhibitor testing, and joint assessments are essential.

Key point: With modern replacement therapy and prophylaxis, many people with hemophilia lead active, near-normal lives and experience far fewer serious bleeds than in the past.
