<gold_response>
Nicotine dependence: Nicotine dependence -- also called tobacco dependence -- is an addiction to tobacco products caused by the drug nicotine. Nicotine dependence means you can't stop using the substance, even though it's causing you harm. Nicotine produces physical and mood-altering effects in your brain that are temporarily pleasing. These effects make you want to use tobacco and lead to dependence. At the same time, stopping tobacco use causes withdrawal symptoms, including irritability and anxiety. While it's the nicotine in tobacco that causes nicotine dependence, the toxic effects of tobacco result from other substances in tobacco. Smokers have much higher rates of heart disease, stroke and cancer than nonsmokers do. Regardless of how long you've smoked, stopping smoking can improve your health. Many effective treatments for nicotine dependence are available to help you manage withdrawal and stop smoking for good. Ask your doctor for help. For some people, using any amount of tobacco can quickly lead to nicotine dependence. Signs that you may be addicted include: - You can't stop smoking. You've made one or more serious, but unsuccessful, attempts to stop. - You experience withdrawal symptoms when you try to stop. Your attempts at stopping have caused physical and mood-related symptoms, such as strong cravings, anxiety, irritability, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, depressed mood, frustration, anger, increased hunger, insomnia, constipation or diarrhea. - You keep smoking despite health problems. Even though you've developed health problems with your lungs or your heart, you haven't been able to stop. - You give up social or recreational activities in order to smoke. You may stop going to smoke-free restaurants or stop socializing with certain family members or friends because you can't smoke in these locations or situations. You're not alone if you've tried to stop smoking but haven't been able to stop for good. Most smokers make many attempts to stop smoking before they achieve stable, long-term abstinence from smoking. You're more likely to stop for good if you follow a treatment plan that addresses both the physical and the behavioral aspects of nicotine dependence. Using medications and working with a counselor specially trained to help people stop smoking (a tobacco treatment specialist) will significantly boost your chances of success. Ask your doctor, counselor or therapist to help you develop a treatment plan that works for you or to advise you on where to get help to stop smoking. Nicotine is the chemical in tobacco that keeps you smoking. Nicotine is very addictive when delivered by inhaling tobacco smoke into the lungs, which quickly releases nicotine into the blood allowing it to get into the brain within seconds of taking a puff. In the brain nicotine increases the release of brain chemicals called neurotransmitters, which help regulate mood and behavior. Dopamine, one of these neurotransmitters, is released in the "reward center" of the brain and causes improved mood and feelings of pleasure. Experiencing these effects from nicotine is what makes tobacco so addictive. Nicotine dependence involves behavioral (routines, habits, feelings) as well as physical factors. These behavioral associations with smoking may act as triggers - situations or feelings that activate a craving for tobacco, even if you have not smoked for some time. Behaviors and cues that you may associate with smoking include: - Certain times of the day, such as first thing in the morning, with morning coffee or during breaks at work - After a meal - Drinking alcohol - Certain places or friends - Talking on the phone - Stressful situations or when you're feeling down - Sight or smell of a burning cigarette - Driving your car To overcome your dependence on tobacco, you need to become aware of your triggers and develop a plan to deal with the behaviors and routines that you associate with smoking. Anyone who smokes or uses other forms of tobacco is at risk of becoming dependent. Factors that influence who will use tobacco include: - Genetics. The likelihood that you will start smoking and keep smoking may be partly inherited - genetic factors may influence how receptors on the surface of your brain's nerve cells respond to high doses of nicotine delivered by cigarettes. - Home and peer influence. Children who grow up with parents who smoke are more likely to become smokers. Children with friends who smoke also are more likely to try cigarettes. Evidence suggests that smoking shown in movies and on the Internet can encourage young people to smoke. - Age. Most people begin smoking during childhood or the teen years. The younger you are when you begin smoking, the greater the chance that you'll become a heavy smoker as an adult. - Depression or other mental illness. Many studies show an association between depression and smoking. People who have depression, schizophrenia, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) or other forms of mental illness are more likely to be smokers. - Substance use. People who abuse alcohol and illegal drugs are more likely to be smokers. Tobacco smoke contains more than 60 known cancer-causing chemicals and thousands of other harmful substances. Even "all natural" or herbal cigarettes have chemicals that are harmful to your health. Smoking harms almost every organ of your body and impairs your body's immune system. About half of all regular smokers will die of a disease caused by tobacco. Women smokers are now at equal risk to men smokers of dying from lung cancer, COPD and cardiovascular disease caused by using tobacco. The negative health effects include: - Lung cancer and other lung diseases. Smoking causes nearly 9 out of 10 lung cancer cases. In addition, smoking causes other lung diseases, such as emphysema and chronic bronchitis. Smoking also makes asthma worse. - Other cancers. Smoking is a major cause of cancers of the esophagus, larynx, throat (pharynx) and mouth and is related to cancers of the bladder, pancreas, kidney and cervix, and some leukemias. Overall, smoking causes 30 percent of all cancer deaths. - Heart and circulatory system problems. Smoking increases your risk of dying of heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) disease, including heart attack and stroke. Even smoking just one to four cigarettes daily increases your risk of heart disease. If you have heart or blood vessel disease, such as heart failure, smoking worsens your condition. However, stopping smoking reduces your risk of having a heart attack by 50 percent in the first year. - Diabetes. Smoking increases insulin resistance, which can set the stage for the development of type 2 diabetes. If you have diabetes, smoking can speed the progress of complications, such as kidney disease and eye problems. - Eye problems. Smoking can increase your risk of serious eye problems such as cataracts and loss of eyesight from macular degeneration. - Infertility and impotence. Smoking increases the risk of reduced fertility in women and the risk of impotence in men. - Pregnancy and newborn complications. Mothers who smoke while pregnant face a higher risk of miscarriage, preterm delivery, lower birth weight and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) in their newborns. - Cold, flu and other illnesses. Smokers are more prone to respiratory infections, such as colds, flu and bronchitis. - Weakened senses. Smoking deadens your senses of taste and smell, so food isn't as appetizing. - Teeth and gum disease. Smoking is associated with an increased risk of developing inflammation of the gum (gingivitis) and a serious gum infection that can destroy the support system for teeth (periodontitis). - Physical appearance. The chemicals in tobacco smoke can change the structure of your skin, causing premature aging and wrinkles. Smoking also yellows your teeth, fingers and fingernails. - Risks to your family. Nonsmoking spouses and partners of smokers have a higher risk of lung cancer and heart disease compared with people who don't live with a smoker. If you smoke, your children will be more prone to SIDS, worsening asthma, ear infections and colds. Your doctor may ask you questions or have you complete a questionnaire to get a sense of how dependent you are on nicotine. The more cigarettes you smoke each day and the sooner you smoke after awakening, the more dependent you are. Knowing your degree of dependence will help your doctor determine the best treatment plan for you. Like most smokers, you've probably made at least one serious attempt to stop. But it's rare to stop smoking on your first attempt - especially if you try to do it without help. You're much more likely to stop if you use medications and counseling, which have both been proved effective, especially in combination. Medications Many treatments, including nicotine replacement therapy and non-nicotine medications, have been approved as safe and effective in treating nicotine dependence. Using more than one medication may help you get better results. For example, combining a longer acting medication with a short-acting nicotine replacement product may be beneficial. Talk to your health care provider about the right treatment for you. If you're pregnant or breast-feeding, you smoke fewer than 10 cigarettes a day, or you're under age 18, talk to your doctor before taking any over-the-counter nicotine replacement products. Nicotine replacement therapy Nicotine replacement therapy gives you nicotine without tobacco and the harmful chemicals in tobacco smoke. Nicotine replacement products help relieve withdrawal symptoms and cravings. The best time to start using nicotine replacement medication is on the date you've set to stop smoking. Some smokers start earlier in order to reduce smoking on their way to stopping altogether. The following nicotine replacement products are available over-the-counter: - Nicotine patch (NicoDerm CQ, Habitrol, others). The patch delivers nicotine through your skin and into your bloodstream. You wear a new patch each day. You typically use the patch for eight weeks or longer. If you haven't been able to stop smoking completely after two weeks of wearing the patch, ask your doctor about adjusting the dose or adding another nicotine replacement product. Common side effects include skin irritation, insomnia and vivid dreams. - Nicotine gum (Nicorette, others). This gum delivers nicotine to your blood through the lining of your mouth. Nicotine gum is often recommended to curb cravings. Chew the gum for a few times until you feel a mild tingling or peppery taste, then park the gum between your cheek and gumline for several minutes. This chewing and parking allows nicotine to be gradually absorbed in your bloodstream. Mouth irritation is a common side effect. Other side effects are often a result of overly vigorous chewing that releases nicotine too quickly. These include heartburn, nausea and hiccups. - Nicotine lozenge (Commit, Nicorette mini lozenge, others). This lozenge dissolves in your mouth and, like nicotine gum, delivers nicotine through the lining of your mouth. Place the lozenge in your mouth between your gumline and cheek or under your tongue and allow it to dissolve. You'll start with one lozenge every one to two hours and gradually increase the time between lozenges. Avoid drinking anything right before, while using or right after the lozenge. Side effects include mouth irritation as well as nicotine-related effects such as heartburn, nausea and hiccups. These nicotine replacement products are available by prescription: - Nicotine nasal spray (Nicotrol NS). The nicotine in this product, sprayed directly into each nostril, is absorbed through your nasal membranes into your blood vessels. The nasal spray delivers nicotine a bit quicker than gum, lozenges or the patch, but not as rapidly as smoking a cigarette. It's usually prescribed for three-month periods for up to six months. Nasal and throat irritation, runny nose, sneezing and coughing are common side effects. - Nicotine inhaler (Nicotrol). This device is shaped something like a cigarette holder. You puff on it, and it delivers nicotine vapor into your mouth. You absorb the nicotine through the lining in your mouth, where it then enters your bloodstream. Common side effects are mouth and throat irritation and occasional coughing. Non-nicotine medications Medications that don't contain nicotine and are available by prescription include: - Bupropion (Zyban). The antidepressant drug bupropion increases levels of dopamine and norepinephrine, brain chemicals that are also boosted by nicotine. Typically your doctor will advise you to start bupropion one week before you stop smoking. Bupropion has the advantage of helping to minimize weight gain after you quit smoking. Common side effects include insomnia, agitation, headache and dry mouth. If you have a history of seizures or serious head trauma, such as a skull fracture, you shouldn't take this drug. - Varenicline (Chantix). This medication acts on the brain's nicotine receptors, decreasing withdrawal symptoms and reducing the feelings of pleasure you get from smoking. Typically your doctor will advise you to start varenicline one week before you stop smoking. Common side effects include nausea, headache, insomnia and vivid dreams. Rarely, varenicline has been associated with serious psychiatric symptoms, such as depressed mood and suicidal thoughts. - Nortriptyline (Pamelor). This medication may be prescribed if other medications haven't helped. This tricyclic antidepressant acts by increasing the levels of the brain neurotransmitter norepinephrine. Common side effects may include dry mouth, drowsiness, dizziness and constipation. Counseling, support groups and other programs Combining medications with behavioral counseling provides the best chance for establishing long-term smoking abstinence. Medications help you cope by reducing withdrawal symptoms including tobacco craving, while behavioral treatments help you develop the skills you need to avoid tobacco over the long run. The more time you spend with a counselor, the better your treatment results will be. Several types of counseling and support can help with stopping smoking: - Telephone counseling. No matter where you live, you can take advantage of phone counseling to help you give up tobacco. Every state in the U.S. has a telephone quit line, and some have more than one. To find the options in your state, call 800-QUIT-NOW (800-784-8669). - Individual or group counseling program. Your doctor may recommend local support groups or a treatment program where counseling is provided by a tobacco treatment specialist. Counseling helps you learn techniques for preparing to stop smoking and provides support for you during the process. Many hospitals, health care plans, health care providers and employers offer treatment programs or have tobacco treatment specialists who are certified to provide treatment for nicotine dependence. Nicotine Anonymous groups are available in many locations to provide support for smokers trying to quit. Some medical centers provide residential treatment programs - the most intensive treatment available. - Internet-based programs. Several websites offer support and strategies for people who want to stop smoking. BecomeAnEX is free and provides information and techniques as well as blogs, community forums, ask the expert and many other features. Text messaging services, including personalized reminders about a quit-smoking plan, also may prove helpful. Methods to avoid It's not a good idea to substitute another type of tobacco use for cigarette smoking. Tobacco in any form is not safe. Even products that deliver nicotine without tobacco are risky. Stick with proven stop-smoking aids and steer clear of the following products: - Dissolvable tobacco products. Tobacco pouches, lozenges, strips or other products contain small amounts of tobacco and nicotine you hold or dissolve in your mouth. There is no evidence they will help you stop smoking and little is known about their health effects. - E-cigarettes. Electronic cigarettes, or e-cigarettes, are battery-powered devices that heat liquid containing nicotine into a vapor to be inhaled. Because these products are new, there isn't much data about possible safety risks. Studies of e-cigarettes for smoking cessation have shown mixed results. For these reasons, e-cigarettes aren't recommended for people trying to quit smoking. - Flavored cigarettes. Clove cigarettes (kreteks) and flavored cigarettes (bidis) carry the same health risks as smoking regular cigarettes and can cause additional health problems. Although they're banned in the United States, flavored cigarettes are available in other countries. - Hookahs (narghiles). These are water pipes that burn tobacco, and the smoke is inhaled through a hose. They are not safer than cigarettes. The water does not filter out toxins in the smoke, and the water and pipe have a risk of transmitting infections. - Nicotine lollipops and balms. Products containing nicotine salicylate are not approved by the Food and Drug Administration, and they pose a risk for accidental use by children. - Pipes and cigars. These products have similar, though less frequent, health risks as cigarettes, and they are not a safe alternative. - Smokeless tobacco and snuff (snus). These products contain nicotine in amounts similar to cigarettes and increase your risk of mouth and throat cancer, tooth and gum diseases, and other health problems. It's important to have a plan for managing nicotine withdrawal symptoms. Withdrawal symptoms are usually the most intense during the first week after you stop smoking. They may continue for several weeks, with declining intensity. Although most nicotine withdrawal symptoms pass within a month, you may occasionally experience a strong urge or craving to smoke months after stopping. Triggers or cues that were associated with your smoking can provoke these urges or cravings. Here's what you can do to help manage nicotine withdrawal symptoms: - Exercise regularly. Regular physical activity has been found to reduce withdrawal symptoms and help people stop smoking. Exercise also helps avoid potential weight gain often associated with stopping. - Wait out cravings. Cravings or urges usually last less than five minutes. Wash the dishes, go for a walk or have a healthy snack, such as carrots, an apple or sunflower seeds, which will keep your mouth busy. Do something that keeps your hands busy, and before you know it, the urge will have passed. This is why you want to get rid of tobacco supplies when you decide to quit. You don't want to have any on hand when a craving hits. - Identify rationalizations. If you find yourself thinking, "I'll just smoke one to get through this tough time" or "Just one won't hurt," recognize it as a message that can derail your plan. Review your reasons for quitting, and replace that thought with something positive to support your stopping. - Talk to a support person. If you're feeling anxious or depressed or need encouragement, a support person can help you get through a difficult craving. - Avoid high-risk situations. Know your triggers, and stay away from people, places and situations that tempt you to smoke. - Eat regular, healthy meals. Include plenty of fruits and vegetables, and drink more water. Many products claim to be smoking-cessation aids. Many also claim to be "natural." Just remember that "natural" doesn't necessarily mean "safe." Talk with your doctor before trying any alternative medicine treatments. - Acupuncture. Acupuncture involves stimulating points on the body, typically with thin, solid, metallic needles. Several studies have been conducted on the effects of acupuncture or acupressure for smoking cessation, but there's no definitive evidence that it works. - Herbs and supplements. A few studies have been conducted on the dietary supplements SAMe, silver acetate and St. John's wort for the treatment of tobacco dependence, but there is no current evidence that any natural product improves smoking cessation rates. - Hypnosis. Although no evidence supports the use of hypnosis - also called hypnotherapy - in smoking cessation, some people find it helpful. If you choose to pursue hypnosis, talk to your doctor about finding a reputable therapist. - Meditation. Although no evidence supports the effectiveness of meditation in smoking cessation, some people find it helpful to reduce symptoms of anxiety.

How often you need a Pap smear (Pap test) depends mainly on your age, your test history, and certain risk factors. Current U.S. guidelines that most professional groups (ACOG, USPSTF, ACS) agree on are:

• Age 21–29  
  – Pap test (cytology) every 3 years.  
  – Routine HPV testing is not recommended in this age group unless the Pap result is abnormal.  

• Age 30–65 – three acceptable choices  
  1. Pap test alone every 3 years, OR  
  2. High-risk HPV test alone every 5 years, OR  
  3. Co-testing (Pap + high-risk HPV) every 5 years.  

• Over 65  
  – You can stop screening if you have had adequate prior negative results (e.g., three negative Pap tests or two negative HPV-based tests in the past 10 years, with the most recent within 3–5 years) and no history of cervical precancer (CIN 2 or higher) in the last 20 years.  
  – Continue screening past 65 if these conditions are not met or if you have risk factors.  

• After a total hysterectomy (removal of uterus AND cervix) for reasons other than cancer or high-grade precancer  
  – No further Pap smears are needed, unless you have a history of cervical cancer or high-grade dysplasia.  

• Higher-risk situations (HIV infection, immunosuppression, DES exposure in utero, or a previous diagnosis of CIN 2/3 or cervical cancer)  
  – Need more frequent or prolonged screening; follow your specialist’s advice.  

Key points  
1. Start at age 21 even if you’re not sexually active or received the HPV vaccine.  
2. Follow the schedule that matches your age and prior results unless your clinician recommends a different interval.  
3. Abnormal results or positive HPV tests change the follow-up plan; your provider will tell you when to return.  
4. Guidelines can vary slightly by country and may change as evidence evolves—always confirm with your health-care provider.

how often do you need a pap smear
</question>

The response will be provided in these tags:
<response>
How often you need a Pap smear (Pap test) depends mainly on your age, your test history, and certain risk factors. Current U.S. guidelines that most professional groups (ACOG, USPSTF, ACS) agree on are:

• Age 21–29  
  – Pap test (cytology) every 3 years.  
  – Routine HPV testing is not recommended in this age group unless the Pap result is abnormal.  

• Age 30–65 – three acceptable choices  
  1. Pap test alone every 3 years, OR  
  2. High-risk HPV test alone every 5 years, OR  
  3. Co-testing (Pap + high-risk HPV) every 5 years.  

• Over 65  
  – You can stop screening if you have had adequate prior negative results (e.g., three negative Pap tests or two negative HPV-based tests in the past 10 years, with the most recent within 3–5 years) and no history of cervical precancer (CIN 2 or higher) in the last 20 years.  
  – Continue screening past 65 if these conditions are not met or if you have risk factors.  

• After a total hysterectomy (removal of uterus AND cervix) for reasons other than cancer or high-grade precancer  
  – No further Pap smears are needed, unless you have a history of cervical cancer or high-grade dysplasia.  

• Higher-risk situations (HIV infection, immunosuppression, DES exposure in utero, or a previous diagnosis of CIN 2/3 or cervical cancer)  
  – Need more frequent or prolonged screening; follow your specialist’s advice.  

Key points  
1. Start at age 21 even if you’re not sexually active or received the HPV vaccine.  
2. Follow the schedule that matches your age and prior results unless your clinician recommends a different interval.  
3. Abnormal results or positive HPV tests change the follow-up plan; your provider will tell you when to return.  
4. Guidelines can vary slightly by country and may change as evidence evolves—always confirm with your health-care provider.
</response>

Dysplasia can be detected by a medical test called a Pap smear. Dysplasia is fully treatable. That is why it is important for women to get regular Pap smears, so that precancerous cells can be removed before they can become cancer. Pap smear screening should start at age 21. Talk with your provider about how often you should have a Pap smear.

predicted_text:
How smoking tobacco affects the brain

1. Nicotine reaches the brain in seconds  
• With each puff, nicotine crosses the blood-brain barrier in 10–20 seconds.  
• It binds mainly to “nicotinic” acetylcholine receptors, overstimulating them and triggering the release of several brain chemicals—especially dopamine (pleasure/reward), norepinephrine (alertness), serotonin (mood), and endorphins (pain relief).

2. Creates rapid dependence and addiction  
• The dopamine surge produces a brief feeling of pleasure or stress-relief that the brain quickly learns to repeat.  
• Over time the brain produces more nicotine receptors and becomes less sensitive to its own natural chemicals.  
• When nicotine levels fall (even after a couple of hours), withdrawal symptoms appear—irritability, craving, poor concentration—driving the next cigarette.

3. Short-term functional changes  
• Momentary increase in alertness and reaction time.  
• Mild appetite suppression.  
• Constriction of blood vessels, briefly reducing brain oxygen; some people experience light-headedness or headache.  
• Temporary rise in heart rate and blood pressure, which stresses brain blood vessels.

4. Long-term structural and cognitive effects  
• Imaging studies show reduced gray matter volume in areas involved with memory, decision-making, and impulse control (prefrontal cortex, hippocampus).  
• White-matter damage (“small-vessel disease”) appears earlier and more extensively in smokers, slowing information processing.  
• Faster age-related cognitive decline and up to 40 % higher risk of dementia, including Alzheimer’s disease.  
• In teens and young adults, smoking interferes with brain development, leading to poorer attention, learning, and emotional regulation.

5. Mood and mental-health impact  
• Many smokers report smoking to “calm nerves,” but long-term use is linked to higher rates of anxiety, depression, and irritability.  
• Withdrawal can intensify these feelings, creating a cycle that reinforces addiction.  
• People with existing mental-health conditions often need higher nicotine doses and find quitting harder, but they benefit greatly when they do stop.

6. Vascular injury → Stroke and aneurysm risk  
• Tobacco smoke damages the lining of blood vessels, promotes clot formation, raises blood pressure, and lowers “good” HDL cholesterol.  
• Smokers are about twice as likely to suffer an ischemic (clot-related) stroke and up to four times as likely to have a hemorrhagic stroke or brain aneurysm rupture.  
• Second-hand smoke also increases stroke risk in nonsmokers.

7. Other neurologic concerns  
• Greater frequency of migraines and cluster headaches.  
• Possible worsening of multiple sclerosis progression.  
• In pregnant smokers, nicotine and carbon monoxide impair fetal brain growth, increasing the chance of learning difficulties, behavioral disorders, and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

8. What happens after quitting?  
Within 20 minutes blood pressure and heart rate begin to normalize.  
• 1–3 days: Most nicotine leaves the body; receptor activity starts to reset.  
• 2–12 weeks: Brain blood flow and oxygenation improve; many people notice clearer thinking and better mood.  
• 1–5 years: Stroke risk drops sharply—often reaching that of a nonsmoker after 5 years.  
• Long-term: Cognitive decline slows, and risk of dementia and depression continues to fall.

9. Tips and resources for quitting  
• Combine behavioral support (counseling, quit-lines, apps) with evidence-based medications (nicotine replacement, bupropion, varenicline) for the best success.  
• Set a quit date, identify triggers, and plan alternatives (deep breathing, short walks, water).  
• Talk with a healthcare professional if you have mood disorders or other medical conditions; tailored plans improve outcomes.  
• Free help:  
  – 1-800-QUIT-NOW (USA) connects to your state quit-line  
  – Smokefree.gov, SmokefreeTXT, and Smokefree apps  
  – Local pharmacy or community health clinics often offer programs.

Bottom line  
Smoking delivers nicotine to the brain almost instantly, creating powerful addiction, altering brain chemistry, and, over time, damaging brain structure and blood vessels. These changes raise the risk of stroke, cognitive decline, and mood disorders. The brain begins to heal soon after quitting, and the earlier you stop, the more protection you gain.

<gold_response>
Nicotine and tobacco: The nicotine in tobacco can be addictive like alcohol, cocaine, and morphine. Tobacco is a plant grown for its leaves, which are smoked, chewed, or sniffed. - Tobacco contains a chemical called nicotine. Nicotine is an addictive substance. - Millions of people in the United States have been able to quit smoking. Although the number of cigarette smokers in the United States has dropped in recent years, the number of smokeless tobacco users has steadily increased. Smokeless tobacco products are either placed in the mouth, cheek, or lip and sucked or chewed on, or placed in the nasal passage. The nicotine in these products is absorbed at the same rate as smoking tobacco, and addiction is still very strong. Both smoking and smokeless tobacco use carry many health risks. Nicotine use can have many different effects on the body. It can: - Decrease the appetite; fear of weight gain makes some people unwilling to stop smoking - Boost mood, give people a sense of well-being, and possibly even relieve minor depression - Increase activity in the intestines - Create more saliva and phlegm - Increase the heart rate by around 10 to 20 beats per minute - Increase blood pressure by 5 to 10 mm Hg - Possibly cause sweating, nausea, and diarrhea - Stimulate memory and alertness; people who use tobacco often depend on it to help them accomplish certain tasks and perform well Symptoms of nicotine withdrawal appear within 2 to 3 hours after you last use tobacco. People who smoked the longest or smoked a greater number of cigarettes each day are more likely to have withdrawal symptoms. For those who are quitting, symptoms peak about 2 to 3 days later. Common symptoms include: - Intense craving for nicotine - Anxiety - Depression - Drowsiness or trouble sleeping - Bad dreams and nightmares - Feeling tense, restless, or frustrated - Headaches - Increased appetite and weight gain - Problems concentrating You may notice some or all of these symptoms when switching from regular to low-nicotine cigarettes or reducing the number of cigarettes you smoke. It is hard to stop smoking or using smokeless tobacco, but anyone can do it. There are many ways to quit smoking. There are also resources to help you quit. Family members, friends, and co-workers may be supportive. Quitting tobacco is hard if you are trying to do it alone. To be successful, you must really want to quit. Most people who have quit smoking were unsuccessful at least once in the past. Try not to view past attempts as failures. See them as learning experiences. Most smokers find it hard to break all the habits they have created around smoking. A smoking cessation program may improve your chance for success. These programs are offered by hospitals, health departments, community centers, work sites, and national organizations. Nicotine replacement therapy may also be helpful. It involves the use of products that provide low doses of nicotine, but none of the toxins found in smoke. Nicotine replacement comes in the form of: - Gum - Inhalers - Throat lozenges - Nasal spray - Skin patches You can buy many types of nicotine replacement without a prescription. The goal is to relieve cravings for nicotine and ease your withdrawal symptoms. Health experts warn that e-cigarettes are not a replacement therapy for cigarette smoking. It is not known exactly how much nicotine is in e-cigarette cartridges, because information on labels is often wrong. Your health care provider can also prescribe other types of medicines to help you quit and prevent you from starting again. Your provider can refer you to stop smoking programs. These are offered by hospitals, health departments, community centers, work sites, and national organizations. People who are trying to quit smoking often become discouraged when they do not succeed at first. Research shows that the more times you try, the more likely you are to succeed. If you start smoking again after you have tried to quit, do not give up. Look at what worked or did not work, think of new ways to quit smoking, and try again. There are many more reasons to quit using tobacco. Knowing the serious health risks from tobacco may help motivate you to quit. Tobacco and related chemicals can increase your risk of serious health problems such as cancer, lung disease, and heart attack. See your provider if you wish to stop smoking, or have already done so and are having withdrawal symptoms. Your provider can help recommend treatments. Updated by: Laura J. Martin, MD, MPH, ABIM Board Certified in Internal Medicine and Hospice and Palliative Medicine, Atlanta GA. Internal review and update on 09/01/2016 by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

predicted_text:
How smoking harms the body – from head to toe

Smoking does far more than hurt the lungs. The thousands of chemicals in cigarette smoke circulate through the bloodstream within seconds, so nearly every organ is exposed. Below is a plain-language tour of the major effects.

1. Brain and nervous system  
• Nicotine reaches the brain in 10-20 seconds, releasing dopamine, which makes smoking feel rewarding and fosters addiction.  
• Over time, smoking narrows arteries that supply the brain, increasing the risk of stroke, aneurysm and vascular dementia.  
• Carbon monoxide reduces oxygen delivery, which can contribute to headaches, fatigue and poor concentration.

2. Eyes, ears, mouth  
• Raises the chance of cataracts, macular degeneration and vision loss.  
• Contributes to hearing loss by damaging blood flow to the inner ear.  
• Causes gum disease, tooth loss, stained teeth, bad breath and cancers of the lip, mouth, throat and larynx.

3. Heart and blood vessels  
• Nicotine triggers the release of adrenaline, raising heart rate and blood pressure.  
• Smoke chemicals injure the lining of arteries, making them sticky; LDL (“bad”) cholesterol is more likely to build up, forming plaques.  
• Plaques plus blood clotting factors in smoke sharply raise the risk of heart attack, stroke and peripheral artery disease.  
• Smokers have about 2–4 times the risk of coronary heart disease compared with nonsmokers.

4. Lungs and airways  
• Damages cilia (tiny cleaning hairs) and inflames the airways, leading to chronic cough and mucus.  
• Main cause of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD: emphysema and chronic bronchitis).  
• About 80–90 % of lung cancers are linked to smoking, but it also raises risk for cancers of the trachea, bronchus and other respiratory sites.  
• Worsens asthma and increases susceptibility to pneumonia and tuberculosis.

5. Immune system  
• Weakens immune cells, making smokers more prone to infections (e.g., influenza, COVID-19 complications, wound infections).  
• Promotes systemic inflammation, which is tied to autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis.

6. Digestive system  
• Raises acid production and weakens the lower esophageal sphincter, contributing to heartburn and GERD.  
• Greatly increases risk of cancers of the esophagus, stomach, pancreas, liver and colon.  
• Aggravates Crohn’s disease and peptic ulcers; slows healing of ulcers.

7. Kidneys and urinary tract  
• Smoking is a significant risk factor for bladder and kidney cancers.  
• Accelerates progression of chronic kidney disease, especially in people with diabetes or high blood pressure.

8. Reproductive system  
Men:  
 • Impairs blood flow needed for erections (erectile dysfunction).  
 • Lowers sperm count and motility, raising infertility risk.  
Women:  
 • Damages eggs and accelerates loss of ovarian reserve, advancing menopause by 1-2 years.  
 • Raises infertility, ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage rates.  
Pregnancy:  
 • Nicotine and carbon monoxide reduce oxygen and nutrients to the fetus, leading to preterm birth, low birth weight, sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and lifelong health problems in children.

9. Endocrine and metabolic effects  
• Increases insulin resistance, doubling the risk of type 2 diabetes and worsening its complications.  
• Central (abdominal) fat accumulates even if body weight is not high.

10. Bones, muscles and joints  
• Reduces blood supply to bone and muscle, slowing injury recovery.  
• Lowers bone-forming cells’ activity, leading to earlier osteoporosis and higher fracture risk, particularly in the hip, spine and wrist.  
• Impairs spinal disc nutrition, contributing to chronic back pain.

11. Skin and appearance  
• Constricts blood vessels and breaks down collagen and elastin, causing premature wrinkles, skin discoloration and slower wound healing.  
• Yellow stains on fingers and nails; hair may become dull or thin.

12. Blood components  
• Raises levels of carbon monoxide, which binds hemoglobin more tightly than oxygen, reducing oxygen transport.  
• Increases blood viscosity and clotting factors, making clots more likely.

13. Cancer in many sites  
Besides lungs, smoking is linked to cancers of the mouth, throat, esophagus, stomach, pancreas, liver, kidney, bladder, cervix, colon, rectum, and some forms of leukemia.

Secondhand smoke  
People nearby inhale many of the same toxins. Children exposed to secondhand smoke have more ear infections, asthma, pneumonia and sudden infant death syndrome, while adults face higher heart disease, stroke and lung cancer risk.

Good news: Benefits of quitting start quickly  
• 20 minutes: heart rate and

 • Damages eggs and accelerates loss of ovarian reserve, advancing menopause by 1-2 years.  
 • Raises infertility, ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage rates.  
Pregnancy:  
 • Nicotine and carbon monoxide reduce oxygen and nutrients to the fetus, leading to preterm birth, low birth weight, sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and lifelong health problems in children.

9. Endocrine and metabolic effects  
• Increases insulin resistance, doubling the risk of type 2 diabetes and worsening its complications.  
• Central (abdominal) fat accumulates even if body weight is not high.

10. Bones, muscles and joints  
• Reduces blood supply to bone and muscle, slowing injury recovery.  
• Lowers bone-forming cells’ activity, leading to earlier osteoporosis and higher fracture risk, particularly in the hip, spine and wrist.  
• Impairs spinal disc nutrition, contributing to chronic back pain.

11. Skin and appearance  
• Constricts blood vessels and breaks down collagen and elastin, causing premature wrinkles, skin discoloration and slower wound healing.  
• Yellow stains on fingers and nails; hair may become dull or thin.

12. Blood components  
• Raises levels of carbon monoxide, which binds hemoglobin more tightly than oxygen, reducing oxygen transport.  
• Increases blood viscosity and clotting factors, making clots more likely.

13. Cancer in many sites  
Besides lungs, smoking is linked to cancers of the mouth, throat, esophagus, stomach, pancreas, liver, kidney, bladder, cervix, colon, rectum, and some forms of leukemia.

Secondhand smoke  
People nearby inhale many of the same toxins. Children exposed to secondhand smoke have more ear infections, asthma, pneumonia and sudden infant death syndrome, while adults face higher heart disease, stroke and lung cancer risk.

Benefits of quitting tobacco (Summary): If you smoke, you should quit. But quitting can be hard. Most people who have quit smoking have tried at least once, without success, in the past. View any past attempts to quit as a learning experience, not a failure. There are many reasons to quit using tobacco. Long-term use of tobacco can increase your risk of many serious health problems. THE BENEFITS OF QUITTING You may enjoy the following when you quit smoking. - Your breath, clothes, and hair will smell better. - Your sense of smell will return. Food will taste better. - Your fingers and fingernails will slowly appear less yellow. - Your stained teeth may slowly become whiter. - Your children will be healthier and will be less likely to start smoking. - It will be easier and cheaper to find an apartment or hotel room. - You may have an easier time getting a job. - Friends may be more willing to be in your car or home. - It may be easier to find a date. Many people do not smoke and do not like to be around people who smoke. - You will save money. If you smoke a pack a day, you spend about $2,000 a year on cigarettes. HEALTH BENEFITS Some health benefits begin almost immediately. Every week, month, and year without tobacco further improves your health. - Within 20 minutes of quitting: Your blood pressure and pulse rate drop to normal and the temperature of your hands and feet increases to normal. - Within 8 hours of quitting: Your blood carbon monoxide levels drop and your blood oxygen levels increase to normal levels. - Within 24 hours of quitting: Your risk of a sudden heart attack goes down. - Within 48 hours of quitting: Your nerve endings begin to regrow. Your senses of smell and taste begin to return to normal. - Within 2 weeks to 3 months of quitting: Your circulation improves. Walking becomes easier. Your lungs work better. Wounds heal more quickly. - Within 1 to 9 months of quitting: You have more energy. Smoking-related symptoms, such as coughing, nasal congestion, fatigue, and shortness of breath improve. You will have fewer illnesses, colds, and asthma attacks. You will gradually no longer be short of breath with everyday activities. - Within 1 year of quitting: Your risk of coronary heart disease is half that of someone still using tobacco. - Within 5 years of quitting: Your risk of mouth, throat, esophagus, and bladder cancers are reduced by half. - Within 10 years of quitting: Your risk of dying from lung cancer is about one half that of a person who still smokes. Other health benefits of quitting smoking include: - Lower chance of blood clots in the legs, which may travel to the lungs - Lower risk of erectile dysfunction - Fewer problems during pregnancy, such as babies born at low birth weight, premature labor, miscarriage, and cleft lip - Lower risk of infertility due to damaged sperm - Healthier teeth, gums, and skin Infants and children who you live with will have: - Asthma that is easier to control - Fewer visits to the emergency room - Fewer colds, ear infections, and pneumonia - Reduced risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) MAKING THE DECISION Like any addiction, quitting tobacco is difficult, especially if you do it alone. There are a lot of ways to quit smoking and many resources to help you. Talk to your health care provider about nicotine replacement therapy and smoking cessation medications. If you join smoking cessation programs, you have a much better chance of success. Such programs are offered by hospitals, health departments, community centers, and work sites.

Below is general, evidence-based information for educational purposes. It is not a substitute for a professional evaluation or treatment plan. If anxiety feels unmanageable, if you are having thoughts of self-harm, or if you notice it interfering with your ability to function, seek help from a qualified mental-health professional right away (or call 988 in the U.S. / your local emergency number).

-------------------------------------------------
1. Start with the basics
-------------------------------------------------
• Rule out medical causes  
  – Thyroid problems, cardiac arrhythmias, vitamin deficiencies, some medications, excessive caffeine or substance use can mimic or worsen anxiety.  
  – A routine physical exam and lab tests can help identify reversible contributors.

• Tend to pillars of health  
  – Sleep: Aim for 7-9 hours; keep a consistent bedtime, reduce screen time 1-2 h before bed.  
  – Nutrition: Eat balanced meals, stabilize blood sugar (protein, whole grains, healthy fats). Limit stimulants (caffeine, energy drinks) and alcohol.  
  – Movement: 150 min/week of moderate aerobic activity (e.g., brisk walking, cycling) has been shown to reduce anxiety symptoms by up to 20–30 %.  

-------------------------------------------------
2. Quick in-the-moment strategies
-------------------------------------------------
• 4-7-8 breathing: Inhale through your nose for 4 s, hold 7 s, exhale slowly for 8 s (4 cycles). This slows heart rate and activates the parasympathetic nervous system.

• Grounding (5-4-3-2-1): Identify 5 things you can see, 4 you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, 1 you can taste. Helps shift focus away from racing thoughts.

• Progressive muscle relaxation: Starting at your toes and moving upward, tense each muscle group for 5 s, then release 15 s. Lowers physical tension that fuels anxious feelings.

• Temperature change: Splash cold water on face or hold a chilled pack to the neck for 30 s; the “dive reflex” slows heart rate.

-------------------------------------------------
3. Long-term psychological approaches
-------------------------------------------------
• Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)  
  – Gold-standard for generalized anxiety, panic, social anxiety, OCD.  
  – Teaches you to identify unhelpful thought patterns (“catastrophizing,” “all-or-nothing”), test them against evidence, and replace them with balanced thoughts.  
  – Often includes graduated exposure to feared situations, reducing avoidance.

• Mindfulness-based interventions  
  – Practices like mindful breathing, body scan, or guided meditation enhance present-moment awareness and reduce rumination.  
  – Apps with randomized controlled trial support: Headspace, Calm, Insight Timer.

• Acceptance & Commitment Therapy (ACT)  
  – Focuses on accepting anxious sensations, defusing from thoughts, and acting in line with personal values despite discomfort.

• Self-help resources  
  – Books: “The Anxiety and Phobia Workbook” (Bourne), “Feeling Good” (Burns), “Rewire Your Anxious Brain” (Pittman & Karle).  
  – Free CBT worksheets: PsychologyTools.com, TherapistAid.com.

-------------------------------------------------
4. Lifestyle & social supports
-------------------------------------------------
• Social connection: Schedule regular time with supportive friends/family. Isolation amplifies anxiety.

• Time in nature: 20-30 min of “green time” (park, garden) lowers cortisol and heart rate variability.

• Limit screen/news exposure: Continuous negative news cycles can heighten worry; set daily limits.

• Structured routine: Predictability calms the nervous system; use planners, reminders, or phone alarms.

-------------------------------------------------
5. When to consider professional help
-------------------------------------------------
• Physical symptoms (palpitations, dizziness, GI distress) are frequent/daily.  
• You avoid work, school, social or family activities due to fear or worry.  
• Sleep is chronically poor despite sleep-hygiene efforts.  
• Panic attacks, intrusive thoughts, compulsive behaviors, or constant restlessness.  
• Self-help hasn’t improved things after 4-6 weeks.  
• Thoughts of harming yourself or others: treat as an emergency (call 911 or go to the nearest ER in the U.S.; emergency services in your country).

-------------------------------------------------
6. What professionals can offer
-------------------------------------------------
• Psychotherapy (CBT, ACT, exposure therapy, EMDR, etc.).  
• Medication if appropriate: SSRIs, SNRIs, buspirone, beta-blockers for performance anxiety, short-term benzodiazepines (usually weeks) under close supervision.  
• Combination therapy (med + therapy) often yields the best outcomes for moderate-to-severe anxiety.

-------------------------------------------------
7. Digital & community resources
-------------------------------------------------
• National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI): nami.org, helpline 1-

Generalized anxiety disorder - self-care (Therapy): Talk therapy takes place with a trained therapist and in a safe place. It helps you learn ways of managing and reducing your anxiety. Some forms of talk therapy can help you understand what causes your anxiety. This allows you to gain better control over it. Many types of talk therapy may be helpful for GAD. One common and effective talk therapy is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT can help you understand the relationship between your thoughts, your behaviors, and your symptoms. Often CBT involves a set number of visits. During CBT you can learn how to: - Understand and gain control of distorted views of stressors, such as other people's behavior or life events. - Recognize and replace panic-causing thoughts to help you feel more in control. - Manage stress and relax when symptoms occur. - Avoid thinking that minor problems will develop into terrible ones. Your provider can discuss talk therapy options with you. Then you can decide together if it is right for you.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Safe, sustainable weight-loss comes down to creating a modest, long-term calorie deficit while protecting your physical and mental health. The exact plan will look a little different for everyone, but the evidence-based framework below can help you get started and stay on track.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Start With a Clear, Realistic Goal
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Aim to lose about 0.5–1 kg (1–2 lb) per week.  
• Set process goals (“Walk 30 min most days”) as well as outcome goals (“Lose 10 lb by July”).  
• Consider measuring waist circumference, energy level, sleep quality, and mood—not just scale weight.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Know Your Calorie “Ballpark”
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Most adults need a deficit of 500–750 cal/day to lose 0.5–1 kg per week.  
• Online calculators (NIH Body Weight Planner, Mayo Clinic, etc.) can estimate your maintenance calories; subtract 10–20 % to begin.  
• Extremely low-calorie diets (<1200 cal/day for women, <1500 cal/day for men) usually backfire unless medically supervised.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Build a Plate That Fills You Up, Not Out
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The simplest pattern:  
  • ½ plate vegetables & fruit  
  • ¼ plate lean protein (chicken, fish, beans, tofu, eggs)  
  • ¼ plate whole grains or starchy veg (brown rice, quinoa, sweet potato)  
  • 1–2 thumb-sized portions of healthy fat (olive oil, nuts, avocado)

Other evidence-based styles: Mediterranean, DASH, high-fiber plant-forward, or moderate-carb/high-protein plans.

Practical tips  
• Eat mostly foods with one ingredient: produce, legumes, whole grains, lean meats.  
• Swap sugar-sweetened beverages for water, seltzer, or unsweetened tea/coffee.  
• Limit highly processed snacks, refined grains, and alcohol (each drink �� 100–150 cal).  
• Use smaller plates, measure portions for a week or two, and pre-prep healthy snacks.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Move More—In Planned Workouts and Everyday Life
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Cardiovascular activity  
• Goal: 150 min/week moderate (brisk walk) or 75 min vigorous (running, HIIT).  
• Break into 10–15 min bouts if you’re busy.

Strength training  
• 2–3 non-consecutive days/week.  
• Focus on major muscle groups: squats, lunges, push-ups, rows, planks or resistance-band equivalents.  
• Builds/maintains muscle, which boosts resting metabolism.

Daily movement (“NEAT”)  
• Stand, stretch, pace during phone calls, park farther away, take the stairs. These extra 100–300 cal/day add up.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Behavior & Mind-Set Tools That Predict Success
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Self-monitoring  
• Keep a food/exercise log (paper, app, or photos) at least until new habits stick.  
• Weigh yourself 1–2 times/week or track waist size.

Mindful eating  
• Eat seated, screen-free when possible. Notice hunger/fullness (0–10 scale); aim to stop at ~7 “comfortably satisfied.”

Environment design  
• Keep fresh fruit/vegs visible; store chips, sweets out of sight.  
• Pack healthy snacks before long workdays or travel.

Sleep & stress  
• 7–9 hours sleep improves appetite hormone balance.  
• Manage stress with walks, deep breathing, yoga, hobbies; chronic stress raises cortisol and cravings.

Social support  
• Tell friends/family your goals; join a walking group or online community; consider a registered dietitian (RD) or weight-loss program for accountability.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6. Know When Medical Help Makes Sense
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• See your primary care provider before major lifestyle changes, especially if you have heart disease, diabetes, hypertension, or joint problems.  
• Ask about lab screening (thyroid, blood sugars, lipids).  
• FDA-approved weight-loss medications or bariatric surgery may be options if BMI ≥ 30 (or ≥ 27 with medical complications). These ALWAYS work best alongside lifestyle changes.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7. Watch Out for Red Flags
--------------------------------------------------------------------
�� Fad diets that promise >10 lb loss in a week  
�� Detox teas, “fat-burning” supplements, or injections not prescribed by a physician  
�� Programs that eliminate entire food groups without a medical reason  
�� Plans that don’t teach lasting habits or charge hidden fees

--------------------------------------------------------------------
8. Track, Tweak, Repeat
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Review progress every 2–4 weeks. If weight plateaus for >4 weeks, reduce calories slightly (100–200 per day) or add 1–2 extra activity sessions.  
• Celebrate non-scale victories: lower blood pressure,

Managing Prostate Cancer – A Patient-Centered Overview
(Information for adults already diagnosed or told they may have prostate cancer. It does not replace advice from your own doctor.)

1. First things first: find out exactly what you’re dealing with  
   • Stage (how far it has spread: I, II, III, IV)  
   • Grade/Gleason score or Grade Group (how aggressive the tumor cells look)  
   • PSA level and how fast it is rising (PSA “velocity”)  
   • Your age, general health, other illnesses, and personal goals  

These facts guide every treatment decision. Most men benefit from a second opinion—ideally from a multidisciplinary team that includes a urologist, radiation oncologist, and medical oncologist.

2. Main treatment paths  
(You may receive one, a combination, or move from one to another over time.)

A. Active Surveillance  
   • What it is: close monitoring (PSA every 3–6 mo, digital rectal exam, repeat biopsy/from MRI) with treatment only if the cancer shows signs of growing.  
   • Best for: very-low-risk or low-risk cancer, older men, or anyone wanting to avoid/ delay side effects.  
   • Pros: maintains quality of life; avoids unnecessary treatment.  
   • Cons: requires reliable follow-up; possible anxiety; small risk the cancer could progress between checks.

B. Surgery (Radical Prostatectomy)  
   • Removes the entire prostate ± nearby lymph nodes.  
   • Approaches: open, laparoscopic, or robot-assisted. All offer similar cancer control when done by an experienced surgeon.  
   • Possible side effects: urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, infrequent bowel problems, surgical risks (bleeding, infection).  
   • Recovery: most men out of bed the same day; catheter ~1 wk; return to desk work in 2-3 wk, heavy work 4-6 wk.

C. Radiation Therapy  
   • External-Beam (IMRT, VMAT, SBRT) – daily treatments for 1–9 wk depending on technique.  
   • Brachytherapy – radioactive seeds or temporary high-dose wires placed in the prostate.  
   • Side effects: fatigue, urinary urgency/ frequency, bowel irritation, erectile dysfunction over time.  
   • Cure rates comparable to surgery for localized disease.

D. Androgen-Deprivation Therapy (Hormone Therapy)  
   • Goal: starve cancer of testosterone.  
   • Forms: injected or implanted LHRH agonists/antagonists, oral anti-androgens, or surgical removal of the testes.  
   • Often combined with radiation or used for recurrent/metastatic disease.  
   • Side effects: hot flashes, fatigue, weight gain, loss of sex drive, osteoporosis, metabolic changes—discuss bone and heart monitoring.

E. Systemic Therapies for Advanced / Metastatic Cancer  
   • Chemotherapy: docetaxel, cabazitaxel.  
   • Targeted androgen-signaling blockers: abiraterone (+ prednisone), enzalutamide, apalutamide, darolutamide.  
   • PARP inhibitors (olaparib, rucaparib) for tumors with certain DNA-repair mutations (BRCA1/2, ATM, etc.).  
   • Immunotherapy: sipuleucel-T (proven to extend survival in some men).  
   • Radiopharmaceuticals: Radium-223 for cancer that has spread to bones.

F. Focal or Minimally Invasive Options (selected centers)  
   • High-intensity focused ultrasound (HIFU), cryotherapy, irreversible electroporation.  
   • Typically for small, well-defined tumors or salvage therapy after radiation.

3. Managing symptoms & side effects  
   • Urinary Control: pelvic-floor (Kegel) exercises, bladder training, incontinence pads; medications or sling/artificial sphincter if persistent.  
   • Sexual Function: early penile-rehabilitation programs (PDE-5 drugs such as sildenafil, vacuum devices, injections, implants).  
   • Bone Health: calcium, vitamin D, weight-bearing exercise; bisphosphonates or denosumab if on long-term hormone therapy.  
   • Hot flashes: lifestyle tricks (layers, fans), low-dose antidepressants or gabapentin, acupuncture.  
   • Mood & Fatigue: stay active, balanced diet, screen for depression; counseling or support groups benefit many men.  
   • Pain from metastases: radiation to painful bone spots, radiopharmaceuticals, nerve blocks, palliative care.

4. Lifestyle steps that help  
   • Keep moving: 150 min/week of moderate activity + strength training twice weekly lowers fatigue, boosts bone strength and mood.  
   • Heart-healthy, “

How to Help Prevent Atherosclerosis  
(A consumer-friendly guide based on recommendations from the American Heart Association, U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and similar expert bodies)

WHAT ATHEROSCLEROSIS IS  
• A chronic process in which cholesterol-rich plaque, inflammation and scar tissue build up inside arteries, making them stiff and narrow.  
• Over years this can lead to heart attack, stroke, peripheral artery disease and kidney problems.

WHY PREVENTION MATTERS  
The disease usually develops silently for decades. Because the first sign may be a life-threatening event, starting prevention early—and maintaining it lifelong—is key.

---------------------------------
A. TACKLE THE “BIG FIVE” MODIFIABLE RISK FACTORS
---------------------------------

1. Quit smoking and vaping  
   • Smoking is one of the strongest accelerators of plaque formation.  
   • Benefits start within weeks of stopping and continue for decades.  
   • Combine counseling + FDA-approved medications (nicotine replacement, bupropion, varenicline) for the best quit rates.

2. Optimize blood cholesterol  
   Target numbers (general population):  
   • LDL (“bad”) cholesterol: <100 mg/dL; <70 mg/dL if you already have cardiovascular disease or diabetes.  
   • Non-HDL cholesterol: <130 mg/dL.  
   How to get there:  
   • Heart-healthy eating pattern (see Section B).  
   • Regular exercise.  
   • If needed, cholesterol-lowering drugs (statins are first-line) prescribed by a clinician.

3. Control blood pressure  
   • Aim for <120/80 mm Hg (or <130/80 mm Hg in most guidelines).  
   • Strategies: weight loss, reduced sodium (<1,500–2,300 mg/day), at least 4,700 mg potassium/day from foods, limiting alcohol, daily physical activity, and prescription medication when lifestyle alone is not enough.

4. Keep blood sugar in the healthy range  
   • Fasting blood glucose <100 mg/dL or HbA1c <5.7 %.  
   • If you have prediabetes or diabetes, tight control (HbA1c usually <7 %) plus the newer glucose-lowering drugs that protect the heart (e.g., GLP-1 receptor agonists, SGLT2 inhibitors) reduces atherosclerotic risk.

5. Maintain a healthy weight and waist size  
   • Body mass index (BMI) 18.5–24.9 kg/m², but waist circumference is often more predictive: <35 inches (88 cm) for most women, <40 inches (102 cm) for most men.  
   • Even 5 %–10 % weight loss can improve lipids, blood pressure and insulin resistance.

---------------------------------
B. EAT A CARDIO-PROTECTIVE DIET
---------------------------------

Foundation:  
• Mostly plants—vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, seeds and whole grains.  
• Fish (especially oily varieties) or other omega-3 sources twice a week.  
• Moderate, low-fat dairy and skinless poultry; limit red and processed meats.

Focus nutrients & tips:  
• Fiber: ≥25–30 g/day (whole grains + legumes + produce).  
• Fats: Prioritize mono- and poly-unsaturated fats (olive oil, canola, nuts, seeds, avocados); severely limit trans fat (zero is the goal) and keep saturated fat <6 % of total calories.  
• Sodium: 1,500–2,300 mg/day.  
• Added sugars: <25 g (women) or <36 g (men) daily.  
• Alcohol: None is safest; if used, ≤1 drink/day for women, ≤2 for men.

Evidence-based patterns: Mediterranean, DASH, or whole-food plant-based diets have the strongest data for slowing or reversing early plaque.

---------------------------------
C. MOVE MORE, SIT LESS
---------------------------------

Minimum goals (adults):  
• 150–300 minutes/week of moderate-intensity aerobic activity (brisk walking, cycling, swimming).  
  OR  
• 75–150 minutes/week of vigorous activity (running, fast cycling, HIIT).  
• Muscle-strengthening exercises on 2+ days/week.  
• Break up sitting every 30–60 minutes with a 1–2-minute walk or stretch.

---------------------------------
D. ADDITIONAL, OFTEN-OVERLOOKED STRATEGIES
---------------------------------

1. Manage stress chronically, not just acutely  
   • Mindfulness, cognitive-behavioral therapy, yoga, breathing exercises each show BP- and lipid-lowering effects.

2. Prioritize sleep  
   • 7–9 hours/night; treat obstructive sleep apnea if present.

3. Stay up-to-date on key vaccinations  
   • Influenza and COVID-19 vaccines reduce

Atherosclerosis (PREVENTION): Taking action to control your risk factors can help prevent or delay atherosclerosis and its related diseases. Your risk for atherosclerosis increases with the number of risk factors you have. One step you can take is to adopt a healthy lifestyle, which can include: Heart-Healthy Eating. Adopt heart-healthy eating habits, which include eating different fruits and vegetables (including beans and peas), whole grains, lean meats, poultry without skin, seafood, and fat-free or low-fat milk and dairy products. A heart-healthy diet is low in sodium, added sugar, solid fats, and refined grains. Following a heart-healthy diet is an important part of a healthy lifestyle. Physical Activity. Be as physically active as you can. Physical activity can improve your fitness level and your health. Ask your doctor what types and amounts of activity are safe for you. Read more about Physical Activity and Your Heart. Quit Smoking. If you smoke, quit. Smoking can damage and tighten blood vessels and raise your risk for atherosclerosis. Talk with your doctor about programs and products that can help you quit. Also, try to avoid secondhand smoke. Read more about Smoking and Your Heart. Weight Control. If you’re overweight or obese, work with your doctor to create a reasonable weight-loss plan. Controlling your weight helps you control risk factors for atherosclerosis. Other steps that can prevent or delay atherosclerosis include knowing your family history of atherosclerosis. If you or someone in your family has an atherosclerosis-related disease, be sure to tell your doctor. If lifestyle changes aren’t enough, your doctor may prescribe medicines to control your atherosclerosis risk factors. Take all of your medicines as your doctor advises.

predicted_text:
Ways to lower your risk of “pink eye” (conjunctivitis)

1. Wash or sanitize hands often  
   • Scrub with soap and water for 20 seconds, especially after you cough, sneeze, blow your nose, touch your face or care for someone who is sick.  
   • Keep a small alcohol‐based hand gel with you when sinks aren’t handy.

2. Keep hands away from your eyes  
   • Rubbing transfers germs and allergens directly to the conjunctiva.  
   • Teach children the “no-rub rule” and give them tissues to blot instead.

3. Don’t share items that touch the face  
   • Towels, washcloths, pillows, eye drops, eye makeup, mascara, eyeliner, contact-lens cases, solutions and swimming goggles can all pass infection.  
   • Launder towels and pillowcases in hot water if someone in the home has pink eye.

4. Follow strict contact-lens hygiene  
   • Wash and dry hands before handling lenses.  
   • Clean/store lenses only in fresh disinfecting solution—never in tap water or saliva.  
   • Replace lens cases every 1–3 months.  
   • Never sleep or swim in lenses unless they are specifically approved for that purpose.

5. Disinfect high-touch surfaces  
   • Wipe phones, keyboards, toys, doorknobs, remote controls and bathroom counters with household disinfectant, especially during a family member’s infection or during cold/flu season.

6. Stay home (or keep children home) while contagious  
   • Viral and bacterial conjunctivitis are usually most contagious for the first 24–48 h after symptoms start and until any discharge is gone.  
   • Return to work or school only after a doctor says it is safe (often 24 h after starting antibiotic drops for bacterial cases).

7. Control allergies to prevent allergic conjunctivitis  
   • Keep windows closed on high-pollen days, use air conditioning and HEPA filters, and shower before bed.  
   • Ask your clinician about daily allergy eye drops or oral antihistamines.

8. Protect eyes from irritants  
   • Wear swim goggles in chlorinated pools.  
   • Use safety glasses when handling chemicals or working in dusty environments.  
   • Take breaks from screen time to reduce dry, irritated eyes.

9. Keep vaccinations up to date  
   • Childhood Hib and pneumococcal vaccines lower the risk of certain bacterial eye infections.  
   • MMR vaccine prevents measles, which can involve the eyes.

10. Seek early care for red, painful or draining eyes  
    • Prompt treatment can shorten contagious periods and prevent complications.  
    • See an eye-care professional immediately if vision changes, severe pain, light sensitivity, or thick yellow-green discharge occur.

Key take-away: Good hand hygiene, not sharing personal items, sound contact-lens care, controlling allergies and staying home when infected are the most effective ways to keep conjunctivitis from spreading or starting in the first place.

predicted_text:
How to Lower Your Risk of Diabetes (Especially Type 2)

1. Know your personal risk  
   • Family history of diabetes, being overweight (BMI ≥ 25, or ≥ 23 if Asian), having had gestational diabetes, being ≥ 45 years old, certain ethnic backgrounds, high blood pressure, abnormal cholesterol, polycystic ovary syndrome, and a sedentary lifestyle all raise risk. If any apply, ask your clinician about earlier or more frequent screening (fasting glucose or A1C tests).

2. Keep a healthy body weight  
   • Losing just 5 – 10 % of your current weight can cut the chance of progressing from pre-diabetes to diabetes by 50 % or more.  
   • Favor slow, steady weight loss (1–2 lb per week) through diet and activity rather than crash diets.

3. Move more, sit less  
   • Aim for at least 150 minutes a week of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (e.g., brisk walking, cycling, swimming) or 75 minutes vigorous (running, fitness classes).  
   • Add strength or resistance training twice weekly; it improves insulin sensitivity.  
   • Break up long sitting periods—stand, stretch, or walk for 2–3 minutes every 30 minutes.

4. Choose diabetes-smart foods  
   • Emphasize vegetables, fruits, beans, lentils, nuts, seeds, whole-grain breads/cereals, and healthy fats (olive oil, avocado, fatty fish).  
   • Limit refined carbohydrates (white bread, sweets, chips), sugary drinks (soda, “energy” or fruit-punch beverages), and excessive fruit juice.  
   • Go easy on red/processed meats and high-saturated-fat foods; choose skinless poultry, fish, or plant proteins instead.  
   • Watch portion sizes; use a 9-inch plate where ½ is non-starchy veggies, ¼ lean protein, ¼ whole grain or starchy veggie.

5. Quit smoking and curb alcohol  
   • Smoking raises insulin resistance and cardiovascular risk. Get help to quit.  
   • If you drink, keep it moderate (≤ 1 drink/day for women, ≤ 2 for men) and never on an empty stomach.

6. Get enough sleep & manage stress  
   • Target 7–9 hours of quality sleep. Sleep deprivation alters hormones that regulate appetite and glucose.  
   • Practice stress-reducing techniques (deep breathing, meditation, yoga, walking outdoors); chronic stress elevates blood sugar.

7. Monitor heart-health numbers  
   • Keep blood pressure < 130/80 mm Hg and LDL cholesterol in target range; both interact with diabetes risk.  
   • Discuss statins or other medications if lifestyle alone does not reach goals.

8. Follow-up and screening  
   • If your fasting glucose is 100–125 mg/dL or A1C 5.7–6.4 % (prediabetes), enroll in a Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP) or similar structured lifestyle intervention.  
   • Some high-risk patients benefit from medication (e.g., metformin); only start under professional guidance.

9. Special situations  
   • Gestational diabetes: Maintain healthy weight before and during pregnancy, stay active, and follow prenatal care closely; postpartum weight loss and breastfeeding lower future diabetes risk.  
   • Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease and currently cannot be prevented; research is ongoing. Early recognition of symptoms (excess thirst, frequent urination, weight loss) is vital.

When to seek medical advice
• Unexplained fatigue, increased urination/thirst, blurred vision, or sudden weight changes.  
• If you have risk factors and haven’t had a glucose or A1C test in the past 1–3 years.  
• Before starting vigorous exercise or major diet changes, especially if you have other medical conditions.

Bottom line: Most cases of type 2 diabetes can be delayed or prevented with sustainable weight management, regular physical activity, balanced eating, and routine check-ups. Partner with a healthcare professional for a personalized plan.

predicted_text:
How to lower your risk of lung cancer  

No strategy can guarantee that you will never develop lung cancer, but research shows that the following steps can dramatically reduce your chances:

1. Don’t start smoking, and quit if you do smoke  
   • Cigarette smoking causes about 80–90 % of all lung-cancer deaths.  
   • The risk falls soon after quitting and keeps dropping each year; after ~15 years your risk can approach that of a lifetime non-smoker.  
   • Any form of tobacco (cigarettes, cigars, pipes, hookah, e-cigarettes that deliver nicotine plus tobacco smoke) increases risk.  
   • If you need help, talk with your clinician about counseling, nicotine-replacement products or prescription medicines; free help lines: 800-QUIT-NOW (U.S.).

2. Avoid second-hand smoke  
   • Ask household members, friends and co-workers not to smoke around you.  
   • Support smoke-free laws in workplaces, restaurants and public spaces.

3. Test your home for radon  
   • Radon is a naturally occurring, odorless radioactive gas that seeps up from soil and can accumulate indoors.  
   • It is the second-leading cause of lung cancer in the U.S. and the leading cause among never-smokers.  
   • Inexpensive do-it-yourself test kits are sold at hardware stores or online; mitigation systems are effective and usually cost less than major home repairs.

4. Limit exposure to occupational and environmental carcinogens  
   • At work, follow safety rules for asbestos, arsenic, diesel exhaust, silica, chromium, nickel and certain other chemicals.  
   • Use proper ventilation and wear approved respirators when recommended.  
   • If you’re unsure about hazards, ask your employer for the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) or consult OSHA/NIOSH resources.

5. Keep your lungs as healthy as possible  
   • Vaccinations (influenza, pneumococcal, COVID-19) help prevent infections that can weaken the lungs.  
   • Reduce indoor and outdoor air pollution exposure where possible (e.g., use exhaust fans, avoid burning trash, check air-quality alerts before exercising outside).

6. Choose a lifestyle that supports overall cancer prevention  
   • Eat plenty of vegetables, fruits, whole grains and lean protein; limit processed meats and charred foods.  
   • Be physically active (at least 150 min/week of moderate exercise or 75 min of vigorous activity).  
   • Maintain a healthy weight.  
   • Limit alcohol (no more than 1 drink/day for women, 2 for men, or less).

7. Consider lung-cancer screening if you are high-risk  
   • Annual low-dose CT scanning is recommended (U.S. guideline) for adults 50–80 years old who:  
     – have a 20 pack-year smoking history (packs per day × years smoked), AND  
     – currently smoke or quit within the past 15 years.  
   • Screening doesn’t prevent cancer, but it can detect it earlier when it is more treatable.

8. Know your family history and discuss it with your doctor  
   • A first-degree relative with lung cancer can raise your risk, especially if combined with smoking.  
   • A clinician can advise whether genetic counseling or earlier screening is appropriate.

9. Stay informed — new evidence continues to emerge  
   • Clinical trials are studying chemoprevention and targeted vaccines, but at present no drug or supplement is proven to prevent lung cancer in the general population.

If you smoke and have tried to quit before, remember: most people need several attempts to quit for good. Getting support (behavioral counseling plus FDA-approved cessation aids) doubles or triples success rates.

When to seek professional help  
• You want to quit smoking and need assistance.  
• You detect a persistent cough, shortness of breath, coughing up blood, unexplained chest pain or weight loss.  
• You are uncertain whether you should be screened.  

Always consult your health-care provider for advice tailored to your personal risk and circumstances.

   • A first-degree relative with lung cancer can raise your risk, especially if combined with smoking.

   • Clinical trials are studying chemoprevention and targeted vaccines, but at present no drug or supplement is proven to prevent lung cancer in the general population.

• You detect a persistent cough, shortness of breath, coughing up blood, unexplained chest pain or weight loss.  
• You are uncertain whether you should be screened.

Answer (general consumer information – not a substitute for personal medical advice):

At present there is no guaranteed way to prevent schizophrenia. The illness appears to arise from a complex mix of genes, early-life events, brain development and later environmental stresses. While no single lifestyle change can eliminate risk, the following measures are supported by research as sensible ways to lower risk or promote the best possible outcome if someone is vulnerable:

1. Before and during pregnancy
   • Adequate prenatal care and good maternal nutrition (especially folate, iron, vitamin D and omega-3 fatty acids).  
   • Avoidance of smoking, alcohol, cannabis and other drugs during pregnancy.  
   • Prevention and prompt treatment of significant maternal infections (e.g., influenza, toxoplasmosis).

2. Early-life health
   • Full childhood vaccination schedule to reduce central-nervous-system infections.  
   • Protection against serious head injuries (proper car-seat and helmet use, safe play environments).  
   • Monitoring and management of childhood developmental delays or significant emotional/behavioral changes.

3. Adolescence and young adulthood (peak risk period)
   • Avoid or delay use of cannabis and other recreational drugs; heavy adolescent cannabis use is one of the most consistent modifiable risk factors.  
   • Minimize binge drinking; avoid stimulant or hallucinogen use.  
   • Prompt treatment of significant anxiety, depression or sleep disorders, which can be early warning signs or aggravating factors.  
   • Stress-management skills, regular exercise, adequate sleep, stable daily routines and balanced diet.

4. Family history / high-risk individuals
   • If schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders run in the family, consider early counseling with a mental-health professional familiar with “clinical high-risk” or prodromal programs.  
   • Psycho-education for the individual and family about early warning signs (social withdrawal, unusual thoughts, marked drop in function).  
   • Early intervention services (sometimes called “first-episode” or “early psychosis” clinics) have been shown to improve long-term outcomes.

5. General lifestyle measures that support brain health
   • Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week), which may improve brain connectivity and stress resilience.  
   • Omega-3–rich diet (fatty fish, flaxseed, walnuts) or supplements if advised by a clinician.  
   • Avoid chronic sleep deprivation; aim for 7–9 hours of quality sleep.  
   • Foster strong social connections and supportive relationships.

Key take-away
Schizophrenia cannot yet be completely prevented, but reducing modifiable risk factors—especially prenatal health, avoidance of psychoactive drugs (notably cannabis) in adolescence, timely treatment of mental-health problems, and early specialized care when symptoms first appear—can lower risk and improve outcomes.

If you or someone you know is experiencing early symptoms (confusion, withdrawal, unusual beliefs or perceptions), seek a prompt evaluation from a qualified mental-health professional.
