predicted_text:
I’m not a medical professional, but here is reliable, general information about what to do when a heart attack (sometimes called a myocardial infarction) is suspected and how it is treated. Always call your local emergency number right away if you think someone is having a heart attack.

1. ACT FAST – CALL FOR HELP  
   • Dial 911 (or your local emergency number) at the very first sign of chest pain, pressure, or other classic symptoms (pain radiating to arm, neck, jaw; shortness of breath; sweating; nausea).  
   • Time is muscle: the sooner blood flow is restored, the more heart muscle can be saved.

2. WHAT YOU CAN DO WHILE WAITING FOR THE AMBULANCE  
   • Chew and swallow one adult aspirin (325 mg) or four low-dose (81 mg) tablets if the person is not allergic, has no history of severe bleeding, and is fully conscious. Aspirin helps keep the clot from growing.  
   • If prescribed nitroglycerin (for known heart disease), take it as directed (usually one tablet or spray under the tongue), but don’t take someone else’s medication.  
   • Have the person sit in a comfortable, upright position, loosen tight clothing, and stay calm.  
   • If the person becomes unresponsive and is not breathing normally, begin CPR and send someone to get an AED (automated external defibrillator) if available. Follow the voice prompts of the AED.

3. WHAT HAPPENS IN THE HOSPITAL  
   Emergency department staff will quickly confirm the diagnosis (ECG, blood tests) and start one of two “re-perfusion” strategies to open the blocked artery:  
   a) Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) – balloon angioplasty with possible stent placement. This is the preferred treatment if it can be done within about 90 minutes of first medical contact.  
   b) Thrombolytic (“clot-busting”) drugs – given intravenously if PCI cannot be done quickly.  
   Additional hospital care usually includes:  
   • Oxygen and pain relief (often morphine)  
   • Antiplatelet and anticoagulant drugs (aspirin, P2Y12 inhibitors, heparin)  
   • Beta-blockers to reduce heart workload  
   • ACE inhibitors or ARBs to support heart function  
   • Statins to lower cholesterol  
   • Continuous monitoring for arrhythmias or heart failure  
   Sometimes coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery is required if blockages are complex or PCI fails.

4. RECOVERY & LONG-TERM CARE  
   • Cardiac rehabilitation: a supervised program of exercise, education, and counseling shown to lower the risk of another heart event.  
   • Daily medicines: most people go home on aspirin, another antiplatelet drug, a beta-blocker, a statin, and often an ACE inhibitor/ARB. Take exactly as prescribed and never stop without medical advice.  
   • Lifestyle changes: quit smoking, eat a heart-healthy diet (fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein), maintain a healthy weight, exercise regularly (as cleared by your doctor), manage stress, and keep blood pressure, diabetes, and cholesterol under control.  
   • Follow-up visits: keep all appointments so your care team can adjust medications, track recovery, and screen for depression, which is common after a heart attack.

5. KNOW THE WARNING SIGNS FOR NEXT TIME  
   Chest discomfort, shortness of breath, fatigue, light-headedness, or sudden sweating can all be red flags—especially in women, older adults, and people with diabetes, who may have less typical symptoms.

6. WHEN TO SEEK IMMEDIATE CARE AGAIN  
   • New or returning chest pain or pressure  
   • Shortness of breath at rest  
   • Rapid or irregular heartbeat, fainting, or severe weakness  
   • Any concerning symptom your care team has told you to watch for

Remember: The single most important step in treating a heart attack is to activate emergency medical services immediately. Swift action saves lives. If you have questions about your own heart-disease risk or recovery plan, discuss them with your physician or a qualified cardiac specialist.

<gold_response>
Heart attack (Treatment): IMMEDIATE TREATMENT - You will be hooked up to a heart monitor, so the health care team can see how regularly your heart is beating. - You will receive oxygen so that your heart doesn't have to work as hard. - An intravenous line (IV) will be placed into one of your veins. Medicines and fluids pass through this IV. - You may get nitroglycerin and morphine to help reduce chest pain. - You may receive aspirin, unless it would not be safe for you. In that case, you will be given another medicine that prevents blood clots. - Dangerous abnormal heartbeats (arrhythmias) may be treated with medicine or electric shocks. EMERGENCY PROCEDURES Angioplasty is a procedure to open narrowed or blocked blood vessels that supply blood to the heart. - Angioplasty is often the first choice of treatment. It should be done within 90 minutes after you get to the hospital, and usually no later than 12 hours after a heart attack. - A stent is a small, metal mesh tube that opens up (expands) inside a coronary artery. A stent is usually placed after or during angioplasty. It helps prevent the artery from closing up again. You may be given drugs to break up the clot. This is called thrombolytic therapy. It is best if these drugs are given soon after the onset of symptoms, usually no later than 12 hours after it and ideally within 30 minutes of arriving to the hospital. Some people may also have heart bypass surgery to open narrowed or blocked blood vessels that supply blood to the heart. This procedure is also called coronary artery bypass grafting and/or open heart surgery. TREATMENT AFTER A HEART ATTACK After several days, you will be discharged from the hospital. You will likely need to take medicines, some for the rest of your life. Always talk to your provider before stopping or changing how you take any medicines. Stopping certain medicines can be deadly. While under the care of your health care team, you will learn: - How to take medicines to treat your heart problem and prevent more heart attacks - How to eat a heart-healthy diet - How to be active and exercise safely - What to do when you have chest pain - How to stop smoking Strong emotions are common after a heart attack. - You may feel sad - You may feel anxious and worry about being careful about everything you do All of these feelings are normal. They go away for most people after 2 or 3 weeks. You may also feel tired when you leave the hospital to go home. Most people who have had a heart attack take part in a cardiac rehabilitation program.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Autoimmune blood disorders are diseases in which a person’s immune system—whose normal job is to protect the body from germs—mistakenly attacks one or more components of the blood. Depending on what is targeted, the problem can involve red blood cells (which carry oxygen), white blood cells (which fight infection), platelets (which help blood clot), or clotting-factor proteins. The attack can destroy the cells, remove them from circulation, or block their normal functions, leading to anemia, bleeding, easy bruising, infections, or abnormal clotting.

COMMON TYPES

• Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA, including warm- and cold-antibody types) – antibodies coat and destroy red blood cells, causing fatigue, paleness, jaundice, and dark urine.

• Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) – antibodies attack platelets, resulting in low platelet counts, easy bruising, nosebleeds, and, in severe cases, internal bleeding.

• Autoimmune neutropenia – antibodies target neutrophils (a type of white blood cell), increasing the risk of bacterial and fungal infections.

• Evans syndrome – a combination of AIHA and ITP (sometimes neutropenia as well).

• Cold agglutinin disease or paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria – red-cell destruction triggered or worsened by cold exposure.

• Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) and acquired hemophilia – antibodies attack clotting proteins, leading to dangerous blood clots or, conversely, excessive bleeding.

WHY THEY OCCUR

The exact cause is usually unclear. Some cases are “primary” (idiopathic); others are “secondary,” triggered by another autoimmune illness (e.g., lupus), certain infections (e.g., HIV, hepatitis), cancers (e.g., lymphoma, leukemia), or specific drugs. Genetics, hormones, and environmental exposures may all play a role.

TYPICAL SIGNS & SYMPTOMS

• Fatigue, shortness of breath, light-headedness (anemia).  
• Yellowing of skin or eyes, dark or reddish urine (red-cell breakdown).  
• Pin-point red spots (petechiae), easy bruising, prolonged bleeding after cuts (low platelets).  
• Frequent or severe infections (low white blood cells).  
• Unexplained blood clots, miscarriages, or stroke (antiphospholipid antibodies).  

HOW THEY ARE DIAGNOSED

• Complete blood count (CBC) to look at the number and appearance of blood cells.  
• Direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test for antibodies on red cells.  
• Platelet, neutrophil, and reticulocyte counts.  
• Antibody assays (e.g., antiphospholipid, platelet-bound antibodies).  
• Other tests—peripheral smear, bone-marrow exam, clotting studies—when needed.

TREATMENT OPTIONS

• Corticosteroids (prednisone) – first-line therapy for many autoimmune blood disorders.  
• Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) – rapidly raises platelet or red-cell counts in ITP or AIHA.  
• Other immunosuppressants or monoclonal antibodies (rituximab, azathioprine, mycophenolate).  
• Splenectomy – sometimes recommended if medications fail, because the spleen often removes the antibody-coated cells.  
• Blood transfusions, platelet transfusions, or erythropoietin to correct low counts.  
• Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) or specific clotting-factor concentrates for conditions like APS or acquired hemophilia.  
• Treat any underlying trigger (infections, medications, cancer).

LIVING WITH AN AUTOIMMUNE BLOOD DISORDER

• Report new bleeding, bruising, fatigue, or infections promptly.  
• Take medicines exactly as prescribed and keep follow-up appointments for blood tests.  
• Avoid aspirin or NSAIDs unless approved, since they can worsen bleeding.  
• Stay current on vaccines (discuss live vaccines with your doctor if you are on immunosuppressants).  
• Wear a medical alert bracelet if you have severe thrombocytopenia, hemophilia, or APS.  
• Discuss pregnancy plans early; some disorders (e.g., APS, ITP) can affect pregnancy and require special management.

WHEN TO SEEK URGENT CARE

• Sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, or leg swelling (possible blood clot).  
• Severe or persistent bleeding, blood in urine or stool, or black tarry stools.  
• High fever or signs of sepsis in anyone with low white blood cells.

Bottom line: Autoimmune blood disorders are conditions in which the immune system damages blood cells or clotting proteins, leading to anemia, bleeding, infections, or abnormal clotting. They are diagnosed with blood tests and treated with medicines that

Autoimmune blood disorders are diseases in which a person’s immune system—whose normal job is to protect the body from germs—mistakenly attacks one or more components of the blood. Depending on what is targeted, the problem can involve red blood cells (which carry oxygen), white blood cells (which fight infection), platelets (which help blood clot), or clotting-factor proteins. The attack can destroy the cells, remove them from circulation, or block their normal functions, leading to anemia, bleeding, easy bruising, infections, or abnormal clotting.

COMMON TYPES

• Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA, including warm- and cold-antibody types) – antibodies coat and destroy red blood cells, causing fatigue, paleness, jaundice, and dark urine.

• Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) – antibodies attack platelets, resulting in low platelet counts, easy bruising, nosebleeds, and, in severe cases, internal bleeding.

• Autoimmune neutropenia – antibodies target neutrophils (a type of white blood cell), increasing the risk of bacterial and fungal infections.

• Evans syndrome – a combination of AIHA and ITP (sometimes neutropenia as well).

• Cold agglutinin disease or paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria – red-cell destruction triggered or worsened by cold exposure.

<gold_response>
Autoimmune disorders: An autoimmune disorder occurs when the body's immune system attacks and destroys healthy body tissue by mistake. There are more than 80 types of autoimmune disorders. The blood cells in the body's immune system help protect against harmful substances. Examples include bacteria, viruses, toxins, cancer cells, and blood and tissue from outside the body. These substances contain antigens. The immune system produces antibodies against these antigens that enable it to destroy these harmful substances. When you have an autoimmune disorder, your immune system does not distinguish between healthy tissue and antigens. As a result, the body sets off a reaction that destroys normal tissues. The exact cause of autoimmune disorders is unknown. One theory is that some microorganisms (such as bacteria or viruses) or drugs may trigger changes that confuse the immune system. This may happen more often in people who have genes that make them more prone to autoimmune disorders. An autoimmune disorder may result in: - The destruction of body tissue - Abnormal growth of an organ - Changes in organ function An autoimmune disorder may affect one or more organ or tissue types. Areas often affected by autoimmune disorders include: - Blood vessels - Connective tissues - Endocrine glands such as the thyroid or pancreas - Joints - Muscles - Red blood cells - Skin A person may have more than one autoimmune disorder at the same time. Common autoimmune disorders include: - Addison disease - Celiac disease - sprue (gluten-sensitive enteropathy) - Dermatomyositis - Graves disease - Hashimoto thyroiditis - Multiple sclerosis - Myasthenia gravis - Pernicious anemia - Reactive arthritis - Rheumatoid arthritis - Sjögren syndrome - Systemic lupus erythematosus - Type I diabetes Symptoms will vary based on the type and location of the faulty immune response. Common symptoms include: - Fatigue - Fever - General ill-feeling (malaise) - Joint pain - Rash The health care provider will do a physical exam. Signs depend on the type of disease. Tests that may be done to diagnose an autoimmune disorder include: - Antinuclear antibody tests - Autoantibody tests - CBC - Comprehensive metabolic panel - C-reactive protein (CRP) - Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) - Urinalysis The goals of treatment are to: - Reduce symptoms - Control the autoimmune process - Maintain the body's ability to fight disease Treatments will depend on your disease and symptoms. Types of treatments include: - Supplements to replace a substance that the body lacks, such as thyroid hormone, vitamin B12, or insulin, due to the autoimmune disease - Blood transfusions if blood is affected - Physical therapy to help with movement if the bones, joints, or muscles are affected Many people take medicines to reduce the immune system's abnormal response. These are often called immunosuppressive medicines. Examples include corticosteroids (such as prednisone) and nonsteroid drugs such as azathioprine, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, sirolimus, or tacrolimus. Targeted drugs called tumor necrosis factor (TFN) blockers can be used for some diseases. The outcome depends on the disease. Most autoimmune diseases are chronic, but many can be controlled with treatment. Symptoms of autoimmune disorders can come and go. When symptoms get worse, it is called a flare-up. Complications depend on the disease. Medicines used to suppress the immune system can cause severe side effects, such as higher risk of infections. Call your health care provider if you develop symptoms of an autoimmune disorder. There is no known prevention for most autoimmune disorders. Updated by: Laura J. Martin, MD, MPH, ABIM Board Certified in Internal Medicine and Hospice and Palliative Medicine, Atlanta, GA. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Causes of Bipolar Disorder  

Researchers still have not identified a single, clear-cut cause of bipolar disorder. Instead, most experts believe the illness develops when several biological and environmental factors interact in a vulnerable person. The factors listed below are those that have the strongest scientific support today.

1. Genetics (family history)
   • Bipolar disorder tends to run in families.  
   • First-degree relatives (parents, brothers, sisters, children) of someone with bipolar disorder have a higher risk than people in the general population.  
   • No single “bipolar gene” has been found; rather, many genes each contribute a small amount of risk.

2. Brain-chemistry and brain-structure differences
   • Imaging studies show average differences in certain brain regions (e.g., the prefrontal cortex and limbic system) in people with bipolar disorder compared with those without it.  
   • Disturbances in neurotransmitters that regulate mood—such as serotonin, dopamine and norepinephrine—are thought to play a role.

3. Sleep-wake (circadian) rhythm disruption
   • People prone to bipolar disorder often have unusually sensitive internal body clocks.  
   • Changes such as jet lag, rotating shift work or even staying up late can sometimes trigger mood episodes.

4. Stressful or traumatic life events
   • Major losses, relationship conflicts, financial or work crises, and physical or emotional trauma can precipitate a first episode or a relapse.  
   • Chronic stress may also worsen the course of the illness.

5. Hormonal and medical influences
   • Thyroid problems, certain neurological conditions, and hormonal shifts (e.g., postpartum period) can mimic or provoke bipolar-like symptoms in susceptible individuals.

6. Substance use
   • Alcohol, cannabis, stimulants (cocaine, amphetamines) and some prescription or over-the-counter medications can trigger or aggravate mood episodes.

7. Developmental factors
   • Adverse childhood experiences (abuse, neglect, household dysfunction) do not directly “cause” bipolar disorder, but they appear to increase vulnerability in people with a genetic risk.

Key point  
Bipolar disorder is best understood as the result of an interaction between inherited biological factors and life experiences. It is not caused by personal weakness or a character flaw.

If you or someone you know is experiencing mood swings, depression, or periods of unusually high energy, seek evaluation from a qualified mental-health professional. Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment can greatly improve outcomes.

predicted_text:
Pancreatic enzymes are natural chemicals made by your pancreas that help break down the food you eat so your body can absorb nutrients.

• Amylase – breaks carbohydrates (starches) into simple sugars  
• Lipase – breaks fats into fatty acids and glycerol  
• Proteases such as trypsin and chymotrypsin – break proteins into amino acids

These enzymes are released into the first part of the small intestine (the duodenum) every time you eat. If the pancreas does not make or release enough enzymes—because of conditions like chronic pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis, pancreatic cancer, or after part of the pancreas has been removed—people can develop greasy stools, weight loss, gas, and vitamin deficiencies. In those cases, doctors may prescribe pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (capsules taken with meals) to supply the missing enzymes and improve digestion.

Pancreatic cancer: Pancreatic cancer is cancer that starts in the pancreas. The pancreas is a large organ behind the stomach. It makes and releases enzymes into the intestines that help the body digest and absorb food, especially fats. The pancreas also makes and releases insulin and glucagon. These are hormones that help the body control blood sugar levels. There are different types of pancreatic cancers. The type depends on the cell the cancer develops in. Examples include: - Adenocarcinoma, the most common type of pancreatic cancer - Other more rare types include glucagonoma, insulinoma, islet cell tumor, VIPoma The exact cause of pancreatic cancer is unknown. It is more common in persons who: - Are obese - Have a diet high in fat and low in fruits and vegetables - Have diabetes - Have long-term exposure to certain chemicals - Have long-term inflammation of the pancreas (chronic pancreatitis) - Smoke Pancreatic cancer is slightly more common in women than in men. The risk increases with age. Family history of the disease also slightly increases the chance of developing this cancer. A tumor (cancer) in the pancreas may grow without any symptoms at first. This means the cancer is often advanced when it is first found. Symptoms of pancreatic cancer include: - Diarrhea - Dark urine and clay-colored stools - Fatigue and weakness - Sudden increase in blood sugar level (diabetes) - Jaundice (a yellow color in the skin, mucous membranes, or white part of the eyes) and itching of the skin - Loss of appetite and weight loss - Nausea and vomiting - Pain or discomfort in the upper part of the belly or abdomen The doctor will perform a physical exam and ask about your symptoms. During the exam, the doctor may feel a lump (mass) in your abdomen. Blood tests that may be ordered include: - Complete blood count (CBC) - Liver function tests - Serum bilirubin Imaging tests that may be ordered include: - CT scan of the abdomen - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) - Endoscopic ultrasound - MRI of the abdomen Diagnosis of pancreatic cancer (and what type) is made by a pancreatic biopsy. If tests confirm you have pancreatic cancer, more tests will be done to see how far the cancer has spread within and outside the pancreas. This is called staging. Staging helps guide treatment and gives you an idea of what to expect. Treatment for adenocarcinoma depends on the stage of the tumor. Surgery may be done if the tumor has not spread or has spread very little. Along with surgery, chemotherapy or radiation therapy or both may be used before or after surgery. A small number of people can be cured with this treatment approach. When the tumor has not spread out of the pancreas but cannot be surgically removed, chemotherapy and radiation therapy together may be recommended. When the tumor has spread (metastasized) to other organs such as the liver, chemotherapy alone is usually used. With advanced cancer, the goal of treatment is to manage pain and other symptoms. For example, if the tube that carries bile is blocked by the pancreatic tumor, a procedure to place a tiny metal tube (stent) may be done to open the blockage. This can help relieve loss of appetite, jaundice, and itching of the skin. You can ease the stress of illness by joining a cancer support group. Sharing with others who have common experiences and problems can help you not feel alone. Some people with pancreatic cancer that can be surgically removed are cured. But in most people, the tumor has spread and cannot be completely removed at the time of diagnosis. Chemotherapy and radiation are often given after surgery to increase the cure rate (this is called adjuvant therapy). For pancreatic cancer that cannot be removed completely with surgery or cancer that has spread beyond the pancreas, a cure is not possible. In this case, chemotherapy is given to improve and extend one's life. Call for an appointment with your health care provider if you have: - Abdominal pain that does not go away - Back pain - Loss of appetite - Unexplained fatigue or weight loss - Other symptoms of this disorder Preventive measures include: - If you smoke, now is the time to quit. - Keep a diet high in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. - Exercise regularly to stay at a healthy weight. Editorial team.

predicted_text:
Below are some of the warning signs and symptoms that are often seen in people with bulimia nervosa.  A person does not have to show every item on this list to have the disorder, and some of the signs can have other medical causes.  If you or someone you know may have bulimia, it’s important to talk with a qualified health-care professional for a full evaluation and guidance.

1. Eating-behavior clues
   • Repeated episodes of eating unusually large amounts of food in a short period of time (bingeing)  
   • Feeling out of control while eating or unable to stop  
   • Secretive food rituals (hiding food, eating alone, disappearing during or right after meals)  
   • Compensatory behaviors meant to “undo” the calories: self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, diuretics, diet pills, enemas, fasting, or excessive exercise  
   • Frequent dieting, fasting, or very rigid food rules  

2. Thoughts and emotions
   • Intense fear of gaining weight or becoming “fat” despite having a normal or low body weight  
   • Preoccupation with body shape, weight, and appearance  
   • Feeling guilt, shame, or depression after eating  
   • Mood swings, anxiety, or irritability  

3. Physical signs
   • Swollen cheeks or jaw area (enlarged parotid glands)  
   • Calluses, sores, or scarring on the knuckles or back of the hand (“Russell’s sign”) from inducing vomiting  
   • Chronic sore throat, hoarse voice, or frequent throat infections  
   • Dental problems: tooth decay, sensitive teeth, erosion of tooth enamel from stomach acid  
   • Acid reflux, heartburn, or stomach pain  
   • Electrolyte imbalances (which can cause dizziness, weakness, irregular heartbeat, or even life-threatening complications)  
   • Dehydration and low blood pressure  
   • Irregular or absent menstrual periods (in females)  
   • Fatigue, poor concentration, or sleep disturbances  

When to seek help
Bulimia can lead to serious medical complications but is treatable. If you suspect you or someone else may have bulimia, consider reaching out promptly to:
• A primary-care doctor  
• A mental-health professional with experience in eating disorders  
• The National Eating Disorders Helpline (in the U.S.) at 1-800-931-2237 or text “NEDA” to 741741  
If there are signs of severe dehydration, chest pain, fainting, or suicidal thoughts, call emergency services right away.

Early intervention greatly improves the chances of recovery.

What are the symptoms of Bulimia?: With bulimia, eating binges may occur as often as several times a day for many months. The person often eats large amounts of high-calorie foods, usually in secret. During these episodes, the person feels a lack of control over the eating. Binges lead to self-disgust, which causes purging to prevent weight gain. Purging may include: - Forcing oneself to vomit - Excessive exercise - Using laxatives, enemas, or diuretics (water pills) Purging often brings a sense of relief. People with bulimia are often at a normal weight, but they may see themselves as being overweight. Because the person's weight is often normal, other people may not notice this eating disorder. Symptoms that other people can see include: - Spending a lot of time exercising - Suddenly eating large amounts of food or buying large amounts of food that disappear right away - Regularly going to the bathroom right after meals - Throwing away packages of laxatives, diet pills, emetics (drugs that cause vomiting), or diuretics
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Treatments for males with Klinefelter syndrome (KS, usually 47-XXY) focus on reducing symptoms, supporting normal development, and preventing long-term health problems.  No single treatment “cures” the extra chromosome, but a coordinated plan that starts as early as possible can make a big difference.

1.  Testosterone (androgen) replacement therapy  
   • Usually started at the time of puberty (around age 11–14) and continued lifelong.  
   • Helps develop typical male secondary sexual characteristics (deeper voice, facial/body hair, increased muscle mass, genital growth).  
   • Improves energy, mood, self-esteem, libido, bone density, and helps prevent osteoporosis and metabolic syndrome.  
   • Forms: monthly or quarterly injections, daily gels/patches, or long-acting implants.

2.  Fertility and reproductive options  
   • Many men with KS have very low or absent sperm in the ejaculate (azoospermia), but sperm can sometimes be retrieved directly from the testicle (micro-TESE) and used with IVF/ICSI to achieve pregnancy.  
   • Early banking of any sperm that appears in adolescence or early adulthood may improve later fertility chances.  
   • Genetic counseling and psychological support are recommended for couples.

3.  Breast tissue management (gynecomastia)  
   • Testosterone therapy may reduce mild breast enlargement.  
   • If breast tissue is prominent or causes discomfort or embarrassment, surgical reduction (mastectomy) is an option.  
   • Regular breast exams are advised because KS modestly raises the risk of breast cancer compared with typical XY males.

4.  Bone health monitoring  
   • DXA scans to look for osteopenia/osteoporosis.  
   • Adequate calcium, vitamin D, weight-bearing exercise; bisphosphonate medication if needed.

5.  Speech, language, and educational support  
   • Early speech-language therapy in childhood can address speech delay and language-processing issues common in KS.  
   • Individualized education plans (IEPs), tutoring, and learning-skills training help with reading, writing, and executive-function challenges.

6.  Physical and occupational therapy  
   • Targets low muscle tone, coordination, and fine-motor skills, especially in younger boys.

7.  Psychological and behavioral counseling  
   • Addresses social skills, self-esteem, anxiety or depression, and any attention-deficit or autistic-spectrum features.  
   • Support groups (in person or online) can reduce isolation for teens and adults.

8.  Metabolic and cardiovascular surveillance  
   • Regular checks for weight, blood pressure, lipid profile, and blood sugar since KS increases risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.  
   • Lifestyle counseling on diet, exercise, and smoking cessation.

9.  Endocrine and general medical follow-up  
   • Annual visits with an endocrinologist or a primary doctor familiar with KS ensure hormone levels are optimal and screen for thyroid, autoimmune, or clotting disorders.

10.  Other specialty care as needed  
   • Dental/orthodontic care for high palate or dental crowding.  
   • Audiology for frequent ear infections or subtle hearing loss.  
   • Orthopedic evaluation for flat feet or scoliosis.  
   • Sleep studies if significant snoring or sleep apnea.

Key points to remember  
• Early diagnosis and early-started testosterone replacement greatly improve growth, pubertal development, and bone health.  
• Most treatments are lifelong, so building a strong relationship with health-care providers experienced in KS is important.  
• A multidisciplinary approach (endocrinology, urology, fertility specialists, therapists, psychologists, and educators) provides the best outcome.

<gold_response>
Klinefelter syndrome (Treatment): If you or your son is diagnosed with Klinefelter syndrome, your health care team may include a doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treating disorders involving the body's glands and hormones (endocrinologist), a speech therapist, a pediatrician, a physical therapist, a genetic counselor, a reproductive medicine or infertility specialist, and a counselor or psychologist. Although there's no way to repair the sex chromosome changes due to Klinefelter syndrome, treatments can help minimize its effects. The earlier a diagnosis is made and treatment is started, the greater the benefits. But it's never too late to get help. Treatment for Klinefelter syndrome may include: - Testosterone replacement therapy. Starting at the time of the usual onset of puberty, testosterone replacement can be given to help stimulate changes that normally occur at puberty, such as developing a deeper voice, growing facial and body hair, and increasing muscle mass and penis size. Testosterone therapy can also improve bone density and reduce the risk of fractures. It will not result in testicle enlargement or improve infertility. - Breast tissue removal. In males who develop enlarged breasts, excess breast tissue can be removed by a plastic surgeon, leaving a more normal-looking chest. - Speech and physical therapy. These treatments can help boys with Klinefelter syndrome overcome problems with speech, language and muscle weakness. - Educational evaluation and support. Some boys with Klinefelter syndrome have trouble learning and socializing and can benefit from extra assistance. Talk to your child's teacher, school counselor or school nurse about what kind of support might help. - Fertility treatment. Most men with Klinefelter syndrome are unable to father children because few or no sperm are produced in the testicles. For some men with minimal sperm production, a procedure called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) may help. During ICSI, sperm is removed from the testicle with a biopsy needle and injected directly into the egg. - Psychological counseling. Having Klinefelter syndrome can be a challenge, especially during puberty and young adulthood. For men with the condition, coping with infertility can be difficult. A family therapist, counselor or psychologist can help work through the emotional issues.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Symptoms that people commonly report when the gallbladder is “non-functioning” (also called gallbladder or biliary dyskinesia—an ejection fraction that is very low on a HIDA scan) are essentially the same symptoms produced by gallstones or chronic gallbladder inflammation. Typical features include:

• Recurrent pain in the right-upper or middle-upper abdomen  
  – Often dull, cramping, or pressure-like  
  – Usually starts 30-60 minutes after eating, especially after a fatty or fried meal  
  – May last 30 minutes to several hours  
  – Can radiate to the right shoulder blade, mid-back, or chest

• Nausea and/or vomiting—frequently triggered by meals

• Bloating, feeling of fullness, or abdominal distention

• Indigestion, belching, excessive gas, or heartburn

• Intolerance of fatty foods (meals provoke pain, queasiness, or loose stools)

• Episodic diarrhea or pale, greasy stools

• Occasionally low-grade fever, chills, or general malaise if the gallbladder becomes inflamed

Symptoms that are less common but warrant urgent attention include jaundice (yellowing of skin or eyes), very dark urine, clay-colored stools, persistent fever, or severe, unrelenting abdominal pain—these may indicate a stone blocking the common bile duct or acute infection and need immediate medical evaluation.

Because the same pattern of pain can be caused by ulcers, reflux, pancreatitis, liver disease, cardiac or musculoskeletal problems, confirming a nonfunctioning gallbladder usually requires a physician’s assessment and a hepatobiliary (HIDA) scan.

Seek medical care if pain is severe, recurrent, or associated with vomiting, fever, jaundice, or weight loss.

predicted_text:
Causes of childhood obesity

Childhood obesity rarely has a single cause. Instead, it develops when several risk factors overlap and persist over time. The most common (and usually interacting) contributors are:

1. Energy imbalance
   • Taking in more calories than are used (overeating, high-calorie beverages, large portion sizes)  
   • Expending too few calories (limited physical activity, lots of sedentary time such as TV, video games, social media)

2. Unhealthy dietary patterns
   • Frequent fast-food or restaurant meals  
   • Sugary drinks (soda, sports drinks, fruit-flavored drinks, sweetened coffees/teas)  
   • Highly processed “snack” foods that are high in sugar, salt, and/or fat  
   • Skipping breakfast, irregular meal patterns, or grazing all day

3. Decreased physical activity
   • Less outdoor play and organized sports  
   • More screen time for entertainment and schoolwork  
   • Neighborhoods without safe parks, sidewalks, or recreation centers

4. Family and genetic influences
   • Genetics can predispose a child to gain weight more easily  
   • Children model parents’ eating and activity habits  
   • Family stress, lack of time to prepare meals, or limited cooking skills

5. Prenatal and early-life factors
   • Excessive weight gain or gestational diabetes during pregnancy  
   • Maternal smoking during pregnancy  
   • Rapid weight gain in infancy, early introduction of solid foods, or formula overfeeding  
   • Being born small for gestational age or large for gestational age

6. Psychological and behavioral factors
   • Using food for comfort or reward  
   • Stress, anxiety, depression, or sleep problems can alter appetite-regulating hormones  
   • Lack of adequate, quality sleep (many school-age kids need 9–11 hours per night)

7. Socioeconomic and environmental factors
   • Limited access to affordable healthy foods (food deserts)  
   • Marketing of calorie-dense products to children  
   • School or childcare settings that don’t provide nutritious meals or daily activity  
   • Busy family schedules, multiple jobs, cost of organized sports

8. Medications and medical conditions (less common)
   • Long-term use of corticosteroids, some antidepressants, antiseizure, or antipsychotic drugs  
   • Endocrine disorders such as Cushing syndrome or hypothyroidism (rare)  
   • Genetic syndromes (e.g., Prader-Willi syndrome)

Key takeaway
Most children become overweight or obese through a combination of excess calories, too little physical activity, and an environment that makes healthy choices difficult. While genes can increase susceptibility, lifestyle and surroundings usually determine whether a child’s predisposition becomes obesity.

Addressing childhood obesity typically requires a family-centered approach that promotes balanced nutrition, daily movement, adequate sleep, stress management, and supportive community or school environments. If you are concerned about a child’s weight or growth pattern, consult a pediatrician or a registered dietitian for individualized guidance.

predicted_text:
Pulmonary hypertension (PH) means the blood pressure in the arteries that carry blood from the heart to the lungs is too high.  It is a sign of an underlying problem rather than a single disease, so doctors group the causes into five main categories.  Each category has several possible triggers or diseases behind it.

1. Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) – problems that start in the lung arteries themselves  
   • Idiopathic (no clear cause)  
   • Heritable gene changes (e.g., BMPR2 mutations)  
   • Drugs/toxins: “fen-phen” diet pills, methamphetamines, cocaine, some cancer drugs (dasatinib, cyclophosphamide, etc.)  
   • Autoimmune / connective-tissue diseases: scleroderma, systemic lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, mixed connective-tissue disease  
   • HIV infection  
   • Cirrhosis or other liver disease with portal hypertension (“porto-pulmonary” hypertension)  
   • Congenital heart defects with left-to-right shunt (ASD, VSD, PDA, Eisenmenger syndrome)  
   • Parasite infection (schistosomiasis)  
   • Rare vein disorders such as pulmonary veno-occlusive disease or pulmonary capillary hemangiomatosis  
   • Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

2. PH due to left-sided heart disease  
   • Heart-failure with reduced or preserved ejection fraction  
   • Mitral or aortic valve stenosis or regurgitation  
   • Cardiomyopathies, congenital obstruction of the left heart outflow

3. PH due to lung diseases and/or long-standing low oxygen (hypoxia)  
   • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD, emphysema, chronic bronchitis)  
   • Interstitial lung diseases / pulmonary fibrosis  
   • Severe or untreated obstructive sleep apnoea  
   • Bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis  
   • Chronic high-altitude exposure, alveolar hypoventilation syndromes, obesity-hypoventilation, severe scoliosis/kyphosis

4. Chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) – long-standing blood clots or other blockages in the lung arteries  
   • Recurrent pulmonary emboli that do not dissolve completely  
   • In-situ thrombosis, tumor or foreign-body obstruction

5. PH with multifactorial or unclear mechanisms  
   • Blood disorders: sickle cell disease, thalassemia, myeloproliferative disorders, long-standing hemolytic anemias, history of splenectomy  
   • Systemic/inflammatory diseases: sarcoidosis, vasculitides (e.g., Takayasu, Behçet), pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis, neurofibromatosis type-1  
   • Metabolic or endocrine disorders: thyroid disease (hyper- or hypothyroidism), glycogen-storage diseases, Gaucher disease, others  
   • Chronic kidney failure, especially patients on long-term dialysis  
   • Tumors compressing or invading the pulmonary arteries, rare congenital abnormalities

Key points for patients
• Having pulmonary hypertension does not necessarily mean you have “high blood pressure” elsewhere in the body.  
• Finding the specific cause is essential because treatment is very different for each group (for example, blood-clot surgery for CTEPH, advanced heart failure therapy for left-heart disease, or targeted PAH drugs for true pulmonary arterial hypertension).  
• Common warning signs include unexplained shortness of breath, fatigue, chest discomfort, swelling of ankles/legs, and fainting spells.  
• If PH is suspected, a cardiologist or pulmonologist usually orders an echocardiogram and other tests (lung scan, CT, right-heart catheterization) to pinpoint the cause.

Always discuss symptoms or test results with a qualified health-care professional; this information is for education and is not a substitute for personal medical advice.

predicted_text:
The great majority of teeth that are lost in adulthood are lost for just two reasons:  

1. Gum (periodontal) disease  
   • Long-standing plaque and tartar cause infection of the gums and the bone that supports the teeth.  
   • As the bone shrinks the teeth loosen and eventually have to be removed or fall out on their own.  
   • It is the single most common reason adults lose teeth.

2. Extensive tooth decay (dental caries)  
   • Untreated cavities can destroy so much of the tooth that it can no longer be repaired with a filling, crown, or root-canal treatment.  
   • When the infection reaches the pulp and spreads to the surrounding bone, extraction may be the only option.  
   • Decay is the second leading cause of tooth loss.

Other, less frequent causes include  

• Trauma or accidents (sports injuries, falls, car crashes)  
• Fractures from biting on hard objects or clenching/grinding  
• Failed dental work (e.g., fracture of a previously root-canaled tooth)  
• Orthodontic or surgical removal of teeth that are impacted or poorly positioned  
• Congenital absence or malformation of teeth  
• Tumors or cysts in the jaw, or radiation/chemotherapy affecting the mouth.

Preventing most tooth loss comes down to good daily oral hygiene, regular dental check-ups and cleanings, a balanced diet low in added sugars, not smoking, and wearing proper mouth protection during sports or high-risk activities.

predicted_text:
Key risk‐factors for developing type 2 diabetes fall into two broad groups—those you cannot change (non-modifiable) and those you can act on (modifiable).  Knowing which ones apply to you can help you—and your health-care team—decide whether and when to be screened and what steps to take to lower your risk.

NON-MODIFIABLE (things you cannot change)
• Age – Risk rises steadily after about age 40 (earlier in some ethnic groups).  
• Family history – Having a parent, brother or sister with type 2 diabetes roughly doubles your risk.  
• Ethnic background – Higher rates are seen in people of African, Hispanic/Latino, Native American, Alaska Native, Pacific Islander, South Asian, and some Asian ancestry.  
• Personal history of gestational diabetes or giving birth to a baby weighing ≥ 9 lb (4 kg).  
• Certain medical conditions: polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), some forms of hormonal disorders, and a history of cardiovascular disease.  
• Low birthweight or exposure to gestational diabetes in the womb.  

MODIFIABLE (things you can influence)
• Overweight or obesity—especially excess fat around the waist (men: ≥ 40 in/102 cm; women: ≥ 35 in/88 cm).  
• Sedentary lifestyle—being physically active less than 150 minutes a week.  
• Unhealthy eating patterns—high intake of sugary drinks, refined carbs, saturated or trans fats; low intake of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts, and legumes.  
• Smoking—current or past tobacco use increases insulin resistance and central obesity.  
• High blood pressure (≥ 130/80 mm Hg) or being treated for hypertension.  
• Abnormal cholesterol or triglycerides—low HDL (“good”) cholesterol (< 40 mg/dL in men, < 50 mg/dL in women) or high triglycerides (≥ 250 mg/dL).  
• Prediabetes—fasting glucose 100–125 mg/dL, A1C 5.7–6.4 %, or an abnormal oral glucose-tolerance test.  
• Sleep problems—obstructive sleep apnea, habitual short sleep (< 6 hrs/night), or shift-work with erratic sleep schedules.  
• Chronic stress or depression—associated with hormonal changes and behaviors that raise blood sugar.  
• Use of certain medications—long-term corticosteroids, some antipsychotics, and others can raise blood glucose.

WHAT YOU CAN DO
• Know your numbers: body-mass index (BMI), waist size, blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting glucose/A1C.  
• Get regular screening: most guidelines advise testing every 3 years from age 35, or earlier/frequently if you have multiple risk factors.  
• Maintain a healthy weight: losing even 5–7 % of body weight can cut diabetes risk by more than half.  
• Move more: aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate activity per week plus strength training twice a week.  
• Eat smart: focus on whole foods, plenty of vegetables, lean proteins, healthy fats, and limit sugary drinks and processed snacks.  
• Quit smoking and limit alcohol.  
• Manage blood pressure, cholesterol, and stress—and get adequate sleep.

If you think you’re at risk, discuss screening and prevention strategies with your healthcare provider. Early identification and lifestyle changes are the most effective ways to delay or avoid type 2 diabetes.

predicted_text:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic (inherited) disease that affects the cells that produce mucus, sweat and digestive juices. Because these secretions become thick and sticky, they block tubes, ducts and passageways—especially in the lungs and digestive system. Symptoms can vary from person to person and may change over time, but the most common ones include:

1. Lung and sinus symptoms  
• A persistent cough that produces thick mucus (sputum)  
• Repeated lung or sinus infections (e.g., bronchitis, pneumonia, sinusitis)  
• Wheezing or shortness of breath  
• Stuffy nose or chronic sinus congestion  
• Nasal polyps (soft growths in the nose or sinuses)

2. Digestive and nutritional symptoms  
• Poor weight gain or growth despite a good appetite  
• Frequent, bulky, greasy, or foul-smelling stools (steatorrhea)  
• Intestinal blockage, especially in newborns (meconium ileus)  
• Abdominal bloating or frequent gas  
• Severe constipation or episodes of intestinal obstruction (distal intestinal obstruction syndrome)  
• Deficiency in fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) leading to night blindness, easy bruising, bone problems, etc.

3. Sweat‐related symptom  
• Salty-tasting skin; parents often notice that their baby’s skin tastes unusually salty when they kiss them. (This sign led to the “sweat test,” still the standard diagnostic test for CF.)

4. Reproductive system effects  
• Almost all males with CF are infertile because of absent or blocked vas deferens.  
• Some females have reduced fertility due to thick cervical mucus, but many can conceive with assistance.

5. Other possible signs or complications  
• Clubbing (rounding and enlargement) of the fingertips or toes due to chronic low oxygen  
• Frequent fatigue or low energy because of lung disease or malnutrition  
• CF-related diabetes (symptoms such as increased thirst, urination, or unexplained weight loss)  
• Osteoporosis or bone fractures from poor nutrient absorption  
• Liver disease (enlarged liver, jaundice, or portal hypertension)  
• Episodes of pancreatitis (upper-abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting)

Early signs in infants and young children  
• Meconium ileus (failure to pass the first stool within 24–48 hours after birth)  
• Persistent cough or wheeze  
• Poor weight gain or “failure to thrive”  
• Prolonged diarrhea or bulky, oily stools  
• Frequent respiratory infections

When to seek medical care  
• If a baby doesn’t pass stool soon after birth, or has salty sweat, poor weight gain, or chronic cough  
• If a child or adult has frequent lung infections, ongoing digestive problems, or unexplained infertility

Because CF symptoms overlap with other conditions, diagnosis is confirmed with a sweat chloride test, genetic testing, or both. If you suspect cystic fibrosis in yourself or your child, consult a healthcare professional promptly for evaluation and management.

predicted_text:
Prostate cancer often develops silently; in its earliest stages it usually causes no warning signs at all. When symptoms do appear, they can vary from man to man and may also be caused by non-cancerous prostate problems (such as benign prostatic hyperplasia or prostatitis). Still, any of the changes below should be discussed with a health-care professional:

Possible symptoms of prostate cancer
• Trouble starting to urinate, a weak or interrupted urine stream, or the feeling that the bladder doesn’t empty completely  
• Frequent urination, especially at night (nocturia)  
• Urgency (sudden, hard-to-delay need to urinate)  
• Pain or burning during urination or ejaculation  
• Blood in the urine or semen  
• Erectile dysfunction or decreased volume of ejaculate  
• Pain or stiffness in the lower back, hips, pelvis, or upper thighs (can indicate spread to bones)  
• Unexplained weight loss, fatigue, or anemia in more advanced disease  

Key points to remember
• Most prostate symptoms are caused by non-cancerous conditions, but only an exam and, if needed, blood tests or imaging can tell the difference.  
• Early-stage prostate cancer may have no symptoms at all, which is why screening discussions with your doctor (often involving a PSA blood test and/or digital rectal exam) are important, particularly for men over 50 or those at higher risk (African-American men and men with a strong family history).  
• See your health-care provider promptly if you notice any of the signs above or have concerns about your prostate health.

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
What are the symptoms of Prostate Cancer?: Symptoms Most cancers in their early, most treatable stages don't cause any symptoms. Early prostate cancer usually does not cause symptoms. However, if prostate cancer develops and is not treated, it can cause these symptoms: - a need to urinate frequently, especially at night - difficulty starting urination or holding back urine - inability to urinate - weak or interrupted flow of urine - painful or burning urination - difficulty in having an erection - painful ejaculation - blood in urine or semen - pain or stiffness in the lower back, hips, or upper thighs. a need to urinate frequently, especially at night difficulty starting urination or holding back urine inability to urinate weak or interrupted flow of urine painful or burning urination difficulty in having an erection painful ejaculation blood in urine or semen pain or stiffness in the lower back, hips, or upper thighs. Any of these symptoms may be caused by cancer, but more often they are due to enlargement of the prostate, which is not cancer. If You Have Symptoms If you have any of these symptoms, see your doctor or a urologist to find out if you need treatment. A urologist is a doctor who specializes in treating diseases of the genitourinary system. The doctor will ask questions about your medical history and perform an exam to try to find the cause of the prostate problems. The PSA Test The doctor may also suggest a blood test to check your prostate specific antigen, or PSA, level. PSA levels can be high not only in men who have prostate cancer, but also in men with an enlarged prostate gland and men with infections of the prostate. PSA tests may be very useful for early cancer diagnosis. However, PSA tests alone do not always tell whether or not cancer is present. PSA screening for prostate cancer is not perfect. (Screening tests check for disease in a person who shows no symptoms.) Most men with mildly elevated PSA do not have prostate cancer, and many men with prostate cancer have normal levels of PSA. A recent study revealed that men with low prostate specific antigen levels, or PSA, may still have prostate cancer. Also, the digital rectal exam can miss many prostate cancers. Other Tests The doctor may order other exams, including ultrasound, MRI, or CT scans, to learn more about the cause of the symptoms. But to confirm the presence of cancer, doctors must perform a biopsy. During a biopsy, the doctor uses needles to remove small tissue samples from the prostate and then looks at the samples under a microscope. If Cancer is Present If a biopsy shows that cancer is present, the doctor will report on the grade of the tumor. Doctors describe a tumor as low, medium, or high-grade cancer, based on the way it appears under the microscope. One way of grading prostate cancer, called the Gleason system, uses scores of 2 to 10. Another system uses G1 through G4. The higher the score, the higher the grade of the tumor. High-grade tumors grow more quickly and are more likely to spread than low-grade tumors.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Headaches have many possible causes, ranging from everyday, harmless triggers to serious medical conditions. Doctors usually group the causes into two broad categories—primary and secondary headaches.

1. Primary headaches  
   These are headaches that are the main problem, not a symptom of something else. Common types and their typical triggers include:

   • Tension-type headache – stress, anxiety, poor posture, eye strain, missing meals, lack of sleep.  
   • Migraine – hormonal changes (menstruation, ovulation, pregnancy), certain foods (aged cheese, chocolate, processed meats), alcohol (especially red wine), caffeine withdrawal, bright lights or loud sounds, strong smells, weather changes, stress, and sleep disruption.  
   • Cluster headache – exact cause is unclear but believed to involve the brain’s hypothalamus; attacks can be set off by alcohol, strong odours, or changes in sleep cycle.  
   • Other primary headaches – exertional headaches (heavy exercise, coughing, sex), “ice-cream” or cold-stimulus headache, and new daily persistent headache.

2. Secondary headaches  
   These occur because something else is irritating, inflaming, or putting pressure on pain-sensitive structures in the head or neck. Important causes include:

   • Illnesses and infections  
     – Common: colds, flu, sinusitis, ear infections, dental infections.  
     – Serious: meningitis, encephalitis, brain abscess, COVID-19.

   • Head or neck problems  
     – Concussion or other traumatic brain injury.  
     – Whiplash, cervical spine arthritis, temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dysfunction.  
     – Giant cell (temporal) arteritis, trigeminal neuralgia.

   • Vascular (blood-vessel) issues  
     – Uncontrolled high blood pressure.  
     – Stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).  
     – Brain aneurysm, cerebral venous thrombosis.  
     – Post-lumbar-puncture or epidural (low-pressure) headache.

   • Medication-related causes  
     – Overuse of pain relievers (rebound headache).  
     – Side-effect of some blood-pressure drugs, nitrates, oral contraceptives, erectile-dysfunction drugs.  
     – Withdrawal from caffeine, opioids, benzodiazepines.

   • Environmental or lifestyle factors  
     – Dehydration, skipping meals, alcohol hangover, high altitude.  
     – Exposure to carbon monoxide, solvents, second-hand smoke, strong perfumes.  
     – Eye strain (un-corrected vision, long screen time).  
     – Noise, glare, very bright or flickering lights.  
     – Poor posture, unsupportive pillows, tight headgear.

   • Hormonal and metabolic conditions  
     – PMS, pregnancy, menopause, hormone-replacement therapy.  
     – Low blood sugar, thyroid disorders, anemia.  
     – Sleep apnea.

   • Structural or space-occupying lesions (uncommon but important)  
     – Brain tumors, cysts, hydrocephalus, Chiari malformation.

When to seek prompt medical attention (“red-flag” headaches)  
• “Worst headache of my life,” sudden and severe (“thunderclap” headache).  
• Headache after a head injury or a fall.  
• Headache with fever, stiff neck, rash, confusion, seizures, vision changes, weakness, or numbness.  
• New or worsening headache in people over 50, or in anyone with cancer, HIV, or on blood thinners.  
• Persistent daily headache that is getting progressively worse.

Take-home points  
– Most headaches are benign and relate to stress, tension, dehydration, or migraine triggers.  
– Keeping a headache diary (time, food, sleep, stress, menstrual cycle, medications) often helps identify personal triggers.  
– Over-the-counter pain relievers, rest, fluids, and healthy habits are adequate for many headaches, but recurrent, severe, or unusual headaches deserve evaluation by a healthcare professional.

<gold_response>
Headache (Causes): The most common type of headache is tension headache. It is likely caused by tight muscles in your shoulders, neck, scalp, and jaw. A tension headache: - May be related to stress, depression, anxiety, a head injury, or holding your head and neck in an abnormal position. - Tends to be on both sides of your head. It often starts at the back of the head and spreads forward. The pain may feel dull or squeezing, like a tight band or vice. Your shoulders, neck, or jaw may feel tight or sore. A migraine headache involves severe pain. It usually occurs with other symptoms, such as vision changes, sensitivity to sound or light, or nausea. With a migraine: - The pain may be throbbing, pounding, or pulsating. It tends to begin on one side of your head. It may spread to both sides. - The headache may be associated with an aura. This is a group of warning symptoms that start before your headache. The pain usually gets worse as you try to move around. - Migraines may be triggered by foods, such as chocolate, certain cheeses, or monosodium glutamate (MSG). Caffeine withdrawal, lack of sleep, and alcohol may also be triggers. Rebound headaches are headaches that keep coming back. They often occur from overuse of pain medicines. For this reason, these headaches are also called medicine overuse headaches. People who take pain medicine more than 3 days a week on a regular basis can develop this type of headache. Other types of headaches: - Cluster headache is a sharp, very painful headache that occurs daily, sometimes up to several times a day for months. It then goes away for weeks to months. In some people, the headaches never come back. The headache usually lasts less than an hour. It tends to occur at the same times every day. - Sinus headache causes pain in the front of the head and face. It is due to swelling in the sinus passages behind the cheeks, nose, and eyes. The pain is worse when you bend forward and when you first wake up in the morning. - Headaches may occur if you have a cold, the flu, a fever, or premenstrual syndrome. - Headache due to a disorder called temporal arteritis. This is a swollen, inflamed artery that supplies blood to part of the head, temple, and neck area. In rare cases, a headache can be a sign of something more serious, such as: - Bleeding in the area between the brain and the thin tissue that covers the brain (subarachnoid hemorrhage) - Blood pressure that is very high - Brain infection, such as meningitis or encephalitis, or abscess - Brain tumor - Buildup of fluid inside the skull that leads to brain swelling (hydrocephalus) - Buildup of pressure inside the skull that appears to be, but is not a tumor (pseudotumor cerebri) - Carbon monoxide poisoning - Lack of oxygen during sleep (sleep apnea) - Problems with the blood vessels and bleeding in the brain, such as arteriovenous malformation (AVM), brain aneurysm, or stroke
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Pulmonary hypertension (PH) means the blood pressure in the arteries that carry blood from the heart to the lungs is too high.  It is a sign of an underlying problem rather than a single disease, so doctors group the causes into five main categories.  Each category has several possible triggers or diseases behind it.

1. Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) – problems that start in the lung arteries themselves  
   • Idiopathic (no clear cause)  
   • Heritable gene changes (e.g., BMPR2 mutations)  
   • Drugs/toxins: “fen-phen” diet pills, methamphetamines, cocaine, some cancer drugs (dasatinib, cyclophosphamide, etc.)  
   • Autoimmune / connective-tissue diseases: scleroderma, systemic lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, mixed connective-tissue disease  
   • HIV infection  
   • Cirrhosis or other liver disease with portal hypertension (“porto-pulmonary” hypertension)  
   • Congenital heart defects with left-to-right shunt (ASD, VSD, PDA, Eisenmenger syndrome)  
   • Parasite infection (schistosomiasis)  
   • Rare vein disorders such as pulmonary veno-occlusive disease or pulmonary capillary hemangiomatosis  
   • Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

2. PH due to left-sided heart disease  
   • Heart-failure with reduced or preserved ejection fraction  
   • Mitral or aortic valve stenosis or regurgitation  
   • Cardiomyopathies, congenital obstruction of the left heart outflow

3. PH due to lung diseases and/or long-standing low oxygen (hypoxia)  
   • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD, emphysema, chronic bronchitis)  
   • Interstitial lung diseases / pulmonary fibrosis  
   • Severe or untreated obstructive sleep apnoea  
   • Bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis  
   • Chronic high-altitude exposure, alveolar hypoventilation syndromes, obesity-hypoventilation, severe scoliosis/kyphosis

4. Chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) – long-standing blood clots or other blockages in the lung arteries  
   • Recurrent pulmonary emboli that do not dissolve completely  
   • In-situ thrombosis, tumor or foreign-body obstruction

5. PH with multifactorial or unclear mechanisms  
   • Blood disorders: sickle cell disease, thalassemia, myeloproliferative disorders, long-standing hemolytic anemias, history of splenectomy  
   • Systemic/inflammatory diseases: sarcoidosis, vasculitides (e.g., Takayasu, Behçet), pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis, neurofibromatosis type-1  
   • Metabolic or endocrine disorders: thyroid disease (hyper- or hypothyroidism), glycogen-storage diseases, Gaucher disease, others  
   • Chronic kidney failure, especially patients on long-term dialysis  
   • Tumors compressing or invading the pulmonary arteries, rare congenital abnormalities

Key points for patients
• Having pulmonary hypertension does not necessarily mean you have “high blood pressure” elsewhere in the body.  
• Finding the specific cause is essential because treatment is very different for each group (for example, blood-clot surgery for CTEPH, advanced heart failure therapy for left-heart disease, or targeted PAH drugs for true pulmonary arterial hypertension).  
• Common warning signs include unexplained shortness of breath, fatigue, chest discomfort, swelling of ankles/legs, and fainting spells.  
• If PH is suspected, a cardiologist or pulmonologist usually orders an echocardiogram and other tests (lung scan, CT, right-heart catheterization) to pinpoint the cause.

Always discuss symptoms or test results with a qualified health-care professional; this information is for education and is not a substitute for personal medical advice.

<gold_response>
Pulmonary Hypertension (Causes): Pulmonary hypertension (PH) begins with inflammation and changes in the cells that line your pulmonary arteries. Other factors also can affect the pulmonary arteries and cause PH. For example, the condition may develop if: The walls of the arteries tighten. The walls of the arteries are stiff at birth or become stiff from an overgrowth of cells. Blood clots form in the arteries. These changes make it hard for your heart to push blood through your pulmonary arteries and into your lungs. Thus, the pressure in the arteries rises, causing PH. Many factors can contribute to the process that leads to the different types of PH. Group 1 pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) may have no known cause, or the condition may be inherited. ("Inherited" means the condition is passed from parents to children through genes.) Some diseases and conditions also can cause group 1 PAH. Examples include HIV infection, congenital heart disease, and sickle cell disease. Also, the use of street drugs (such as cocaine) and certain diet medicines can lead to PAH. Many diseases and conditions can cause groups 2 through 5 PH (often called secondary PH), including: Mitral valve disease Lung diseases, such as COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) Sleep apnea Sarcoidosis For more information about the types of PH and the diseases, conditions, and factors that can cause them, go to "Types of Pulmonary Hypertension."
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
The blood work used to look for (and help confirm) co-eliac / celiac disease belongs to a group called “celiac serology.”  Your doctor will usually order several of these at the same time:

1. IgA tissue-transglutaminase antibody (tTG-IgA)  
   • This is the single most sensitive and specific screening test.  
   • A clearly positive result in someone who is still eating gluten strongly suggests celiac disease.

2. Total serum IgA level  
   • About 2–3 % of people with celiac disease have selective IgA deficiency.  
   • If total IgA is low, the main IgA-based tests can look falsely negative, so an IgG-based test is then used.

3. IgG tissue-transglutaminase antibody (tTG-IgG)  
   • Ordered when the patient is IgA-deficient or very young (<2 years).

4. IgA endomysial antibody (EMA-IgA)  
   • Highly specific; often used to double-check a positive tTG-IgA result.  
   • More expensive and labor-intensive than tTG, so it’s usually a confirmatory test.

5. De-amidated gliadin peptide antibodies (DGP-IgA and/or DGP-IgG)  
   • Helpful in children under 2 years or when tTG is borderline.

Older “anti-gliadin antibodies” (AGA) have largely been replaced by the above tests because they are less accurate.

Additional but NOT diagnostic tests:
• HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 genetic typing – absence of both virtually rules out celiac disease, but their presence alone does not diagnose it because they are common in the general population.

Important:  
• All antibody testing must be done while you are still eating gluten daily; a gluten-free diet can cause false-negative results.  
• A positive blood test is usually followed by an upper endoscopy with small-bowel biopsies to confirm the diagnosis and assess intestinal damage, unless pediatric guidelines for “no-biopsy diagnosis” are met.

Always review test results and next steps with your healthcare provider.

Having these variants alone is not enough to diagnose celiac disease because they also are common in people without the disease. In fact, most people with these genes will never get celiac disease.If blood tests suggest you have celiac disease, your doctor will perform a biopsy to be sure. For a skin biopsy, the doctor removes tiny pieces of skin tissue to examine with a microscope.A doctor examines the skin tissue and checks the tissue for antibodies common in celiac disease. If the skin tissue has the antibodies, a doctor will perform blood tests to confirm celiac disease. If the skin biopsy and blood tests both suggest celiac disease, you may not need an intestinal biopsy.

predicted_text:
What can cause hypoglycemia (low blood-sugar levels)?

Most episodes of hypoglycemia occur in people being treated for diabetes, but other situations can trigger it as well. Common causes include:

1. Diabetes-related causes  
   • Taking too much insulin or diabetes pills (especially sulfonylureas such as glipizide, glyburide, glimepiride)  
   • Delaying, skipping, or eating too little at a meal after taking diabetes medicine  
   • Exercising harder or longer than planned without adjusting food or medication  
   • Drinking alcohol (particularly on an empty stomach) while using insulin or certain diabetes pills

2. Medication side effects in people without diabetes  
   • Quinine (used for malaria)  
   • Large doses of salicylates (e.g., high-dose aspirin)  
   • Some antibiotics (e.g., gatifloxacin)  
   • Pentamidine (used for pneumonia)  
   • β-blockers can mask symptoms and occasionally contribute

3. Alcohol-related hypoglycemia  
   Heavy or binge drinking can block the liver’s ability to release stored glucose, leading to low blood sugar several hours later—especially if you haven’t eaten.

4. Prolonged fasting or very low-carbohydrate diets  
   Not eating for many hours, severe calorie restriction, or strict ketogenic diets can occasionally cause hypoglycemia, particularly in children, older adults, or people with chronic illness.

5. Critical illness or organ failure  
   Severe infection (sepsis), kidney failure, advanced liver disease, heart failure, or certain cancers can interfere with the body’s ability to regulate glucose.

6. Hormone deficiencies  
   • Adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease)  
   • Severe hypothyroidism  
   • Growth-hormone or cortisol deficiency, sometimes seen in pituitary disorders

7. Insulin-producing tumors (insulinoma) or other rare pancreatic disorders  
   These tumors release extra insulin, lowering blood sugar—usually causing fasting hypoglycemia.

8. Reactive (post-prandial) hypoglycemia  
   Blood sugar drops 2–4 hours after a meal, often related to early type 2 diabetes, stomach-surgery (gastric bypass) changes, or an exaggerated insulin response.

9. Pregnancy  
   Pregnant women, especially those with diabetes, can experience hypoglycemia because of fluctuating hormone levels and increased energy needs.

10. Inborn errors of metabolism (rare, usually diagnosed in infancy/childhood)  
    Disorders such as glycogen-storage diseases affect how the body stores or releases glucose.

When to seek help  
• If you have symptoms such as shakiness, sweating, confusion, blurred vision, rapid heartbeat, or loss of consciousness.  
• If low readings (<70 mg/dL or <3.9 mmol/L) occur repeatedly.  
• Call emergency services for severe symptoms (seizure, unconsciousness) or if oral glucose can’t be given safely.

Quick treatment  
Consume 15–20 g of fast-acting carbohydrates (e.g., 4 glucose tablets, 4 oz/120 mL juice, regular soda, or 1 tablespoon honey), re-check in 15 minutes, and repeat if still low. Follow with a snack or meal containing protein and complex carbs.

Prevention tips  
• Eat regular, balanced meals; carry a quick sugar source if you’re at risk.  
• Work with your healthcare provider to adjust insulin or diabetes pills around activity and meals.  
• Limit alcohol and always take it with food.  
• Keep a hypoglycemia emergency plan and, if prescribed, a glucagon kit; teach friends or family how to use it.

Always discuss recurrent or unexplained low blood-sugar episodes with a healthcare professional to identify the exact cause and tailor treatment.

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
Hypoglycemia (Causes): Hypoglycemia occurs when your blood sugar (glucose) level falls too low. There are several reasons why this may happen, the most common is a side effect of drugs used to treat diabetes. Blood sugar regulation But to understand how hypoglycemia happens, it helps to know how your body normally processes blood sugar. When you eat, your body breaks down carbohydrates from foods - such as bread, rice, pasta, vegetables, fruit and milk products - into various sugar molecules, including glucose. Glucose is the main energy source for your body, but it can't enter the cells of most of your tissues without the help of insulin - a hormone secreted by your pancreas. When glucose levels rise, certain cells (beta cells) in your pancreas release insulin. This allows glucose to enter the cells and provide the fuel your cells need to function properly. Any extra glucose is stored in your liver and muscles in the form of glycogen. If you haven't eaten for several hours and your blood sugar level drops, another hormone from your pancreas called glucagon signals your liver to break down the stored glycogen and release glucose back into your bloodstream. This keeps your blood sugar level within a normal range until you eat again. Aside from your liver breaking down glycogen into glucose, your body also has the ability to manufacture glucose. This process occurs primarily in your liver, but also in your kidneys. Possible causes, with diabetes People with diabetes may not make enough insulin (type 1 diabetes) or may be less responsive to it (type 2 diabetes). As a result, glucose tends to build up in the bloodstream and may reach dangerously high levels. To correct this problem, someone with diabetes may take insulin or other drugs to lower blood sugar levels. But too much insulin or other diabetes medications may cause your blood sugar level to drop too low, causing hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemia may also happen if you don't eat as much food as usual after taking diabetes medication, or if you exercise more than you normally would. Possible causes, without diabetes Hypoglycemia in people without diabetes is much less common. Causes may include the following: - Medications. Taking someone else's oral diabetes medication accidentally is a possible cause of hypoglycemia. Other medications may cause hypoglycemia, especially in children or in people with kidney failure. One example is quinine (Qualaquin), which is used to treat malaria. - Excessive alcohol consumption. Drinking heavily without eating can block your liver from releasing stored glucose into your bloodstream, causing hypoglycemia. - Some critical illnesses. Severe illnesses of the liver, such as severe hepatitis, can cause hypoglycemia. Disorders of the kidney, which can keep your body from properly excreting medications, can affect glucose levels due to a buildup of those medications. Long-term starvation, as may occur in the eating disorder anorexia nervosa, can result in the depletion of substances your body needs to generate glucose (gluconeogenesis), causing hypoglycemia. - Insulin overproduction. A rare tumor of the pancreas (insulinoma) may cause overproduction of insulin, resulting in hypoglycemia. Other tumors may result in excessive production of insulin-like substances. Enlargement of beta cells of the pancreas that produce insulin (nesidioblastosis) may result in excessive insulin release, causing hypoglycemia. - Hormone deficiencies. Certain disorders of the adrenal glands and the pituitary gland can result in a deficiency of key hormones that regulate glucose production. Children may experience hypoglycemia if they have a deficiency of growth hormone. Hypoglycemia after meals Hypoglycemia usually occurs when you haven't eaten (when you're in a fasting state), but that's not always the case. Sometimes hypoglycemia occurs after meals because the body produces more insulin than is needed. This type of hypoglycemia, called reactive or postprandial hypoglycemia, may occur in people who have had stomach surgery. It may also occur in people who haven't had this surgery.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Bipolar disorder does not have one single, clear-cut cause. Most experts agree it develops when several factors act together in a vulnerable person:

1. Genetics  
   • Bipolar disorder tends to run in families.  
   • Having a parent or sibling with the illness increases risk, but no single “bipolar gene” exists—many genes each contribute a small amount.

2. Brain chemistry and biology  
   • Imbalances in neurotransmitters such as serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine are linked to mood swings.  
   • Imaging studies show subtle differences in the size or activity of certain brain areas that regulate emotion, sleep, and decision-making.

3. Circadian (sleep–wake) rhythm changes  
   • People with bipolar disorder are unusually sensitive to disruptions in sleep patterns, time-zone changes, or shift work, which can trigger episodes.

4. Stressful or traumatic life events  
   • Major stress, loss, abuse, or other trauma can precipitate the first episode or worsen existing illness, especially in someone who is genetically vulnerable.

5. Substance use and certain medical conditions  
   • Alcohol, stimulants, or other drugs can provoke or worsen mood episodes.  
   • Some medical illnesses (thyroid problems, neurological conditions) and certain medications (for example, steroids) can mimic or trigger bipolar-like symptoms.

6. Developmental and psychological factors  
   • Early childhood adversity, chronic stress, or insecure attachments may affect how the brain’s mood-regulation systems develop.

Key point  
Bipolar disorder arises from a complex interplay of inherited biological factors and life experiences. It is not caused by personal weakness or character flaws, and effective treatments—including medication, psychotherapy, healthy sleep habits, and stress management—are available. If you or someone you know is experiencing extreme mood swings, seek professional help; early diagnosis and treatment greatly improve outcomes.
