<gold_response>
Calcium carbonate overdose: Calcium carbonate is commonly found in antacids (for heartburn) and some dietary supplements. Calcium carbonate overdose occurs when someone takes more than the normal or recommended amount of a product containing this substance. This can be by accident or on purpose. This is for information only and not for use in the treatment or management of an actual overdose. DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual overdose. If you or someone you are with overdoses, call your local emergency number (such as 911), or your local poison center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. Calcium carbonate can be dangerous in large amounts. Some products that contain calcium carbonate are certain: - Antacids (Tums, Chooz) - Mineral supplements - Hand lotions - Vitamin and mineral supplements Other products may also contain calcium carbonate. Symptoms of a calcium carbonate overdose include: - Abdominal pain - Bone pain - Coma - Confusion - Constipation - Depression - Diarrhea - Headache - Irregular heartbeat - Muscle twitching - Nausea - Vomiting Seek medical help right away. DO NOT make the person throw up unless poison control or a health care provider tells you to. Have this information ready: - Person's age, weight, and condition - The name of the product (ingredients and strength, if known) - When it was swallowed - The amount swallowed Your local poison center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. This national hotline number will let you talk to experts in poisoning. They will give you further instructions. This is a free and confidential service. All local poison control centers in the United States use this national number. You should call if you have any questions about poisoning or poison prevention. It does NOT need to be an emergency. You can call for any reason, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Take the container with you to the hospital, if possible. The health care provider will measure and monitor the person's vital signs, including temperature, pulse, breathing rate, and blood pressure. Blood tests may be done. Symptoms will be treated. The person may receive: - Activated charcoal - Blood and urine tests - Breathing support - Chest x-ray - EKG (electrocardiogram, or heart tracing) - Intravenous fluids (through a vein) - Laxative - Medicine to treat symptoms - Tube through the mouth into the stomach to empty the stomach (gastric lavage) Calcium carbonate is not very poisonous. Recovery is quite likely. But, long-term overuse is more serious than a single overdose, because it can cause kidney damage. Few people die from an antacid overdose. Keep all medicines in child-proof bottles and out of the reach of children. Updated by: Jacob L. Heller, MD, MHA, Emergency Medicine, Virginia Mason Medical Center, Seattle, WA. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

predicted_text:
Anyone who is bitten by a mosquito that is carrying the dengue virus can become infected.  
The main factors that determine your risk are:

• Where you are – Dengue is common in tropical and subtropical parts of the world (Central and South America, the Caribbean, most of Asia, parts of the Pacific, Africa, and, occasionally, the southern United States). If you live in, work in, or travel to these areas when the Aedes aegypti or Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are active, you are at risk.

• Whether the mosquitoes around you are infected – Large outbreaks occur when many mosquitoes carry the virus and many people are being bitten.

There is no single age group, sex, or race that is naturally protected or especially prone to catching dengue. Everyone is susceptible if they are exposed and have no immunity.  
Some groups, however, are more likely to develop severe disease once they are infected:

• People who have had dengue before and are infected a second time by a different dengue “serotype.”  
• Infants born to mothers who have had dengue.  
• Young children in some endemic areas.  
• People with chronic illnesses (e.g., asthma, diabetes, sickle-cell disease) or weakened immune systems.  
• Pregnant women (because of higher complication rates for mother and baby).

Key points to remember
1. Risk is tied to mosquito exposure, not to inherent characteristics such as race or age.  
2. The best prevention is avoiding mosquito bites: use insect repellent, wear long sleeves and pants, stay in screened or air-conditioned rooms, and remove standing water around homes.

Dengue (Summary): Summary Dengue is an infection caused by a virus. You can get it if an infected mosquito bites you. Dengue does not spread from person to person. It is common in warm, wet areas of the world. Outbreaks occur in the rainy season. Dengue is rare in the United States. Symptoms include a high fever, headaches, joint and muscle pain, vomiting, and a rash. In some cases, dengue turns into dengue hemorrhagic fever, which causes bleeding from your nose, gums, or under your skin. It can also become dengue shock syndrome, which causes massive bleeding and shock. These forms of dengue are life-threatening. There is no specific treatment. Most people with dengue recover within 2 weeks. Until then, drinking lots of fluids, resting and taking non-aspirin fever-reducing medicines might help. People with the more severe forms of dengue usually need to go to the hospital and get fluids. To lower your risk when traveling to areas where dengue is found - Wear insect repellent with DEET - Wear clothes that cover your arms, legs and feet - Close unscreened doors and windows NIH: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Felodipine is broken down (metabolised) in the wall of the small-intestine and the liver by the enzyme CYP3A4.  
Grapefruit (and grapefruit juice, some pomelos, Seville oranges, tangelos, etc.) contains natural chemicals called furanocoumarins that block this enzyme in the gut for many hours.

What happens if you combine them  
• Less of the drug is destroyed on its first pass through the intestine.  
• A much larger amount of felodipine gets into the bloodstream—often two- to four-fold higher than expected.  
• Blood-pressure–lowering and heart-rate effects become stronger than intended, which can lead to excessive dizziness, fainting, flushing, headache, ankle swelling, or a rapid/irregular heartbeat.

Because the enzyme inhibition can last 24-72 h, simply spacing the juice and the tablet by a few hours is not reliable. The safest advice is to avoid grapefruit products entirely while you are taking felodipine unless your prescriber specifically tells you otherwise.

Felodipine is broken down (metabolised) in the wall of the small-intestine and the liver by the enzyme CYP3A4.  
Grapefruit (and grapefruit juice, some pomelos, Seville oranges, tangelos, etc.) contains natural chemicals called furanocoumarins that block this enzyme in the gut for many hours.

What happens if you combine them  
• Less of the drug is destroyed on its first pass through the intestine.  
• A much larger amount of felodipine gets into the bloodstream—often two- to four-fold higher than expected.  
• Blood-pressure–lowering and heart-rate effects become stronger than intended, which can lead to excessive dizziness, fainting, flushing, headache, ankle swelling, or a rapid/irregular heartbeat.

Because the enzyme inhibition can last 24-72 h, simply spacing the juice and the tablet by a few hours is not reliable. The safest advice is to avoid grapefruit products entirely while you are taking felodipine unless your prescriber specifically tells you otherwise.

If you have accidentally taken grapefruit with felodipine and feel light-headed, faint, or develop a very slow or rapid heartbeat, seek medical attention. Always check with your pharmacist or prescriber before adding any new fruit juices, supplements, or medicines to your routine.

predicted_text:
Keflex is the brand name for cephalexin, an oral antibiotic in the cephalosporin family. It can kill many “regular” (methicillin-susceptible) strains of Staphylococcus aureus, so doctors still prescribe it for some uncomplicated staph skin or soft-tissue infections.  
However, a large and growing proportion of staph infections are caused by methicillin-resistant Staph aureus (MRSA). MRSA is almost always resistant to cephalexin, which means Keflex will not work against it. Because you cannot tell MSSA from MRSA just by looking at the infection, your clinician usually decides what to prescribe based on:

• The type and severity of the infection (skin boil vs. deeper infection, pneumonia, bone infection, etc.)  
• Local resistance patterns and risk factors for MRSA (recent hospital stay, contact sports, recurrent boils, etc.)  
• Culture and sensitivity results, if available.

What this means for you
1. Do not start left-over Keflex or someone else’s prescription on your own; you could be taking an antibiotic that does nothing for the bacteria you actually have, which delays proper treatment and may worsen the infection.  
2. See a healthcare professional promptly. They can examine the area, drain an abscess if needed, send a culture, and choose an antibiotic that is likely to work.  
3. If your provider does prescribe Keflex, take it exactly as directed and finish the entire course—even if you feel better sooner—to reduce the chance of recurrence or resistance.  
4. Seek medical help right away if you develop spreading redness, fever, worsening pain, or you are immunocompromised. Deep or systemic staph infections often require different (sometimes intravenous) antibiotics.

Bottom line  
Keflex can cure some—but not all—staph infections. Whether it is appropriate for you depends on the specific strain and site of infection, so you should only take it under the guidance of a healthcare professional.

Yes.  

Tetanus is a serious, potentially life-threatening infection caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani. The toxin produced by the bacteria attacks the nervous system and can trigger severe, painful muscle spasms, lock-jaw, breathing difficulties, dangerously high blood pressure or abnormal heart rhythms. Without prompt medical care—and sometimes even with intensive care—these complications can lead to respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, or other problems that can be fatal.  

Fortunately, tetanus is almost completely preventable with the routine tetanus-containing vaccines (Td, Tdap) and recommended booster shots every 10 years, or sooner after certain injuries. If someone does develop tetanus, early hospitalization, antitoxin treatment, antibiotics, and supportive care (such as mechanical ventilation if needed) greatly improve the chances of survival.

Tetanus (Complications): Once tetanus toxin has bonded to your nerve endings it is impossible to remove. Complete recovery from a tetanus infection requires new nerve endings to grow, which can take up to several months. Complications of tetanus infection may include: - Broken bones. The severity of spasms may cause the spine and other bones to break. - Blockage of a lung artery (pulmonary embolism). A blood clot that has traveled from elsewhere in your body can block the main artery of the lung or one of its branches. - Death. Severe tetanus-induced (tetanic) muscle spasms can interfere with or stop your breathing. Respiratory failure is the most common cause of death. Lack of oxygen may also induce cardiac arrest and death. Pneumonia is another cause of death.
